abbreviation

--Meanings--
Mare.
Married.
Masculine.
Meta-
Metre(s).
Mile(s).
(in units of measurement) milli-
Million(s)
Minute(s).
Mass.
(on scorecards) maiden over(s).
Male.
Malta (international vehicle registration).
Medium (as a clothes size).
(in units of measurement) mega-
Messier (catalogue of nebulae)
(with reference to solutions) molar.
Monsieur.
(in UK road designations) motorway.
Used with following numeral in measures of money supply.
Mutual inductance.
The thirteenth letter of the alphabet.
Denoting the next after L in a set of items, categories, etc.
The Roman numeral for 1,000.

--Word--
M-1 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A .30-caliber semiautomatic clip-fed rifle capable of firing eight rounds before reloading, the standard rifle used by US troops in World War II and the Korean War.

mabe 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In full "mabe pearl". A type of large, usually hemispherical cultured pearl, grown on the inside shell of an oyster rather than within the body, and often (because of its shape) mounted in jewellery.

Macacus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus (now called Macaca) of Old World monkeys of the family Cercopithecidae, originally comprising a large number of African and Asian species, but later restricted to a smaller number of chiefly Asian species; (also macacus) a member of this genus, a macaque.

Macanese

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
Macao 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A special administrative region on the south-eastern coast of China on the west side of the Pearl River estuary opposite Hong Kong; formerly a Portuguese dependency and comprising the Macao peninsula and the islands of Taipa and Cologne; population 588,000 (estimated 2015); official languages, Portuguese and Cantonese; capital, Macao City. Visited by Vasco da Gama in 1497, Macao was developed by the Portuguese as a trading post and became the chief centre of trade between Europe and China in the 18th century. Under the terms of a 1987 agreement sovereignty passed to China in 1999.
--Examples--
--Word--
Macapá 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A town in northern Brazil, on the Amazon delta, capital of the state of Amapá; population 344,153 (2007).

MacArthur, Douglas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1880–1964), American general. Commander of US (later Allied) forces in the south-western Pacific during the Second World War, he accepted Japan's surrender in 1945, and administered the ensuing Allied occupation.

--Word--
Macaulay, Thomas Babington 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
1st Baron (1800–59), English historian, essayist, and philanthropist. He was a civil servant in India, where he established a system of education and a new criminal code, before returning to Britain and devoting himself to literature and politics. Notable works: The Lays of Ancient Rome (1842) and History of England (1849–61).

Macbeth 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1005–57), king of Scotland 1040–57. He came to the throne after killing his cousin Duncan I in battle, and was himself defeated and killed by Malcolm III. Shakespeare's tragedy Macbeth considerably embroiders the historical events.

--Word--
Judas Maccabaeus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(died c.161 BC), Jewish leader. Leading a Jewish revolt in Judaea against Antiochus IV Epiphanes from around 167 BC, he recovered Jerusalem and dedicated the Temple anew. He is the hero of the two books of the Maccabees in the Apocrypha.
--Examples--

--Examples--
‘the Maccabean revolt’
--Word--
Maccabees 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
The members or followers of the family of the Jewish leader Judas Maccabaeus.
Four books of Jewish history and theology, of which the first and second are in the Apocrypha and feature Judas Maccabaeus.

MacDonald, Ramsay 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1866–1937), British Labour statesman, prime minister 1924, 1929–31, and 1931–5; full name James Ramsay MacDonald. He served as Britain's first Labour prime minister.

--Word--
Macedonia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A landlocked republic in the Balkans; population 2,100,000 (estimated 2015); official language, Macedonian; capital, Skopje. Formerly a constituent republic of Yugoslavia, Macedonia became independent after a referendum in 1991. Also called Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.
An ancient country in south-eastern Europe, north of Greece. In classical times it was a kingdom that became a world power under Philip II and Alexander the Great. The region is now divided between Greece, Bulgaria, and the republic of Macedonia.
A region in the north-east of modern Greece; capital, Thessaloníki.
--Examples--
--Word--
Macedonia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A landlocked republic in the Balkans; population 2,100,000 (estimated 2015); official language, Macedonian; capital, Skopje. Formerly a constituent republic of Yugoslavia, Macedonia became independent after a referendum in 1991. Also called Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.
An ancient country in south-eastern Europe, north of Greece. In classical times it was a kingdom that became a world power under Philip II and Alexander the Great. The region is now divided between Greece, Bulgaria, and the republic of Macedonia.
A region in the north-east of modern Greece; capital, Thessaloníki.

The language of ancient Macedonia, probably a dialect of Greek.
Relating to Macedonia or Macedonian.

--Word--
Mach 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The ratio of the speed of a body to the speed of sound in the surrounding medium. It is often used with a numeral (as Mach 1, Mach 2, etc.) to indicate the speed of sound, twice the speed of sound, etc.
--Examples--
--Word--
mach. 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
machair 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in Scotland, especially the Western Isles) low-lying arable or grazing land formed near the coast by the deposition of sand and shell fragments by the wind.
--Examples--
‘machair is the focus of most Hebridean crofting agriculture’
‘machairs occupy long stretches of the western seaboard’
--Word--
machaira 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

machairodont 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having long sabre-shaped upper canine teeth; sabre-toothed. Also: of or relating to the subfamily Machairodontinae, comprising fossil felids having such teeth.
A machairodont felid.
--Examples--
--Word--
Machairodus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of sabre-toothed fossil felids; (also machairodus) a felid of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
machan 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in South Asia) a platform erected in a tree, used originally for hunting large animals and now for watching animals in wildlife reserves.
--Examples--
--Word--
mache 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Machism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The theories of Ernst Mach, especially his concept of empirio-criticism adopted from Richard Avenarius.
--Examples--
--Word--
machaira 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A short single-edged sword, with a slightly curved convex blade, used by the ancient Greeks.

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

machete 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
Machiavel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person compared to Machiavelli for favouring expediency over morality.
--Examples--
--Word--
Machiavelli, Niccolò 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1469–1527), Italian statesman and political philosopher; full name Niccolò di Bernardo dei Machiavelli. His best-known work is The Prince (1532), which advises rulers that the acquisition and effective use of power may necessitate unethical methods.
A person perceived as prepared to use unethical means to gain an advantage.
--Examples--
--Word--
Machiavellian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Cunning, scheming, and unscrupulous, especially in politics.
A person who schemes in a Machiavellian way.
--Examples--
‘a whole range of outrageous Machiavellian manoeuvres’
--Word--
Machiavellianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
machicolation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in medieval fortifications) an opening between the supporting corbels of a projecting parapet or the vault of a gate, through which stones or burning objects could be dropped on attackers.
A projecting structure containing a series of machicolations.
--Examples--

machila 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A conveyance, usually for one person, used in Africa and consisting of a hammock slung between two poles, carried by bearers.

--Word--
machine 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An apparatus using mechanical power and having several parts, each with a definite function and together performing a particular task.
A coin-operated dispenser.
Any device that transmits a force or directs its application.
An efficient and well-organized group of powerful people.
A person who acts with the mechanical efficiency of a machine.
Make or operate on with a machine.
--Examples--
‘a fax machine’
‘a cigarette machine’
‘the party's fund-raising is helping it to build a formidable political machine’
‘comedians are more than just laugh machines’
‘the cylinder covers are waiting to be machined’
--Word--
machinization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of making into a machine (literal and figurative); the result of the process.
--Examples--

--Word--
broken 
--Type--
verb, adjective
--Meanings--
Having been broken.
(of a marriage or other long-term relationship) having ended.
(of a person) having given up all hope; despairing.
Having breaks or gaps in continuity.
(of a language) spoken falteringly and with many mistakes, as by a foreigner.
Having an uneven and rough surface.
--Examples--
‘he had a broken arm’
‘he went to his grave a broken man’
‘a broken white line across the road’
‘a young man talking in broken Italian’
‘he pressed onwards over the broken ground’
--Word--
cut 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make an opening, incision, or wound in (something) with a sharp-edged tool or object.
Make a deliberate incision in (one's flesh), as a symptom of psychological or emotional distress.
Remove (something) from something larger by using a sharp implement.
Castrate (an animal, especially a horse).
Make something by cutting.
Remove, exclude, or stop eating or doing something undesirable.
Separate an animal from the main herd.
Divide into pieces with a knife or other sharp implement.
Make divisions in (something)
Separate (something) into two; sever.
Cause something to fall by cutting it through at the base.
(of a weapon, bullet, or disease) kill or injure someone.
Make or form (something) by using a sharp tool to remove material.
Make or design (a garment) in a particular way.
Make (a path, tunnel, or other route) by excavation, digging, or chopping.
Make (a sound recording)
Trim or reduce the length of (grass, hair, etc.) by using a sharp implement.
Reduce the amount or quantity of.
Abridge (a text, film, or performance) by removing material.
Delete (part of a text or other display) so as to insert a copy of it elsewhere.
End or interrupt the provision of (a supply)
Switch off (an engine or a light)
Absent oneself from (something one should normally attend, especially school)
Ignore or refuse to recognize (someone)
(of a line) cross or intersect (another line)
Pass or traverse, especially so as to shorten one's route.
Have an effect regardless of (divisions or boundaries between groups)
Leave or move hurriedly.
Stop filming or recording.
Move to another shot in a film.
Make (a film) into a coherent whole by removing parts or placing them in a different order.
Divide a pack of playing cards by lifting a portion from the top, either to reveal a card at random or to place the top portion under the bottom portion.
Strike or kick (a ball) with an abrupt, typically downward motion.
Slice (the ball).
Hit (the ball) to the off side with the bat held almost horizontally; play such a stroke against (the bowler).
(of the ball) turn sharply on pitching.
Mix (an illegal drug) with another substance.
Come up to expectations; meet requirements.
A stroke or blow given by a sharp-edged implement or by a whip or cane.
A haircut.
A reduction in amount or size.
A power cut.
An act of cutting part of a book, play, etc.
An immediate transition from one scene to another in a film.
The halfway point of a golf tournament, where half of the players are eliminated.
A stroke made with an abrupt, typically horizontal or downward action.
A long, narrow incision in the skin made by something sharp.
A long, narrow opening or incision made in a surface or piece of material.
A piece of meat cut from a carcass.
A share of the profits from something.
A recording of a piece of music.
A version of a film after editing.
A passage cut or dug out, as a railway cutting or a new channel made for a river or other waterway.
A wounding remark or act.
The way or style in which something, especially a garment or someone's hair, is cut.

‘he cut his big toe on a sharp stone’
‘when fruit is cut open, it goes brown’
‘I started cutting myself when I was about 14 and continued for four years’
‘I just started high school and I have a lot of self-confidence issues and as a result I started cutting’
‘I cut his photograph out of the paper’
‘some prisoners had their right hands cut off’

‘he cut his food up into teeny pieces’

‘an impeccably cut suit’

‘investigators called for a machete to cut through the bush’
‘quadraphonic LPs had to be cut at a lower volume level than conventional records’
‘Ted was cutting the lawn’
‘cut back all the year's growth to about four leaves’
‘buyers will bargain hard to cut the cost of the house they want’
‘I should cut down my sugar intake’
‘they've cut back on costs’
‘we're looking to cut down on the use of chemicals’
‘he had to cut unnecessary additions made to the opening scene’

‘if the pump develops a fault, the electrical supply is immediately cut off’

macho 
--Type--
adjective, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Masculine in an overly assertive or aggressive way.
A man who is aggressively proud of his masculinity.
Machismo.
A relatively dark, dense object, such as a brown dwarf, a low-mass star, or a black hole, of a kind believed to occur in a halo around a galaxy and to contain a significant proportion of the galaxy's mass.
--Examples--
‘the big macho tough guy’
‘I realized just what a macho I was at heart’

macigno 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sandstone of the northern Apennines that has been used in northern Italy as a building stone; (Geology, usually with capital initial) rock belonging to a Tertiary sequence of thick sandstone and interlayered mudstones, found in the northern Apennines and thought to have formed as turbidites in an ocean trench; also attributive, designating this sequence.

Mackenzie River 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The longest river in Canada, flowing 1,700 km (1,060 miles) north-westwards from the Great Slave Lake to the Beaufort Sea, a part of the Arctic Ocean.
--Examples--
--Word--
mackerel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A predatory marine fish with a greenish-blue back, important as a food fish.
--Examples--
--Word--
mackereler 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who goes mackerel-fishing.
--Examples--
--Word--
mackereling 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Fishing for mackerel.
A patterned effect like that of a mackerel's back, especially as formed by clouds. rare.

--Word--
Mackinac, Straits of 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A passage between lakes Huron and Michigan, crossed since 1957 by the Mackinac Bridge. The Upper Peninsula of Michigan lies to the north, and historic Mackinac Island lies just to the east.

--Word--
MacLaine, Shirley 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1934), US actress, dancer, and writer; born Shirley MacLean Beaty ; the sister of actor Warren Beatty. She appeared in movies such as Some Came Running (1958), The Apartment (1960), Irma la Douce (1963), The Turning Point (1977), Terms of Endearment (1983), and Evening Star (1996). She wrote Don't Fall Off the Mountain (1971).
--Examples--
--Word--
macle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A diamond or other crystal that is twinned.
--Examples--
--Word--
Macleaya 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of tall herbaceous perennials of the family Papaveraceae with large lobed cordate leaves and plumelike panicles of small cream or pink flowers, native to China and Japan and cultivated elsewhere as ornamental plants; (also macleaya) a plant of this genus (which was formerly included in the genus Bocconia), especially Macleaya cordata (also called plume poppy, bocconia).
--Examples--
--Word--
Maclean, Donald 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1913–83), British Foreign Office official and Soviet spy; full name Donald Duart Maclean. After acting as a Soviet agent from the late 1930s he fled to the USSR with Guy Burgess in 1951.
--Examples--
--Word--
macle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A diamond or other crystal that is twinned.
--Examples--
--Word--
MacLeish, Archibald 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1892–1982), US poet and public official. His award-winning works include Conquistador (1932), Collected Poems (1952), and J.B. (1958). He was librarian of Congress 1939–42.
--Examples--
--Word--
Macleod, John James Rickard 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1876–1935), Scottish physiologist. He directed the research on pancreatic extracts by F. G. Banting and C. H. Best which led to the discovery and isolation of insulin. Macleod shared the Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine with Banting in 1923.
--Examples--
--Word--
macle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A diamond or other crystal that is twinned.
--Examples--
--Word--
Maclura 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of the family Moraceae, consisting of dioecious trees and shrubs having the male flowers in loose racemes or spikes, the female flowers in dense heads, and the fruit a fleshy syncarp; (also maclura) a plant of this genus, specifically (more fully "Maclura thorn") the Osage orange, Maclura pomifera, a thorny tree native to Arkansas and Texas, in the 19th cent. much used for hedging in the United States.
--Examples--
--Word--
maclurin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A yellow hydroxylated derivative of benzophenone which occurs (together with morin) in the wood of old fustic and mulberry and has been used in dyes; 2,3′,4,4′,6-pentahydroxybenzophenone, C₁₃H₁₀O₆.
--Examples--
--Word--
Macmillan, Harold 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
1st Earl of Stockton (1894–1986), British Conservative statesman, prime minister 1957–63; full name Maurice Harold Macmillan. His term of office saw the signing of the Test-Ban Treaty (1963) with the US and the USSR. Macmillan resigned on grounds of ill health shortly after the scandal surrounding John Profumo.
--Examples--
--Word--
Macmillanite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of the body subsequently known as the Reformed Presbyterian Church of Scotland.
--Examples--
--Word--
MacNeice, Louis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1907–63), Northern Irish poet; full name Frederick Louis MacNeice. His work, such as Collected Poems (1966), is characterized by the use of assonance, internal rhymes, and ballad-like repetitions.
--Examples--
--Word--
Macon 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial and commercial city in central Georgia, on the Ocmulgee River; population 92,775 (est. 2008).

MacPherson 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Attributive and in compounds, especially in "MacPherson strut". Designating a component of a motor-car suspension consisting of a telescopic shock absorber mounted inside a coil spring.
--Examples--
--Word--
Macquarie River 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river in New South Wales, Australia, rising on the western slopes of the Great Dividing Range and flowing 960 km (600 miles) north-west to join the River Darling, of which it is a headwater.

Macrauchenia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
macro 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A single instruction that expands automatically into a set of instructions to perform a particular task.
A macro lens.
Large-scale; overall.
Relating to macrophotography.
--Examples--
‘the analysis of social events at the macro level’
‘your lens has a macro setting for shooting big close-ups’
--Word--
macro- 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
Large; large-scale.
(used in medical terms) large compared with the norm.
Long; over a long period.
--Examples--
‘macromolecule’
‘macrocephaly’
‘macroevolution’

macroaggregate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

macroaggregated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating a preparation of radiolabelled albumin, made by acidification and heating, that consists of relatively large aggregates of molecules and is used in perfusion scanning.

--Word--
macrocephalus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In plural (in form Macrocephali). A supposed Asian or Scythian tribe or people who characteristically had unusually long heads; (in singular) a member of this tribe. See long head. Now historical.
Medicine. A fetus with macrocephaly (now rare, perhaps obsolete); macrocephaly; an instance of this.

--Word--
macrocyst 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Biology. A (relatively large) encysted stage of the life cycle in a slime mould; specifically a thick-walled, multinucleate structure formed as part of the sexual cycle in certain slime moulds of the phylum Dictyostelida.
Medicine and Pathology. A macroscopic cyst; a large cyst.
Veterinary Medicine. A macroscopic sarcocyst.
--Examples--
--Word--
Macrocystis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of brown algae of which the only species now recognized is Macrocystis pyrifera, a giant kelp which is widespread in the southern hemisphere and along the Pacific coast of America; an alga of this genus.

macroglobulin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any blood plasma globulin of high molecular weight (usually, greater than 400,000); especially immunoglobulin M.
--Examples--
--Word--
macroglobulinaemia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An increased level of macroglobulins, especially of immunoglobulin M, in the blood; specifically (more fully "Waldenström's macroglobulinaemia" Brit./ˈvaldənʃtrəːmz/ U.S./ˈwɑldənstrɑmz//ˈvɑldənʃtrəmz/) a lymphoproliferative disorder affecting chiefly the bone marrow and the reticuloendothelial system, characterized by the presence of monoclonal immunoglobulin M (or, rarely, IgG or IgA).

macrophyllous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having large or long leaves or fronds; (of a leaf) large; specifically (in the Raunkiaer system of leaf size classification) designating a leaf with a surface area of 180–1640 square centimetres, or a plant bearing such a leaf.

--Word--
macroseism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An earthquake, as opposed to an imperceptible earth tremor. Formerly also (in Milne's use): †a major earthquake that involved the ‘nucleus’ of the earth as well as its crust (obsolete).
--Examples--
--Word--
macroseismic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the nature of or relating to a macroseism; (in modern use) designating or relating to those effects of an earthquake that are perceptible without the aid of instruments.

macrosomia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Excessive size of the body or a part of it, gigantism; (later) especially excessive size of the fetus for gestational age (most commonly as a result of maternal diabetes).

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Botany and Mycology. The larger of the two types of spore produced by a heterosporous plant (now usually called megaspore).

macrostructural 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
macrostructure 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The large-scale or overall structure of something, e.g. an organism, a mechanical construction, or a written text.
--Examples--
--Word--
Macrotherium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of large Eurasian chalicotheres of the Miocene epoch; (also macrotherium) a chalicothere of this genus.
--Examples--

--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--

A fish of the family Macrouridae; a rat-tail or grenadier.

--Word--
Mactra 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of marine bivalve molluscs of the family Tridacnidae (formerly Mactridae), which are typically several centimetres long with thin, triangular to ovate shells; (also mactra, plural mactrae, mactras) a mollusc of this genus, or its shell.
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
mad 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, verb
--Meanings--
Mentally ill; insane.
(of behaviour or an idea) extremely foolish; not sensible.
In a frenzied mental or physical state.
(of a dog) rabid.
Very enthusiastic about someone or something.
Very exciting.
Very angry.
Great; remarkable.
Very; extremely.
Make (someone) mad.
--Examples--
‘he felt as if he were going mad’
‘Antony's mother told him he was mad to be leaving Dublin’
‘she pictured loved ones mad with anxiety about her’
‘it was a mad dash to get ready’
‘he's mad about football’
‘another myth is that Scorpios are sex-mad’
‘don't be mad at me’
‘I got mad respect for him’
‘this author has mad skills with the written word’
‘he was mad cool—we immediately hit it off’
‘had I but seen thy picture in this plight, it would have madded me’

--Word--
Madagascar 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island country in the Indian Ocean, off the east coast of Africa; population 24,200,000 (estimated 2015); official languages, Malagasy and French; capital, Antananarivo.

noun

Used to address or refer to a woman in a polite or respectful way.

A woman who runs a brothel.

‘Dear Madam, …’
‘Madam President’
‘she's a proper little madam’

mad-apple 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The fruit of the eggplant or aubergine, Solanum melongena; the plant itself. Occasionally also (formerly also in plural): any of certain other plants of the genus Solanum, especially S. linnaeanum. Now archaic.
The thorn apple, Datura stramonium.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Word--
made beaver 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A unit of exchange formerly used among fur traders, equivalent to the value of the prepared skin of one adult beaver in prime condition; a coin or token equivalent to this. Plural often unchanged.
--Examples--
--Word--
Madeira 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
An island in the Atlantic Ocean off north-western Africa, the largest of the Madeiras, a group of islands which constitutes an autonomous region of Portugal; population 247,161 (2007); capital, Funchal. Encountered by the Portuguese in 1419, the islands were occupied by the Spanish 1580–1640 and the British 1807–14.
A river in north-western Brazil, which rises on the Bolivian border and flows about 1,450 km (900 miles) to meet the River Amazon east of Manaus. It is navigable to large ocean-going vessels as far as Pôrto Velho.
A fortified wine from the island of Madeira.
--Examples--
--Word--
Madeiran 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the island of Madeira.
A native or inhabitant of the island of Madeira.
--Examples--
‘a week in the Madeiran winter sunshine’
‘the Madeirans were no novices in business’
--Word--
Madeira 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
An island in the Atlantic Ocean off north-western Africa, the largest of the Madeiras, a group of islands which constitutes an autonomous region of Portugal; population 247,161 (2007); capital, Funchal. Encountered by the Portuguese in 1419, the islands were occupied by the Spanish 1580–1640 and the British 1807–14.
A river in north-western Brazil, which rises on the Bolivian border and flows about 1,450 km (900 miles) to meet the River Amazon east of Manaus. It is navigable to large ocean-going vessels as far as Pôrto Velho.
A fortified wine from the island of Madeira.
--Examples--

--Word--
Madia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of the family Asteraceae (Compositae), consisting of coarse, viscous, heavy-scented plants allied to the sunflower, and native to western North America and Chile; (also madia) a plant of this genus, especially the Chilean Madia sativa, cultivated for its seeds, which yield a valuable oil and are made into cake for cattle.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--

The state capital of Wisconsin; population 231,916 (est. 2008).
An energetic group dance popular in the 1960s.

--Word--
Madonna 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
The Virgin Mary.
A picture, statue, or medallion of the Madonna.

--Word--
madoqua 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a tiny dik-dik, Madoqua saltiana (formerly Antilope saltiana), of Ethiopia and other parts of eastern Africa. Now (usually) (in form Madoqua): the genus comprising the dik-diks.
--Examples--

A mountain system in Mexico, extending from the border with the US in the north to the southern border with Guatemala.
--Examples--
--Word--
Madrid 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Spain; population 3,213,271 (2008). Situated on a high plateau in the centre of the country, it replaced Valladolid as capital in 1561.
--Examples--
--Word--
madrigal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A part-song for several voices, especially one of the Renaissance period, typically unaccompanied and arranged in elaborate counterpoint.
--Examples--
--Word--
madrigalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A musical feature characteristic of a madrigal, specifically a word or phrase set to music in a way which vividly illustrates its literal meaning.
--Examples--
--Word--
madrigalesque 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
mad 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, verb
--Meanings--
Mentally ill; insane.
(of behaviour or an idea) extremely foolish; not sensible.
In a frenzied mental or physical state.
(of a dog) rabid.
Very enthusiastic about someone or something.
Very exciting.
Very angry.
Great; remarkable.
Very; extremely.
Make (someone) mad.
--Examples--
‘he felt as if he were going mad’
‘Antony's mother told him he was mad to be leaving Dublin’
‘she pictured loved ones mad with anxiety about her’
‘it was a mad dash to get ready’
‘he's mad about football’
‘another myth is that Scorpios are sex-mad’
‘don't be mad at me’
‘I got mad respect for him’
‘this author has mad skills with the written word’
‘he was mad cool—we immediately hit it off’
‘had I but seen thy picture in this plight, it would have madded me’
--Word--
madstone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A stone or similar object supposedly having the power to counteract the effect of the bite of a rabid or venomous animal.
--Examples--
--Word--
madtom 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small North American freshwater catfish which has a venom gland at the base of the pectoral fin spines.

--Word--
madwort 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various plants identified with Greek ἄλυσσον and formerly reputed to cure hydrophobia. In early use: †any of several hoary plants of the family Lamiaceae (Labiatae), perhaps Marrubium alysson (obsolete). In later use: any of various plants belonging to the genus Alyssum, or to the genus Aurinia which was formerly included in it.
A European weed, Asperugo procumbens (family Boraginaceae), with trailing bristly stems and small blue flowers in the leaf axils.
--Examples--
--Word--
madwort 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various plants identified with Greek ἄλυσσον and formerly reputed to cure hydrophobia. In early use: †any of several hoary plants of the family Lamiaceae (Labiatae), perhaps Marrubium alysson (obsolete). In later use: any of various plants belonging to the genus Alyssum, or to the genus Aurinia which was formerly included in it.
A European weed, Asperugo procumbens (family Boraginaceae), with trailing bristly stems and small blue flowers in the leaf axils.

Maecenas, Gaius 
--Type--
proper noun

--Word--
Maeterlinck, Count Maurice 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1862–1949), Belgian poet, playwright, and essayist. His prose dramas La Princesse Maleine (1889) and Pelléas et Mélisande (1892) established him as a leading figure in the symbolist movement. Nobel Prize for Literature (1911).
--Examples--
--Word--
Maeterlinckian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or having the characteristics of Maeterlinck or his writings.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
Mafeking 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Former name of the town of Mafikeng in South Africa, capital of North West. In 1899–1900, during the Second Boer War, a small British force commanded by Lord Baden-Powell was besieged in Mafeking for 215 days; the town's eventual relief was greeted in Britain with widespread celebration.
--Examples--
--Word--
Maffei 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Either of two galaxies ("Maffei 1" and "Maffei 2") near the galactic equator which are visible only in red and infrared light owing to the heavy extinction of shorter-wavelength light by interstellar dust.
--Examples--
--Word--
maffick 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To celebrate uproariously, rejoice extravagantly, especially on an occasion of national celebration (originally the relief of the British garrison besieged in Mafeking (now Mafikeng), South Africa, in May 1900). In later use usually with pejorative connotations.
--Examples--

Mafia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An organized international body of criminals, operating originally in Sicily and now especially in Italy and the US and having a complex and ruthless behavioural code.
Any organized group of criminals resembling the Mafia in its way of operating.
A group regarded as exerting a hidden sinister influence.
--Examples--
‘the rise of criminal mafias in Russian and Eastern Europe’
‘the British literary mafia’
--Word--
Mafia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An organized international body of criminals, operating originally in Sicily and now especially in Italy and the US and having a complex and ruthless behavioural code.
Any organized group of criminals resembling the Mafia in its way of operating.
A group regarded as exerting a hidden sinister influence.
--Examples--
‘the rise of criminal mafias in Russian and Eastern Europe’
‘the British literary mafia’

--Word--
magazine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A periodical publication containing articles and illustrations, often on a particular subject or aimed at a particular readership.
A regular television or radio programme comprising a variety of topical items.
A container or detachable receptacle for holding a supply of cartridges to be fed automatically to the breech of a gun.
A receptacle for storing and feeding film to a camera, CDs to a compact disc player, etc.
A store for arms, ammunition, and explosives for military use.
--Examples--
‘a women's weekly magazine’
‘a religious magazine programme aimed at the ordinary man and woman in the street’
‘he took the machine gun and a spare magazine’
‘you can program only the playback sequence of the discs in the magazine, not individual tracks’

--Word--
Magdalenian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the final Palaeolithic culture in Europe, following the Solutrean and dated to about 17,000–11,500 years ago. It is characterized by a range of bone and horn tools, and by highly developed cave art.
The Magdalenian culture or period.

Magdeburg 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial city in Germany, the capital of Saxony-Anhalt, situated on the River Elbe and linked to the Rhine and Ruhr by the Mittelland Canal; population 229,800 (est. 2006).

--Word--
Magellan 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An American space probe launched in 1989 to map the surface of Venus, using radar to penetrate the dense cloud cover. The probe was deliberately burned up in Venus's atmosphere in 1994.
--Examples--

--Word--
Magh 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of the (largely Buddhist) people of Arakan, a district on the west coast of Burma (Myanmar), and Chittagong, on the Bay of Bengal.
The Tibeto-Burman language of the Maghs, usually regarded as a dialect of Burmese; Arakanese.
Arakanese.
--Examples--
--Word--
Maghreb 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A region of north and north-western Africa between the Atlantic Ocean and Egypt, comprising the coastal plain and Atlas Mountains of Morocco, together with Algeria, Tunisia, and sometimes also Tripolitania.
--Examples--

--Meanings--
The ‘wise men’ from the East who brought gifts to the infant Jesus (Matt. 2:1), said in later tradition to be kings named Caspar, Melchior, and Balthasar who brought gifts of gold, frankincense, and myrrh.

Magyar 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a people who originated in the Urals and migrated westwards to settle in what is now Hungary in the 9th century AD.
The Uralic language of the Magyars; Hungarian.
Relating to the Magyars or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Magyarism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The principles of Magyar patriotism.
--Examples--
--Word--
Magyarization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of Magyarizing something; the state of being Magyarized.
--Examples--
--Word--
Magyarize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To make Magyar in form or character (specifically to respell according to Hungarian orthography); to assimilate (a person or ethnic group) to Hungarian language or culture.
--Examples--
--Word--
Magyarize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To make Magyar in form or character (specifically to respell according to Hungarian orthography); to assimilate (a person or ethnic group) to Hungarian language or culture.

--Word--
Magyar 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a people who originated in the Urals and migrated westwards to settle in what is now Hungary in the 9th century AD.
The Uralic language of the Magyars; Hungarian.
Relating to the Magyars or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
magic 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
The power of apparently influencing events by using mysterious or supernatural forces.
Mysterious tricks, such as making things disappear and reappear, performed as entertainment.
A quality of being beautiful and delightful in a way that seems remote from daily life.
Exceptional skill or talent.
Having or apparently having supernatural powers.
Very effective in producing the desired results.
Wonderful; exciting.
Move, change, or create by or as if by magic.
--Examples--
‘suddenly, as if by magic, the doors start to open’
‘his parents bought him a magic set for Christmas’
‘the magic of the theatre’
‘he's been working his magic on New Zealand movies for the past two decades’
‘a magic wand’
‘confidence is the magic ingredient needed to spark recovery’
‘it was a great time, magic’
‘he must have been magicked out of the car at the precise second it exploded’
--Word--
magical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to, using, or resembling magic.
Beautiful or delightful in a way that seems removed from everyday life.
--Examples--
‘magical healing powers’
‘it was a magical evening of pure nostalgia’
--Word--
magically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Using or as if by magic.
In a beautiful or delightful way.
--Examples--
‘a card seemed to appear magically in his hand’
‘bad scripts don't magically transform into masterpieces on the screen’
‘he played magically’
--Word--
magically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Using or as if by magic.
In a beautiful or delightful way.
--Examples--
‘a card seemed to appear magically in his hand’
‘bad scripts don't magically transform into masterpieces on the screen’
‘he played magically’

--Examples--
‘he was the magician of the fan belt’

--Word--
religious 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or believing in a religion.
(of a belief or practice) forming part of someone's faith in a divine being.
Belonging or relating to a monastic order or other group of people who are united by their practice of religion.
Treated or regarded with a devotion and scrupulousness appropriate to worship.
A person bound by monastic vows.
--Examples--
‘both men were deeply religious and moralistic’
‘religious music’
‘she has strong religious convictions’
‘religious houses were built on ancient pagan sites’
‘I have a religious aversion to reading manuals’
--Word--
sympathetic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Feeling, showing, or expressing sympathy.
Showing approval of or favour towards an idea or action.
(of a person) attracting the liking of others.
(of a structure) designed in a sensitive or appropriate way.
Relating to or denoting the part of the autonomic nervous system consisting of nerves arising from ganglia near the middle part of the spinal cord, supplying the internal organs, blood vessels, and glands, and balancing the action of the parasympathetic nerves.
Relating to, producing, or denoting an effect which arises in response to a similar action elsewhere.
--Examples--
‘she was sympathetic towards staff with family problems’
‘he spoke in a sympathetic tone’
‘he was sympathetic to evolutionary ideas’
‘Hubbell is a more sympathetic character’
‘buildings that were sympathetic to their surroundings’

magister 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A title or form of address given to scholars, especially those teaching in a medieval university.
--Examples--
--Word--
magistery 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Alchemy. A master principle of nature, free of impurities; a potent transmuting or curative quality or agency; (concrete) a substance, such as the philosopher's stone, capable of transmuting or changing the nature of other substances. Also figurative. Now chiefly historical.
Chemistry. The residuum obtained by precipitation from an acid solution; a precipitate; a resinous extract. Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
magisterial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having or showing great authority.
Domineering; dictatorial.
Relating to a magistrate.
(of a person) holding the office of a magistrate.
--Examples--
‘a magisterial pronouncement’
‘he dropped his somewhat magisterial style of questioning’
‘magisterial districts’
‘magisterial officers’

--Word--
magma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Hot fluid or semi-fluid material below or within the earth's crust from which lava and other igneous rock is formed on cooling.
--Examples--
‘when red-hot magma comes into contact with seawater, an explosion results’
‘basaltic magmas are normally expelled at the surface in a very hot and fluid state’

magnesium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 12, a silver-white metal of the alkaline earth series. It is used to make strong lightweight alloys, and is also used in flash bulbs and pyrotechnics, as it burns with a brilliant white flame.

magnesioferrite 
--Type--
noun

--Word--
magnet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A piece of iron or other material which has its component atoms so ordered that the material exhibits properties of magnetism, such as attracting other iron-containing objects or aligning itself in an external magnetic field.
A person or thing that has a powerful attraction.
--Examples--
‘the beautiful stretch of white sand is a magnet for sun-worshippers’
--Word--
magnet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A piece of iron or other material which has its component atoms so ordered that the material exhibits properties of magnetism, such as attracting other iron-containing objects or aligning itself in an external magnetic field.
A person or thing that has a powerful attraction.
--Examples--
‘the beautiful stretch of white sand is a magnet for sun-worshippers’
--Word--
magnetic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Exhibiting or relating to magnetism.
Capable of being attracted by or acquiring the properties of a magnet.
(of a bearing in navigation) measured relative to magnetic north.
Very attractive or alluring.
--Examples--
‘the clock has a magnetic back to stick to the fridge’
‘steel is magnetic’
‘his magnetic personality’

magnetize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Give magnetic properties to; make magnetic.

‘he magnetized the old people with the charm of his personality’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
magneto 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small electric generator containing a permanent magnet and used to provide high-voltage pulses, especially (formerly) in the ignition systems of internal combustion engines.

noun
--Meanings--
The electromagnetic properties and motion of compressible electrically conducting gases, especially plasmas, in the presence of a magnetic field.

--Word--
magnetohydrodynamics 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
The branch of physics that studies the behaviour of an electrically conducting fluid (such as a plasma or molten metal) acted on by a magnetic field.
--Examples--
--Word--
magnetohydrodynamics 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
The branch of physics that studies the behaviour of an electrically conducting fluid (such as a plasma or molten metal) acted on by a magnetic field.
--Examples--

magnetoid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hypothetical supermassive rotating body of magnetized plasma, postulated to account for the huge energy output of quasars.

magnetophone

noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
magnetoplasmadynamic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Originally: designating technologies utilizing magnetoplasmas, especially the generation of electricity by passing plasma at high speed through a transverse magnetic field, and propulsion for spacecraft. Later more widely: of or relating to the behaviour of a plasma in a magnetic field.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

magnetoplumbite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A strongly magnetic greyish black oxide of manganese, lead, and ferric iron occurring as acute dipyramidal crystals of the trigonal system.

magnetoresistance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The dependence of the electrical resistance of a body on an external magnetic field.
--Examples--
--Word--
magneto 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small electric generator containing a permanent magnet and used to provide high-voltage pulses, especially (formerly) in the ignition systems of internal combustion engines.
--Examples--
--Word--
magnetosphere 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The region surrounding the earth or another astronomical body in which its magnetic field is the predominant effective magnetic field.

magnetron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An electron tube for amplifying or generating microwaves, with the flow of electrons controlled by an external magnetic field.
--Examples--
--Word--
magnet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A piece of iron or other material which has its component atoms so ordered that the material exhibits properties of magnetism, such as attracting other iron-containing objects or aligning itself in an external magnetic field.
A person or thing that has a powerful attraction.
--Examples--
‘the beautiful stretch of white sand is a magnet for sun-worshippers’
--Word--
magnify 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make (something) appear larger than it is, especially with a lens or microscope.
Increase or exaggerate the importance or effect of.
Praise highly; glorify.
--Examples--
‘the retinal image will be magnified’
‘you had problems before you went to Vietnam, and 'Nam magnified them’
‘praise the Lord and magnify Him’

magnifiable

adjective

--Word--
magnification 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of magnifying something or the process of being magnified.
The degree to which something is or can be magnified.
The magnifying power of an instrument.
A magnified reproduction of something.
--Examples--
‘the lines are only visible under high magnification’
‘at this magnification the pixels making up the image become visible’
‘this microscope should give a magnification of about ×100’

Magnitogorsk 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial city in southern Russia, on the Ural River close to the border with Kazakhstan; population 409,600 (est. 2009).
--Examples--
--Word--
magnitude 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The great size or extent of something.
Great importance.
Size.
A numerical quantity or value.
The degree of brightness of a star, as represented by a number on a logarithmic scale.
The class into which a star falls by virtue of its brightness.
A difference of one on a scale of brightness, treated as a unit of measurement.
--Examples--
‘they may feel discouraged at the magnitude of the task before them’
‘events of tragic magnitude’
‘electorates of less than average magnitude’
‘the magnitudes of all the economic variables could be determined’
‘the brightest stars have the lowest magnitudes’
‘a star of the fifth magnitude’
‘a range of a tenth of a magnitude’

--Word--
magnoliaceous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Belonging to or characteristic of the family Magnoliaceae of dicotyledonous plants (formerly taken to include the Winteraceae), of which Magnolia is the typical genus.
--Examples--

--Word--
Cro-Magnon 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the first group of modern humans (Homo sapiens sapiens) to inhabit Europe, dated to between 35,000 and 24,000 years ago in the Upper Palaeolithic.
A Cro-Magnon human.
--Examples--
--Word--
magnum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A wine bottle of twice the standard size, normally 11/2 litres.
A gun designed to fire cartridges that are more powerful than its calibre would suggest.
--Examples--
‘a magnum of champagne’
‘that magnum has a kick like a field gun’
‘a magnum bullet’
--Word--

--Word--
Magnus hitch 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of knot tied with two round turns and a half hitch, and used typically to bind a rope to a spar, a ring, or the shackle of an anchor.
--Examples--
--Word--
Gog and Magog 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(in the Bible) the names of enemies of God's people. In Ezek. 38–9, Gog is apparently a ruler from the land of Magog, while in Rev. 20:8, Gog and Magog are nations under the dominion of Satan.
(in medieval legend) opponents of Alexander the Great, living north of the Caucasus.
Two giant statues standing in Guildhall, London, representing either the last two survivors of a race of giants supposed to have inhabited Britain before Roman times, or Gogmagog, chief of the giants, and Corineus, a Roman invader.
--Examples--
--Word--
magot 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The Barbary ape, Macaca sylvana.
A grotesque Chinese or Japanese figurine, represented in a sitting position, of porcelain, ivory, wood, etc.
--Examples--

--Word--
magpie 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A long-tailed crow with boldly marked (or green) plumage and a noisy call.
Any bird of the Australasian butcher-bird family, having black-and-white plumage and musical calls.
Used figuratively to refer to a person who obsessively collects things or who chatters idly.
The division of a circular target next to the outer one, or a shot which strikes this.
--Examples--
‘his father was a garrulous old man who chattered like a magpie’
‘he would carry these documents home to appease his secretive magpie instinct’
--Word--

noun

--Word--
Magritte, René 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1898–1967), Belgian surrealist painter; full name René François Ghislain Magritte. His paintings display startling or amusing juxtapositions of the ordinary, the strange, and the erotic, depicted in a realist manner.
--Examples--

Molly Maguire 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a secret society formed in Ireland in 1843 in order to resist evictions from land for the non-payment of rent.
A member of a union of mineworkers said to have been responsible for strikes and acts of violence and sabotage in the coalfields of Pennsylvania and West Virginia between 1862 and 1876. Also in plural With the. The organization itself.

--Meanings--

--Word--
Mahabharata 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
One of the two great Sanskrit epics of the Hindus, existing in its present form since c.400 AD. It describes the civil war waged between the five Pandava brothers and their one hundred stepbrothers at Kuruksetra near modern Delhi.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mahayana 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
One of the two major traditions of Buddhism, now practised especially in China, Tibet, Japan, and Korea. The tradition emerged around the 1st century AD and is typically concerned with personal spiritual practice and the ideal of the bodhisattva.
--Examples--
--Word--
mahajan 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
mahala 
--Type--
noun, adverb, adjective
--Meanings--
A North American Indian woman or wife.
For nothing, gratis.
Free; acquired without payment or effort. Chiefly in "for mahala": for free.
--Examples--
--Word--
mahaleb 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The fragrant kernels of the fruits of a Eurasian cherry, Prunus mahaleb, which are used in perfumery; the tree itself (also called St Lucie cherry), which has hard scented wood and is used as a dwarf grafting-stock for cherries.

Jackson, Mahalia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1911–72), US gospel singer and musician. She came into her own in the mid 1940s, when her recording of “Move Up a Little Higher” sold over a million copies. She was a featured performer at President Kennedy's inaugural ceremony.

--Examples--
--Word--
mahatma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in South Asia) a revered person regarded with love and respect; a holy person or sage.
Mahatma Gandhi.
(in some forms of theosophy) a person in India or Tibet said to have preternatural powers.
--Examples--

--Word--
Mahdi 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in popular Muslim belief) a spiritual and temporal leader who will rule before the end of the world and restore religion and justice.
A person claiming to be the Mahdi, notably Muhammad Ahmad of Dongola in Sudan (1843–85), whose revolutionary movement captured Khartoum and overthrew the Egyptian regime.
(in Shiite belief) the twelfth imam, who is expected to return and triumph over injustice.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mahdian 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mahdist.

noun
--Meanings--

Mahican 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a North American people formerly inhabiting the Upper Hudson Valley in New York State.
The extinct Algonquian language of the Mahicans.
Relating to the Mahicans or their language.

--Word--
Mahler, Gustav 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1860–1911), Austrian composer, conductor, and pianist. Forming a link between romanticism and the experimentalism of Schoenberg, his works include nine complete symphonies (1888–1910) and the symphonic song cycle Das Lied von der Erde (1908).
--Examples--
--Word--
Pitney, Mahlon 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1858–1924), US Supreme Court associate justice 1912–22. A conservative, he was appointed to the Court by President Taft.
--Examples--
--Word--
mahlstick 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A light stick with a padded leather ball at one end, held against work by a painter or signwriter to support and steady the brush hand.
--Examples--
--Word--
mahmal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An ornately decorated unoccupied palanquin, borne by a camel, and formerly sent by royalty to represent themselves on the annual pilgrimage to Mecca; especially that of the Egyptian royal family.
--Examples--
--Word--
Abbas, Mahmoud 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1935), Palestinian statesman; also known as Abu Mazen. He was appointed first prime minister of the Palestinian Authority in 2003 and in 2005 was elected president, following the death of Yasser Arafat.
--Examples--
--Word--
mahmudi 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(A) A Persian silver coin (originally weighing 4.5 grams, 69 grains) and later reduced to 2.3 grams, 35 grains), equivalent in value to two shahis, and first issued by the Safavid Shah Muhammad Khudabanda (reigned 1578–88), continuing in circulation until the late 18th cent.; a money of account derived from this. (b) Any of a number of Indian coins whose issue was initiated by a ruler called Mahmud, such as the gold mahmudi (weighing 11.5 grams, 177 grains) of Mahmud I (1458–1511), sultan of Gujarat.
--Examples--
--Word--
mahoe 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A small bushy New Zealand tree of the violet family, with whitish bark and clusters of small greenish flowers.
Any of a number of tropical trees and shrubs yielding bast that is used to make cord.

mahogany 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Hard reddish-brown timber from a tropical tree, used for quality furniture.
A rich reddish-brown colour like that of mahogany wood.
The tropical tree which produces mahogany.
Used in names of trees which yield timber similar to mahogany, e.g. African mahogany.
--Examples--
‘the shining mahogany hair flowed to her shoulders’

--Word--
Maratha 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of the princely and military castes of the former Hindu kingdom of Maharashtra in central India. The Marathas rebelled against the Moguls and in 1674 established their own kingdom. They came to dominate southern and central India but were later subdued by the British.
--Examples--

--Word--
may 
--Type--
modal verb
--Meanings--
Expressing possibility.
Used when admitting that something is so before making another, more important point.
Used to ask for or to give permission.
Expressing a wish or hope.
--Examples--
‘that may be true’
‘he may well win’
‘they may have been old-fashioned but they were excellent teachers’
‘you may confirm my identity with your Case Officer, if you wish’
‘may I ask a few questions?’
‘may she rest in peace’
--Word--
Maia 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
The daughter of Atlas and mother of Hermes.
A goddess associated with Vulcan and also with Mercury (Hermes). She was worshipped on 1 May and 15 May; that month is named after her.
--Examples--
--Word--
maya 
--Type--
noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The supernatural power wielded by gods and demons.
The power by which the universe becomes manifest; the illusion or appearance of the phenomenal world.
A member of an indigenous people of Yucatán and elsewhere in Central America.
The language of the Maya, still spoken by about half a million people.
Relating to the Maya or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mayakovsky, Vladimir 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1893–1930), Soviet poet and playwright, born in Georgia; full name Vladimir Vladimirovich Mayakovsky. A fervent futurist, he wrote in a declamatory, aggressive avant-garde style, which he altered to have a comic mass appeal after the Bolshevik revolution.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--
A large family of languages spoken in Central America and Mexico, of which the chief members are Maya, Quiché, and Tzeltal.
Denoting or relating to the Mayan family of languages.
Relating to or denoting the Maya people.

--Word--
maiden 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An unmarried girl or young woman.
A virgin.
An over in which no runs are scored.
(of an older woman) unmarried.
(of a female animal) not having mated.
Being or involving the first attempt or act of its kind.
Denoting a horse that has never won a race, or a race intended for such horses.
(of a tree or other fruiting plant) in its first year of growth.
--Examples--
‘two knights fought to win the hand of a fair maiden’
‘a maiden aunt’
‘the top-priced maiden heifer’
‘the Titanic's maiden voyage’
‘the Beckhampton Maiden Stakes’
--Word--
maiden-child 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A female child. Compare maid-child (archaic in 19th-cent. use.).

--Word--
hair 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of the fine threadlike strands growing from the skin of humans, mammals, and some other animals.
A fine threadlike strand growing from the epidermis of a plant, or forming part of a living cell.
Hairs collectively, especially those growing on a person's head.
A very small quantity or extent.
--Examples--
‘coarse outer hairs overlie the thick underfur’
‘thick black hairs on his huge arms’
‘scalloped leaves edged with silver hairs’
‘it damages the cilia, tiny hairs that clear invading bacteria from the lung’
‘her shoulder-length fair hair’
‘his magic takes him a hair above the competition’

--Word--
mayfly 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A short-lived slender insect with delicate transparent wings and two or three long filaments on the tail. It lives close to water, where the aquatic larvae develop.
An artificial fishing fly made to resemble a mayfly.

--Word--
Wainwright, Jonathan Mayhew 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
IV (1883–1953), US army officer. The general in charge of all US troops on the Philippine Islands in 1942, he was forced to surrender at Corregidor and was held as a prisoner of war by the Japanese until 1945.

--Word--
mail 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Letters and parcels sent by post.
The postal system.
A single delivery or collection of mail.
Email.
A vehicle, such as a train, carrying mail.
A bag of letters to be sent by post.
Used in titles of newspapers.
Send (a letter or parcel) by post.
Send (someone) email.
Armour made of metal rings or plates joined together flexibly.
The protective shell or scales of certain animals.
Clothe or cover with mail.
--Examples--
‘I did not receive any mail’
‘you can order by mail’
‘I had a notice in by this morning's mail’
‘you've got mail’
‘the Daily Mail’
‘three editions were mailed to our members’
‘his site is OK and I can even mail him direct’
‘a coat of mail’
‘he had a mail shirt’
‘a mailed gauntlet’

noun
--Meanings--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating fishes of the order Scorpaeniformes (which includes the scorpionfishes, gurnards, and sculpins), which are distinguished by a suborbital bony ridge extending across the cheek to the pre-operculum.

--Word--
may 
--Type--
modal verb
--Meanings--
Expressing possibility.
Used when admitting that something is so before making another, more important point.
Used to ask for or to give permission.
Expressing a wish or hope.
--Examples--
‘that may be true’
‘he may well win’
‘they may have been old-fashioned but they were excellent teachers’
‘you may confirm my identity with your Case Officer, if you wish’
‘may I ask a few questions?’
‘may she rest in peace’

--Word--
Maimonidean 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or relating to Moses ben Maimon or his teaching, used especially with reference to his belief in the power of reason and the possibility of synthesis between biblical religion and Aristotelian philosophy.
An adherent or student of Maimonides or his teaching.
--Examples--
--Word--
Maimonides 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1135–1204), Jewish philosopher and Rabbinic scholar, born in Spain; born Moses ben Maimon. His Guide for the Perplexed (1190) attempts to reconcile Talmudic scripture with the philosophy of Aristotle.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
main 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Chief in size or importance.
A principal pipe carrying water or gas to buildings, or taking sewage from them.
A principal cable carrying electricity.
The source of public water, gas, or electricity supply through pipes or cables.
The open ocean.
--Examples--
‘a main road’
‘the main problem is one of resources’
‘a faulty gas main’
‘the camcorder can be run directly off the mains’
‘switch off the mains supply’
--Word--
Keynes, John Maynard 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
1st Baron (1883–1946), English economist. He laid the foundations of modern macroeconomics with The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money (1936), in which he argued that full employment is determined by effective demand and requires government spending on public works to stimulate this.
--Examples--

--Word--
Maine 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state in the north-eastern US, on the coast of the Atlantic Ocean; population 1,316,456 (est. 2008); capital, Augusta. Visited by John Cabot in 1498 and colonized by England in the 17th and 18th centuries, it became the 23rd state of the US in 1820.
--Examples--
--Word--
Loire 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river of west central France. France's longest river, it rises in the Massif Central and flows 1,015 km (630 miles) north and west to the Atlantic at St-Nazaire.

--Word--
mainprize 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of procuring the release of a prisoner on someone's undertaking to stand surety (‘mainpernor’) for his or her appearance in court at a specified time. Chiefly in phrases "to let (also receive) to (also in) mainprize", "to deliver upon (also by) mainprize", "to nim under mainprize". "without bail or mainprize": with no permission to obtain release by finding sureties.
--Examples--
--Word--
mainprize 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of procuring the release of a prisoner on someone's undertaking to stand surety (‘mainpernor’) for his or her appearance in court at a specified time. Chiefly in phrases "to let (also receive) to (also in) mainprize", "to deliver upon (also by) mainprize", "to nim under mainprize". "without bail or mainprize": with no permission to obtain release by finding sureties.

--Word--
mainstream 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
The ideas, attitudes, or activities that are shared by most people and regarded as normal or conventional.
Jazz that is neither traditional nor modern, based on the 1930s swing style and consisting especially of solo improvisation on chord sequences.
Belonging to or characteristic of the mainstream.
(of a school or class) for pupils without special needs.
Bring into the mainstream.
--Examples--
‘they withdrew from the mainstream of European politics’
‘it was a form of jazz that had strayed away from the mainstream’
‘mainstream pop music’
‘the state government has supported greater integration of students with disabilities into mainstream schools’
‘vegetarianism has been mainstreamed’
--Word--
mainstream 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
The ideas, attitudes, or activities that are shared by most people and regarded as normal or conventional.
Jazz that is neither traditional nor modern, based on the 1930s swing style and consisting especially of solo improvisation on chord sequences.
Belonging to or characteristic of the mainstream.

‘they withdrew from the mainstream of European politics’
‘it was a form of jazz that had strayed away from the mainstream’
‘mainstream pop music’
‘the state government has supported greater integration of students with disabilities into mainstream schools’
‘vegetarianism has been mainstreamed’

--Word--
maintain 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Cause or enable (a condition or situation) to continue.
Keep (something) at the same level or rate.
Keep (a building, machine, or road) in good condition by checking or repairing it regularly.
Provide with necessities for life or existence.
Keep (a military unit) supplied with equipment and other requirements.
Give one's support to; uphold.
State something strongly to be the case; assert.
--Examples--
‘the need to maintain close links between industry and schools’
‘agricultural prices will have to be maintained’
‘the Department for Transport is responsible for maintaining the main roads in England’
‘the allowance covers the basic costs of maintaining a child’
‘an English garrison was maintained there in the seventeenth century’
‘the king swears he will maintain the laws of God’
‘he has always maintained his innocence’
‘he had persistently maintained that he would not stand against his old friend’

--Meanings--
Cause or enable (a condition or situation) to continue.
Keep (something) at the same level or rate.
Keep (a building, machine, or road) in good condition by checking or repairing it regularly.
Provide with necessities for life or existence.
Keep (a military unit) supplied with equipment and other requirements.
Give one's support to; uphold.
State something strongly to be the case; assert.
--Examples--
‘the need to maintain close links between industry and schools’
‘agricultural prices will have to be maintained’
‘the Department for Transport is responsible for maintaining the main roads in England’
‘the allowance covers the basic costs of maintaining a child’
‘an English garrison was maintained there in the seventeenth century’
‘the king swears he will maintain the laws of God’
‘he has always maintained his innocence’
‘he had persistently maintained that he would not stand against his old friend’
--Word--
maintainer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or thing that maintains something, in particular computer software.
A person who supports a legal action in which he or she has no legally recognized interest.
--Examples--

--Word--
maintenance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process of preserving a condition or situation or the state of being preserved.
The process of keeping something in good condition.
The provision of financial support for a person's living expenses, or the support so provided.
A husband's or wife's provision for their spouse after separation or divorce.
The offence of aiding a party in a legal action without lawful cause.
--Examples--
‘crucial conditions for the maintenance of democratic government’
‘car maintenance’
‘essential maintenance work’
‘a chance of going to university with fees and maintenance paid’
‘a divorced man paying his ex-wife £2,500 a year maintenance’

main-topgallant 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

adjective, noun
--Meanings--

The open ocean.

--Word--
majoid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Resembling or related to the genus Maja; specifically belonging to the group (now a superfamily) Majoidea (formerly Maioidea) of decapod crustaceans, containing the genus Maja and other genera of spider crabs.
A majoid crab.

noun

--Word--
Mayotte 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island to the east of the Comoros in the Indian Ocean; population 240,000 (estimated 2015); languages, French (official), local Swahili dialect; capital, Mamoutzu. When the Comoros became independent in 1974, Mayotte remained an overseas territory of France.

maire 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
The chief municipal officer of a French town or city; (also) the chief municipal officer of one of the arrondissements or districts of Paris.
Any of several New Zealand trees with heavy close-grained wood; especially (a) either of two forest trees of the genus Nestegis (formerly Olea), of the family Oleaceae, N. cunninghamii (more fully "black maire"), a tall tree with dark wood, and N. lanceolata (more fully "white maire"); (b) Mida salicifolia, of the family Santalaceae, a forest tree with leathery leaves; (c) Syzygium (formerly Eugenia) maire, of the family Myrtaceae, a tree of swampy ground with edible red berries.
--Examples--
--Word--
mairie 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In France: a town hall; a public building housing the municipal offices of a town or arrondissement and often also serving as the official residence of the mayor.

--Word--
may 
--Type--
modal verb
--Meanings--
Expressing possibility.
Used when admitting that something is so before making another, more important point.
Used to ask for or to give permission.
Expressing a wish or hope.
--Examples--
‘that may be true’
‘he may well win’
‘they may have been old-fashioned but they were excellent teachers’
‘you may confirm my identity with your Case Officer, if you wish’
‘may I ask a few questions?’
‘may she rest in peace’

maythe 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various white-rayed species of chamomile (genus Anthemis and perhaps allied genera), chiefly weeds of cultivated ground; especially (also more fully "stinking maythe") stinking chamomile, Anthemis cotula. Also: any of several other white-rayed plants of the family Asteraceae (Compositae); especially ox-eye daisy, Leucanthemum vulgare (also "†white maythe").

--Word--
maize 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Central American cereal plant that yields large grains (corn or sweetcorn) set in rows on a cob. The many varieties include some used for stockfeed and corn oil.

--Examples--
--Word--
maja 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Originally (in form maia): the common spider crab of Europe, Maja squinado, having a spiny red, reddish brown, or yellowish carapace. Later (in forms Maia, Maja): a genus of decapod crustaceans (family Majidae), comprising this and various other spider crabs.
In Spain and Spanish-speaking countries: a woman who dresses gaily; a pretty young woman; (in early use sometimes) specifically †one from a lower social class (obsolete).
--Examples--
--Word--
majagua 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various trees found in the New World tropics and used as a source of strong fibre for rope, etc.; especially either of two closely related species of the family Malvaceae, Hibiscus tilaceus and the blue mahoe, H. elatus; the wood of any of these trees.
--Examples--
--Word--
majagua 
--Type--

Any of various trees found in the New World tropics and used as a source of strong fibre for rope, etc.; especially either of two closely related species of the family Malvaceae, Hibiscus tilaceus and the blue mahoe, H. elatus; the wood of any of these trees.

majo 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A West Indian shrub, Picramnia antidesma (family Simaroubaceae); (also) a medicinal preparation of the bark of this plant, formerly used to treat fevers, venereal diseases, and colic (more fully "majo bitters").
In Spain and Spanish-speaking countries: a man who dresses gaily, a dandy; an ostentatious young man; (originally) one from a lower social class (obsolete).

jong 
--Type--
noun, exclamation
--Meanings--
A young black male servant.
A black man.
Used as a form of address to both men and women, expressing affection or exasperation.
A boyfriend or lover.
Used to express surprise, pleasure, or anger, or to add emphasis to a statement.
--Examples--
‘there are sharks out there, jong’
‘he was my jong and I had a child by him’
‘he's nice, but jong is he strict!’
--Word--
major 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Important, serious, or significant.
Greater or more important; main.
(of a surgical operation) serious or life-threatening.
(of a scale) having intervals of a semitone between the third and fourth, and seventh and eighth degrees.
(of an interval) equivalent to that between the tonic and another note of a major scale, and greater by a semitone than the corresponding minor interval.
(of a key) based on a major scale, tending to produce a bright or joyful effect.
(appended to a surname in public schools) indicating the elder of two brothers.
(of a term) occurring as the predicate in the conclusion of a categorical syllogism.
(of a premise) containing the major term in a categorical syllogism.
A rank of officer in the army and the US air force, above captain and below lieutenant colonel.
An officer in charge of a section of band instruments.
A major key, interval, or scale.
A system of change-ringing using eight bells.
A major organization or competition.
A student's principal subject or course.
A student specializing in a specified subject.
A major term or premise.
A goal.
Specialize in (a particular subject) at college or university.
--Examples--
‘the use of drugs is a major problem’
‘he got the major share of the spoils’
‘he had to undergo major surgery’
‘C to E is a major third’
‘Prelude in G Major’
‘a trumpet major’
‘the majors have swept up the smaller independent companies in licensing deals’
‘it's not unreasonable to believe someone can win all four majors’
‘the oil majors had a profit bonanza’
‘many students would ignore courses outside their major’
‘a math major’
‘South was anxious to mention his four-card major and bid one spade’
‘I was trying to decide if I should major in drama or English’
--Word--
labia majora

plural noun
--Meanings--
The larger outer folds of the vulva.
--Examples--

major-domo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chief steward of a large household.
--Examples--
‘I twice left a message, once with Pippa and once with her major-domo, asking him to ring back’

--Word--
major 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Important, serious, or significant.
Greater or more important; main.
(of a surgical operation) serious or life-threatening.
(of a scale) having intervals of a semitone between the third and fourth, and seventh and eighth degrees.
(of an interval) equivalent to that between the tonic and another note of a major scale, and greater by a semitone than the corresponding minor interval.
(of a key) based on a major scale, tending to produce a bright or joyful effect.
(appended to a surname in public schools) indicating the elder of two brothers.
(of a term) occurring as the predicate in the conclusion of a categorical syllogism.
(of a premise) containing the major term in a categorical syllogism.
A rank of officer in the army and the US air force, above captain and below lieutenant colonel.
An officer in charge of a section of band instruments.
A major key, interval, or scale.
A system of change-ringing using eight bells.
A major organization or competition.
A student's principal subject or course.
A student specializing in a specified subject.
A major term or premise.
A goal.
Specialize in (a particular subject) at college or university.
--Examples--
‘the use of drugs is a major problem’
‘he got the major share of the spoils’
‘he had to undergo major surgery’
‘C to E is a major third’
‘Prelude in G Major’
‘a trumpet major’
‘the majors have swept up the smaller independent companies in licensing deals’
‘it's not unreasonable to believe someone can win all four majors’
‘the oil majors had a profit bonanza’
‘many students would ignore courses outside their major’
‘a math major’
‘South was anxious to mention his four-card major and bid one spade’
‘I was trying to decide if I should major in drama or English’

majoritarian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--

A person who supports government by a majority.

--Word--
majority 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The greater number.
The number by which the votes cast for one party or candidate exceed those for the next.
A party or group receiving the greater number of votes.
The number by which votes for one candidate are more than those for all other candidates together.
The age at which a person is legally a full adult, usually either 18 or 21.
The rank or office of a major.
--Examples--
‘in the majority of cases all will go smoothly’
‘it was a majority decision’
‘Labour retained the seat with a majority of 9,830’
‘kids get control of the money when they reach the age of majority’

--Word--
majo 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A West Indian shrub, Picramnia antidesma (family Simaroubaceae); (also) a medicinal preparation of the bark of this plant, formerly used to treat fevers, venereal diseases, and colic (more fully "majo bitters").
In Spain and Spanish-speaking countries: a man who dresses gaily, a dandy; an ostentatious young man; (originally) one from a lower social class (obsolete).

--Word--
makar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A poet or bard.
(in Scotland) an eminent poet appointed by an official body, especially one appointed by the government as the national poet of Scotland.
--Examples--
‘poetry is in great shape, with Robertson and Paterson prominent among the many makars, as Scots of old called their poets’
‘in 2011 she was named as the second Scots Makar’
‘being Edinburgh Makar for the last six years has been a great honour’
--Word--
makara 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mythical crocodile or other sea-animal, variously represented in Indian art; (in Indian contexts) the equivalent of Capricorn in the signs of the zodiac.

makatea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The raised terrace of coralline limestone typically surrounding South Pacific islands; the annular raised rim of a Pacific island formed by the uplifting of an atoll so that the lagoon is lost.
