--Word--
make 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Form (something) by putting parts together or combining substances; create.
Alter something so that it forms (something else)
Compose or draw up (something written or abstract)
Prepare (a dish, drink, or meal)
Arrange bedclothes tidily on (a bed) ready for use.
Arrange and light materials for (a fire).
Complete or close (a circuit).
Cause (something) to exist or come about; bring about.
Cause to become or seem.
Carry out, perform, or produce (a specified action or sound)
(in soccer) enable a teammate to score (a goal) by one's play.
Communicate or express (an idea, request, or requirement)
Enter into a contract of (marriage)
Appoint or designate (someone) to a position.
Represent or cause to appear in a specified way.
Cause to be successful.
Compel (someone) to do something.
Constitute; amount to.
Be suitable for or likely to develop into.
Consider to be; estimate as.
Agree or decide on (a specified arrangement)
Gain or earn (money or profit)
Score (a specified number of runs)
Manage to arrive at (a place) within a specified time or catch (a train or other form of transport)
Become successful.
Succeed in reaching safety or in surviving.
Achieve a place in.
Achieve the rank of.
Prepare to go in a particular direction.
Act as if one is about to perform an action.
Induce (someone) to have sexual intercourse with one.
(in bridge, whist, etc.) win (a trick).
Win a trick with (a card).
Win the number of tricks that fulfils (a contract).
Shuffle (cards) for dealing.
(of the tide) begin to flow or ebb.
The manufacturer or trade name of a product.
The structure or composition of something.
The making of electrical contact.
--Examples--
‘my grandmother made a dress for me’
‘cricket bats are made of willow’
‘buffalo's milk can be made into cheese’
‘make a list of all the points you can think of’
‘she was making lunch for Lucy and Francis’
‘I'll make us both a cup of tea’
‘after breakfast you'd have until 8.25 to make your bed’
‘the drips had made a pool on the floor’
‘decorative features make brickwork more interesting’
‘the best way to disarm your critics is to make them laugh’
‘anyone can make a mistake’
‘there are two more points to make’
‘make him an offer he can't refuse’
‘as many sailors do, he made a foolish marriage’
‘he was made a fellow of the Royal Institute’
‘the issue price makes them good value’
‘the work which made Wordsworth's reputation’
‘she bought me a brandy and made me drink it’
‘they made an unusual duo’
‘this fern makes a good houseplant’
‘How many are there? I make it sixteen’
‘let's make it 7.30’
‘he'd made a lot of money out of hardware’
‘he made a century’
‘we've got a lot to do if you're going to make the shuttle’
‘they didn't always make it on time’
‘he waited confidently for his band to make it’
‘the pilot didn't make it—his neck's broken’
‘Australia should make the final’
‘he wasn't going to make captain’
‘he struggled to his feet and made towards the car’
‘she made as if to leave the room’
‘he had been trying to make Cynthia for two years now’
‘the make, model, and year of his car’

--Word--
fray 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a fabric, rope, or cord) unravel or become worn at the edge, typically through constant rubbing.
(of a person's nerves or temper) show the effects of strain.
(of a male deer) rub (a bush or small tree) with the head in order to remove the velvet from newly formed antlers, or to mark territory during the rut.
A situation of intense competitive activity.
A battle or fight.
--Examples--
‘cheap fabric soon frays’
‘as the temperature rose, tempers frayed’
‘bucks mark their territory by fraying small trees’
‘ten companies intend to bid for the contract, with three more expected to enter the fray’
‘he charged into the thick of the fray and went down fighting’
--Word--
make-up game 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A game previously postponed which is played to complete the number of scheduled league matches.
--Examples--
--Word--
hawk 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A bird of prey with broad rounded wings and a long tail, typically taking prey by surprise with a short chase.
A bird of prey related to the buzzards.
Any diurnal bird of prey used in falconry.
A person who advocates an aggressive or warlike policy, especially in foreign affairs.
Used in names of hawkmoths, e.g. eyed hawk.
(of a person) hunt game with a trained hawk.
(of a bird or dragonfly) hunt on the wing for food.
--Examples--
‘severe limits were put on the peace plan by party hawks’
‘he spent the afternoon hawking’
‘swifts hawked low over the water’
--Word--
king 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The male ruler of an independent state, especially one who inherits the position by right of birth.
A person or thing regarded as the finest or most important in their sphere or group.
(in the UK) the national anthem when there is a male sovereign.
Used in names of animals and plants that are particularly large, e.g. king cobra.
The most important chess piece, of which each player has one, which the opponent has to checkmate in order to win. The king can move in any direction, including diagonally, to any adjacent square that is not attacked by an opponent's piece or pawn.
A piece in draughts with extra capacity for moving, made by crowning an ordinary piece that has reached the opponent's baseline.
A playing card bearing a representation of a king, normally ranking next below an ace.
Make (someone) king.
Act in an unpleasantly superior and domineering way.
--Examples--
‘King Henry VIII’
‘a country where football is king’
‘the king of rock’
‘he'll start kinging it over the lot of us again’
‘science kings it over the realm of intellectual discourse’
--Word--
law 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The system of rules which a particular country or community recognizes as regulating the actions of its members and which it may enforce by the imposition of penalties.
An individual rule as part of a system of law.
Systems of law as a subject of study or as the basis of the legal profession.
Statute law and the common law.
Something regarded as having binding force or effect.
The police.
A rule defining correct procedure or behaviour in a sport.
A statement of fact, deduced from observation, to the effect that a particular natural or scientific phenomenon always occurs if certain conditions are present.
A generalization based on a fact or event perceived to be recurrent.
The body of divine commandments as expressed in the Bible or other religious texts.
The Pentateuch as distinct from the other parts of the Hebrew Bible (the Prophets and the Writings).
The precepts of the Pentateuch.
--Examples--
‘shooting the birds is against the law’
‘they were taken to court for breaking the law’
‘law enforcement’
‘a new law was passed to make divorce easier and simpler’
‘he was still practising law’
‘a law firm’
‘law students’
‘he had supreme control—what he said was law’
‘he'd never been in trouble with the law in his life’
‘the laws of the game’
‘the second law of thermodynamics’
‘the first law of American corporate life is that dead wood floats’

--Word--
make 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Form (something) by putting parts together or combining substances; create.
Alter something so that it forms (something else)
Compose or draw up (something written or abstract)
Prepare (a dish, drink, or meal)
Arrange bedclothes tidily on (a bed) ready for use.
Arrange and light materials for (a fire).
Complete or close (a circuit).
Cause (something) to exist or come about; bring about.
Cause to become or seem.
Carry out, perform, or produce (a specified action or sound)
(in soccer) enable a teammate to score (a goal) by one's play.
Communicate or express (an idea, request, or requirement)
Enter into a contract of (marriage)
Appoint or designate (someone) to a position.
Represent or cause to appear in a specified way.
Cause to be successful.
Compel (someone) to do something.
Constitute; amount to.
Be suitable for or likely to develop into.
Consider to be; estimate as.
Agree or decide on (a specified arrangement)
Gain or earn (money or profit)
Score (a specified number of runs)
Manage to arrive at (a place) within a specified time or catch (a train or other form of transport)
Become successful.
Succeed in reaching safety or in surviving.
Achieve a place in.
Achieve the rank of.
Prepare to go in a particular direction.
Act as if one is about to perform an action.
Induce (someone) to have sexual intercourse with one.
(in bridge, whist, etc.) win (a trick).
Win a trick with (a card).
Win the number of tricks that fulfils (a contract).
Shuffle (cards) for dealing.
(of the tide) begin to flow or ebb.
The manufacturer or trade name of a product.
The structure or composition of something.
The making of electrical contact.
--Examples--
‘my grandmother made a dress for me’
‘cricket bats are made of willow’
‘buffalo's milk can be made into cheese’
‘make a list of all the points you can think of’
‘she was making lunch for Lucy and Francis’
‘I'll make us both a cup of tea’
‘after breakfast you'd have until 8.25 to make your bed’
‘the drips had made a pool on the floor’
‘decorative features make brickwork more interesting’
‘the best way to disarm your critics is to make them laugh’
‘anyone can make a mistake’
‘there are two more points to make’
‘make him an offer he can't refuse’
‘as many sailors do, he made a foolish marriage’
‘he was made a fellow of the Royal Institute’
‘the issue price makes them good value’
‘the work which made Wordsworth's reputation’
‘she bought me a brandy and made me drink it’
‘they made an unusual duo’
‘this fern makes a good houseplant’
‘How many are there? I make it sixteen’
‘let's make it 7.30’
‘he'd made a lot of money out of hardware’
‘he made a century’
‘we've got a lot to do if you're going to make the shuttle’
‘they didn't always make it on time’
‘he waited confidently for his band to make it’
‘the pilot didn't make it—his neck's broken’
‘Australia should make the final’
‘he wasn't going to make captain’
‘he struggled to his feet and made towards the car’
‘she made as if to leave the room’
‘he had been trying to make Cynthia for two years now’
‘the make, model, and year of his car’
--Word--
shame 
--Type--
noun, verb, exclamation
--Meanings--
A painful feeling of humiliation or distress caused by the consciousness of wrong or foolish behaviour.
A loss of respect or esteem; dishonour.
A person, action, or situation that brings a loss of respect or honour.
A regrettable or unfortunate situation or action.
Make (someone) feel ashamed.
Bring shame to.
Cause (someone) to feel inadequate by outdoing or surpassing them.
Used to express sentimental pleasure, especially at something small and endearing.
--Examples--
‘she was hot with shame’
‘he felt a pang of shame at telling Alice a lie’
‘the incident had brought shame on his family’
‘ignorance of Latin would be a disgrace and a shame to any public man’
‘what a shame Ellie won't be here’
‘it is a shame that they are not better known’
‘I tried to shame him into giving some away’
‘legal action must be taken and companies named and shamed’
‘the entire debacle has shamed Scotland’
‘she shames me with her eighty-year-old energy’
‘look at the foals—shame, aren't they sweet?’

--Word--
talk 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Speak in order to give information or express ideas or feelings; converse or communicate by spoken words.
Have the power of speech.
Discuss personal or intimate feelings.
Persuade or cause (someone) to do something by talking.
Used to emphasize the seriousness, importance, or extent of the thing one is discussing.
Reveal secret or confidential information.
Gossip.
Have formal dealings or discussions; negotiate.
Use (a particular language) in speech.
Communication by spoken words; conversation or discussion.
A period of conversation or discussion, especially a relatively serious one.
Rumour, gossip, or speculation.
Empty promises or boasting.
A current subject of widespread gossip or speculation in (a particular place)
Formal discussions or negotiations over a period.
An informal address or lecture.
--Examples--
‘the two men talked’
‘we'd sit and talk about jazz’
‘it was no use talking to Anthony’

‘he can talk as well as you or I can’

‘there was a slight but noticeable lull in the talk’

‘he's all talk’

‘peace talks’

Malaya 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A former country in SE Asia, consisting of the southern part of the Malay Peninsula and some adjacent islands (originally including Singapore), now forming the western part of the federation of Malaysia and known as West Malaysia.

malaria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

malaxation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of reducing ingredients to a soft mass by kneading or rolling.
Pétrissage.
Entomology. The action of repeatedly squeezing captured prey between the mandibles prior to feeding, characteristic of fossorial wasps.
--Examples--
--Word--
malaxator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various machines for mixing materials, usually consisting of a cylindrical container with a rotating central spindle bearing radial blade-like arms.
--Examples--
--Word--
Malcolm 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The name of four kings of Scotland.
Malcolm I (d.954), reigned 943–54.
Malcolm II (c.954–1034), reigned 1005–34.
Malcolm III (c.1031–93), son of Duncan I, reigned 1058–93; known as Malcolm Canmore (from Gaelic Ceann-mor great head). He came to the throne after killing Macbeth in battle (1057), and helped to form Scotland into an organized kingdom.
Malcolm IV (1141–65), grandson of David I, reigned 1153–65; known as Malcolm the Maiden. His reign witnessed a progressive loss of power to Henry II of England; he died young and without an heir.
--Examples--

--Meanings--
Unacceptable conduct; especially improper or dishonest administration of an office, business, etc.

--Word--
male 
--Type--
adjective, noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
Of or denoting the sex that produces gametes, especially spermatozoa, with which a female may be fertilized or inseminated to produce offspring.
Relating to or characteristic of men or male animals.
(of a plant or flower) bearing stamens but lacking functional pistils.
(of a fitting or part of machinery) manufactured to fit inside a corresponding female part.
A male person, plant, or animal.
The capital of the Maldives; population 111,000 (est. 2007).
--Examples--
‘male children’
‘a deep male voice’
‘the valve has standard half-inch threaded male ends’
‘the audience consisted of adult males’

noun

Malenkov, Georgi 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1902–88), Soviet statesman, born in Russia; full name Georgi Maksimilianovich Malenkov. He became prime minister and First Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party in 1953, but was forced to resign in 1955 following internal party struggles.

Malevich, Kazimir 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1878–1935), Russian painter and designer, founder of the suprematist movement; full name Kazimir Severinovich Malevich. In his abstract works he used only basic geometrical shapes and a severely restricted range of colour.

--Meanings--
An abnormally formed part of the body.
Abnormality of shape or form.
--Examples--
‘the drug may cause malformations in the developing embryo’
‘malformation of one or both ears’
--Word--
malformed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a person or part of the body) abnormally formed; misshapen.
Not conforming to a standard type.
--Examples--
‘her ribs are malformed’
‘malformed web pages’
--Word--
malfunction 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a piece of equipment or machinery) fail to function normally.
A failure to function normally.
--Examples--
‘the unit is clearly malfunctioning’
‘a computer malfunction’
‘they were sent back to the manufacturers at the first sign of malfunction’

--Word--
malgré 
--Type--
preposition
--Meanings--
In spite of, notwithstanding. Now archaic and rare.
"malgré lui" Brit./ˌmalɡreɪ ˈlwiː/ U.S./ˌmaelˌɡreɪ ˈlwi/: in spite of himself, herself, or itself. "malgré elle" (also "malgré eux", "malgré moi", etc.): in spite of herself (themselves, myself, etc.).
"malgré tout": despite everything.
--Examples--
--Word--
Malherbe, François de 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1555–1628), French poet. An architect of classicism in poetic form and grammar, he criticized excess of emotion and ornamentation and the use of Latin and dialectal forms.
--Examples--
--Word--
mali 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A gardener.
A landlocked country in West Africa, south of Algeria; population 17,600,000 (estimated 2015); languages, French (official), other languages mainly of the Mande group; capital, Bamako.

malicho 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Probably: wrongdoing, misdeeds. In later use in allusion to Shakespeare's miching malicho and taken to be generally suggestive of dark deeds, mystery, or intrigue, and used in these senses.

malignancy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or presence of a malignant tumour; cancer.
A cancerous growth.
A form of cancer.
The quality of being malign.
--Examples--

‘diffuse malignancies such as leukaemia’
‘her eyes sparkled with renewed malignancy’

--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or relating to one of the four Sunni schools of Islamic law, founded in the 8th cent. and based on the teachings of Mālik ibn Anas, now prevalent mainly in western and northern Africa. Also absol.: the school itself.
A member of this school.

Mallarmé, Stéphane 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1842–98), French poet. A symbolist, he experimented with rhythm and syntax by transposing words and omitting grammatical elements. Notable poems: ‘Hérodiade’ (c.1871) and ‘L'Après-midi d'un faune’ (1876).

malleation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of beating something with a hammer; the condition of being marked or dented as with a hammer. Now chiefly Archaeology.
Medicine. Hammering of one hand or both against another part of the body, as a symptom of neurological illness. Now rare. Perhaps Obsolete.

--Word--
mallee 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A low-growing bushy Australian eucalyptus which has several slender stems.
Scrub which is dominated by mallee, typical of some arid parts of Australia.
Any semi-arid area of mainland Australia which has mallee scrub as its principal natural vegetation.
--Examples--
‘moving to the Mallee was a major culture shock’

--Word--
Mallon, Mary 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(circa 1870–1938) US cook; born in Ireland; known as Typhoid Mary. Immune to typhoid herself, she spread the disease while working in New York City. She was institutionalized for life from 1914 to protect others.
--Examples--

--Word--
Mallory 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Used with reference to a staining technique using haematoxylin and phosphotungstic acid to demonstrate connective tissue elements and cytological detail; especially in "Mallory's phosphotungstic acid haematoxylin", "Mallory's phosphotungstic acid haematoxylin stain".
Used with reference to a staining technique using acid fuchsin, aniline blue, orange G, and phosphotungstic (originally phosphomolybdic) acid to produce differential staining of collagen and ground substance (blue), nuclei, fibrin and neuroglia (red), elastin (yellow or pink), etc.; now especially in "Mallory's trichrome stain", "Mallory's triple stain".
--Examples--

--Word--
malolactic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or denoting bacterial fermentation which converts malic acid to lactic acid, especially as a secondary process used to reduce the acidity of some wines.
Malolactic fermentation.
--Examples--
‘malolactic fermentation is essential in poor years when the grapes are not fully ripe’
‘most Champagnes undergo malolactic’

malonic ester 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The diethyl ester, CH₂(COOC₂H₅)₂, of malonic acid, which is a liquid widely used in synthesis, as of carboxylic acids RR′C(COOH)₂ or RR′CHCOOH by alkylation with alkyl halides ("malonic ester synthesis").
--Examples--
--Word--
malonyl 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The divalent radical —CO·CH₂·CO— derived from malonic acid by removal of the two hydroxyl groups. Usually attributive.

Malpighi, Marcello 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1628–94), Italian microscopist. He discovered the alveoli and capillaries in the lungs and the fibres and red cells of clotted blood, and demonstrated the pathway of blood from arteries to veins.

Malraux, André 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1901–76), French novelist, politician, and art critic. Involved in the Chinese communist uprising of 1927 and the Spanish Civil War, he was later appointed France's first Minister of Cultural Affairs (1959–69). Notable novels: La Condition humaine (1933).

noun

Abnormal rotation of a part of the body; specifically failure of normal rotation of the intestines or other organs during fetal development; an instance of this. Later also: abnormal rotation of the fetus during delivery.

--Word--
Malthus, Thomas Robert 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1766–1834), English economist and clergyman. In An Essay on the Principle of Population (1798) he argued that without the practice of ‘moral restraint’ the population tends to increase at a greater rate than its means of subsistence, resulting in the population checks of war, famine, and epidemic.
--Examples--
--Word--
Malthusian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the English economist and clergyman Thomas Robert Malthus or his ideas about population.
A person who supports the theories about population proposed by the English economist and clergyman Thomas Robert Malthus.
--Examples--
‘it seems we face a curious Malthusian catastrophe’
‘Malthusians spoke of moral restraint’
--Word--
Malthusianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The view that without ‘moral restraint’ the population will increase at a greater rate than its means of subsistence, as proposed by the English economist and clergyman Thomas Robert Malthus.
--Examples--
‘birth control became associated with Malthusianism only in the last quarter of the century’

maltose 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sugar produced by the breakdown of starch, e.g. by enzymes found in malt and saliva. It is a disaccharide consisting of two linked glucose units.

malum prohibitum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Something which is not intrinsically wicked, but which is regarded as wrong because it contravenes a law or regulation. Also as adjective: evil by convention rather than by inherent nature.

Malus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant of the genus Malus (family Rosaceae), which consists of deciduous trees and shrubs grown ornamentally and for their fruit (apples and crab apples) in the temperate zones of both hemispheres; (in form Malus) the genus itself.
--Examples--
--Word--
malva 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mallow; specifically a plant of the dicotyledonous genus Malva, of the family Malvaceae, the members of which are found chiefly in Europe and temperate Asia and are characterized by having an epicalyx of three bracts enclosing the calyx and one-seeded nutlets arranged in a flat whorl round a central axis. Also (in form Malva): the genus itself.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

Mameluke 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a regime descended from Turkish, Mongol, and Circassian slaves which ruled Syria (1260–1516) and Egypt (1250–1517), and continued as a ruling military caste in Ottoman Egypt until massacred by the viceroy Muhammad Ali in 1811.

Mamertine 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Originally: one of a group of mercenaries from Campania in Italy who seized Messana (now Messina) in Sicily in 288 b.c. Later: any inhabitant of Messana.
A sweet wine from the Messina region of Sicily.
Of, relating to, or designating the city of Messana (now Messina) in Sicily or its people; specifically designating wine from the Messina region.

mammal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A warm-blooded vertebrate animal of a class that is distinguished by the possession of hair or fur, females that secrete milk for the nourishment of the young, and (typically) the birth of live young.
--Examples--
--Word--

noun

mammet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An image, a dressed-up figure; a doll, a puppet.
A contemptible or hateful person; a weakling, a physically or mentally feeble person. Now chiefly English regional.
--Examples--

mammy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A child's word for their mother.
(formerly in the southern United States) a black nursemaid or nanny in charge of white children.
--Examples--

mamillary 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Shaped like or resembling a breast or nipple.
(of a mineral) having several smoothly rounded convex surfaces.
Denoting two rounded bodies in the floor of the hypothalamus in the brain.

‘the mamillary bodies’

mammoth 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--

Huge.
--Examples--

--Word--
man 
--Type--
noun, verb, exclamation
--Meanings--
An adult human male.
A male member of a workforce, team, etc.
Ordinary members of the armed forces as distinct from the officers.
A husband or lover.
A male person associated with a particular place, activity, or occupation.
A person with the qualities associated with males, such as bravery, spirit, or toughness.
A male pursued or sought by another, especially in connection with a crime.
A manservant or valet.
A vassal.
A human being of either sex; a person.
Human beings in general; the human race.
An individual; one.
A type of prehistoric human named after the place where the remains were found.
A group or person in a position of authority over others, such as a corporate employer or the police.
White people collectively regarded as the controlling group in society.
A figure or token used in playing a board game.
(of personnel) work at, run, or operate (a place or piece of equipment) or defend (a fortification)
Provide someone to fill (a post)
Fortify the spirits or courage of.
Used, irrespective of the sex of the person addressed, to express surprise, admiration, delight, etc., or for emphasis.
--Examples--
‘a small man with mischievous eyes’
‘the men's semi-finals’
‘over 700 men were made redundant’
‘he had a platoon of forty men to prepare for battle’
‘the two of them lived for a time as man and wife’
‘a Cambridge man’
‘I'm a solid Labour man’
‘she was more of a man than any of them’
‘Inspector Bull was sure they would find their man’
‘get me a cocktail, my man’
‘God cares for all men’
‘places untouched by the ravages of man’
‘a man could buy a lot with eighteen million dotillars’
‘Cro-Magnon man’
‘they've mastered their emotive grunge-pop without haggling with the Man’
‘he urged that black college athletes boycott the Man's Rose Bowl’
‘the helpline is manned by trained staff’
‘the firemen manned the pumps and fought the blaze’
‘the chaplaincy was formerly manned by the cathedral’
‘he manned himself with dauntless air’
‘wow, like cosmic, man’

--Word--
manage 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Be in charge of (a business, organization, or undertaking); run.
Have the position of supervising (staff) at work.
Be the manager of (a sports team or a performer)
Use (money, time, or other resources) sensibly.
Maintain control over (a person or animal)
Control the use or exploitation of (land)
Succeed in surviving or in achieving something despite difficult circumstances; cope.
Succeed in achieving or producing (something difficult)
Succeed in dealing with or withstanding (something)
Be free to attend at (a certain time)
--Examples--
‘their elder son managed the farm’
‘the skills needed to manage a young, dynamic team’
‘he managed five or six bands in his career’
‘we manage our cash extremely well’
‘she manages horses better than anyone I know’
‘the forest is managed to achieve maximum growth’
‘Catherine managed on five hours' sleep a night’
‘she managed a brave but unconvincing smile’
‘Blanche finally managed to hail a cab’
‘there was more stress and anxiety than he could manage’
‘he could not manage 24 March after all’

--Word--
management 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process of dealing with or controlling things or people.
The people managing a company or organization, regarded collectively.
The responsibility for and control of a company or organization.
The treatment or control of diseases or disorders, or the care of patients who suffer them.
Trickery; deceit.
--Examples--
‘the management of the economy’
‘businesses were slow to adopt the key elements of environmental risk management’
‘management were extremely cooperative’
‘a successful career in management’
‘long-term management of patients with cirrhosis’
‘if there has been any management in the business, it has been concealed from me’

--Word--
manager 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person responsible for controlling or administering an organization or group of staff.
A person who controls the professional and business activities of a performer, sports player, group of musicians, etc.
A person in charge of the activities, tactics, and training of a sports team.
A person regarded in terms of their skill in managing resources, especially those of a household.
A program or system that controls or organizes a peripheral device or process.
(in the Houses of Parliament and the US Senate) a member of a committee appointed by one house to confer with a similar committee of the other house.
--Examples--
‘the manager of a bar’
‘if I was his manager I would offer Lewis $8 m for the fight’
‘the team manager’
‘she was a good manager, and could make a meal out of nothing’
‘a file manager’

--Meanings--

--Word--
back 
--Type--
noun, adverb, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
The rear surface of the human body from the shoulders to the hips.
The upper surface of an animal's body that corresponds to a person's back.
The spine of a person or animal.
The main structure of a ship's hull or an aircraft's fuselage.
The part of a chair against which the sitter's back rests.
The part of a garment that covers a person's back.
A person's back regarded as carrying a load or bearing an imposition.
The side or part of something that is away from the spectator or from the direction in which it moves or faces; the rear.
The position directly behind someone or something.
The side or part of an object that is not normally seen or used.
A player in a team game who plays in a defensive position behind the forwards.
The grounds of Cambridge colleges which back on to the River Cam.
In the opposite direction from the one that one is facing or travelling towards.
Expressing movement of the body into a reclining position.
At a distance away.
Behind.
Losing by a specified margin.
So as to return to an earlier or normal position or condition.
At a place previously left or mentioned.
Fashionable again.
In or into the past.
In return.
Give financial, material, or moral support to.
Supplement in order to strengthen.
Be in favour of.
(in popular music) provide musical accompaniment to (a singer or musician)
Bet money on (a person or animal) winning a race or contest.
Cover the back of (an article) in order to support, protect, or decorate it.
Walk or drive backwards.
(of the wind) change direction anticlockwise around the points of the compass.
Put (a sail) aback in order to slow the vessel down or assist in turning through the wind.
(of a building or other structure) have its back facing or adjacent to.
Lie behind or at the back of.
Put a piece of music on the less important side of (a vinyl recording)
Of or at the back of something.
In a remote or subsidiary position.
From or relating to the past.
Directed towards the rear or in a reversed course.
(of a sound) articulated at the back of the mouth.
--Examples--
‘he lay on his back’
‘back pain’
‘the adults have white bodies with grey backs’
‘Demetrius broke its back on the rocks in a force 11 gale’
‘a top with a scooped neckline and a low back’
‘the Press are on my back’
‘at the back of the hotel is a secluded garden’
‘a rubber dinghy with an engine at the back’
‘she unbuttoned her dress from the back’
‘the back of a postcard’
‘their backs showed some impressive running and passing’
‘he moved back a pace’
‘she walked away without looking back’
‘he leaned back in his chair’
‘sit back and relax’
‘keep back from the roadside’
‘he knew that other people were back of him’
‘the team was five points back’
‘she put the book back on the shelf’
‘he drove to Glasgow and back in a day’
‘things were back to normal’
‘the folks back home are counting on him’
‘sideburns are back’
‘he made his fortune back in 1955’
‘they wrote back to me’
‘he had a newspaper empire backing him’
‘his mother backed him up on everything’
‘firefighters, backed up by helicopters and planes, fought to bring the flames under control’
‘over 97 per cent backed the changes’
‘on his new album he is backed by an American group’
‘he backed the horse at 33–1’
‘a mirror backed with tortoiseshell’
‘she tried to back away’
‘the government backed away from the plan’
‘he backed the Mercedes into the yard’
‘the wind had backed to the north-west’
‘his garage wall backs on to the neighbouring property’
‘the promenade is backed by lots of cafes’
‘the new single is backed with a track from the LP’
‘the back garden’
‘the back pocket of his jeans’
‘back roads’
‘she was owed back pay’
‘a back header’
‘a long back vowel, as in 'dance' or 'bath'’
--Word--
bearing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person's way of standing or moving.
The way a person behaves or conducts themselves.
Relation; relevance.
The ability to tolerate something bad or to be tolerated.
A part of a machine that allows one part to rotate or move in contact with another part with as little friction as possible.
The direction or position of something, or the direction of movement, relative to a fixed point. It is usually measured in degrees, typically with magnetic north as zero.
Awareness of one's position relative to one's surroundings.
A device or charge.
--Examples--
‘a man of precise military bearing’
‘she has the bearing of a First Lady’
‘the case has no direct bearing on the issues being considered’
‘school was bad enough, but now it's past bearing’
‘the Point is on a bearing of 015°’
‘there were no steeples or bridges from which to take a bearing’
‘he flashed the torch around, trying to get his bearings’
‘armorial bearings’

--Word--
born 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Existing as a result of birth.
Having a specific nationality.
Having a natural ability to do a particular job.
Perfectly suited or trained to do a particular job.
(of an organization, movement, or idea) brought into existence.
Existing as a result of (a particular situation or feeling)
--Examples--
‘she was born in Aberdeen’
‘I was born with a sense of curiosity’
‘a newly born baby’
‘a German-born philosopher’
‘he's a born engineer’
‘men born to rule’
‘on 1 January 1992, the new company was born’
‘his work is born of despair’

brute 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A savagely violent person or animal.
A cruel or insensitive person.
Something awkward, difficult, or unpleasant.
An animal as opposed to a human being.
Characterized by an absence of reasoning or intelligence.
Merely physical.
Fundamental, inescapable, and unpleasant.
--Examples--

‘a great brute of a machine’

‘we achieve little by brute force’
‘the brute necessities of basic subsistence’

mancala

noun

manchester 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
Household linen.
An industrial city and metropolitan district in north-western England; population 396,300 (est. 2009). Founded in Roman times, it developed in the 18th and 19th centuries as a centre of the English cotton industry.

Manchu 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a people originally living in Manchuria, who formed the last imperial dynasty of China (1644–1912).
The Tungusic language of the Manchus, still spoken by a few thousand people in Xinjiang, though most Manchus now speak Chinese.
Relating to the Manchu people or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Manchuria 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A mountainous region forming the north-eastern portion of China, now comprising the provinces of Jilin, Liaoning, and Heilongjiang. In 1932 it was declared an independent state by Japan and renamed Manchukuo; it was restored to China in 1945.

mancus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(A) A money of account used in various parts of western Europe between the 8th and 12th centuries, and in England equivalent to thirty silver pence, two and a half twelve-pence shillings, or six five-pence shillings. Also: (the name of) a coin of this value. (b) A unit of weight (especially of gold) equivalent to the weight of thirty silver pence.

mandarin 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
The standard literary and official form of Chinese, spoken by over 730 million people.
An official in any of the nine top grades of the former imperial Chinese civil service.
(of clothing) characteristic of a former Chinese mandarin.
A porcelain ornament consisting of a nodding figure in traditional Chinese costume.
Porcelain decorated with Chinese figures dressed as mandarins.
A powerful official or senior bureaucrat, especially one perceived as reactionary and secretive.
A small flattish citrus fruit with a loose yellow-orange skin.
The citrus tree that yields the mandarin.
--Examples--
‘a red-buttoned mandarin cap’
‘a civil service mandarin’

--Word--
mandat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In full "mandat territorial". A unit of currency issued in the form of paper money by the revolutionary government of France from 1796 to 1797. Compare "assignat"historical.
In France: a money order.

--Word--
mandate 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An official order or commission to do something.
A commission by which a party is entrusted to perform a service, especially without payment and with indemnity against loss by that party.
A written authorization enabling someone to carry out transactions on another's bank account.
A commission from the League of Nations to a member state to administer a territory.
The authority to carry out a policy, regarded as given by the electorate to a party or candidate that wins an election.
A period during which a government is in power.
Give (someone) authority to act in a certain way.
Require (something) to be done; make mandatory.
(of territory) be assigned to (another power) under a mandate of the League of Nations.
--Examples--
‘a mandate to seek the release of political prisoners’
‘the end of the British mandate in Palestine’
‘he called an election to seek a mandate for his policies’
‘the last mandate of Trudeau, from 1980 to 1984, was a remarkable chapter in Canadian history’
‘the rightful king was mandated and sanctioned by God’
‘the government began mandating better car safety’
‘mandated territories’

noun
--Meanings--
A Mediterranean plant of the nightshade family, with a forked fleshy root which supposedly resembles the human form and which was formerly used in herbal medicine and magic; it was alleged to shriek when pulled from the ground.
--Examples--
--Word--
mandrake 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Mediterranean plant of the nightshade family, with a forked fleshy root which supposedly resembles the human form and which was formerly used in herbal medicine and magic; it was alleged to shriek when pulled from the ground.
--Examples--
--Word--
mandrel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A shaft or spindle in a lathe, to which work is fixed while being turned.
A cylindrical rod round which metal or other material is forged or shaped.
A miner's pick.

man-eater 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An animal that has a propensity for killing and eating humans.
A dominant woman who has many sexual partners.
--Examples--
‘occasionally, a tiger becomes a man-eater’
‘he obviously imagined that she was some kind of flighty man-eater!’

--Word--
Manet, Édouard 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1832–83), French painter. He adopted a realist approach which greatly influenced the impressionists, using pure colour to give a direct unsentimental effect. Notable works: Déjeuner sur l'herbe (1863), Olympia (1865), and A Bar at the Folies-Bergère (1882).
--Examples--
--Word--
Manetho 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(3rd century BC), Egyptian priest. He wrote a history of Egypt from mythical times to 323, in which he arbitrarily divided the succession of rulers known to him into thirty dynasties, an arrangement which is still followed.
--Examples--
--Word--
Manetti 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A very vigorous dwarf variety of rose used as a stock; a stock formed by this rose.
--Examples--
--Word--
manoeuvre 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A movement or series of moves requiring skill and care.
A carefully planned or cunning scheme or action.
The fact or process of taking carefully planned or cunning action.
A large-scale military exercise of troops, warships, and other forces.
Move skilfully or carefully.
Carefully guide or manipulate (someone or something) in order to achieve an end.
Manipulate a situation to achieve an end.
--Examples--
‘snowboarders performed daring manoeuvres on precipitous slopes’
‘shady financial manoeuvres’
‘the economic policy provided no room for manoeuvre’
‘the Russian vessel was on manoeuvres’
‘the lorry was unable to manoeuvre comfortably in the narrow street’
‘she tried to manoeuvre her trolley round people’
‘they were manoeuvring him into betraying his friend’
‘Rann was manoeuvring to elope with the girl’
--Word--
manoeuvrability 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
manoeuvrable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a vehicle or ship) able to be manoeuvred easily while in motion.
--Examples--
‘a plane which was surprisingly fast and manoeuvrable for its size’

--Word--
Richthofen, Manfred 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Freiherr von (1882–1918), German fighter pilot; known as the Red Baron. He joined a fighter squadron in 1915, flying a distinctive bright red aircraft. He was eventually shot down after destroying eighty enemy planes.
--Examples--

--Word--
mang 
--Type--
noun, verb, verb
--Meanings--
A title of courtesy or respect prefixed to the first name of an older man.
To mix, mingle; to knead. Now Newfoundland and British regional.
Now Scottish and English regional (northern).(a) with object. To bewilder, to lead astray; (b) without object to be bewildered, to go wrong; to rave, go mad.
To beg (someone) for money, etc. Also without object: to beg, cadge.
--Examples--
--Word--

A style of Japanese comic books and graphic novels, typically aimed at adults as well as children.

‘Takahashi is an artist who truly represents the very best from the world of manga’

manganese 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 25, a hard grey metal of the transition series. Manganese is an important component of special steels and magnetic alloys.
The black dioxide of manganese as an industrial raw material or additive, especially in glass-making.
--Examples--

--Word--
mange 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A skin disease of mammals caused by parasitic mites and occasionally communicable to humans. It is characterized by severe itching, hair loss, and the formation of scabs and lesions.
--Examples--
‘foxes that get mange die in three or four months’
‘my dog has the mange’
--Word--

noun

mangemange

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
mangle 
--Type--
verb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Destroy or severely damage by tearing or crushing.
Ruin or spoil (a text, piece of music, etc.)
A machine having two or more rollers turned by a handle, between which wet laundry is squeezed to remove excess moisture.
A large machine for ironing sheets or other fabrics, usually when they are damp, using heated rollers.
Press or squeeze with a mangle.
--Examples--
‘the car was mangled almost beyond recognition’
‘he was mangling Bach on the piano’
‘the hard household labour often involved pounding clothes in a dolly tub and mangling them with a hand wringer’

--Word--
mango 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fleshy, oval, yellowish-red tropical fruit that is eaten ripe or used green for pickles or chutneys.
The evergreen tropical Indian tree that bears the mango.
A tropical American hummingbird that typically has green plumage with purple feathers on the wings, tail, or head.
--Examples--
--Word--
man-god 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Theology. Usually Man-God. Jesus, viewed as a being who is both man and God.
Generally. A being who is both a man (i.e. a human being) and a god; (occasionally) a god having the form of a man (i.e. of a male human being).

--Word--
mangrove 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tree or shrub which grows in tidal, chiefly tropical, coastal swamps, having numerous tangled roots that grow above ground and form dense thickets.
A tidal swamp which is dominated by mangroves.
--Examples--
--Word--
mangrove 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tree or shrub which grows in tidal, chiefly tropical, coastal swamps, having numerous tangled roots that grow above ground and form dense thickets.
A tidal swamp which is dominated by mangroves.

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Word--
Mangue 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a Central American people formerly inhabiting the west coast of Nicaragua, closely related to the Chorotega of the Nicoya peninsula of north-western Costa Rica.
The Oto-Manguean language formerly spoken by the Mangues.
Of or designating the Mangues or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
manhandle 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Move (a heavy object) by hand with great effort.
Handle (someone) roughly by dragging or pushing.
--Examples--
‘men used to manhandle the piano down the stairs’
‘we were spat on, sworn at, and manhandled’

Handle (someone) roughly by dragging or pushing.
--Examples--
‘men used to manhandle the piano down the stairs’
‘we were spat on, sworn at, and manhandled’

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
manhattan 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A cocktail made of vermouth and whisky, sometimes with a dash of bitters.
An island near the mouth of the Hudson River forming part of the city of New York. The site of the original Dutch settlement of New Amsterdam, it is now a borough containing the commercial and cultural centre of New York City.
--Examples--
--Word--
Manhattanite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of the borough of Manhattan, in New York City.
--Examples--
‘Manhattanites don't want their neighbourhood uprooted by expressways’
--Word--
Manhattanize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To make similar in character or appearance to Manhattan or its inhabitants; specifically to fill (a city or skyline) with tall buildings so that it resembles Manhattan Island.
--Examples--

Having a particular person in charge; having a director or leader.

--Word--
manhood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or period of being a man rather than a child.
The qualities traditionally associated with men, such as courage, strength, and sexual potency.
The men of a country or society regarded collectively.
Used euphemistically to refer to a man's penis.
The condition of being human.
--Examples--
‘boys in the process of growing to manhood’
‘we drank to prove our manhood’
‘Germany had lost the best of her young manhood’
‘car worker Dave nearly lost his manhood on the production line’
‘the unity of Godhead and manhood in Christ’

noun

--Word--
Manichaeism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dualistic religious system with Christian, Gnostic, and pagan elements, founded in Persia in the 3rd century by Manes (c.216–c.276) and based on a supposed primeval conflict between light and darkness. It was widespread in the Roman Empire and in Asia, and survived in eastern Turkestan (Xinjiang) until the 13th century.
Religious or philosophical dualism.
--Examples--
--Word--
Manichaean 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--

An adherent of Manichaeism.

--Word--
manifest 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Clear or obvious to the eye or mind.
Show (a quality or feeling) by one's acts or appearance; demonstrate.
Be evidence of; prove.
(of an ailment) become apparent through the appearance of symptoms.
(of a ghost or spirit) appear.
A document listing a ship's contents, cargo, passengers, and crew, for the use of customs officers.
A list of passengers or cargo in an aircraft.
A list of the wagons forming a freight train.
Record in a manifest.
--Examples--
‘her manifest charm and proven ability’
‘Lizzy manifested signs of severe depression’
‘bad industrial relations are often manifested in strikes’
‘a disorder that usually manifests in middle age’
‘one deity manifested in the form of a bird’
‘every passenger is manifested at the point of departure’
--Word--
manifestable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Capable of being manifested.
--Examples--
--Word--
manifestation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An event, action, or object that clearly shows or embodies something abstract or theoretical.
The action or fact of showing something.
A symptom of an ailment.
A version or incarnation of something or someone.
An appearance of a ghost or spirit.
--Examples--
‘the first obvious manifestations of global warming’
‘the manifestation of anxiety over disease’
‘a characteristic manifestation of Lyme disease’
‘the butterfly was one of the many manifestations of the Goddess’
‘some supernatural manifestations are regarded as portents of good or evil’

‘one deity manifested in the form of a bird’
‘every passenger is manifested at the point of departure’

--Word--
manifold 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Many and various.
Having many different forms or elements.
A pipe or chamber branching into several openings.
(in an internal combustion engine) the part conveying air and fuel from the carburettor to the cylinders or that leading from the cylinders to the exhaust pipe.
A collection of points forming a certain kind of set, such as those of a topologically closed surface or an analogue of this in three or more dimensions.
(in Kantian philosophy) the sum of the particulars furnished by sense before they have been unified by the synthesis of the understanding.
--Examples--
‘the implications of this decision were manifold’
‘the appeal of the crusade was manifold’
‘US aircraft attacked the pipeline manifold feeding the Sea Island’
‘the exhaust manifold’

manyfold 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
By many times.
--Examples--
‘the problems would be multiplied manyfold’

--Word--
manipulate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Handle or control (a tool, mechanism, information, etc.) in a skilful manner.
Alter, edit, or move (text or data) on a computer.
Examine or treat (a part of the body) by feeling or moving it with the hand.
Control or influence (a person or situation) cleverly or unscrupulously.
Alter or present (data) so as to mislead.
--Examples--
‘he manipulated the dials of the set’
‘the pupils can manipulate the data or screen image’
‘this system of healing is based on manipulating the ligaments of the spine’
‘the masses were deceived and manipulated by a tiny group’
‘nations may still be able to manipulate their own data’

noun, adjective
--Meanings--

Giving forth sound, especially loud or resonant sound.
Having an imposing sound but little substance.
--Examples--
‘he took soundings about the possibility of moving offices’
‘he went in with a sounding plunge’
‘the orator has been apt to deal in sounding commonplaces’

--Word--
Manitoba 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A province of central Canada, with a coastline on Hudson Bay; population 1,148,401 (2006); capital, Winnipeg. The area was part of Rupert's Land from 1670 until it was transferred to Canada by the Hudson's Bay Company and became a province in 1870.
--Examples--
--Word--
Manitoban 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the Canadian province of Manitoba.
A native or inhabitant of the Canadian province of Manitoba.
--Examples--
‘the tiny Manitoban town’
‘a Manitoban of great prowess’

--Word--
Manitoulin Island 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island in southern Canada, in the province of Ontario, in northern Lake Huron. At 1,068 square miles (2,766 sq km), it is the largest lake island in the world.

(1909–93), US movie director, producer, and screenwriter. He wrote and directed A Letter to Three Wives (1949) and All About Eve (1950).

Mankiller, Wilma 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1945–2010), US Cherokee Nation tribal leader 1985–95 and historian; full name Wilma Pearl Mankiller. A women's rights activist, she wrote Mankiller: A Chief and Her People (1993).

minute 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A period of time equal to sixty seconds or a sixtieth of an hour.
The distance covered in a minute by someone driving or walking.
A very short time.
A point in time.

‘I'll be there in ten minutes' time’
‘the hotel is situated just ten minutes from the centre of the resort’
‘come and sit down for a minute’

‘Delta Lyrae is a double star with a separation of over 10 minutes of arc’

noun
--Meanings--
(in the Bible) the substance miraculously supplied as food to the Israelites in the wilderness (Exod. 16).

(in Christian contexts) spiritual nourishment, especially the Eucharist.

mannan 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a group of polysaccharides that are composed chiefly of mannose residues and occur in many yeasts (as components of the cell wall) and in certain plants (especially as reserve foods).

--Word--
mannerism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A habitual gesture or way of speaking or behaving.
An ordinary gesture or expression that becomes abnormal through exaggeration or repetition.
Excessive use of a distinctive style in art, literature, or music.
A style of 16th-century Italian art preceding the Baroque, characterized by distortions in scale and perspective and the use of bright, often lurid colours. It is particularly associated with the work of Parmigianino, Pontormo, Vasari, and the later Michelangelo.
--Examples--
‘learning the great man's speeches and studying his mannerisms’
‘he seemed deliberately to be stripping his art of mannerism’
--Word--

--Type--
noun

noun
--Meanings--

man 
--Type--
noun, verb, exclamation
--Meanings--
An adult human male.
A male member of a workforce, team, etc.
Ordinary members of the armed forces as distinct from the officers.
A husband or lover.
A male person associated with a particular place, activity, or occupation.
A person with the qualities associated with males, such as bravery, spirit, or toughness.
A male pursued or sought by another, especially in connection with a crime.
A manservant or valet.
A vassal.
A human being of either sex; a person.
Human beings in general; the human race.
An individual; one.
A type of prehistoric human named after the place where the remains were found.
A group or person in a position of authority over others, such as a corporate employer or the police.
White people collectively regarded as the controlling group in society.
A figure or token used in playing a board game.
(of personnel) work at, run, or operate (a place or piece of equipment) or defend (a fortification)
Provide someone to fill (a post)
Fortify the spirits or courage of.
Used, irrespective of the sex of the person addressed, to express surprise, admiration, delight, etc., or for emphasis.
--Examples--
‘a small man with mischievous eyes’
‘the men's semi-finals’
‘over 700 men were made redundant’
‘he had a platoon of forty men to prepare for battle’
‘the two of them lived for a time as man and wife’
‘a Cambridge man’
‘I'm a solid Labour man’
‘she was more of a man than any of them’
‘Inspector Bull was sure they would find their man’
‘get me a cocktail, my man’
‘God cares for all men’
‘places untouched by the ravages of man’
‘a man could buy a lot with eighteen million dotillars’
‘Cro-Magnon man’
‘they've mastered their emotive grunge-pop without haggling with the Man’
‘he urged that black college athletes boycott the Man's Rose Bowl’
‘the helpline is manned by trained staff’
‘the firemen manned the pumps and fought the blaze’
‘the chaplaincy was formerly manned by the cathedral’
‘he manned himself with dauntless air’
‘wow, like cosmic, man’

--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river of West Africa. It rises in north-western Liberia and flows south-west to the Atlantic Ocean, forming for part of its length the boundary between Liberia and Sierra Leone.
--Examples--
--Word--
Manobo 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a group of proto-Malay peoples of Mindanao in the Philippines.
Any of various dialects comprising a subdivision of the Southern Philippine subgroup of the Malayo-Polynesian language family.
Of or relating to the Manobo or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
manoeuvre 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A movement or series of moves requiring skill and care.
A carefully planned or cunning scheme or action.
The fact or process of taking carefully planned or cunning action.
A large-scale military exercise of troops, warships, and other forces.
Move skilfully or carefully.
Carefully guide or manipulate (someone or something) in order to achieve an end.
Manipulate a situation to achieve an end.
--Examples--
‘snowboarders performed daring manoeuvres on precipitous slopes’
‘shady financial manoeuvres’
‘the economic policy provided no room for manoeuvre’
‘the Russian vessel was on manoeuvres’
‘the lorry was unable to manoeuvre comfortably in the narrow street’
‘she tried to manoeuvre her trolley round people’
‘they were manoeuvring him into betraying his friend’
‘Rann was manoeuvring to elope with the girl’

manometer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An instrument for measuring the pressure acting on a column of fluid, consisting of a U-shaped tube of liquid in which a difference in the pressures acting in the two arms of the tube causes the liquid to reach different heights in the two arms.
--Examples--

--Word--
manor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large country house with lands.
(in England and Wales) a unit of land, originally a feudal lordship, consisting of a lord's demesne and lands rented to tenants.
(in North America) an estate or district leased to tenants, especially one granted by royal charter in a British colony or by the Dutch governors of what is now New York State.
The district covered by a police station.
One's own neighbourhood or area of operation.
--Examples--
‘a Tudor manor house in the English countryside’
‘Kelmscott Manor’
‘the right to mine ores within the manor of Little Langdale’
‘they were the undisputed rulers of their manor’
--Word--
man orchis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The man orchid, Orchis anthropophora. Also (British regional): the twayblade, Listera ovata.
--Examples--

--Word--
manred 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Vassals collectively, a body of retainers; the men whom a lord could call upon in time of war; = manrent. Hence generally: a supply of men for military purposes. In the 16th and 17th centuries chiefly Scottish. Now historical.
--Examples--

man-root 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Either of two North American ipomoeas with large tuberous roots, Ipomoea leptophylla, of the dry plains east of the Rocky Mountains, and the wild potato vine, I. pandurata.
Any of several western North American gourds of the genus Marah (family Cucurbitaceae).
The medicinal root of a ginseng (genus Panax), especially one from Asia.

--Word--
man 
--Type--
noun, verb, exclamation
--Meanings--
An adult human male.
A male member of a workforce, team, etc.
Ordinary members of the armed forces as distinct from the officers.
A husband or lover.
A male person associated with a particular place, activity, or occupation.
A person with the qualities associated with males, such as bravery, spirit, or toughness.
A male pursued or sought by another, especially in connection with a crime.
A manservant or valet.
A vassal.
A human being of either sex; a person.
Human beings in general; the human race.
An individual; one.
A type of prehistoric human named after the place where the remains were found.
A group or person in a position of authority over others, such as a corporate employer or the police.
White people collectively regarded as the controlling group in society.
A figure or token used in playing a board game.
(of personnel) work at, run, or operate (a place or piece of equipment) or defend (a fortification)
Provide someone to fill (a post)
Fortify the spirits or courage of.
Used, irrespective of the sex of the person addressed, to express surprise, admiration, delight, etc., or for emphasis.
--Examples--
‘a small man with mischievous eyes’
‘the men's semi-finals’
‘over 700 men were made redundant’
‘he had a platoon of forty men to prepare for battle’
‘the two of them lived for a time as man and wife’
‘a Cambridge man’
‘I'm a solid Labour man’
‘she was more of a man than any of them’
‘Inspector Bull was sure they would find their man’
‘get me a cocktail, my man’
‘God cares for all men’
‘places untouched by the ravages of man’
‘a man could buy a lot with eighteen million dotillars’
‘Cro-Magnon man’
‘they've mastered their emotive grunge-pop without haggling with the Man’
‘he urged that black college athletes boycott the Man's Rose Bowl’
‘the helpline is manned by trained staff’
‘the firemen manned the pumps and fought the blaze’
‘the chaplaincy was formerly manned by the cathedral’
‘he manned himself with dauntless air’
‘wow, like cosmic, man’

Manson, Charles 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1934), US cult leader. He founded a commune based on free love and complete subordination to him. In 1969 its members carried out a series of murders, including that of the US actress Sharon Tate (1943–69), for which he and some followers received the death sentence (later commuted to life imprisonment).

Mantell, Gideon Algernon 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1790–1852), English geologist. Mantell is best known as the first person to recognize dinosaur remains as reptilian. In 1825 he published a description of the teeth of a ‘giant fossil lizard’ which he named Iguanodon.

The part of a floating-point number which represents the significant digits of that number.
--Examples--
--Word--
mantissa 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The part of a logarithm after the decimal point.
The part of a floating-point number which represents the significant digits of that number.
--Examples--
--Word--
mantissa 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The part of a logarithm after the decimal point.

--Examples--
--Word--
mantle 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A loose sleeveless cloak or shawl, worn especially by women.
A covering of a specified sort.
A bird's back, scapulars, and wing coverts, especially when of a distinctive colour.
(in molluscs, cirripedes, and brachiopods) a fold of skin enclosing the viscera and secreting the shell.
An important role or responsibility that passes from one person to another.
A fragile mesh cover fixed round a gas jet, kerosene wick, etc., to give an incandescent light when heated.
The region of the earth's interior between the crust and the core, believed to consist of hot, dense silicate rocks (mainly peridotite)
The part of another planetary body corresponding to the earth's mantle.
Cloak or envelop.
(of blood) suffuse (the face)
(of the face) glow with a blush.
(of a liquid) become covered with a head or froth.
(of a bird of prey on the ground or on a perch) spread the wings and tail so as to cover captured prey.
--Examples--
‘she was wrapped tightly in her mantle’
‘the houses were covered with a thick mantle of snow’
‘many gulls are all white except for dark grey mantle and wings’
‘the second son has now assumed his father's mantle’
‘magmas erupted at mid-ocean ridges are derived from the upper mantle’
‘mantle rock’
‘the presence of hot mantle leads to melting at the base of the lithosphere’
‘the lunar mantle’
‘heavy mists mantled the forested slopes’
‘a warm pink mounted to the girl's cheeks and mantled her brow’
‘her rich face mantling with emotion’
‘the poison mantled in the bowl’
‘the female Goshawk is feeding while mantling with spread wings over her prey’

--Word--
mantua 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A woman's loose gown of a kind fashionable during the 17th and 18th centuries.

--Examples--
--Word--
Manu 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The archetypal first man of Hindu mythology, survivor of the great flood and father of the human race. He is also the legendary author of one of the most famous codes of Hindu religious law, the Manusmriti (Laws of Manu), composed in Sanskrit and dating in its present form from the 1st century BC.

Using or working with the hands.
A book giving instructions or information.

A vehicle with manual transmission.
An organ keyboard played with the hands not the feet.

‘manual dexterity’
‘a manual typewriter’
‘a manual labourer’
‘a computer manual’

manualist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who uses his or her hands for some task; one who tends to engage in physical rather than mental exertion; especially a manual labourer, a person whose work demands manual skill or dexterity.

A writer or compiler of manuals or handbooks.

Noriega, Manuel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1940–2017), Panamanian statesman and general, head of state 1983–9; full name Manuel Antonio Morena Noriega. Charged with drug trafficking by a US grand jury in 1988, he eventually surrendered to US troops sent into Panama and was brought to trial and convicted in 1992.

manufacture 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make (something) on a large scale using machinery.
(of a living thing) produce (a substance) naturally.
Make or produce (something abstract) in a merely mechanical way.
Invent (evidence or a story)
The making of articles on a large scale using machinery.
A specified branch of industry.
Manufactured articles.
--Examples--
‘firms who manufacture ball bearings’
‘most plants use the sun's light to manufacture their food through photosynthesis’
‘Julia manufactured a smile’
‘claims that the entire row had been manufactured by the press’
‘the manufacture of armoured vehicles’
‘the porcelain manufacture for which France became justly renowned’
‘exports and imports of manufactures’

noun

Manzoni, Alessandro 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1785–1873), Italian novelist, playwright, and poet. He is remembered chiefly as the author of the novel I Promessi Sposi (1825–42), a historical reconstruction of 17th-century Lombardy.

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The communist doctrines of Mao Zedong as formerly practised in China, having as a central idea permanent revolution and stressing the importance of the peasantry, small-scale industry, and agricultural collectivization.
--Examples--
--Word--
Maoist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A follower of the communist doctrines of Mao Zedong.
Relating to or denoting the communist doctrines of Mao Zedong.
--Examples--
‘the army thought he was a Maoist’
‘Maoist policies’

--Word--
map 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A diagrammatic representation of an area of land or sea showing physical features, cities, roads, etc.
A two-dimensional representation of the positions of stars or other astronomical objects.
A diagram or collection of data showing the spatial arrangement or distribution of something over an area.
A representation of the sequence of genes on a chromosome or of bases in a DNA or RNA molecule.
A person's face.
Represent (an area) on a map; make a map of.
Record in detail the spatial distribution of (something)
Associate (a group of elements or qualities) with an equivalent group, according to a particular formula or model.
Associate each element of (a set) with an element of another set.
Be associated with or linked to.
--Examples--
‘a street map’
‘she went inside to check a star map’
‘an electron density map’
‘a physical and genetic map of the entire human genome’
‘you ought to know my map by now’
‘inaccessible parts will be mapped from the air’
‘the project to map the human genome’
‘the transformational rules map deep structures into surface structures’
‘the direct sum of two rings A and B may be mapped homomorphically on the summand’
‘if more than one suffix can be mapped on to the end of a word then the longest is chosen for removal’
--Word--
mapau 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several New Zealand shrubs and small trees, chiefly with undulate, evergreen leaves; especially (a) Myrsine australis (family Myrsinaceae), with reddish twigs and bearing clusters of small white flowers and black berries; (b) (more fully "black mapau") Pittosporum tenuifolium (family Pittosporaceae), with black bark and light green leaves.
--Examples--

Maputo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital and chief port of Mozambique, on the Indian Ocean in the south of the country; population 1,099,102 (2007). Founded as a Portuguese fortress in the late 18th century, it became the capital of Mozambique in 1907.

Marat, Jean Paul 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1743–93), French revolutionary and journalist. A virulent critic of the moderate Girondists, he was instrumental (with Danton and Robespierre) in their fall from power in 1793.
--Examples--
--Word--
Maratha 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of the princely and military castes of the former Hindu kingdom of Maharashtra in central India. The Marathas rebelled against the Moguls and in 1674 established their own kingdom. They came to dominate southern and central India but were later subdued by the British.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
marble 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A hard crystalline metamorphic form of limestone, typically white with coloured mottlings or streaks, which may be polished and is used in sculpture and architecture.
Used figuratively to refer to something with the smoothness, hardness, or colour of marble.
A marble sculpture.
A small ball of coloured glass or similar material used as a toy.
A game in which marbles are rolled along the ground with the aim of hitting those of one's opponent.
One's mental faculties.
Stain or streak (something) so that it looks like marble.
--Examples--
‘the spotless white marble of the Taj Mahal’
‘a marble floor’
‘her shoulders were as white as marble’
‘a pair of dramatic marbles showing dogs attacking a buck’
‘a couple of girls were playing marbles’
‘I thought she'd lost her marbles, asking a question like that’
‘the stone walls were marbled with moss and lichen’
--Word--
arched 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Constructed with or in the form of an arch or arches.
--Examples--
‘high arched windows’
--Word--
breasted 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
‘a bare-breasted woman’
‘a crimson-breasted bird’
--Word--
calm 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb, abbreviation
--Meanings--
Not showing or feeling nervousness, anger, or other strong emotions.
(of a place) peaceful after violent activity.
(of the weather) pleasantly free from wind.
(of the sea) not disturbed by large waves.
The absence of strong emotions; calm feelings.
The absence of violent activity in a place.
The absence of wind.
Still air represented by force 0 on the Beaufort scale (less than 1 knot or 1 km/h).
An area of the sea without wind.
Make (someone) tranquil and quiet; soothe.
(of a person) become tranquil and quiet.
(in Australia) the Department of Conservation and Land Management.
--Examples--
‘she had to keep calm at all costs’
‘his voice was calm’
‘the city was reported to be calm, but army patrols remained’
‘the night was clear and calm’
‘a dead calm sea’
‘his usual calm deserted him’
‘the elections proceeded in an atmosphere of relative calm’
‘an edgy calm reigned in the capital’
‘in the centre of the storm calm prevailed’
‘flat calms’
‘I took him inside and tried to calm him down’
‘gradually I calmed down and lost my anxiety’
‘the reserve contains some 500 species of plants and is managed by CALM’
--Word--
marble 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A hard crystalline metamorphic form of limestone, typically white with coloured mottlings or streaks, which may be polished and is used in sculpture and architecture.
Used figuratively to refer to something with the smoothness, hardness, or colour of marble.
A marble sculpture.
A small ball of coloured glass or similar material used as a toy.
A game in which marbles are rolled along the ground with the aim of hitting those of one's opponent.
One's mental faculties.
Stain or streak (something) so that it looks like marble.
--Examples--
‘the spotless white marble of the Taj Mahal’
‘a marble floor’
‘her shoulders were as white as marble’
‘a pair of dramatic marbles showing dogs attacking a buck’
‘a couple of girls were playing marbles’
‘I thought she'd lost her marbles, asking a question like that’
‘the stone walls were marbled with moss and lichen’

--Word--
marbled 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(especially of paper) having a streaked and patterned appearance like that of variegated marble.
(of meat) having the lean part streaked with thin layers of fat.
--Examples--
‘attractively marbled cloth or paper’
--Word--
marble 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A hard crystalline metamorphic form of limestone, typically white with coloured mottlings or streaks, which may be polished and is used in sculpture and architecture.
Used figuratively to refer to something with the smoothness, hardness, or colour of marble.
A marble sculpture.
A small ball of coloured glass or similar material used as a toy.
A game in which marbles are rolled along the ground with the aim of hitting those of one's opponent.
One's mental faculties.
Stain or streak (something) so that it looks like marble.
--Examples--
‘the spotless white marble of the Taj Mahal’
‘a marble floor’
‘her shoulders were as white as marble’
‘a pair of dramatic marbles showing dogs attacking a buck’
‘a couple of girls were playing marbles’
‘I thought she'd lost her marbles, asking a question like that’
‘the stone walls were marbled with moss and lichen’
--Word--
grinding 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a difficult situation) oppressive and seemingly without end.
(of a sound or movement) harsh and grating.
--Examples--
‘grinding poverty’
‘the grinding roar of the lorries’
--Word--

--Word--
Marblehead 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A coastal town in northeastern Massachusetts, a noted yachting and fishing port; population 19,951 (est. 2008).

--Word--
marbleization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state of being or process of becoming veined like marble.

--Word--
pale 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Light in colour or shade; containing little colour or pigment.
(of a person or their complexion) having less colour than usual, typically as a result of shock, fear, or ill health.
(of a light) not strong or bright.
Inferior or unimpressive.
Become pale in one's face from shock or fear.
Seem or become less important.
--Examples--
‘choose pale floral patterns for walls’
‘she looked pale and drawn’
‘a pale dawn’
‘the new cheese is a pale imitation of continental cheeses’
‘I paled at the thought of what she might say’
‘all else pales by comparison’
--Word--
paved 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a piece of ground) covered with flat stones or bricks; laid with paving.
--Examples--
‘a paved courtyard’

--Word--
marblewood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several kinds of decorative timber with mottled or banded grain; (Australian) the timber of the tall rainforest tree Acacia bakeri (family Mimosaceae (Leguminosae)) of eastern Australia.
Such timber from any of several trees of the genus Diospyros (family Ebenaceae); especially (more fully "Andaman marblewood") the timber of the tree D. marmorata of the Andaman Islands.
--Examples--
--Word--
marbly 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
marbling 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Colouring or marking that resembles marble, especially as a decorative finish for interior walls.
Streaks of fat in lean meat.
--Examples--
‘finishes like ragging, marbling, and stippling’
‘French Shell, Antique, and a thousand other marblings’
‘a degree of marbling in the meat’
--Word--

--Word--
Marburg 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in the state of Hesse in west central Germany; population 79,400 (est. 2006). It was the scene in 1529 of a debate between German and Swiss theologians, notably Martin Luther and Ulrich Zwingli, on the doctrine of consubstantiation.
--Examples--
--Word--
Hutchinson, Anne Marbury 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1591–1643), American religious leader; born in England. She was banished from Massachusetts Bay Colony in 1637 for her liberal views on grace and salvation. First moving to Rhode Island and then settling in New York in 1642, she and most of her family were killed by Indians.
--Examples--
--Word--
marc 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The refuse of grapes or other fruit that have been pressed for winemaking.
An alcoholic spirit distilled from marc.
--Examples--
‘the spent marc can be seen in purple-black piles by the roadside’
‘each press takes a marc of 4,000 kilograms’
‘working men sat over bowls of milky coffee and glasses of marc’

Marcan 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to St Mark or the Gospel ascribed to him.
--Examples--
--Word--
marcasite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A semi-precious stone consisting of iron pyrites.
A bronze-yellow mineral consisting of iron disulphide but differing from pyrite in typically forming aggregates of tabular crystals.
A piece of polished steel or a similar metal cut as a gem.

proper noun

--Word--
Marcellian 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a 4th-cent. Christian group who believed that the Son and the Spirit only emerged from the Divine Unity for the purposes of creation and redemption, and will return to it after the redemptive work is achieved.
--Examples--

--Word--
Malpighi, Marcello 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1628–94), Italian microscopist. He discovered the alveoli and capillaries in the lungs and the fibres and red cells of clotted blood, and demonstrated the pathway of blood from arteries to veins.
--Examples--
--Word--
Marcellus shale 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A highly bituminous black shale of Devonian age found in the north-eastern United States.

--Word--
march 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Walk in a military manner with a regular measured tread.
Walk quickly and with determination.
Force (someone) to walk somewhere quickly.
Walk along public roads in an organized procession as a form of protest.
(of something abstract) proceed or advance inexorably.
An act or instance of marching.
A piece of music composed to accompany marching or with a rhythm suggestive of marching.
A procession organized as a protest.
The steady and inevitable development or progress of something.
--Examples--
‘thousands marched behind the coffin’
‘without a word she marched from the room’
‘she gripped Rachel's arm and marched her through the door’
‘unemployed workers marched from Jarrow to London’
‘they planned to march on Baton Rouge’
‘time marches on’
‘the relieving force was more than a day's march away’
‘he began to hum a funeral march’
‘a protest march’
‘the march of history’
--Word--
march 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Walk in a military manner with a regular measured tread.

Walk along public roads in an organized procession as a form of protest.

A piece of music composed to accompany marching or with a rhythm suggestive of marching.
A procession organized as a protest.
The steady and inevitable development or progress of something.

‘unemployed workers marched from Jarrow to London’
‘they planned to march on Baton Rouge’

‘he began to hum a funeral march’
‘a protest march’
‘the march of history’

--Word--
Marchantia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(In form Marchantia) a genus of liverworts; (also marchantia) a liverwort of this genus, especially M. polymorpha, one of the most representative liverworts and the one to which the name was first applied.
--Examples--
--Word--
Marche 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A region of east central Italy, between the Apennines and the Adriatic Sea; capital, Ancona. Italian name Le Marche /ˈmarke/.
