--Word--
alla marcia 
--Type--
adverb, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Especially as a musical direction: in the style of a march.
A movement, passage, or composition marked to be played alla marcia.
That is marked to be played alla marcia; of the nature of an alla marcia.
--Examples--
--Word--
Marciano, Rocky 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1923–69), American boxer; born Rocco Francis Marchegiano. He became world heavyweight champion in 1952 and successfully defended his title six times until he retired, undefeated, in 1956.
--Examples--

--Word--
Marcionism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The doctrines of the Marcionites.
--Examples--
--Word--
Marcionist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= Marcionite.
--Examples--
--Word--
Marcionite 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An adherent of the rigorously ascetic sect founded in Rome in the 2nd cent. a.d. by Marcion of Sinope, who rejected the authority of the Old and New Testaments (with the exception of ten of the Epistles of St Paul and an edited recension of the Gospel of St Luke) on the grounds that the god to which they referred was a God of Law rather than the God of Love.
Of or relating to the Marcionites.
--Examples--
--Word--
Marcionitism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The doctrines of the Marcionites.
--Examples--
--Word--
Coriolanus, Gaius Marcius 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(5th century BC), Roman general, who got his name from the capture of the Volscian town of Corioli; also called Gnaeus Marcius Coriolanus. According to legend, after his banishment from Rome he led a Volscian army against the city and was only turned back by the pleas of his mother and wife.
--Examples--
--Word--
Polo, Marco

proper noun

Marcobrunn 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A German white wine of the Rheingau region.

--Word--
Marcomanni 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Treated as plural. An ancient Germanic people of the Suevian group who inhabited parts of central Europe to the north of the Danube.
--Examples--
--Word--
Marcomannic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
Marconi, Guglielmo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1874–1937), Italian electrical engineer, the founder of radio. In 1912 Marconi produced a continuously oscillating wave, essential for the transmission of sound. He went on to develop short-wave transmission over long distances. Nobel Prize for Physics (1909).
--Examples--
--Word--
Marconigram 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A radiotelegram.
--Examples--
--Word--
Marconi, Guglielmo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1874–1937), Italian electrical engineer, the founder of radio. In 1912 Marconi produced a continuously oscillating wave, essential for the transmission of sound. He went on to develop short-wave transmission over long distances. Nobel Prize for Physics (1909).

marc 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The refuse of grapes or other fruit that have been pressed for winemaking.
An alcoholic spirit distilled from marc.
--Examples--

‘each press takes a marc of 4,000 kilograms’
‘working men sat over bowls of milky coffee and glasses of marc’

San Marcos 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in southwestern California, north of San Diego; population 79,114 (est. 2008).
A city in south central Texas, south of Austin; population 52,927 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
Marcosian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An adherent of a Gnostic sect founded by Marcus, a follower of Valentinus, in the Rhône valley in the 2nd cent. a.d.
Of, resembling, or characteristic of Ferdinand Marcos or his (authoritarian) rule.
--Examples--
--Word--
marcot 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A branch of a plant used for marcottage; a plant propagated by marcottage.
To perform marcottage.
--Examples--
--Word--
marcottage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A method of propagation of woody plants in which a wound made in the bark of a shoot is covered with a layer of rooting medium and wrapped to retain moisture, encouraging new roots to form before the shoot is severed from the parent plant.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
Aurelius, Marcus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(121–80), Roman emperor 161–80; full name Caesar Marcus Aurelius Antoninus Augustus. He was occupied for much of his reign with wars against invading Germanic tribes. His Meditations, a collection of aphorisms and reflections, are evidence of his philosophical nature.
--Examples--
--Word--
Marcuse, Herbert 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1898–1979), German-born American philosopher. A member of the Frankfurt School, in Soviet Marxism (1958) he argued that revolutionary change can come only from alienated elites such as students.
--Examples--
--Word--

A carnival or fair held at any time.

Marduk 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The chief god of ancient Babylon, who became lord of the gods of heaven and earth after conquering Tiamat, the monster of primeval chaos.

--Word--
mare 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
The female of a horse or other equine animal.
A woman.
A very unpleasant or frustrating experience.
(especially in sport) a very poor performance.
A large, level basalt plain on the surface of the moon, appearing dark by contrast with highland areas.
--Examples--
‘that crazy mare put three bullets in him’
‘this week is going to be a bit of a mare but at least the end is in sight’
‘Eboue had an absolute mare down the right hand side’
‘the maria are largely confined to the near side of the moon’
‘Mare Imbrium’

--Type--
noun, noun

A woman with a dark complexion, especially (in South and Central America) a woman of mixed descent or of African origin.
Especially among speakers of the Sotho languages: a title of or respectful form of address used to a chief or (more generally) any person in authority. Hence: a chief, a master.

--Examples--
--Word--
Thatcher, Margaret 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Baroness Thatcher of Kesteven (1925–2013), British Conservative stateswoman, prime minister 1979–90; full name Margaret Hilda Thatcher. She was the country's first female prime minister, and became the longest-serving British prime minister of the 20th century. Her period in office was marked by an emphasis on monetarist policies, privatization of nationalized industries, and trade union legislation. She became known for her determination and her emphasis on individual responsibility and enterprise.
--Examples--
--Word--

margarita 
--Type--
noun
UnKnownKind, proper noun
--Meanings--
A cocktail made with tequila and citrus fruit juice.
An island in the Caribbean Sea, off the coast of Venezuela. Visited by Columbus in 1498, it was used as a base by Simón Bolívar in 1816 in the struggle for independence from Spanish rule.

‘we split a Caesar salad and a margarita pizza’
--Word--
margarite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mineralogy. A calcium aluminium silicate of the mica group, CaAl₄Si₂O₁₀(OH)₂, usually occurring as minute scales with a pearly lustre. Formerly also called pearl mica.
Geology A line of globulites resembling a string of pearls, commonly occurring in glassy igneous rocks.
--Examples--
--Word--
margarodid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Any scale insect of the family Margarodidae, some of which form pearl-like subterranean cysts on the roots of plants and can be a pest of grapevines.
Of, relating to, or designating scale insects of the family Margarodidae.

margarodite

--Meanings--

--Word--
Kempe, Margery 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1373–c.1440), English mystic. From about 1432 to 1436 she dictated one of the first autobiographies in English, The Book of Margery Kempe. It gives an account of her series of pilgrimages, as well as details of her mystic self-transcendent visions.

--Word--
margin 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The edge or border of something.
The blank border on each side of the print on a page.
A line ruled on paper to mark off a margin.
An amount by which something is won.
An amount of something included so as to be sure of success or safety.
The furthest limit of possibility, success, etc.
A profit margin.
A sum deposited with a broker to cover the risk of loss on a transaction or account.
An increment to a basic wage, paid for extra skill or responsibility.
Provide with an edge or border.
Annotate or summarize (a text) in the margins.
Deposit an amount of money with a broker as security for (an account or transaction)
--Examples--
‘the eastern margin of the Indian Ocean’
‘the notations in the margin’
‘they won by a convincing 17-point margin’
‘there was no margin for error’
‘the lighting is brighter than before but is still at the margins of acceptability’
‘launching these new products helped increase margins and market share’
‘the plant's leaves are margined with yellow’
‘these he deals forth as the notable Matters, margined for better Notice’
‘new contracts are margined with the winnings of previously held contracts’
--Word--
margined 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having an edge or border.
Denoting or relating to an account or transaction for which an amount of money is deposited with a broker as security.
--Examples--
‘margined pages’
‘cream-margined leaves’
‘margined holdings hit record levels in July’
‘the risks involved in margined trading’
--Word--
marginal 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or at the edge or margin.
Relating to water adjacent to the land's edge or coast.
Minor and not important; not central.
(of costs or benefits) relating to or resulting from small or unit changes.
(of taxation) relating to increases in income.
(of a decision or distinction) very narrow; borderline.
(of a parliamentary or council seat) held by a small majority and therefore at risk in an election.
Close to the limit of profitability, especially through difficulty of exploitation.
A seat in a parliament or on a council that is held by a small majority and is at risk in an election.
A plant that grows in water close to the edge of land.
--Examples--
‘marginal notes’
‘water lilies and marginal aquatics’
‘it seems likely to make only a marginal difference’
‘the cost is negligible, less than marginal’
‘the issue is to estimate the marginal benefit from the increased frequency of screening examinations against the marginal increased cost’
‘the marginal tax rates on these incomes rise to as much as 80 per cent in some republics’
‘a marginal offside decision’
‘marginal farmland’
‘she is defending a key marginal for the Tories’
‘remove any dead foliage on water lilies and marginals’
--Word--
marginalia 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
Notes written in the margins of a text.
--Examples--
‘the book was covered with marginalia’
‘you will be relegated to the marginalia of political life’
--Word--
marginality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
marginalize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Treat (a person, group, or concept) as insignificant or peripheral.
--Examples--
‘by removing religion from the public space, we marginalize it’
--Word--
marginally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
To only a limited extent; slightly.
--Examples--
‘inflation is predicted to drop marginally’
‘he's marginally worse than he was’

--Word--
Marginella 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of marine gastropod molluscs; (also marginella) a mollusc of this genus or of the family Marginellidae; the shell of any of these molluscs, usually glossy with a small or flattened spire and a thickened outer lip.
--Examples--
--Word--
marginelliform 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having the form of a gastropod of the genus Marginella; denoting or belonging to a broader category including the family Marginellidae.
--Examples--

marginicidal

adjective
--Meanings--
Designating dehiscence in which the septa break away from the united margins of the carpels.

marginiform 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling or forming a margin or rim.

--Word--
Fonteyn, Dame Margot 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1919–91), English ballet dancer; born Margaret Hookham. In 1962 she began a celebrated partnership with Rudolf Nureyev, dancing with him in Giselle and Romeo and Juliet. In 1979 she was named prima ballerina assoluta, a title given only three times in the history of ballet.

Marcheshvan 
--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
Mari 
--Type--
proper noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An ancient city on the west bank of the River Euphrates, in Syria. Its period of greatest importance was from the late 19th to the mid 18th centuries BC; the vast palace of the last king, Zimri-Lim, has yielded an archive of 25,000 cuneiform tablets, which are the principal source for the history of northern Syria and Mesopotamia at that time.
A member of a people of the central Volga valley in Russia.
The Uralic language of the Mari, which has two dialects with over 700,000 speakers in all.
Relating to the Mari or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mary 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
Mother of Jesus; known as the (Blessed) Virgin Mary, or St Mary, or Our Lady. According to the Gospels she was a virgin betrothed to Joseph and conceived Jesus by the power of the Holy Spirit. She has been venerated by Catholic and Orthodox Churches from the earliest Christian times. Feast days, 1 January (Roman Catholic Church), 25 March (Annunciation), 15 August (Assumption), 8 September (Nativity), 8 December (Immaculate Conception).
The name of two queens of England.
Mary I (1516–58), daughter of Henry VIII and Catherine of Aragon, reigned 1553–8; known as Mary Tudor or Bloody Mary. In an attempt to reverse the country's turn towards Protestantism she instigated the series of religious persecutions by which she earned her nickname.
Mary II (1662–94), daughter of James II, reigned 1689–94. Having been invited to replace her Catholic father on the throne after his deposition in 1689, she insisted that her husband, William of Orange, be crowned along with her.
An Aboriginal woman.
--Examples--
--Word--
maria 
--Type--
UnKnownKind

--Word--
mariachi 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Denoting a type of traditional Mexican folk music, performed by a small group of strolling musicians.
A musician in a group performing mariachi music.
--Examples--
‘a town where roving mariachis still appear on Saturday nights’
‘a mariachi band’

marialite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Haüynite. Now historical.
A tetragonal aluminosilicate mineral that is the sodium- and chloride-rich endmember of the scapolite series and occurs as transparent or translucent crystals of various colours.

Mariana Trench 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ocean trench to the south-east of the Mariana Islands in the western Pacific, with the greatest known ocean depth (11,034 m, 36,201 ft at the Challenger Deep).
--Examples--

--Word--
Mary 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
Mother of Jesus; known as the (Blessed) Virgin Mary, or St Mary, or Our Lady. According to the Gospels she was a virgin betrothed to Joseph and conceived Jesus by the power of the Holy Spirit. She has been venerated by Catholic and Orthodox Churches from the earliest Christian times. Feast days, 1 January (Roman Catholic Church), 25 March (Annunciation), 15 August (Assumption), 8 September (Nativity), 8 December (Immaculate Conception).
The name of two queens of England.
Mary I (1516–58), daughter of Henry VIII and Catherine of Aragon, reigned 1553–8; known as Mary Tudor or Bloody Mary. In an attempt to reverse the country's turn towards Protestantism she instigated the series of religious persecutions by which she earned her nickname.
Mary II (1662–94), daughter of James II, reigned 1689–94. Having been invited to replace her Catholic father on the throne after his deposition in 1689, she insisted that her husband, William of Orange, be crowned along with her.
An Aboriginal woman.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--
A city in northwestern Georgia, a northwestern suburb of Atlanta; population 67,562 (est. 2008).

--Meanings--

Used in names of plants with yellow flowers other than true marigolds, e.g. corn marigold, marsh marigold.

--Word--
Maryland 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state of the eastern US, on the coast of the Atlantic Ocean, surrounding Chesapeake Bay; population 5,633,597 (est. 2008); capital, Annapolis. Colonized by England in the 17th century, it was one of the original thirteen states of the Union and ratified the US Constitution in 1788.

--Word--
Mary 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
Mother of Jesus; known as the (Blessed) Virgin Mary, or St Mary, or Our Lady. According to the Gospels she was a virgin betrothed to Joseph and conceived Jesus by the power of the Holy Spirit. She has been venerated by Catholic and Orthodox Churches from the earliest Christian times. Feast days, 1 January (Roman Catholic Church), 25 March (Annunciation), 15 August (Assumption), 8 September (Nativity), 8 December (Immaculate Conception).
The name of two queens of England.
Mary I (1516–58), daughter of Henry VIII and Catherine of Aragon, reigned 1553–8; known as Mary Tudor or Bloody Mary. In an attempt to reverse the country's turn towards Protestantism she instigated the series of religious persecutions by which she earned her nickname.
Mary II (1662–94), daughter of James II, reigned 1689–94. Having been invited to replace her Catholic father on the throne after his deposition in 1689, she insisted that her husband, William of Orange, be crowned along with her.
An Aboriginal woman.
--Examples--
--Word--
Monroe, Marilyn 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1926–62), American actress; born Norma Jeane Mortenson; later Norma Jean Baker. Her film roles, largely in comedies, made her the definitive Hollywood sex symbol. She is thought to have died of an overdose of sleeping pills. Notable films: Gentlemen Prefer Blondes (1953), Some Like it Hot (1959), and The Misfits (1961).
--Examples--
--Word--
Marymass 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In Irvine, Ayrshire, Scotland: a festival held on the third Saturday after the first Monday in August, to commemorate a visit by Mary, Queen of Scots (1542–87), to the town in 1563.

--Word--
finish 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Bring (a task or activity) to an end; complete.
Consume or get through the final amount or portion of (something, especially food or drink)
(of a period or activity) come to an end.
End a period of time or course of action by doing something or being in a particular position.
Reach the end of a race or other competition.
(in soccer) score a goal or goals.
Kill, destroy, or comprehensively defeat.
Reduce to utter exhaustion or helplessness.
Complete the manufacture or decoration of (an article) by giving it an attractive surface appearance.
Complete the fattening of (livestock) before slaughter.
Prepare (a girl) for entry into fashionable society.
An end or final part or stage of something.
A point or place at which a race or competition ends.
The manner in which the manufacture of an article is completed in detail.
The surface appearance of a manufactured material or object, or the material used to produce this.
The final taste impression of a wine or beer.
--Examples--
‘they were straining to finish the job’
‘we finished eating our meal’
‘Seagram finished off a margarita as he waited’
‘the war has finished but nothing has changed’
‘he finished up as one of Britain's greatest architects’
‘the first four horses to finish’
‘Falkirk finished fifth in the Scottish Premier League’
‘Dean finished well to put his team ahead’
‘the English men-at-arms finished them off in hand-to-hand combat’
‘the interior was finished with American oak’
‘over 100,000 head of cattle are finished every year’
‘a reduction in prices for finished cattle’
‘where were you finished?’
‘a bowl of raspberries was the perfect finish to the meal’
‘I really enjoyed the film from start to finish’
‘he surged into a winning lead 200 metres from the finish’
‘the car's popularity is helped by its high-quality finish and strong diesel engine’
‘lightweight nylon with a shiny finish’
‘the wine has a lemony tang on the finish’

Marinetti, Filippo Tommaso 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1876–1944), Italian poet and playwright. He launched the futurist movement with a manifesto (1909) which exalted technology, glorified war, and demanded revolution in the arts.
--Examples--

--Word--
San Marino 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A republic forming a small enclave in Italy, near Rimini; population 32,000 (estimated 2015); official language, Italian; capital, the town of San Marino. It is perhaps Europe's oldest state, claiming to have been independent almost continuously since its foundation in the 4th century.

(1920–99), US writer. He wrote the novel The Godfather in 1969 and the subsequent screenplay for it in 1972. His other works included Fools Die (1978) and The Sicilian (1984).

--Examples--
--Word--
Mari 
--Type--
proper noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An ancient city on the west bank of the River Euphrates, in Syria. Its period of greatest importance was from the late 19th to the mid 18th centuries BC; the vast palace of the last king, Zimri-Lim, has yielded an archive of 25,000 cuneiform tablets, which are the principal source for the history of northern Syria and Mesopotamia at that time.
A member of a people of the central Volga valley in Russia.
The Uralic language of the Mari, which has two dialects with over 700,000 speakers in all.
Relating to the Mari or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mary 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
Mother of Jesus; known as the (Blessed) Virgin Mary, or St Mary, or Our Lady. According to the Gospels she was a virgin betrothed to Joseph and conceived Jesus by the power of the Holy Spirit. She has been venerated by Catholic and Orthodox Churches from the earliest Christian times. Feast days, 1 January (Roman Catholic Church), 25 March (Annunciation), 15 August (Assumption), 8 September (Nativity), 8 December (Immaculate Conception).
The name of two queens of England.
Mary I (1516–58), daughter of Henry VIII and Catherine of Aragon, reigned 1553–8; known as Mary Tudor or Bloody Mary. In an attempt to reverse the country's turn towards Protestantism she instigated the series of religious persecutions by which she earned her nickname.
Mary II (1662–94), daughter of James II, reigned 1689–94. Having been invited to replace her Catholic father on the throne after his deposition in 1689, she insisted that her husband, William of Orange, be crowned along with her.
An Aboriginal woman.

--Word--
Maritsa 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river of southern Europe, which rises in the Rila Mountains of south-western Bulgaria and flows 480 km (300 miles) south to the Aegean Sea. It forms the border between Bulgaria and Greece and that between Greece and Turkey. Its ancient name is the Hebros or Hebrus.

Petipa, Marius 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1818–1910), French ballet dancer and choreographer, resident in Russia from 1847; full name Marius Ivanovich Petipa. Petipa choreographed more than fifty ballets, working with Tchaikovsky on Sleeping Beauty (1890) and The Nutcracker (1892).

Rawlings, Marjorie Kinnan 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1896–1953), US writer. Her award-winning The Yearling (1938), for young adults, was made into a movie in 1946. Her other works include the memoir Cross Creek (1942) and the novel The Sojourner (1953).
--Examples--
--Word--
mark 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small area on a surface having a different colour from its surroundings, typically one caused by damage or dirt.
A spot, area, or feature on a person's or animal's body by which they may be identified or recognized.
A line, figure, or symbol made as an indication or record of something.
A sign or indication of a quality or feeling.
A written symbol made on a document in place of a signature by someone who cannot write.
A competitor's starting point in a race.
A piece of material or a knot used to indicate a depth on a sounding line.
One of two possible states of a signal in certain systems.
A level or stage that is considered significant.
A particular temperature level in a gas oven.
A point awarded for a correct answer or for proficiency in an examination or competition.
A figure or letter representing the total number of marks awarded in an examination or competition and signifying a person's score.
An official assessment of a horse's form, expressed as a figure between 0 and 140 and used as the basis for calculating the weight the horse has to carry in a race.
(especially in athletics) a time or distance achieved by a competitor, especially one which represents a record or personal best.
(followed by a numeral) a particular model or type of a vehicle or machine.
A target.
A person who is easily deceived or taken advantage of.
The act of cleanly catching the ball direct from a kick, knock-on, or forward throw by an opponent, on or behind one's own 22-metre line, and exclaiming ‘Mark’, after which a free kick can be taken by the catcher.
An act of catching a ball that has been kicked at least fifteen metres before it reaches the ground, or the spot from which the subsequent kick is taken.
Make a visible impression or stain on.
Become stained.
Write a word or symbol on (an object) in order to give information.
Write or draw (a word, symbol, line, etc.) on an object.
Put a line by or through something written or printed to indicate that it has passed or been dealt with.
Indicate the position of.
Separate or delineate (a particular section or area)
(of a particular quality or feature) distinguish (someone or something) from other people or things.
Select or destine someone for (a particular role or fate)
Judge someone to be (a particular type of person)
Acknowledge or celebrate (an important event) with a particular action.
Be an indication of (a significant event or stage)
Characterize as having a particular quality or feature.
(of a clock or watch) show (a certain time)
(of a teacher or examiner) assess the standard of (written work) by assigning points for proficiency or correct answers.
Reduce the number of marks awarded to a person or their work.
Notice or pay careful attention to.
(of a player in a team game) stay close to (an opponent) in order to prevent them getting or passing the ball.
Catch (the ball) from a kick of at least ten metres.
--Examples--
‘the blow left a red mark down one side of her face’
‘he was five feet nine, with no distinguishing marks’
‘the first syllable has a stress mark’
‘the flag was at half mast as a mark of respect’
‘he signed his mark in the visitor's book’
‘unemployment had passed the two million mark’
‘preheat the oven to Gas Mark 5’
‘many candidates lose marks because they don't read the questions carefully’
‘full marks to them for highlighting the threat to the rainforest’
‘the highest mark was 98 per cent’
‘horses tend to run off a higher mark over fences than they would over hurdles’
‘he blasted away from the field during the second lap to knock a second off the existing mark’
‘a Mark 10 Jaguar’
‘few bullets could have missed their mark’
‘they figure I'm an easy mark’
‘he fingered the photograph gently, careful not to mark it’
‘they're made from a woven surface which doesn't mark or tear’
‘she marked all her possessions with her name’
‘she marked the date down on a card’
‘he marked off their names in a ledger’
‘the top of the pass marks the border between Alaska and the Yukon’
‘you need to mark out the part of the garden where the sun lingers longest’
‘his sword marked him out as an officer’
‘the solicitor general marked him out for government office’
‘she had marked him down as a dangerous liberal’
‘to mark its fiftieth birthday the charity held a fashion show’
‘a series of incidents which marked a new phase in the terrorist campaign’
‘the reaction to these developments has been marked by a note of hysteria’
‘his watch marked five past eight’
‘the examiner may have hundreds of scripts to mark’
‘teachers must mark down GCSE work containing poor grammar’
‘he'll leave you, you mark my words!’
‘each central defender marks one attacker’
‘I did well at marking the ball’

--Word--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

‘the word ‘drake’ is semantically marked as masculine’
‘a marked increase in UK sales’

--Word--
marker 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An object used to indicate a position, place, or route.
A distinctive feature or characteristic indicative of a particular quality or condition.
A thing serving as a standard of comparison.
A radio beacon used to guide the pilot of an aircraft.
An allele used to identify a chromosome or to locate other genes on a genetic map.
A felt-tip pen with a broad tip.
(in team games) a player who stays close to an opponent to prevent them from getting or passing the ball.
A person who assesses the standard of a test or examination.
A person who records the score in snooker, billiards, or squash.
A promissory note; an IOU.
--Examples--
‘they erected a granite marker at the crash site’
‘identification with one's own language has always been a marker of nationalism’
‘he has already laid down a marker by setting a fast time during practice’
‘a heavy line drawn by a marker’
‘Quinn took the ball wide of his marker’
‘the aim of the marker is to help the student do better next time’
‘we'll give you a marker, you give us the car’

--Word--
market 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A regular gathering of people for the purchase and sale of provisions, livestock, and other commodities.
An open space or covered building where vendors convene to sell their goods.
An area or arena in which commercial dealings are conducted.
A demand for a particular commodity or service.
The state of trade at a particular time or in a particular context.
The free market.
A stock market.
Advertise or promote (something)
Offer for sale.
Go shopping for provisions.
--Examples--
‘they wanted to browse around the street market’
‘Billingsgate Market’
‘the UK market remained in recession’
‘the labour market’
‘there is a market for high-priced wine’
‘the bottom's fallen out of the market’
‘future development cannot be left to the market’
‘a market economy’
‘the sale of the company's shares on world markets’
‘the product was marketed under the name ‘aspirin’’
‘sheep farmers are still unable to market their lambs’
‘then I have to go uptown and market’

markland 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A piece of land having an annual rental value of one mark. Hence also: a unit of land based on this value, used in land assessment.
Orkney and Shetland. An area of land having the capital value of one mark. Usually used as a unit of land assessment and subdivided into eight ures.

Markova, Dame Alicia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1910–2004), English ballet dancer; born Lilian Alicia Marks. She founded the Markova–Dolin Ballet with Anton Dolin in 1935 and was prima ballerina with the London Festival Ballet 1950–2.

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
mark 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small area on a surface having a different colour from its surroundings, typically one caused by damage or dirt.
A spot, area, or feature on a person's or animal's body by which they may be identified or recognized.
A line, figure, or symbol made as an indication or record of something.
A sign or indication of a quality or feeling.
A written symbol made on a document in place of a signature by someone who cannot write.
A competitor's starting point in a race.
A piece of material or a knot used to indicate a depth on a sounding line.
One of two possible states of a signal in certain systems.
A level or stage that is considered significant.
A particular temperature level in a gas oven.
A point awarded for a correct answer or for proficiency in an examination or competition.
A figure or letter representing the total number of marks awarded in an examination or competition and signifying a person's score.
An official assessment of a horse's form, expressed as a figure between 0 and 140 and used as the basis for calculating the weight the horse has to carry in a race.
(especially in athletics) a time or distance achieved by a competitor, especially one which represents a record or personal best.
(followed by a numeral) a particular model or type of a vehicle or machine.
A target.
A person who is easily deceived or taken advantage of.
The act of cleanly catching the ball direct from a kick, knock-on, or forward throw by an opponent, on or behind one's own 22-metre line, and exclaiming ‘Mark’, after which a free kick can be taken by the catcher.
An act of catching a ball that has been kicked at least fifteen metres before it reaches the ground, or the spot from which the subsequent kick is taken.
Make a visible impression or stain on.
Become stained.
Write a word or symbol on (an object) in order to give information.
Write or draw (a word, symbol, line, etc.) on an object.
Put a line by or through something written or printed to indicate that it has passed or been dealt with.
Indicate the position of.
Separate or delineate (a particular section or area)
(of a particular quality or feature) distinguish (someone or something) from other people or things.
Select or destine someone for (a particular role or fate)
Judge someone to be (a particular type of person)
Acknowledge or celebrate (an important event) with a particular action.
Be an indication of (a significant event or stage)
Characterize as having a particular quality or feature.
(of a clock or watch) show (a certain time)
(of a teacher or examiner) assess the standard of (written work) by assigning points for proficiency or correct answers.
Reduce the number of marks awarded to a person or their work.
Notice or pay careful attention to.
(of a player in a team game) stay close to (an opponent) in order to prevent them getting or passing the ball.
Catch (the ball) from a kick of at least ten metres.
--Examples--
‘the blow left a red mark down one side of her face’
‘he was five feet nine, with no distinguishing marks’
‘the first syllable has a stress mark’
‘the flag was at half mast as a mark of respect’
‘he signed his mark in the visitor's book’
‘unemployment had passed the two million mark’
‘preheat the oven to Gas Mark 5’
‘many candidates lose marks because they don't read the questions carefully’
‘full marks to them for highlighting the threat to the rainforest’
‘the highest mark was 98 per cent’
‘horses tend to run off a higher mark over fences than they would over hurdles’
‘he blasted away from the field during the second lap to knock a second off the existing mark’
‘a Mark 10 Jaguar’
‘few bullets could have missed their mark’
‘they figure I'm an easy mark’
‘he fingered the photograph gently, careful not to mark it’
‘they're made from a woven surface which doesn't mark or tear’

‘she marked the date down on a card’
‘he marked off their names in a ledger’
‘the top of the pass marks the border between Alaska and the Yukon’
‘you need to mark out the part of the garden where the sun lingers longest’

marlberry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An evergreen shrub or small tree, Ardisia escallonioides (family Myrsinaceae), bearing white flowers and shiny black berries, and occurring in tropical and subtropical America (also "†marlberry-cherry"). Later also: a related shrub, A. japonica, native to Japan and China, with white flowers and pink fruits (rare).
--Examples--

--Word--
Dietrich, Marlene 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1901–92), German-born American actress and singer; born Maria Magdelene Dietrich. She became famous for her part as Lola in The Blue Angel (1930), one of many films she made with Josef von Sternberg. From the 1950s she was also successful as an international cabaret star.

--Meanings--

A game in which marbles are rolled along the ground with the aim of hitting those of one's opponent.
--Examples--
‘your knuckles are skinned from shooting marleys’
‘she had a flair for marleys’

marl 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
An unconsolidated sedimentary rock or soil consisting of clay and lime, formerly used as fertilizer.
Apply marl to.
A mottled yarn of differently coloured threads, or fabric made from this yarn.
--Examples--
‘the ancient right to dig marl for fertilizer’
‘the road cuttings show red and green marls’
‘small fields were being assiduously marled to produce corn crops’
‘blue marl leggings’

--Examples--

Brando, Marlon 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1924–2004), American actor. An exponent of method acting, he first attracted critical acclaim in the stage production of A Streetcar Named Desire (1947); he starred in the film version four years later. Other notable films: On the Waterfront (1954, for which he won an Oscar) and The Godfather (1972).
--Examples--
--Word--
Marlovian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the English playwright and poet Christopher Marlowe or his works.
Relating to the view that Christopher Marlowe wrote the plays attributed to Shakespeare.
A student or admirer of the works of the English playwright and poet Christopher Marlowe.
A supporter of the view that Christopher Marlowe wrote the plays attributed to Shakespeare.
--Examples--
‘Marlovian depictions of erotic desire’
‘the Marlovian theory was reinvented by a determined Broadway press agent’
‘I have been privileged to benefit from the advice of some excellent Marlovians’
‘the Marlovians contend that Christopher Marlowe faked his own death’
--Word--
Marlowe, Christopher 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1564–93), English playwright and poet. As a playwright he brought a new strength and vitality to blank verse; his work influenced Shakespeare's early historical plays. Notable plays: Doctor Faustus (c.1590) and The Jew of Malta (1592).
--Examples--

--Meanings--
Characteristic or reminiscent of the work of Marlowe.

Marmara, Sea of 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A small sea in north-western Turkey. Connected by the Bosporus to the Black Sea and by the Dardanelles to the Aegean, it separates European Turkey from Asian Turkey. In ancient times it was known as the Propontis.

--Examples--
--Word--
Marne 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river of east central France, which rises in the Langres plateau north of Dijon and flows 525 km (328 miles) north and west to join the River Seine near Paris. Its valley was the scene of two important battles in the First World War. The first battle (September 1914) halted and repelled the German advance on Paris; the second (July 1918) ended the final German offensive.
--Examples--

--Examples--
‘a wealthy Maronite businessman’
--Word--
maroon 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Of a brownish-red colour.
A brownish-red colour.
A firework that makes a loud bang, used as a signal or warning.
Leave (someone) trapped and alone in an inaccessible place, especially an island.
A member of any of various communities in parts of the Caribbean who were originally descended from escaped slaves. In the 18th century Jamaican Maroons fought two wars against the British, both of which ended with treaties affirming the independence of the Maroons.
--Examples--
‘ornate maroon and gold wallpaper’
‘the hat is available in either white or maroon’
‘cold pinks, purples, and maroons’
‘a novel about schoolboys marooned on a desert island’

Marquand, J. P. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1893–1960), US writer; full name John Phillips Marquand. He created the character Mr. Moto, a Japanese detective featured in several of his novels, such as Last Laugh, Mr. Moto (1942). His other works include The Late George Apley (1937), Point of No Return (1949), and Women and Thomas Harrow (1958).

Marquois scale 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plain-edged scale used in conjunction with a triangle for drawing equidistant parallel lines. Also more fully "Marquois parallel scales", "Marquois scale and triangle", and "a pair of Marquois scales".
--Examples--
--Word--
Marrism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The body of Marxist linguistic theories put forward by Marr and his followers (especially I. I. Meshchaninov), in which language was regarded as monogenetic (with all languages developing from four elements, sal, roš, jon, and ber) and as belonging to social class rather than nationality (being, in Marxist terms, part of the social and economic superstructure rather than the base); advocacy of such theories.
--Examples--
--Word--
marrow 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A long white-fleshed gourd with green skin, which is eaten as a vegetable.
The plant of the gourd family which produces marrows.
A soft fatty substance in the cavities of bones, in which blood cells are produced.
The essential part of something.
--Examples--
‘marrow donors’
‘a bone marrow transplant’
‘such men were the marrow of the organization’
--Word--
marraine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In France during the First World War (1914–18): a local woman who befriends a soldier at the front, giving him moral and material support, as by letters, food parcels, etc. Now historical.
--Examples--

Marrakech 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in western Morocco, in the foothills of the High Atlas Mountains; population 1,070,838 (2004). It was founded in 1062 as the capital of the Almoravids.

marry

verb
--Meanings--
Join in marriage.
Take (someone) as one's wife or husband in marriage.
Enter into marriage.
Become a member of (a family) by marriage.
(of a parent or guardian) give (a son or daughter) in marriage, especially for reasons of expediency.
Join together; combine harmoniously.
Blend or combine with something.
Splice (rope ends) together without increasing their girth.

‘I was married in church’
‘my sister got married to a Welshman’
‘Eric asked me to marry him’
‘they had no plans to marry’
‘both men married into my mother's family’
‘her parents married her to a wealthy landowner’
‘the show marries poetry with art’
‘most Chardonnays don't marry well with salmon’

marriage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The legally or formally recognized union of two people as partners in a personal relationship (historically and in some jurisdictions specifically a union between a man and a woman)
The state of being married.
A combination or mixture of elements.
(in bezique and other card games) a combination of a king and queen of the same suit.
--Examples--
‘a happy marriage’
‘the children from his first marriage’
‘marriage vows’
‘they were celebrating 50 years of marriage’
‘her music is a marriage of funk, jazz, and hip-hop’

Marryat, Frederick 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1792–1848), English novelist and naval officer; known as Captain Marryat. Notable works: Peter Simple (1833), Mr Midshipman Easy (1836), The Children of the New Forest (1847).

--Examples--
--Word--
marrier 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who takes another in marriage.
--Examples--
--Word--
marrier 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who takes another in marriage.
--Examples--
--Word--
marry 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Join in marriage.
Take (someone) as one's wife or husband in marriage.
Enter into marriage.
Become a member of (a family) by marriage.
(of a parent or guardian) give (a son or daughter) in marriage, especially for reasons of expediency.
Join together; combine harmoniously.
Blend or combine with something.
Splice (rope ends) together without increasing their girth.
--Examples--
‘I was married in church’
‘my sister got married to a Welshman’
‘Eric asked me to marry him’
‘they had no plans to marry’
‘both men married into my mother's family’
‘her parents married her to a wealthy landowner’
‘the show marries poetry with art’
‘most Chardonnays don't marry well with salmon’
--Word--

--Word--
mar 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Impair the quality or appearance of; spoil.
--Examples--
‘violence marred a number of New Year celebrations’
--Word--
Marriott, J. Willard 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1900–1985), US businessman; full name John Willard Marriott. He founded the Marriott hotel chain, which began in 1927 with a Hot Shoppe in Washington, DC.
--Examples--

marrow 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A long white-fleshed gourd with green skin, which is eaten as a vegetable.
The plant of the gourd family which produces marrows.
A soft fatty substance in the cavities of bones, in which blood cells are produced.
The essential part of something.
--Examples--
‘marrow donors’
‘a bone marrow transplant’
‘such men were the marrow of the organization’

--Word--
marrowsky 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A variety of slang, or a slip in speaking, characterized by the transposition of the initial letters or syllables of two (consecutive) words. Occasionally in "marrowsky language". Compare "spoonerism" (now the more usual word).
An instance of this; a spoonerism.
--Examples--
--Word--
marrube 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The plant white horehound, Marrubium vulgare.
--Examples--
--Word--
Marrubium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of plants of the family Lamiaceae (Labiatae), typically with a white cottony down, which occur chiefly in the eastern Mediterranean and western Asia; (also marrubium) a plant of this genus, especially white horehound, M. vulgare. Also: a preparation of white horehound, used in some traditional cough remedies; a bitter constituent of this plant (perhaps marrubiin).
--Examples--
--Word--
Marrucinian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of an Oscan-Umbrian people living in the area around Teate (now Chieti) in ancient Italy.
The Oscan-Umbrian language of the Marrucinians.
Of or relating to the Marrucinians or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mars 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The god of war and the most important Roman god after Jupiter. The month of March is named after him.
A small reddish planet which is the fourth in order from the sun and is periodically visible to the naked eye.
--Examples--

Marseillaise 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The national anthem of France, written by Rouget de Lisle in 1792 and first sung in Paris by Marseilles patriots.

Marseilles 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city and port on the Mediterranean coast of southern France, the capital of Provence–Alpes–Côte d'Azur; population 860,363 (2007). French name Marseille /maʀsɛj/.

Marseilles 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city and port on the Mediterranean coast of southern France, the capital of Provence–Alpes–Côte d'Azur; population 860,363 (2007). French name Marseille /maʀsɛj/.

Marsic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the Marsi. "Marsic War"noun the Social War, 90–89 b.c., in which the Marsi played a prominent part on the side of the Italian allies against Rome.
The Marsi language; = Marsian.
--Examples--
--Word--
marsh 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An area of low-lying land which is flooded in wet seasons or at high tide, and typically remains waterlogged at all times.
--Examples--
‘the marsh marigold loves damp fields, riverbanks, and marshes’
‘patches of marsh’
‘marsh plants’
--Word--
marshal 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An officer of the highest rank in the armed forces of some countries.
A high-ranking officer of state.
A federal or municipal law-enforcement officer.
The head of a police department.
The head of a fire department.
An official responsible for supervising sports events, and for controlling crowds in other public events.
(in the UK) an official accompanying a judge on circuit to act as secretary and personal assistant.
Assemble and arrange (a group of people, especially troops) in order.
Methodically assemble and arrange (facts, ideas, objects, etc.)
Correctly position or arrange (rolling stock).
Direct the movement of (an aircraft) on the ground at an airport.
Combine (coats of arms) to indicate marriage, descent, or the bearing of office.
--Examples--
‘Marshal Tito’
‘ground marshals joined the referee and touch judges in trying to regain order’
‘the general marshalled his troops’
‘she is one of those people who can marshal their thoughts quickly and articulate them clearly’
‘the quarters include those appearing on the Warwick Plate, but in addition there is marshalled that of Grey’
--Word--
marshalate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The position or rank of marshal, especially in the French army.
US. The position or rank of marshal. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
marshalcy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The office, rank, or position of a marshal.
In the English Royal household: a department presided over by a marshal (formerly, the marshal of the King's house; subsequently, the Earl Marshal as President of the College of Arms).
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
McLuhan, Marshall 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1911–80), Canadian writer and thinker; full name Herbert Marshall McLuhan. He became famous in the 1960s for his phrase ‘the medium is the message’ and his argument that it is the characteristics of a particular medium rather than the information it disseminates which influence and control society.
--Examples--

--Word--
Marshall Islands 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A country that consists of two chains of islands in the north-western Pacific Ocean; population 53,000 (estimated 2015); capital, Majuro; languages, English (official) and local Austronesian languages.

--Word--
marshalsea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in England) a court formerly held before the steward and the knight marshal of the royal household. It was abolished in 1849.
A former prison in Southwark, London, under the control of the knight marshal.

--Word--
marshmallow 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A soft, chewy item of confectionery made with sugar and gelatin.
A tall pink-flowered European plant that grows in brackish marshes. The roots were formerly used to make marshmallow, and it is sometimes cultivated for medicinal use.
--Examples--
‘toasting marshmallows over a campfire’
‘chocolate-covered marshmallow cookies’
‘a tough-as-nails reporter with a marshmallow centre’
--Word--
marshmallow 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A soft, chewy item of confectionery made with sugar and gelatin.
A tall pink-flowered European plant that grows in brackish marshes. The roots were formerly used to make marshmallow, and it is sometimes cultivated for medicinal use.
--Examples--
‘toasting marshmallows over a campfire’
‘chocolate-covered marshmallow cookies’
‘a tough-as-nails reporter with a marshmallow centre’
--Word--
marshmallowy 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling a marshmallow, especially in sweetness or softness of texture; (frequently figurative) cloying, sentimental.

Marsyas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A satyr who challenged Apollo to a contest in flute playing and was flayed alive when he lost.
--Examples--
--Word--
Marsilea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of aquatic or semiaquatic plants of the family Marsileaceae (allied to the ferns), the members of which have creeping rhizomes, four-lobed leaves, and sporocarps on or at the base of the petioles; (also marsilea) a plant of this genus (also called pepperwort, water clover).
--Examples--
--Word--
marsileaceous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Belonging to or resembling the Marsileaceae, a family of aquatic ferns of which Marsilea is the type genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
Marsilea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of aquatic or semiaquatic plants of the family Marsileaceae (allied to the ferns), the members of which have creeping rhizomes, four-lobed leaves, and sporocarps on or at the base of the petioles; (also marsilea) a plant of this genus (also called pepperwort, water clover).

marsipobranch 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having pouched gills. Formerly also: relating to or belonging to the class Marsipobranchii.
--Examples--
--Word--
Marston Moor, Battle of 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A battle of the English Civil War, fought in 1644 on Marston Moor near York, in which the Royalist armies suffered a defeat which fatally weakened Charles I's cause.
--Examples--
--Word--
marsupium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pouch that protects eggs, offspring, or reproductive structures, especially the pouch of a female marsupial mammal.
--Examples--
--Word--
marsupial 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A mammal of an order whose members are born incompletely developed and are typically carried and suckled in a pouch on the mother's belly. Marsupials are found chiefly in Australia and New Guinea, and also in America.
Relating to the marsupials.
--Examples--
--Word--
Marsupialia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Treated as plural. An order of mammals comprising forms which lack a complete placenta and give birth to very immature young which complete their development while attached to the mother's mammae, typically located in a protective abdominal pouch.
--Examples--
--Word--
marsupialize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To convert (a cyst, abscess, or other cavity) into a pouch by making a permanent wide opening to the exterior.
--Examples--
--Word--
marsupialization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The formation of a pouch or pouch-like cavity; specifically an operative technique for draining a cyst or other cavity that cannot be excised, in which the cyst is opened and emptied, and its edges then sutured to the skin incision, forming a pouch that allows continued external drainage.
--Examples--
--Word--
marsupialize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To convert (a cyst, abscess, or other cavity) into a pouch by making a permanent wide opening to the exterior.
--Examples--

martelé 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a piece of music: having heavily accented and shortened notes. Of a musical instrument: played in this style. Also as noun: this style of playing.
--Examples--
--Word--
martellato 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of notes: heavily accented and left before their full time has expired; percussive. Of a note, passage, etc.: played in this style.
Martellato style of playing or musical direction.
--Examples--
--Word--
Martello 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of numerous small circular forts that were erected for defence purposes along the coasts of Britain during the Napoleonic Wars.

--Word--
martial 
--Type--
adjective, proper noun
--Meanings--
Relating to fighting or war.
(c.40–c.104 AD), Roman epigrammatist, born in Spain; Latin name Marcus Valerius Martialis. His fifteen books of epigrams, in a variety of metres, reflect all facets of Roman life.
--Examples--
‘martial bravery’

Navratilova, Martina 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1956), Czech-American tennis player. Her major successes include nine Wimbledon singles titles (1978–9; 1982–7; 1990), two world championships (1980; 1984), and eight successive grand slam doubles titles.
--Examples--
--Word--
Martineau, Harriet 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1802–76), English writer. She wrote mainly on social, economic, and historical subjects, and is known for her twenty-five-volume series Illustrations of Political Economy (1832–4) and her translation of Auguste Comte's Philosophie positive (1853).

martingale 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A strap or set of straps running from the noseband or reins to the girth of a horse, used to prevent the horse from raising its head too high.
A gambling system of continually doubling the stakes in the hope of an eventual win that must yield a net profit.

--Word--
Martynia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of the family Pedaliaceae, consisting of sticky-haired plants, native to warm and tropical parts of America, with two-lipped flowers and long-beaked pods which can be pickled; (also martynia) a plant of this genus, especially Martynia annua, native to Mexico (also called unicorn plant).

--Word--
Martinique 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island in the Caribbean, in the Lesser Antilles group; population 396,000 (estimated 2015); capital, Fort-de-France. It is an overseas department of France.

--Word--
martyr 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A person who is killed because of their religious or other beliefs.
A person who displays or exaggerates their discomfort or distress in order to obtain sympathy.
A constant sufferer from (an ailment)
Kill (someone) because of their beliefs.
Cause great pain or distress to.
--Examples--
‘the first Christian martyr’
‘she wanted to play the martyr’
‘I'm a martyr to migraine!’
‘she was martyred for her faith’
‘there was no need to martyr themselves again’
--Word--
martyrdom 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The death or suffering of a martyr.
A display of pretended or exaggerated suffering to obtain sympathy.
--Examples--
‘the martyrdom of St Anthony’
‘you know martyrdom isn't my style’

Maruts 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The sons of Rudra. In the Rig Veda they are the storm gods, Indra's helpers.

MARV 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A missile warhead capable of altering its course during the descent phase of its flight, for increased accuracy and so as to avoid interception, atmospheric disturbances, etc.

--Word--
Marvell, Andrew 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1621–78), English metaphysical poet. He was best known during his lifetime for his verse satires and pamphlets attacking the corruption of Charles II and his ministers; most of his poetry was published posthumously and was not recognized until the 20th century. Notable poems: ‘To his Coy Mistress’ and ‘Bermudas’.
--Examples--

Gaye, Marvin 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1939–84), American soul singer, composer, and musician. Best known for ‘I Heard It Through the Grapevine’ (1968), he later recorded the albums Let's Get It On (1973) and Midnight Love (1982). He was shot dead by his father in a quarrel.

--Examples--
--Word--
Marx, Karl 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1818–83), German political philosopher and economist, resident in England from 1849; full name Karl Heinrich Marx. The founder of modern communism with Friedrich Engels, he collaborated with him in the writing of the Communist Manifesto (1848), and enlarged it into a series of books, most notably the three-volume Das Kapital.
--Examples--
--Word--
Marxian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the German political philosopher and economist Karl Marx or his ideas.
A person who supports the theories of the German political philosopher and economist Karl Marx.
--Examples--
‘a traditionally Marxian conception of ruling class power’
‘the Marxian makes an allowance for restructuring in view of the unpredictability of knowledge’

--Word--
Masaccio 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1401–28), Italian painter; born Tommaso Giovanni di Simone Guidi. A pioneer in the application of the laws of perspective to painting, he is remembered particularly for his frescoes in the Brancacci Chapel in the church of Santa Maria del Carmine in Florence (1424–7).
--Examples--
--Word--

A member of a pastoral people living in Tanzania and Kenya.
The Nilotic language of the Masai, with about 700,000 speakers.
Relating to the Masai or their language.

Masaryk, Tomáš 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1850–1937), Czechoslovak statesman, president 1918–35; full name Tomáš Garrigue Masaryk. He became Czechoslovakia's first president when the country achieved independence in 1918.

--Word--
mascagnite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Ammonium sulphate occurring as colourless, grey, or yellowish crystals of the orthorhombic system, usually in translucent crusts formed as sublimation products of volcanoes and burning coal seams, and in Peruvian guano.
--Examples--

--Meanings--
A representation, often grotesque, of a human or animal face, used as an architectural ornament.
--Examples--
--Word--
mascle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A charge in the form of a lozenge with a central lozenge-shaped opening through which the field appears.

mascon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A concentration of denser material below the surface of the moon or other body, causing a local increase in gravitational pull.

mascot 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or thing that is supposed to bring good luck, especially one linked to a particular organization or event.

‘the team's dolphin mascot’

--Word--
Mascouten 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a North American Indian people inhabiting a region around the south of Lake Michigan, who merged with the Kickapoo at the beginning of the 19th cent.
The extinct Algonquian language of the Mascouten.

--Word--
masculine 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having qualities or appearance traditionally associated with men.
Relating to men; male.
Of or denoting a gender of nouns and adjectives, conventionally regarded as male.
The male sex or gender.
A masculine word or form.
--Examples--
‘he is outstandingly handsome and robust, very masculine’
‘a masculine voice’
‘masculine pronouns’
‘the dance presents the world of the masculine, its raw energy’
--Word--
masculinely 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
masculinize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Induce male physiological characteristics in.
Make (someone or something) masculine in nature or appearance.
--Examples--
‘male sex steroids masculinize female hyenas’
‘the women in the play find subtle ways to masculinize their performances’
‘a slightly masculinized swagger’
--Word--

--Type--

--Word--
masculinism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Advocacy of the rights of men; adherence to or promotion of opinions, values, etc., regarded as typical of men; (more generally) anti-feminism, machismo.
--Examples--
--Word--
masculinist 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Characterized by or denoting attitudes or values held to be typical of men.
Relating to the advocacy of the rights or needs of men.
An advocate of the rights or needs of men.
--Examples--
‘masculinist language’
‘new masculinists’
--Word--
masculinity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Qualities or attributes regarded as characteristic of men.
--Examples--
‘handsome, muscled, and driven, he's a prime example of masculinity’

Masdeu 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sweet, full-bodied red wine with a mellow flavour, produced at the Masdeu vineyard in southern France and sometimes drunk as an alternative to port.
--Examples--
--Word--
masdevallia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of numerous small epiphytic orchids of the genus Masdevallia, native to cool mountainous regions of South America and cultivated elsewhere as ornamentals. Also (in form Masdevallia): the genus itself.
--Examples--
--Word--
Masefield, John 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1878–1967), English poet and novelist; full name John Edward Masefield. He was appointed Poet Laureate in 1930. Notable works: Salt-Water Ballads (1902).
--Examples--
--Word--
maser 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device using the stimulated emission of radiation by excited atoms to amplify or generate coherent monochromatic electromagnetic radiation in the microwave range.

Maseru 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Lesotho, situated on the Caledon River near the border with the province of Free State in South Africa; population 211,000 (est. 2007).
--Examples--
--Word--
mash 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Reduce (a food or other substance) to a pulpy mass by crushing it.
Crush or smash (something) to a pulp.
Press forcefully on (something)
Attack or assault.
(in brewing) mix (powdered malt) with hot water to form wort.
(with reference to tea) brew or infuse.
A soft mass made by crushing a substance into a pulp, sometimes with the addition of liquid.
Mashed potato.
Bran mixed with hot water, given as a warm food to horses and other animals.
(in brewing) a mixture of powdered malt and hot water, which is left to stand until the sugars dissolve to form the wort.
mash something up
Mix or combine two or more different elements.
--Examples--
‘mash the beans to a paste’
‘he almost had his head mashed by a slamming door’
‘the worst thing you can do is mash the brake pedal’
‘they both got mashed up pretty bad’
‘the barley is dried out over peat fires and mashed with water which flows through peat ground’
‘I've just mashed a pot of tea’
‘we'd let the pot mash for ten minutes’
‘pound the garlic to a mash’
‘for supper there was sausages and mash’
‘a bucket of mash’
‘the brewer now transfers the mash to a mash tun’
‘in my films I've always tried to artfully mash up genres’
‘Dinsdale mashes up dance styles like UK garage, house, and hip-hop with masterful aplomb’
--Word--
masha 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A unit of weight, legally fixed in 1833 in British India as 15 grains (0.97 grams).
--Examples--
--Word--
masher 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A utensil for mashing food.
A dandy of late Victorian or Edwardian times.
A man who makes unwelcome sexual advances to women.
--Examples--
‘a potato masher’
--Word--
mashallah 
--Type--
exclamation
--Meanings--
In Muslim countries, expressing praise or resignation: ‘(this is) what God wills’. Later also in extended use.
--Examples--
--Word--
Masham 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A breed of sheep produced by crossing Wensleydale or Teeswater rams with Blackface or Swaledale ewes; a sheep of this breed.
--Examples--

--Word--
Mashhad 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in north-eastern Iran, close to the border with Turkmenistan; population 2,427,316 (2006). The burial place in AD 809 of the Abbasid caliph Harun ar-Rashid and in 818 of the Shiite leader Ali ar-Rida, it is a holy city of the Shiite Muslims. It is the second largest city in Iran.
--Examples--

--Word--
mask 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A covering for all or part of the face, worn as a disguise, or to amuse or frighten others.
A covering made of fibre or gauze and fitting over the nose and mouth to protect against air pollutants, or made of sterile gauze and worn to prevent infection of the wearer or (in surgery) of the patient.
A protective covering fitting over the whole face, worn in fencing, ice hockey, and other sports.
A respirator used to filter inhaled air or to supply gas for inhalation.
A masked person.
A face pack.
A likeness of a person's face moulded or sculpted in clay or wax.
A person's face regarded as having set into a particular expression.
A hollow model of a human head worn by ancient Greek and Roman actors.
The face or head of a fox or other game animal, as a trophy.
A manner or expression that hides one's true character or feelings.
A piece of material such as card used to cover a part of an image that is not required when exposing a print.
A patterned metal film used in the manufacture of microcircuits to allow selective modification of the underlying material.
The enlarged labium of a dragonfly larva, which can be extended to seize prey.
Cover (the face) with a mask.
Conceal (something) from view.
(of a taste, smell, etc.) prevent the perception of (another sensation)
Cover (an object or surface) so as to protect it during painting.
--Examples--
‘this exfoliating mask helps clear your pores and leaves your skin feeling soft and healthy’
‘his face was a mask of rage’
‘I let my mask of respectability slip’
‘he had been masked, bound, and abducted’
‘the poplars masked a factory’
‘brandy did not completely mask the bitter taste’
‘mask off doors and cupboards with sheets of plastic’
--Word--
maskable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That may be masked.
--Examples--
--Word--
masked 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Wearing a mask on all or part of the face.
(of one's true character or feelings) concealed.
--Examples--
‘a raid by masked gunmen’
‘masked dancers’
‘the barely masked anger in their tone’
--Word--
Muskego 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a North American Indian people inhabiting a swampy region on the western coast of Hudson and James Bays, Canada.
--Examples--
--Word--
maskelynite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A colourless glassy aluminosilicate of calcium and sodium with the composition of plagioclase, found in certain kinds of meteorite.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--

‘college accommodation is a great masker of taste’

--Word--
maskette 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of (especially miniature) mask used by indigenous Indian and Inuit peoples of North America, usually worn above or below the face.
--Examples--
--Word--
mask 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A covering for all or part of the face, worn as a disguise, or to amuse or frighten others.
A covering made of fibre or gauze and fitting over the nose and mouth to protect against air pollutants, or made of sterile gauze and worn to prevent infection of the wearer or (in surgery) of the patient.
A protective covering fitting over the whole face, worn in fencing, ice hockey, and other sports.
A respirator used to filter inhaled air or to supply gas for inhalation.
A masked person.
A face pack.
A likeness of a person's face moulded or sculpted in clay or wax.
A person's face regarded as having set into a particular expression.
A hollow model of a human head worn by ancient Greek and Roman actors.
The face or head of a fox or other game animal, as a trophy.
A manner or expression that hides one's true character or feelings.
A piece of material such as card used to cover a part of an image that is not required when exposing a print.
A patterned metal film used in the manufacture of microcircuits to allow selective modification of the underlying material.
The enlarged labium of a dragonfly larva, which can be extended to seize prey.
Cover (the face) with a mask.
Conceal (something) from view.
(of a taste, smell, etc.) prevent the perception of (another sensation)
Cover (an object or surface) so as to protect it during painting.
--Examples--
‘this exfoliating mask helps clear your pores and leaves your skin feeling soft and healthy’
‘his face was a mask of rage’
‘I let my mask of respectability slip’
‘he had been masked, bound, and abducted’
‘the poplars masked a factory’
‘brandy did not completely mask the bitter taste’
‘mask off doors and cupboards with sheets of plastic’

--Word--
maslin 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A mixture of various kinds of grain, especially rye mixed with wheat; bread made from this.
Figurative. A mixture, a medley; a muddle, a mess.
Mixed, mingled; muddled, confused.
--Examples--
--Word--
masochism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The tendency to derive sexual gratification from one's own pain or humiliation.
(in general use) the enjoyment of an activity that appears to be painful or tedious.
--Examples--
‘with things such as bondage and masochism, it's all right if you both go for it’
‘there's plenty to do when the weather turns moorland walks into exercises in masochism’

--Word--
mason 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A person skilled in cutting, dressing, and laying stone in buildings.
A Freemason.
Build from or strengthen with stone.
Cut or dress (stone)
--Examples--
‘the chief mason at Westminster Abbey’
‘a Mason's handshake’
‘the other building was masoned up out of hewn limestone’
‘one course of massive stones, roughly masoned’

noun
--Meanings--
Fibreboard made from wood fibre pulped under steam at high pressure.
--Examples--
‘quality Masonite boards’
--Word--
masonry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Stonework.
The occupation or work of a mason.
Freemasonry.
--Examples--
‘cracks in the finished masonry’
‘masonry nails’
‘hands roughened from carpentry and masonry’
‘the ‘degrees’ found in Masonry are symbolic practices’

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Built of or provided with masonry.

--Word--
mason 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A person skilled in cutting, dressing, and laying stone in buildings.
A Freemason.
Build from or strengthen with stone.
Cut or dress (stone)
--Examples--
‘the chief mason at Westminster Abbey’
‘a Mason's handshake’
‘the other building was masoned up out of hewn limestone’
‘one course of massive stones, roughly masoned’
--Word--
mason's mark 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A distinctive device carved on stone by the mason who dressed it.
--Examples--
--Word--
mason-work 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Stonework, masonry.
The work of a mason.

--Word--
Masorah 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The collection of information and comment on the text of the traditional Hebrew Bible by the Masoretes.
The Masoretic text of the Bible.
--Examples--
--Word--
Masorete 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of the Jewish scholars of the 6th to 10th centuries AD who contributed to the establishment of a recognized text of the Hebrew Bible, and to the compilation of the Masorah.

--Word--
masque 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A form of amateur dramatic entertainment, popular among the nobility in 16th- and 17th-century England, which consisted of dancing and acting performed by masked players.
--Examples--
‘adding a treatment masque to your cleansing routine works wonders’
--Word--
masker 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A thing that masks or conceals something else.
A person taking part in a masquerade or masked ball.
--Examples--
‘college accommodation is a great masker of taste’
--Word--
masquerade 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A false show or pretence.
The wearing of disguise.
A masked ball.
Pretend to be someone one is not.
Be disguised or passed off as something else.
--Examples--
‘I doubt he could have kept up the masquerade for long’
‘dressing up, role playing, and masquerade’
‘a journalist masquerading as a man in distress’
‘idle gossip that masquerades as news’

masquing 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The action of performing or taking part in a masquerade or a masque; an instance of this; a masque. Now historical.
Used in or intended for a masquerade; that is a masquerade. Now historical.

--Word--
mass 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A large body of matter with no definite shape.
Any of the main portions in a painting or drawing that each have some unity in colour, lighting, or some other quality.
A large number of people or objects crowded together.
A large amount of material.
A large quantity or amount of something.
The majority of.
The ordinary people.
The quantity of matter which a body contains, as measured by its acceleration under a given force or by the force exerted on it by a gravitational field.
(in general use) weight.
Involving or affecting large numbers of people or things.
Assemble or cause to assemble into a single body or mass.
--Examples--
‘the sun broke out from behind a mass of clouds’
‘the masterly distribution of masses’
‘a mass of cyclists’
‘a mass of conflicting evidence’
‘we get masses of homework’
‘the mass of the people think that the problems are caused by government inefficiency’
‘seaside towns that catered for the masses’
‘stellar objects of intermediate mass’
‘multiply the mass of the payload by the distance travelled’
‘the film has mass appeal’
‘a mass exodus of refugees’
‘both countries began massing troops in the region’
‘clouds massed heavily on the horizon’
--Word--
massa 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in representations of black speech) master.
--Examples--
‘Massa, I have some news for you’
--Word--
Massachusett 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of an extinct North American people, formerly found in eastern Massachusetts.
The Algonquian language of the Massachusett.
--Examples--
--Word--
Massachusetts 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state in the north-eastern US, on the coast of the Atlantic Ocean; population 6,497,967 (est. 2008); capital, Boston. Settled by the Pilgrim Fathers in 1620, it was a centre of resistance to the British before becoming one of the original thirteen states of the Union, ratifying the US Constitution in 1788.
--Examples--
--Word--
massacre 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An indiscriminate and brutal slaughter of many people.
A heavy defeat of a sporting team or contestant.
Deliberately and brutally kill (many people)
Inflict a heavy defeat on (a sporting opponent)
Perform (a piece of music, a play, etc.) very ineptly.
--Examples--
‘reports of massacres by government troops’
‘the 25,000 ecstatic fans that packed into Coruna's shabby Riazor Stadium witnessed a massacre’
‘thousands were brutally massacred by soldiers’
‘we haven't been massacred in any game over the last six years’
‘the choir was massacring ‘In the Bleak Midwinter’’

massage 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The rubbing and kneading of muscles and joints of the body with the hands, especially to relieve tension or pain.
Rub and knead (a person or part of the body) with the hands.
Rub a substance into (the skin or hair)
Manipulate (facts or figures) to give a more acceptable result.
--Examples--
‘massage can ease tiredness’
‘a massage will help loosen you up’
‘she massaged his tired muscles’
‘gently massage the cream on to your face’
‘the accounts had been massaged to suit the government’

--Word--
Messalian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a Christian movement of dualistic tendency of 4th-cent. Near Eastern origin, frequently regarded as heretical, which rejected the efficacy of the sacraments and good works, regarding prayer as essential to salvation; a member of one of the later heterodox or marginal movements supposedly related to this.
Of, relating to, or characteristic of the Messalians.
--Examples--

--Word--
Massasoit 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(circa 1580–1661), chief of the Wampanoag Indians; father of King Philip. He signed a peace treaty with the Pilgrims at Plymouth in 1621 and remained a friend to white settlers, although their territorial expansion troubled him.
--Examples--
--Word--
Massawa 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The chief port of Eritrea, on the Red Sea; population 36,700 (est. 2004).

--Word--
massecuite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In sugar manufacture (originally in the Caribbean): a semi-solid mixture obtained from the juice of sugar cane after several rounds of concentration by boiling, which is separated into molasses and pure sugar by centrifugation.
--Examples--

--Word--
Massey, Raymond 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1896–1983), US actor and producer; born in Canada; full name Raymond Hart Massey. His movies include Abe Lincoln in Illinois (1940), Arsenic and Old Lace (1944) and East of Eden (1955). He also played Dr. Leonard Gillespie on the television series Dr. Kildare (1961–66).
--Examples--
--Word--
Massena 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In full "Massena partridge", "Massena quail". The Montezuma quail, Cyrtonyx montezumae (family Odontophoridae), a plump, short-tailed quail of the southern United States and Mexico.
--Examples--
--Word--
mass energy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The mass of a body regarded as energy, according to the laws of relativity.

masseter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A muscle which runs through the rear part of the cheek from the temporal bone to the lower jaw on each side and closes the jaw in chewing.
--Examples--

masseteric 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or connected with the masseter muscle; (of a blood vessel or nerve) supplying the masseter muscle.

Massine, Léonide 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1895–1979), US choreographer and ballet dancer, born in Russia; full name Léonide Fédorovitch Massine; born Leonid Fyodorovich Myasin. He was the originator of the symphonic ballet, and danced in and choreographed the film The Red Shoes (1948).
--Examples--

--Meanings--

Massinger, Philip 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1583–1640), English playwright. Notable works: The Duke of Milan (1621–2), A New Way to Pay Old Debts (1625–6), and The City Madam (1632).
