--Word--
massive 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Large and heavy or solid.
Exceptionally large.
Very serious.
Very successful or influential.
(of rocks or beds) having no discernible form or structure.
(of a mineral) not visibly crystalline.
A group of young people from a particular area with a common interest in dance music.
--Examples--
‘a massive rampart of stone’
‘massive crowds are expected’
‘a massive heart attack’
‘the band are going to be massive’
‘a massive limestone without bedding planes’
‘massive sulphides’
‘the Bristol massive’
--Word--
massively 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
On a vast scale.
To a very great extent; extremely.
In a very large and heavy or solid form.
--Examples--
‘biotechnology is expected to contribute massively to the global economy’
‘research at all levels is massively underfunded’
‘a massively built four-storey building’

-monger 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
Denoting a dealer or trader in a specified commodity.
Denoting a person who promotes a specified activity, situation, or feeling, especially one that is undesirable or discreditable.
--Examples--

‘cheesemonger’
‘warmonger’
--Word--
massoy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "massoy bark". The aromatic bark of any of several tropical Asian trees of the family Lauraceae, especially Cryptocarya aromatica (Massoia aromatica) of New Guinea, from which an essential oil is derived, widely used in eastern medicine.
--Examples--
--Word--
Masson, André 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1896–1987), French painter and graphic artist. He joined the surrealists in the mid 1920s and pioneered ‘automatic’ drawing, a form of fluid, spontaneous composition intended to express images emerging from the unconscious.
--Examples--
--Word--
Masorah 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The collection of information and comment on the text of the traditional Hebrew Bible by the Masoretes.
The Masoretic text of the Bible.
--Examples--
--Word--
Masorete 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of the Jewish scholars of the 6th to 10th centuries AD who contributed to the establishment of a recognized text of the Hebrew Bible, and to the compilation of the Masorah.
--Examples--
--Word--
Masoretic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
massotherapy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The use of massage to treat medical conditions or relieve pain.
--Examples--
--Word--
massotherapist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who practises massotherapy.

--Word--
-penny 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
(especially in pre-decimal currency) costing a specified number of pence.
--Examples--
‘threepenny’
--Word--
mass-priest 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A priest, especially as celebrant of the Mass..
--Examples--
--Word--
mass-produce 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Produce large quantities of (a standardized article) by an automated mechanical process.
--Examples--
‘Henry Ford made his fortune mass-producing the Model T’
--Word--
mass-produced 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Manufactured in large quantities by an automated mechanical process.
--Examples--
‘cheap mass-produced goods’
--Word--
massula 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In certain orchids: any of the clusters of pollen grains, each developed from a single cell, which make up a pollinium.
In aquatic ferns of the families Azollaceae and Salviniaceae: a rounded mass of cytoplasmic foam, having hooked bristles in many species, enclosing a group of microspores.
--Examples--
--Word--
mass-word 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mass noun.
--Examples--
--Word--
mast 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tall upright post, spar, or other structure on a ship or boat, in sailing vessels generally carrying a sail or sails.
A tall upright post on land, especially a flagpole or a television or radio transmitter.
--Examples--
--Word--
mast 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tall upright post, spar, or other structure on a ship or boat, in sailing vessels generally carrying a sail or sails.

--Examples--
--Word--
mastaba 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An ancient Egyptian tomb consisting of an underground burial chamber with rooms above it (at ground level) to store offerings.
(in Islamic countries) a stone or brick bench built into the wall of a house.
--Examples--

--Type--

(in Islamic countries) a stone or brick bench built into the wall of a house.

--Word--
master 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A man who has people working for him, especially servants or slaves.
A person who has complete control of something.
A male head of a household.
The owner of a dog, horse, or other domesticated animal.
A machine or device directly controlling another.
A man in charge of an organization or group.
A male schoolteacher.
The head of a college or school.
The presiding officer of a livery company or Masonic lodge.
The captain of a merchant ship.
The person in control of a pack of hounds.
(in England and Wales) an official of the Supreme Court.
A skilled practitioner of a particular art or activity.
A great artist or musician.
A very strong chess player, especially one who has qualified for the title at international tournaments.
(in some sports) a class for competitors over the usual age for the highest level of competition.
A person who holds a second or further degree.
A postgraduate degree.
Used as a title prefixed to the name of a boy not old enough to be called ‘Mr’
A title for a man of high rank or learning.
The title of the heir apparent of a Scottish viscount or baron.
An original recording, film, or document from which copies can be made.
Having or showing very great skill or proficiency.
Denoting a person skilled in a particular trade and able to teach others.
Main; principal.
Acquire complete knowledge or skill in (a subject, technique, or art)
Gain control of; overcome.
Make a master copy of (a film or recording)
--Examples--
‘he acceded to his master's wishes’
‘he was master of the situation’
‘the master of the house’
‘in many ways dogs reflect the styles of their masters’
‘a master cylinder’
‘the games master’
‘the master of the Aylesbury Vale Hunt’
‘I'm a master of disguise’
‘follow in the footsteps of the masters and paint in locations made famous by their work’
‘a chess master’
‘a master's degree’
‘a Master of Arts’
‘I had a master's in computer engineering’
‘Master James Wishart’
‘the master tape’
‘you don't have to be a master chef in order to cook meat properly’
‘a heart-warming story from a master storyteller’
‘a master bricklayer’
‘the apartment's master bathroom has a free-standing oval bathtub’
‘I never mastered Latin’
‘I managed to master my fears’
‘all records are now being mastered and manufactured for us in the Netherlands’
--Word--
masterable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Capable of being mastered.
--Examples--
--Word--
master-at-arms 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A warrant officer appointed to carry out or supervise police duties on board a ship.
--Examples--
--Word--
masterate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A master's degree; a course of study for, or status conferred by, such a degree.
--Examples--
--Word--
master builder 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who is skilled in the art of building; an architect. Chiefly figurative (especially in rhetorical use).
Nautical. A senior officer of a shipyard, in charge of the major part of the workforce and responsible for all building and repairs; a master shipwright. Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
masterdom 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

masterful 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Powerful and able to control others.
Performed or performing very skilfully.
--Examples--

‘a masterful assessment of the difficulties’
--Word--
masterfully 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a powerful way that shows ability to control others.
In a very skilful manner.
--Examples--
‘she masterfully took over’
‘a masterfully crafted novel’

mastery 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Comprehensive knowledge or skill in a particular subject or activity.

‘man's mastery over nature’

--Word--
master-man 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A craftsman, an artist; a master with apprentices or employees. Compare "mister man", with which this word was sometimes confused.
--Examples--

--Word--
mastermind 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A person with an outstanding intellect.
A person who plans and directs an ingenious and complex scheme or enterprise.
Plan and direct (an ingenious and complex scheme or enterprise)
--Examples--
‘an eminent musical mastermind’
‘McAvoy was the mastermind of the robbery’
‘he was accused of masterminding a gold-smuggling racket’

A postgraduate degree.

A title for a man of high rank or learning.

An original recording, film, or document from which copies can be made.

Denoting a person skilled in a particular trade and able to teach others.
Main; principal.

--Word--
vein 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of the tubes forming part of the blood circulation system of the body, carrying in most cases oxygen-depleted blood towards the heart.
(in general use) a blood vessel.
(in plants) a slender rib running through a leaf or bract, typically dividing or branching, and containing a vascular bundle.
(in insects) a hardened branching rib that forms part of the supporting framework of a wing, consisting of an extension of the tracheal system; a nervure.
A fracture in rock containing a deposit of minerals or ore and typically having an extensive course underground.
A streak or stripe of a different colour in wood, marble, cheese, etc.
A source of a specified quality.
A distinctive quality, style, or tendency.
--Examples--
‘he felt the adrenaline course through his veins’
‘gold-bearing quartz veins’
‘he managed to tap into the thick vein of discontent to his own advantage’
‘United have hit a rich vein of form’
‘he closes his article in a somewhat humorous vein’
--Word--
masterwork 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A masterpiece.
--Examples--
‘towering architectural masterworks like London St Pancras’
--Word--
masterwork 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

‘towering architectural masterworks like London St Pancras’

masterwork

--Meanings--

--Word--
masterwort 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant of the parsley family with white or pinkish flowers and lobed leaves, native to central and southern Europe.
--Examples--

mast-fed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
masthead 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The highest part of a ship's mast or of the lower section of a mast.
The title of a newspaper or magazine at the head of the first or editorial page.
The listed details in a newspaper or magazine referring to ownership, editorial staff, advertising rates, etc.
Send (a sailor) to the masthead as a punishment.
Raise (a flag or sail) to the masthead.
--Examples--
‘the paper lists forty smart writers on its masthead’
‘get below, sir, or I'll masthead you!’
‘the Royal Standard was mastheaded’

masty

--Examples--
--Word--
mastic 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An aromatic gum or resin that exudes from the bark of a Mediterranean tree, used in making varnish and chewing gum and as a flavouring.
The bushy evergreen Mediterranean tree which yields mastic and has aromatic leaves and fruit, closely related to the pistachio.
Used in names of trees that are similar or related to the mastic tree, e.g. American mastic.
A waterproof filler and sealant used in building.
--Examples--
‘incense made from sandalwood, eagle-wood, mastic and cloves’
‘run a bead of mastic along the gap’
‘a mastic sealant’
‘use a mastic between the joints’
--Word--

--Word--
mastic 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An aromatic gum or resin that exudes from the bark of a Mediterranean tree, used in making varnish and chewing gum and as a flavouring.
The bushy evergreen Mediterranean tree which yields mastic and has aromatic leaves and fruit, closely related to the pistachio.
Used in names of trees that are similar or related to the mastic tree, e.g. American mastic.
A waterproof filler and sealant used in building.
--Examples--
‘incense made from sandalwood, eagle-wood, mastic and cloves’
‘run a bead of mastic along the gap’
‘a mastic sealant’
‘use a mastic between the joints’

noun

mastoidectomy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Surgical removal of the lateral wall and contents of the mastoid process, usually to treat mastoiditis; (later also, chiefly in "(modified) radical mastoidectomy") this procedure combined with excision of some or all of the adjacent middle ear structures.

Masuria 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A low-lying region of north-eastern Poland known for its forests and lakes. Formerly part of East Prussia, it was assigned to Poland after the Second World War. Also called Masurian Lakes.

matachin 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A 16th-cent. sword dance related to the morris dance, performed by dancers in extravagant costume and representing a fight or duel.
Chiefly in Central America and the south-western United States: a person or character who takes part in a ritual dance based on the history of Montezuma II. Chiefly in plural.
Frequently in plural, with singular concord. The ritual dance performed by matachin dancers.

--Word--
match 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A contest in which people or teams compete against each other in a particular sport.
A person or thing that is equal to another in quality or strength.
A person or thing that resembles or corresponds to another.
A string that fulfils the specified conditions of a computer search.
A similar or complementary pair.
The fact or appearance of corresponding.
A person viewed in regard to their eligibility for marriage, especially as regards class or wealth.
A marriage.
Correspond or cause to correspond in some essential respect; make or be harmonious.
Put (someone or something) together with someone or something else appropriate or harmonious.
Be equal to (something) in quality or strength.
Succeed in reaching or equalling (a standard or quality)
Equalize (two coupled electrical impedances) so as to bring about the maximum transfer of power from one to the other.
Place (a person or group) in competition with another.
--Examples--
‘a boxing match’
‘they were no match for the mercenaries’
‘the child's identical twin would be a perfect match for organ donation’
‘when the software finds a match, it writes the correct character’
‘the headdresses and bouquet were a perfect match’
‘stones of a perfect match and colour’
‘he was an unsuitable match for any of their girls’
‘a dynastic match’
‘I thought we'd have primrose walls to match the bath’
‘the jacket and trousers do not match’
‘she was trying to match the draperies to the couch’
‘his anger matched her own’
‘he tried to match her nonchalance’
‘the impedance of microphones, auxiliary equipment, and loudspeakers must be matched’
‘the big names were matched against nobodies’

mate 
--Type--
noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
A bitter infusion of the leaves of a South American shrub, which is high in caffeine.
The leaves of the maté shrub.
The South American shrub of the holly family which produces maté leaves.
The sexual partner of a bird or other animal.
A person's husband, wife, or other sexual partner.
One of a matched pair.
A fellow member or joint occupant of a specified thing.
A friend or companion.
Used as a friendly form of address between men or boys.
An assistant or deputy in certain trades.
An officer on a merchant ship subordinate to the master.
(of animals or birds) come together for breeding; copulate.
Bring (animals) together for breeding.
Connect or be connected mechanically.
--Examples--
‘maté has an agreeable slightly aromatic odor’
‘a male bird sings to court a mate’
‘he couldn't satisfy his frisky young mate’
‘a sock without its mate’
‘his table-mates’
‘my best mate Steve’
‘‘See you then, mate.’’
‘a plumber's mate’
‘successful males may mate with many females’
‘ovulation occurs only if mating has taken place’
‘a male is mated to several females’
‘the four-cylinder engine is mated to a five-speed gearbox’
--Word--
mate 
--Type--
noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
A bitter infusion of the leaves of a South American shrub, which is high in caffeine.
The leaves of the maté shrub.
The South American shrub of the holly family which produces maté leaves.
The sexual partner of a bird or other animal.
A person's husband, wife, or other sexual partner.
One of a matched pair.
A fellow member or joint occupant of a specified thing.
A friend or companion.
Used as a friendly form of address between men or boys.
An assistant or deputy in certain trades.
An officer on a merchant ship subordinate to the master.
(of animals or birds) come together for breeding; copulate.
Bring (animals) together for breeding.
Connect or be connected mechanically.
--Examples--
‘maté has an agreeable slightly aromatic odor’
‘a male bird sings to court a mate’
‘he couldn't satisfy his frisky young mate’
‘a sock without its mate’
‘his table-mates’
‘my best mate Steve’
‘‘See you then, mate.’’
‘a plumber's mate’
‘successful males may mate with many females’
‘ovulation occurs only if mating has taken place’
‘a male is mated to several females’
‘the four-cylinder engine is mated to a five-speed gearbox’

--Word--
material 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The matter from which a thing is or can be made.
Things needed for an activity.
A person of a specified quality or suitability.
Information or ideas for use in creating a book or other work.
Items, such as songs or jokes, comprising a performer's act.
Cloth or fabric.
Denoting or consisting of physical objects rather than the mind or spirit.
Concerned with money or possessions rather than the needs of the mind or spirit.
Concerned with the matter of reasoning, not its form.
Significant; important.
(of evidence or a fact) significant or relevant, especially to the extent of determining a cause or affecting a judgement.
--Examples--
‘goats can eat more or less any plant material’
‘highly flammable materials’
‘cleaning materials’
‘he's not really Olympic material’
‘his colonial experiences gave him material’
‘a watchable band playing original material’
‘a piece of dark material’
‘dress materials’
‘the material world’
‘material living standards have risen’
‘political conflict lacks mathematical or material certitude’
‘the insects did not do any material damage to the crop’
‘information that could be material to a murder inquiry’

--Word--
materialize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Become actual fact; happen.
Appear or be present when expected.
(of a ghost, spirit, or similar entity) appear in bodily form.
Represent or cause to appear in bodily or physical form.
--Examples--
‘the forecast rate of increase did not materialize’
‘the train failed to materialize’
‘he plays a teenager whose make-believe friend materializes’
‘a medium, she was reputed to materialize substances’

--Word--
materialism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tendency to consider material possessions and physical comfort as more important than spiritual values.
The theory or belief that nothing exists except matter and its movements and modifications.
The theory or belief that consciousness and will are wholly due to material agency.
--Examples--
‘they hated the sinful materialism of the wicked city’

--Word--
materialist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who considers material possessions and physical comfort as more important than spiritual values.
A person who supports the theory that nothing exists except matter and its movements and modifications.
Considering material possessions and physical comfort as more important than spiritual values.
Relating to the theory that nothing exists except matter and its movements and modifications.
--Examples--
‘greedy materialists lusting for consumer baubles’
‘an atheist and philosophical materialist’
‘a greedy materialist population’
‘his anger at social injustice and materialist greed’
‘atheistic materialist philosophy’

mat-grass 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A wiry, densely tufted grass, Nardus stricta, often dominating acid heaths and moorland in Europe and temperate Asia (also "moor mat-grass").
(More fully "sea mat-grass") marram grass, Ammophila arenaria.

mathematic 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Figurative.
A member of a group of disciples of Pythagoras who studied his scientific proofs and demonstrations, rather than following his doctrines and precepts unquestioningly. Opposed to acousmatic.
Mathematical.
--Examples--
--Word--
mathematical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to mathematics.
Resembling mathematics in being rigorously precise.
--Examples--
‘mathematical symbols’
‘mathematical thinking’
‘he arranged the meal with mathematical precision on a plate’
--Word--
mathematically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
By means of mathematics; in mathematical terms.
In a way that relates to mathematics.
In a rigorously precise manner characteristic of mathematics.
--Examples--
‘pressure is described mathematically as a force exerted over an area’
‘to the mathematically inclined person, this book is an excellent introduction’
‘his description of detail is almost mathematically precise’

Mather, Increase 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1639–1723), American minister; father of Cotton Mather. A Congregationalist, he was a church pastor in Boston 1664–1723 and the president of Harvard College 1685–1701.

Brady, Mathew B. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1823–96) US photographer. The publication of his Gallery of Illustrious Americans (1850) established him as a leading US photographer, and his photographs of the Union armies taken during the Civil War became the basis for his National Photographic Collection.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brady, Mathew B. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1823–96) US photographer. The publication of his Gallery of Illustrious Americans (1850) established him as a leading US photographer, and his photographs of the Union armies taken during the Civil War became the basis for his National Photographic Collection.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mathewson, Christy 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1880–1925), US baseball player; full name Christopher Mathewson. A pitcher for the New York Giants 1900–1916, he won 22 or more games per year for 12 straight years and pitched three shutouts in the 1905 World Series. Baseball Hall of Fame (1936).
--Examples--
--Word--
Mathias, Bob 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1930–2006), US track and field athlete and politician; full name Robert Bruce Mathias. At 17, he was the youngest winner of the decathlon with a gold medal in the 1948 Olympic Games and another in the 1952 games. He later served as a Republican member of the US House of Representatives from California 1967–1975.
--Examples--

Matilda 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
(1102–67), English princess, daughter of Henry I and mother of Henry II; known as the Empress Maud. Henry's only legitimate child, she was named his heir, but her cousin Stephen seized the throne on Henry's death in 1135. She waged an unsuccessful civil war against Stephen until 1148.
A bushman's bundle of personal belongings.

matildite

--Word--
matipo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several New Zealand evergreen shrubs or small trees of the genera Pittosporum (family Pittosporaceae) and Myrsine (family Myrsinaceae); especially (more fully "black matipo") P. tenuifolium, with black bark and clusters of dark purple flowers, and (more fully "red matipo") M. australis, with dark red bark.
--Examples--
--Word--
Matisse, Henri 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1869–1954), French painter and sculptor; full name Henri Emile Benoît Matisse. His use of non-naturalistic colour led him to be regarded as a leader of the Fauvists. His later painting and sculpture displays a trend towards formal simplification and abstraction, and includes large figure compositions and abstracts made from cut-out coloured paper.
--Examples--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Without a mat or mats; not covered with a mat.

--Word--
matlockite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tetragonal fluoride and chloride of lead, PbFCl, usually occurring as transparent, colourless to yellow or yellowish brown tabular crystals.

matriarch 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A woman who is the head of a family or tribe.
An older woman who is powerful within a family or organization.
--Examples--
‘in some cultures the mother proceeds to the status of a matriarch’
‘a domineering matriarch’
--Word--
matriarchal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a form of social organization in which a woman is the head.
Denoting an older woman who is powerful within a family or organization.
--Examples--
‘a matriarchal society’
‘an overbearing matriarchal figure’

--Word--
matriarchy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A system of society or government ruled by a woman or women.
A form of social organization in which descent and relationship are reckoned through the female line.
The state of being an older, powerful woman in a family or group.
--Examples--
‘a matriarchy run by morally superior women’
‘feminism has revived an interest in matriarchy’
‘she cherished a dream of matriarchy—catered to by grandchildren’
--Word--
matriarchic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or of the nature of a matriarch; characterized by matriarchy; matriarchal.

matrical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the womb. Also figurative. Now rare.
Biology. Relating to a matrix.
Mathematics= "matric".
--Examples--
--Word--
matricaria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The plant feverfew, Tanacetum parthenium.
In form Matricaria. A genus of Eurasian plants of the family Asteraceae (Compositae), mostly having white ray florets and yellow discs, which includes wild chamomile, Matricaria recutita, and the pineapple weed, M. discoidea; (also matricaria) a plant of this genus.

--Examples--
--Word--
matricula 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A list or register of people belonging to a university, guild, etc.
A certificate of enrolment in the register of a university, society, etc. Also (in extended use): an authorization or pass; (now) specifically an identity card. rare.
In the Holy Roman Empire and its successors: a list of the contributions, usually of money but sometimes also of manpower, etc., required by the imperial authorities from constituent states; (also occasionally) the total amount of this levy. In later use in Spanish colonies: a register of those due to pay tax or tribute; the tax paid by those on this register. Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
matriculator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who matriculates; a matriculant.
--Examples--
--Word--
matriculant 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who is enrolled as a student in a college or university.
A student who has passed the final school-leaving examination.
--Examples--
‘medical school matriculants’
‘matriculants at the University of Florida’
‘under this programme training is provided to selected matriculants to prepare them for a career in the exciting world of banking’

--Examples--
--Word--
matriculate 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Be enrolled at a college or university.
Admit (a student) to membership of a college or university.
Pass the final school-leaving examination.
Record (arms) in an official register.
A person who has matriculated.
--Examples--
‘they had recently matriculated as undergraduates at Jesus College’
‘he was matriculated at Balliol College, Oxford’
‘a total of 123 boys and girls who matriculated last year were registered with his department’
‘the arms have been matriculated by the Lord Lyon King of Arms in Edinburgh’

--Word--
matriculation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of matriculating at a college or university.
An examination to qualify for enrolment at a college or university.
(in South Africa) a school-leaving examination taken at the end of the twelfth year.
The registration of arms in an official register.
--Examples--
‘matriculation requirements’

matrilateral 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating a relationship (especially a marriage between cousins) in which a mother and one of her siblings or other relatives are both involved as parents.

--Word--
matrix 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The cultural, social, or political environment in which something develops.
A mass of fine-grained rock in which gems, crystals, or fossils are embedded.
The substance between cells or in which structures are embedded.
Fine material used to bind together the coarser particles of a composite substance.
A mould in which something, such as a record or printing type, is cast or shaped.
A rectangular array of quantities or expressions in rows and columns that is treated as a single entity and manipulated according to particular rules.
An organizational structure in which two or more lines of command, responsibility, or communication may run through the same individual.
--Examples--
‘Oxbridge was the matrix of the ideology’
‘nodules of secondary limestone set in a matrix of porous dolomite’
‘such fossils will often be partly concealed by matrix’
‘the lipid matrix of olfactory cells’
‘the matrix of gravel paths is hoed regularly’
‘her two duets with Isobel Baillie were never issued and the matrices were destroyed’
‘this formula applies for all square matrices’
‘matrix structures are said to foster greater flexibility’
--Word--
matrix 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The cultural, social, or political environment in which something develops.
A mass of fine-grained rock in which gems, crystals, or fossils are embedded.
The substance between cells or in which structures are embedded.
Fine material used to bind together the coarser particles of a composite substance.
A mould in which something, such as a record or printing type, is cast or shaped.
A rectangular array of quantities or expressions in rows and columns that is treated as a single entity and manipulated according to particular rules.
An organizational structure in which two or more lines of command, responsibility, or communication may run through the same individual.
--Examples--
‘Oxbridge was the matrix of the ideology’
‘nodules of secondary limestone set in a matrix of porous dolomite’
‘such fossils will often be partly concealed by matrix’
‘the lipid matrix of olfactory cells’
‘the matrix of gravel paths is hoed regularly’
‘her two duets with Isobel Baillie were never issued and the matrices were destroyed’
‘this formula applies for all square matrices’
‘matrix structures are said to foster greater flexibility’

matrixing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of combining signals in different proportions, so as to obtain one or more linear combinations.

matroclinous 
--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
matroid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mathematical entity consisting of a finite set E together with a collection ℐ of subsets of E such that (i) the empty set is a member of ℐ, (ii) any subset of a member of ℐ is also a member of ℐ, and (iii) if two subsets I₁ and I₂ are in ℐ, where the cardinality of I₁ is less than that of I₂, then there exists an element e that is in I₂ but not I₁ such that the union of I₁ with {e} is also an element of ℐ.
--Examples--
--Word--
matron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A woman in charge of domestic and medical arrangements at a boarding school or other institution.
The woman in charge of the nursing in a hospital (the official term is now senior nursing officer)
A female prison officer.
An older married woman, especially one who is staid or dignified.
--Examples--
‘she initiated training for matrons of residential homes’
‘‘This is preposterous,’ sighed Matron’
‘she had been matron of a Belgian Hospital’
‘respectable suburban matrons’

--Word--
matt 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
(of a surface or colour) dull and flat; without a shine.
A matt paint or finish.
A sheet of cardboard placed on the back of a picture, either as a mount or to form a border.
Give a matt appearance to (something)
--Examples--
‘prints are available on matt or glossy paper’
‘a matt black’
‘the varnishes are available in gloss, satin, and matt’
‘try mounting prints against a deep matt or ground of the same background colour’
‘its bright fresh surface was soon matted with dust and insects’
--Word--
mat. 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Matins.
Maturity.
--Examples--
--Word--
matsu 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several Japanese pine trees; especially either of two trees valuable for timber and also grown ornamentally, the Japanese red pine, Pinus densiflora, and the Japanese black pine, P. thunbergii; (also) the wood of these trees. Frequently as the second element in compounds: see aka-matsu, o-matsu.
--Examples--
--Word--
Matsuyama

proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in Japan, the capital and largest city of the island of Shikoku; population 513,902 (2007).

--Word--
matter 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Physical substance in general, as distinct from mind and spirit; (in physics) that which occupies space and possesses rest mass, especially as distinct from energy.
A particular substance.
Written or printed material.
A subject or situation under consideration.
Something which is to be tried or proved in court; a case.
The present state of affairs.
The reason for distress or a problem.
The substance or content of a text as distinct from its style or form.
The body of a printed work, as distinct from titles, headings, etc.
The particular content of a proposition, as distinct from its form.
Be important or significant.
(of a person) be important or influential.
(of a wound) secrete or discharge pus.
--Examples--
‘the structure and properties of matter’
‘organic matter’
‘faecal matter’
‘reading matter’
‘a great deal of work was done on this matter’
‘financial matters’
‘we can do nothing to change matters’
‘what's the matter?’
‘it doesn't matter what the guests wear’
‘what did it matter to them?’
‘she was trying to get known by the people who matter’

--Word--
Matterhorn 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A mountain in the Alps, on the border between Switzerland and Italy. Rising to 4,477 m (14,688 ft), it was first climbed in 1865 by the English mountaineer Edward Whymper.
--Examples--

adjective
--Meanings--

The body of a printed work, as distinct from titles, headings, etc.
The particular content of a proposition, as distinct from its form.
Be important or significant.
(of a person) be important or influential.
(of a wound) secrete or discharge pus.
--Examples--
‘the structure and properties of matter’
‘organic matter’
‘faecal matter’
‘reading matter’
‘a great deal of work was done on this matter’
‘financial matters’
‘we can do nothing to change matters’
‘what's the matter?’
‘it doesn't matter what the guests wear’
‘what did it matter to them?’
‘she was trying to get known by the people who matter’
--Word--
matterless 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having no matter; not embodied in matter; immaterial. Now chiefly Philosophy.
Chiefly British regional. Of no concern or importance; irrelevant.
--Examples--
--Word--
a matter of 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
No more than (a specified period of time)
A thing that involves or depends on.
Something that evokes (a specified feeling)
--Examples--
‘they were shown the door in a matter of minutes’
‘it's a matter of working out how to get something done’
‘it's a matter of complete indifference to me’
--Word--
a matter of course 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
The usual or expected thing.
--Examples--
‘the reports are published as a matter of course’
--Word--
matter of fact 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A fact as distinct from an opinion or conjecture.
The part of a judicial inquiry concerned with the truth of alleged facts.
Unemotional and practical.
Concerned only with factual content rather than style or expression.
--Examples--
‘it's a matter of fact that they had a relationship’
‘she tried to keep her tone light and matter-of-fact’
‘the text is written in a breezy matter-of-fact manner’
--Word--
matter-of-factly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an unemotional and practical manner.
--Examples--
‘he took the news calmly and matter-of-factly’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
matter 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Physical substance in general, as distinct from mind and spirit; (in physics) that which occupies space and possesses rest mass, especially as distinct from energy.
A particular substance.
Written or printed material.
A subject or situation under consideration.
Something which is to be tried or proved in court; a case.
The present state of affairs.
The reason for distress or a problem.

The body of a printed work, as distinct from titles, headings, etc.
The particular content of a proposition, as distinct from its form.
Be important or significant.

Matthau, Walter 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1920–2000), American actor, of Jewish-Russian parentage; born Walter Matuschanskavas. His early success on Broadway in plays including Neil Simon's The Odd Couple (1965, filmed 1968) was followed by a long and successful career in films such as The Sunshine Boys (1975).

Matthews, Stanley 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(1824–89), US Supreme Court associate justice 1881–89. He was appointed to the Court by President Garfield. A previous nomination by President Hayes in 1880 had been rejected because it was felt that a conflict of interest existed.

maturation

noun

--Word--
mature 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Fully developed physically; full-grown.
(especially of a young person) having reached a stage of mental or emotional development characteristic of an adult.
(of thought or planning) careful and thorough.
Used euphemistically to describe someone middle-aged or old.
Having reached the most advanced stage in a process.
(of certain foods or drinks) ready for consumption.
Denoting an economy, industry, or market that has developed to a point where substantial expansion and investment no longer takes place.
(of a bill, bond, etc.) due for payment or repayment.
(of a person or thing) become fully grown or developed.
(of a person) reach an advanced stage of mental or emotional development.
(with reference to certain foods or drinks) become or cause to become ready for consumption.
(of an insurance policy, security, etc.) reach the end of its term and hence become payable.
--Examples--
‘she was now a mature woman’
‘owls are sexually mature at one year’
‘a young man mature beyond his years’
‘on mature reflection he decided they should not go’
‘Miss Walker was a mature lady when she married’
‘Van Gogh's mature work’
‘a rather nice mature Camembert’
‘a mature, sophisticated economy’
‘children mature at different ages’
‘the trees take at least thirty years to mature’
‘he has matured and is ready to take on new responsibilities’
‘leave the cheese to mature’
‘the Scotch is matured for a minimum of three years’
‘when the policy matures it pays off the loan’

--Word--
Mau Mau 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An African secret society originating among the Kikuyu that in the 1950s used violence and terror to try to expel European settlers and end British rule in Kenya. The British eventually subdued the organization, but went on to institute political and social reforms which led to Kenya's independence in 1963.
Terrorize or threaten (someone)
--Examples--
‘the group mau-maus the white coats of the medical establishment’

--Word--
Maugham, W. Somerset 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1874–1965), British novelist, short-story writer, and playwright, born in France; full name William Somerset Maugham. Notable works: Of Human Bondage (novel, 1915), The Moon and Sixpence (novel, 1919), East of Suez (play, 1922), and Cakes and Ale (novel, 1930).
--Examples--

--Word--
maul 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of an animal) wound (a person or animal) by scratching and tearing.
Treat (something) savagely or roughly.
Handle (someone) roughly, especially for sexual gratification.
Defeat heavily in a game or match.
Subject to fierce criticism.
Take part in a maul.
(in rugby union) a loose scrum formed around a player with the ball off the ground.
--Examples--
‘a man was mauled by a lion at London Zoo’
‘the body was badly mauled in battle’
‘the last thing I wanted to do was have a slobbering drunk mauling me’
‘the team were mauled 4-0 by Manchester City’
‘during the trial she was mauled by the media’
‘the forwards rucked and mauled to near perfection’

--Word--
mauling 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An attack by an animal causing serious injury.
An instance of fierce criticism.
A heavy defeat in a game or match.
(in rugby union) the action of forming a loose scrum around a player with the ball off the ground.
--Examples--
‘increased incidences of grizzly bear maulings’
‘he faces a mauling at next week's conference’
‘the mauling they received from Bristol Rovers’
‘the forwards' rucking and mauling was exceptional’
--Word--
maul 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of an animal) wound (a person or animal) by scratching and tearing.
Treat (something) savagely or roughly.
Handle (someone) roughly, especially for sexual gratification.
Defeat heavily in a game or match.
Subject to fierce criticism.
Take part in a maul.
(in rugby union) a loose scrum formed around a player with the ball off the ground.
--Examples--
‘a man was mauled by a lion at London Zoo’
‘the body was badly mauled in battle’
‘the last thing I wanted to do was have a slobbering drunk mauling me’
‘the team were mauled 4-0 by Manchester City’
‘during the trial she was mauled by the media’
‘the forwards rucked and mauled to near perfection’
--Word--
mahlstick 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A light stick with a padded leather ball at one end, held against work by a painter or signwriter to support and steady the brush hand.
--Examples--

moulvi

noun
--Meanings--
(especially in South Asia) a Muslim doctor of the law.

--Word--
Mau Mau 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An African secret society originating among the Kikuyu that in the 1950s used violence and terror to try to expel European settlers and end British rule in Kenya. The British eventually subdued the organization, but went on to institute political and social reforms which led to Kenya's independence in 1963.
Terrorize or threaten (someone)
--Examples--
‘the group mau-maus the white coats of the medical establishment’

noun

Maupassant, Guy de 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1850–93), French novelist and short-story writer; full name Henri René Albert Guy de Maupassant. He wrote about 300 short stories and six novels in a simple, direct narrative style. Notable novels: Une Vie (1883) and Bel-Ami (1885).

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A cylindrically-shaped cheese made from goat's milk, named after the village in the Touraine where it is chiefly produced.

O'Sullivan, Maureen 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1911–98), US actress; born in Ireland; mother of Mia Farrow. She starred as Jane to Johnny Weissmuller's Tarzan in such movies as Tarzan the Ape Man (1932), Tarzan and His Mate (1934), and Tarzan's Secret Treasure (1941). She also starred in The Big Clock (1948) and appeared in Peggy Sue Got Married (1986) and Hannah and Her Sisters (1986).

Maury, Matthew Fontaine 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1806–73), American oceanographer. He conducted the first systematic survey of oceanic winds and currents, and published charts of his findings.

--Word--
Maurya 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A dynasty which ruled northern India 321–c.184 BC. It was founded by Chandragupta Maurya, who introduced a centralized government and uniform script. The oldest extant Indian art dates from this era.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mauriac, François 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1885–1970), French novelist, playwright, and critic. His stories show the conflicts of convention, religion, and human passions suffered by prosperous bourgeoisie. Notable works: Thérèse Desqueyroux (novel, 1927). Nobel Prize for Literature (1952).
--Examples--

--Word--
Richard, Maurice 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1921–2000), Canadian hockey player; nickname The Rocket ; full name Maurice Joseph Henri Richard. Playing for the Montreal Canadiens 1942–60, he was the first professional hockey player to score 50 goals in one season 1944–45, a record that stood until the early 1980s. Hockey Hall of Fame (1961).
--Examples--

--Word--
Maximilian 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1832–67), Austrian emperor of Mexico 1864–7; full name Ferdinand Maximilian Joseph. Brother of Franz Josef, Maximilian was established as emperor of Mexico under French auspices in 1864. He was executed by a popular uprising led by Benito Juárez.
--Examples--
--Word--
Robespierre, Maximilien de 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1758–94), French revolutionary; full name Maximilien François Marie Isidore de Robespierre. As leader of the radical Jacobins in the National Assembly he backed the execution of Louis XVI, implemented a purge of the Girondists, and initiated the Terror, but the following year he fell from favour and was guillotined.
--Examples--
--Word--
maximin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The highest of a set of minimum values.
Denoting a method or strategy in game theory that maximizes the smallest gain that can be relied on by a participant in a game or other situation of conflict.

--Word--
maximum 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adverb
--Meanings--
As great, high, or intense as possible or permitted.
Denoting the greatest or highest point or amount attained.
The greatest amount, extent, or intensity possible, permitted, or recorded.
A maximum permitted custodial sentence for an offence.
At the most.
--Examples--
‘the vehicle's maximum speed’
‘a maximum penalty of ten years' imprisonment’
‘the maximum depth of the pool is 6 feet’
‘the school takes a maximum of 32 pupils’
‘production levels are near their maximum’
‘an offence which carries a maximum of 14 years’
‘the table has a length of 4 feet maximum’
--Word--
maximumly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Maximally.
--Examples--
--Word--
maximum 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adverb
--Meanings--
As great, high, or intense as possible or permitted.
Denoting the greatest or highest point or amount attained.

‘the school takes a maximum of 32 pupils’

Maxwellian 
--Type--
adjective, adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or derived by the physicist James Clerk Maxwell; in accordance with or obeying Maxwell's law, equations, or distribution.
Of, relating to, or regarded as characteristic of Robert Maxwell, especially in relation to his misuse of employees' pension funds for business deals.

mazaedium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In certain ascomycete fungi (chiefly of the order Caliciales or family Onygenaceae): a powdery mass of free spores.

noun
--Meanings--

Mazarin, Jules 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1602–61), Italian-born French statesman; Italian name Giulio Mazzarino. Sent to Paris as the Italian papal legate (1634), he became a naturalized Frenchman; he was made a cardinal in 1641 and then chief minister of France (1642).
--Examples--
--Word--
mazarine hood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of woman's hood or chaperon, fashionable in the late 17th cent.
--Examples--

Mazatec 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of an American Indian people of northern Oaxaca in southern Mexico.
The Oto-Manguean language spoken by this people.
Of or relating to the Mazatecs or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mazatlán 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A seaport and resort in Mexico, on the Pacific coast in the state of Sinaloa; population 352,471 (2005). Founded in 1531, it developed as a centre of Spanish trade with the Philippines.
--Examples--

maze 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A network of paths and hedges designed as a puzzle through which one has to find a way.
A complex network of paths or passages.
A confusing mass of information.
Be dazed and confused.
--Examples--
‘the house has a maze and a walled Italian garden’
‘they were trapped in a menacing maze of corridors’
‘a maze of petty regulations’
‘she was still mazed with the drug she had taken’

Mazhabi 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a convert to Sikhism from Islam. In later use (from the end of the 19th cent.): (in the Punjab) a Sikh convert from the Chuhra group of outcastes (traditionally sweepers and scavengers).

Masurian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or relating to Masuria, a low-lying forested region of north-east Poland (formerly part of East Prussia) containing numerous glacial lakes. Chiefly in "Masurian Lakes".
An inhabitant of Masuria.

--Word--
Mazzini, Giuseppe 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1805–72), Italian nationalist leader. He founded the patriotic movement Young Italy (1831) and was a leader of the Risorgimento. Following the country's unification as a monarchy in 1861, he continued to campaign for a republican Italy.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mazzinian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A follower or supporter of Giuseppe Mazzini.
Of, relating to, or supporting Mazzini or his patriotic and revolutionary views, especially his advocacy of a united republican Italy.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mazzinianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The principles or methods of Mazzini or Mazzinians.

mc 
--Type--
noun, abbreviation, noun, verb, abbreviation
--Meanings--
A miscarriage (particularly used in online forums)
Megacycle(s), a unit of frequency equal to one million cycles.
A person who provides entertainment at a club or party by instructing the DJ and performing rap music.
Perform as an MC.
(in the UK) Military Cross.
Monaco (international vehicle registration).
Music cassette.
--Examples--
‘I suffered a mc at 13 weeks last year’
‘the chance to vote for their MC’
‘he's MC'd at all of our parties’
‘he was awarded the MC’
‘it is now available on Deutsche Grammophon CD and MC’

MCC 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Marylebone Cricket Club, founded in 1787, which has its headquarters at Lord's Cricket Ground in London. The tacitly accepted governing body of cricket until 1969, it continues to have primary responsibility for the game's laws.
--Examples--
--Word--
McCarthy, Mary 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1912–89), American novelist and critic; full name Mary Therese McCarthy. Notable novels: The Groves of Academe (1952) and The Group (1963).
--Examples--
--Word--
McCarthyism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A vociferous campaign against alleged communists in the US government and other institutions carried out under Senator Joseph McCarthy in the period 1950–4. Many of the accused were blacklisted or lost their jobs, though most did not in fact belong to the Communist Party.
--Examples--
--Word--
McCartney, Linda 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1941–98), US photographer, entrepreneur, and musician; born Linda Eastman ; wife of Paul McCartney. Well known for her photographs, especially of musicians, she promoted vegetarianism and animal rights.
--Examples--
--Word--
McClellan, George Brinton 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1826–85), US army officer; known as Little Mac. He became general in chief of the US Army 1861 during the Civil War. Although he repulsed Lee at Antietam 1862, he was removed from command due to a lack of military aggressiveness. The Democratic presidential candidate in 1864, he was defeated by the incumbent Abraham Lincoln. He later served as governor of New Jersey 1878–81.
--Examples--
--Word--
McCoy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The real thing; the genuine article.
--Examples--
‘the apparent fake turned out to be the real McCoy’
--Word--
McCormack, John 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1884–1945), US opera singer; born in Ireland. A tenor, he sang with various opera groups, including the Chicago and Metropolitan opera companies. He was also popular for his renderings of Irish folk songs.
--Examples--
--Word--
McCormick, Cyrus Hall 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1809–84), US inventor and industrialist. His patented reaper 1834 was the cornerstone of his harvesting machinery company, and the innovative deferred-payment plans and guarantees that he offered customers became a model in US consumerism.
--Examples--
--Word--
McCourt, Frank 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1930–2009), US writer. He wrote the award-winning Angela's Ashes (1996), a memoir about his impoverished childhood, some of which was spent in Ireland. Other works include 'Tis (1999), based on his later experiences.
--Examples--
--Word--
MCC 
--Type--

--Meanings--
Marylebone Cricket Club, founded in 1787, which has its headquarters at Lord's Cricket Ground in London. The tacitly accepted governing body of cricket until 1969, it continues to have primary responsibility for the game's laws.

McCullers, Carson 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1917–67), American writer; full name Lula Carson McCullers. Her work deals sensitively with loneliness and the plight of the eccentric. Notable works: The Heart is a Lonely Hunter (1940) and The Ballad of The Sad Cafe (1951).
--Examples--

McCullough, Colleen 
--Type--

--Meanings--
(1937–2015), Australian writer. Her novels include Tim (1974), The Thorn Birds (1977) The Song of Troy (1998), and Morgan's Run (2000).

McGonagall, William

McGovern, George 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1922–2012), US politician; full name George Stanley McGovern. A Democrat from South Dakota, he was a member of the US House of Representatives 1956–61 and of the US Senate 1963–81. He was the Democratic presidential candidate in 1972.
--Examples--

McGraw, John 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1873–1934), US baseball player and manager; nickname Little Napoleon ; full name John Joseph McGraw. He played mostly for the Baltimore Orioles during 1891–99 and then managed the New York Giants 1902–32. Baseball Hall of Fame (1937).
--Examples--

McKenna, Joseph

--Meanings--

McKenney 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In defensive play, a system of signals and discards by which a player indicates a desire for his or her partner to lead a particular suit. Usually attributive, frequently in "McKenney convention".
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--

McKinley, William

proper noun
--Meanings--
(1843–1901), American Republican statesman, 25th president of the US 1897–1901. He was assassinated by an anarchist.

McKinney 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in northeastern Texas, in the northeastern part of the Dallas–Fort Worth metropolitan area; population 121,211 (est. 2008). It is noted for its remarkable growth since 1990, when its population was 21,283.
--Examples--
--Word--
McKuen, Rod 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1933–2015), US poet, writer, and composer. Some of his poetry is collected in Stanyan Street and Other Sorrows (1966) and Listen to the Warm (1967). He also wrote many songs and movie scores.
--Examples--
--Word--
McLean, John 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1785–1861), US Supreme Court associate justice 1829–61. The US postmaster general 1823–29, he was appointed to the Court by President Jackson.
--Examples--
--Word--
McLeod gauge 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of mercury-in-glass manometer for the absolute measurement of low pressures, in which a known volume of the gas to be measured is compressed by the mercury into a small volume, and the resulting pressure is found from the height of the column of mercury it supports.
--Examples--
--Word--
McLuhan, Marshall 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1911–80), Canadian writer and thinker; full name Herbert Marshall McLuhan. He became famous in the 1960s for his phrase ‘the medium is the message’ and his argument that it is the characteristics of a particular medium rather than the information it disseminates which influence and control society.
--Examples--
--Word--
McMahon Line 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A line proposed by the British under Sir Henry McMahon at the Simla Conference (1913–14) as the frontier between Tibet and Assam, running along the Himalayas from the eastern border of Bhutan to the Brahmaputra River.
--Examples--
--Word--
Stanton, Edwin McMasters 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1814–69), US lawyer and public official. As secretary of war 1862–68 and briefly during 1868, he served under President Lincoln and later played a pivotal role in the impeachment proceedings against President Andrew Johnson. In 1869, President Grant appointed him to the US Supreme Court but died before taking office.
--Examples--
--Word--
McMinnville 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in northwestern Oregon, northwest of Salem; population 31,185 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
McNamara, Robert 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1916–2009), US businessman and public official; full name Robert Strange McNamara. He was secretary of the US Department of Defense 1961–68 during the Kennedy and Johnson administrations and president of the World Bank 1968–81.

(1834–1903), American painter and etcher; full name James Abbott McNeill Whistler. Notable works: Arrangement in Grey and Black: The Artist's Mother (portrait, 1872).

--Word--
me 
--Type--
pronoun
--Meanings--
Used by a speaker to refer to himself or herself as the object of a verb or preposition.
Used after the verb ‘to be’ and after ‘than’ or ‘as’
I or my.
To or for myself.
Used in exclamations.
--Examples--
‘do you understand me?’
‘wait for me!’
‘hi, it's me’
‘you have more than me’
‘I'll get me coat’
‘me can come an go as me please’
‘I've got me a job’
‘dear me!’
--Word--
me 
--Type--
pronoun
--Meanings--
Used by a speaker to refer to himself or herself as the object of a verb or preposition.
Used after the verb ‘to be’ and after ‘than’ or ‘as’
I or my.
To or for myself.
Used in exclamations.
--Examples--
‘do you understand me?’
‘wait for me!’
‘hi, it's me’
‘you have more than me’
‘I'll get me coat’
‘me can come an go as me please’
‘I've got me a job’
‘dear me!’
--Word--
mea culpa 
--Type--
exclamation
--Meanings--
Used as an acknowledgement of one's fault or error.
--Examples--
‘‘Well, whose fault was that?’ ‘Mea culpa!’ Frank said’
--Word--
meeching 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Skulking, furtive; mean, cheap, contemptible; poor, obsequious.
--Examples--
--Word--
meacon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A radio beacon used by the Royal Air Force in the Second World War (1939–45) to intercept and redirect enemy navigational signals.
--Examples--
--Word--
mead 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--

A meadow.

--Word--
Meade, George 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1815–72), US army officer; born in Spain to American parents; full name George Gordon Meade. A veteran of the Mexican War, he commanded the Army of the Potomac 1863–65 during the Civil War. He is most noted for his victory at Gettysburg in 1863.
--Examples--
--Word--
mead 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
An alcoholic drink of fermented honey and water.
A meadow.
--Examples--
‘the tavern stocks beer, cider, perry, and mead’
--Word--

--Meanings--

--Word--
meadow 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A piece of grassland, especially one used for hay.
A piece of low ground near a river.
--Examples--
‘a meadow ready for cutting’
‘143 acres of meadow and pasture’
‘a pleasant campsite in a meadow, complete with sparkling stream’
--Word--
meadow brown 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A common Eurasian butterfly that has brown and orange wings with small eyespots.
--Examples--
--Word--
meadowed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Provided with meadows (chiefly as the second element of a compound, as "well-meadowed").
--Examples--
--Word--

noun
--Meanings--
Land used or suitable for the cultivation of grass.

Meadowlands 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An entertainment and sports complex in northeastern New Jersey, in the meadows of the Hackensack River, northwest of New York City.

--Word--
meagre 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of something provided or available) lacking in quantity or quality.
(of a person or animal) lean; thin.
A large predatory marine fish of the drum family, found in the Mediterranean, eastern Atlantic, and south-western Indian Ocean. It is an important food fish in southern Africa.
--Examples--
‘they were forced to supplement their meagre earnings’
‘a meagre diet of bread and beans’
‘a tall, meagre man’

--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Type--
noun

--Examples--
‘job satisfaction eclipses the meagreness of income’

--Word--
meak 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An implement with a long handle and crooked iron or blade used to pull up or cut down peas, bracken, reeds, etc. Compare pea-make, "pease-meak".

mealy 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling or containing meal.
(of a person's complexion, an animal's muzzle, or a bird's plumage) pale.
(of part of a plant or fungus) covered with granules resembling meal.
--Examples--

‘mealy puddings’
‘in its dark colour and mealy muzzle the Exmoor pony resembles the tarpan’
‘mealy leaves’

--Word--
mealy-mouth 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The mouth, voice, or manner of speaking of a mealy-mouthed person.
A mealy-mouthed person.
British regional. Any of several birds, as the willow warbler, Phylloscopus trochilus, or the whitethroat, Sylvia communis.
And with object. To speak indecisively (about); to equivocate, especially due to timidity or fear.
--Examples--
--Word--
mealy-mouthed 
--Type--

--Meanings--
Afraid to speak frankly or straightforwardly.
--Examples--
‘mealy-mouthed excuses’

--Word--
mean 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Intend to convey or refer to (a particular thing); signify.
(of a word) have (something) as its signification in the same language or its equivalent in another language.
Genuinely intend to express (something)
Be of a specified degree of importance to (someone)
Intend (something) to occur or be the case.
Be supposed to do something.
Design or destine for a particular purpose.
Have something as a motive or explanation in saying or doing.
Be generally considered to be.
Have as a consequence or result.
Necessarily or usually entail or involve.
--Examples--
‘I don't know what you mean’
‘he was asked to clarify what his remarks meant’
‘I meant you, not Jones’
‘its name means ‘painted rock’ in Cherokee’
‘when she said that she meant it’
‘animals have always meant more to him than people’
‘they mean no harm’
‘it was meant to be a secret’
‘we were meant to go over yesterday’
‘the jacket was meant for a much larger person’
‘what do you mean by leaving me out here in the cold?’
‘this one's meant to be priceless’
‘the proposals are likely to mean another hundred closures’
‘heavy rain meant that the pitch was waterlogged’
‘coal stoves mean a lot of smoke’
--Word--
acting 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The art or occupation of performing fictional roles in plays, films, or television.
Temporarily doing the duties of another person.
--Examples--
‘she studied acting in New York’
‘I'd prefer him not to go into acting as it's such an insecure business’
‘an acting career’
‘the acting supervisor’

--Word--
meander 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a river or road) follow a winding course.
Wander at random.
(of language, thought, etc.) proceed aimlessly or with little purpose.
A winding curve or bend of a river or road.
An indirect or aimless journey.
An ornamental pattern of winding or interlocking lines.
--Examples--
‘a river that meandered gently through a meadow’
‘kids meandered in and out’
‘a stylish offbeat thriller which occasionally meanders’
‘the river flows in sweeping meanders’
‘a leisurely meander round the twisting coastline road’

--Word--
meandering 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Following a winding course.
Proceeding in a convoluted or undirected fashion.
An act of following a winding course.
An act of wandering in a leisurely or aimless manner.
Convoluted or undirected thought or language.
--Examples--
‘meandering rivers flow at vastly different rates’
‘a brilliant sample of meandering discourse’
‘a florid and rather meandering melody’
‘ox-bow lagoons left by the river's meanderings’
‘in the course of his meanderings through the city’
‘he has a penchant for obscure verbal meanderings’

--Meanings--

dressed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of food, especially poultry or shellfish) cleaned and prepared for cooking or eating.

(of stone) having had the surface smoothed.
(of an artificial fly) made for use in fishing.

‘a fine frontage in red brick with dressed white stone on the facings’
‘dressed Cotswold stone’
‘a dressed wet fly’

meanness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Lack of generosity; miserliness.
Unkindness, spitefulness, or unfairness.
Aggressive character; viciousness.
Lack of quality or attractiveness; shabbiness.
--Examples--
‘all the hatred and meanness, despair and sorrow surrounding us’
‘he is also callous, with a streak of meanness’
‘the meanness of that existence’

--Word--
meaning 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
What is meant by a word, text, concept, or action.
Implied or explicit significance.
Important or worthwhile quality; purpose.
Intended to communicate something that is not directly expressed.
--Examples--
‘the meaning of the Hindu word is ‘breakthrough, release’’
‘the meaning of life’
‘he gave me a look full of meaning’
‘this can lead to new meaning in the life of older people’
‘she gave Gabriel a meaning look’
--Word--
meaningful 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having meaning.
Serious, important, or worthwhile.
Communicating something that is not directly expressed.
Having a recognizable function in a logical language or other sign system.
--Examples--
‘meaningful elements in a language’
‘words likely to be meaningful to pupils’
‘the new structure would bring meaningful savings’
‘meaningful glances and repressed passion’
--Word--
meaningfully 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that has meaning.
In a serious, important, or worthwhile manner.
In a way that communicates something without directly expressing it.
--Examples--
‘the parts, however entertaining individually, must cohere meaningfully’
‘even isolated communities can contribute meaningfully to national development’
‘the right to participate meaningfully in the decisions that affect one's life’
‘when he reports to work, his supervisor stares meaningfully at the clock’

--Word--
means 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
An action or system by which a result is achieved; a method.
Financial resources; income.
Substantial resources; wealth.
Resources; capability.
--Examples--
‘technology seen as a means to bring about emancipation’
‘resolving disputes by peaceful means’

--Word--
mean tone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(As two words or hyphenated.) Either of the two equal intervals of a whole tone into which a major third may be divided, used as a basis for tuning keyboard instruments before the general adoption of equal temperament.
--Examples--

--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In the intervening period of time.
At the same time.
On the other hand.
--Examples--
‘meanwhile, I will give you a prescription for some pills’

‘he has said little, meanwhile, about how he plans to live his life’

--Word--
measure 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Ascertain the size, amount, or degree of (something) by using an instrument or device marked in standard units.
Be of (a specified size or degree)
Ascertain the size and proportions of (someone) in order to make or provide clothes for them.
Take an exact quantity of something.
Assess the importance, effect, or value of (something)
Judge someone or something by comparison with (a certain standard)
Reach the required or expected standard.
Scrutinize someone in order to form an assessment of them.
Travel over (a certain distance or area)
A plan or course of action taken to achieve a particular purpose.
A legislative bill.
A standard unit used to express the size, amount, or degree of something.
A system or scale of units expressing size, amount, or degree of something.
A standard quantity or amount.
A container of standard capacity used for taking fixed amounts of a substance.
A graduated rod or tape used for ascertaining the size of something.
A quantity contained in another an exact number of times; a divisor.
The width of a full line of type or print, typically expressed in picas.
A certain quantity or degree of something.
An indication of the degree, extent, or quality of something.
The rhythm of a piece of poetry or a piece of music.
A particular metrical unit or group.
A bar of music or the time of a piece of music.
A dance, typically one that is stately.
A group of rock strata.
--Examples--
‘the amount of water collected is measured in pints’
‘the fabric measures 137 cm wide’
‘he will be measured for his team blazer next week’
‘she helped to measure out the ingredients’
‘it is hard to measure teaching ability’
‘she did not need to measure herself against some ideal’
‘I'm afraid we didn't measure up to the standards they set’
‘the two shook hands and silently measured each other up’
‘we must measure twenty miles today’
‘cost-cutting measures’
‘children were evacuated as a precautionary measure’
‘the Senate passed the measure by a 48–30 vote’
‘a furlong is an obsolete measure of length’
‘tables of weights and measures’
‘the dimensions were in imperial measure’
‘heavy drinking may be five measures of spirits per day’
‘gifts have included silver measures from a whisky company’
‘most schools had only metric measures available’
‘the states retain a large measure of independence’
‘his resignation is a measure of how angry he is’
‘measures of two or three syllables are more frequent in English prose’
‘now tread we a measure!’

--Word--
mechanical 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Operated by a machine or machinery.
Relating to machines or machinery.
(of an action) done without thought or spontaneity; automatic.
Relating to physical forces or motion; physical.
(of a theory) explaining phenomena in terms only of physical processes.
Relating to mechanics as a science.
Relating to the exclusive legal right to reproduce a particular recorded version of a song or piece of music.
The working parts of a vehicle.
A manual worker.
--Examples--
‘a mechanical device’
‘the helicopters are prone to mechanical failure’
‘she stopped the mechanical brushing of her hair’
‘the smoothness was the result of mechanical abrasion’
‘mechanical copyright’
‘mechanical royalties’
‘a major overhaul of the mechanicals’
‘rude mechanicals’

mechanics 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
The branch of applied mathematics dealing with motion and forces producing motion.
The practical study of machinery.
The machinery or working parts of something.
The way in which something is done or operated.
--Examples--
‘the laws of mechanics and electricity predicted that the electrons would spiral inward until they collided with the nucleus’
‘skills like carpentry, motor mechanics, and electrics’
‘he looks at the mechanics of a car before the bodywork’
‘the mechanics of cello playing’

--Word--
mechanism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A system of parts working together in a machine; a piece of machinery.
A natural or established process by which something takes place or is brought about.
A contrivance in the plot of a literary work.
The doctrine that all natural phenomena, including life and thought, can be explained with reference to mechanical or chemical processes.
--Examples--
‘a third motor powers the tape eject mechanism’
‘the immune system's mechanism for detecting pathogens’
‘his Irma La Douce is a musical based on the farce mechanism’

--Meanings--
A system of parts working together in a machine; a piece of machinery.
A natural or established process by which something takes place or is brought about.
A contrivance in the plot of a literary work.
The doctrine that all natural phenomena, including life and thought, can be explained with reference to mechanical or chemical processes.
--Examples--
‘a third motor powers the tape eject mechanism’
‘the immune system's mechanism for detecting pathogens’
‘his Irma La Douce is a musical based on the farce mechanism’
--Word--
mechanist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who believes in the doctrine of mechanism.
A person skilled in the design or construction of machinery.
--Examples--
--Word--
mechanistic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to theories which explain phenomena in purely physical or deterministic terms.
Determined by physical processes alone.
--Examples--
‘a mechanistic interpretation of nature’
‘he insisted that animals were entirely mechanistic’

adverb
--Meanings--

--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Introduce machines or automatic devices into (a process or place)

‘public virtue cannot be mechanized or formulated’

mechanochemistry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The branch of science that deals with the relation between mechanical and chemical phenomena and the interconversion of these forms of energy.

--Word--
mechanology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the terminology of T. De Quincey: (the study of) the mechanisms of literary style. Compare organology. Now historical.
The science of machines and mechanisms. Formerly also: a treatise dealing with this.
--Examples--

Mechitarist 
--Type--
noun, adjective

A member of a congregation of Uniate Armenian monks devoted especially to the study and publication of texts in Armenian, founded by Mechitar in 1701.

--Meanings--

--Word--
mechoacan 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The whitish tuberous root of a kind of morning glory, Ipomoea macrorhiza (I. jalapa), native to Mexico and the southern United States, which was formerly much used in medicine as a purgative; the plant itself. Also called white jalap. With distinguishing word or phrase: any of several other kinds of purgative root.
US. The wild potato vine, Ipomoea pandurata.

meclozine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A piperazine derivative, C₂₅H₂₇ClN₂, with antihistamine properties, used mainly as an anti-emetic, especially in preventing motion sickness. [Meclozine is the International Nonproprietary Name and British Approved Name; meclizine is the name in the Pharmacopeia of the U.S.A.]

meconic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A crystalline cyclic acid, C₇H₄O₇, a characteristic constituent of opium that is used as an indicator of its presence; 3-hydroxy-γ-pyrone-2,6-dicarboxylic acid.

meconine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A crystalline aromatic lactone, C₁₀H₁₀O₄, that is one of the constituents of opium, and is also found in the root of goldenseal, Hydrastis canadensis; dimethoxyphthalide.

bush 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A shrub or clump of shrubs with stems of moderate length.
A bunch of ivy as a vintner's sign.
(especially in Australia and Africa) wild or uncultivated country.
Vegetation growing in the bush.
Indigenous rainforest.
Uncivilized or primitive.
A luxuriant growth of thick hair or fur.
A woman's pubic hair.
Spread out into a thick clump.

‘they have to spend a night camping in the bush’
‘the lowland country was covered in thick bush’

Medan 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in Indonesia, in north-eastern Sumatra near the Strait of Malacca; population 1,772,800 (est. 2009). It was established as a trading post by the Dutch in 1682 and became a leading commercial centre.
--Examples--
--Word--
Medawar, Sir Peter 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1915–87), English immunologist; full name Sir Peter Brian Medawar. He studied the biology of tissue transplantation, and showed that the rejection of grafts was the result of an immune mechanism. Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine (1960).
--Examples--

Mede 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of an Indo-European people who inhabited ancient Media, establishing an extensive empire during the 7th century BC.
--Examples--
--Word--
Medea 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A sorceress, daughter of Aeetes king of Colchis, who helped Jason to obtain the Golden Fleece and then married him. When Jason deserted her for Creusa, the daughter of King Creon of Corinth, she took revenge by killing Creon, Creusa, and her own children, and fled to Athens.
--Examples--
--Word--
Medellín 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in eastern Colombia, the second largest city in the country; population 2,219,861 (2005). A major centre of coffee production, it has in recent years gained a reputation as the hub of the Colombian drug trade.
--Examples--
--Word--
medevac 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The evacuation of military or other casualties to hospital in a helicopter or aeroplane.
Transport (someone) to hospital in a helicopter or aeroplane.
--Examples--
‘we radioed Pleiku and asked for medevac’
‘three big medevac choppers’
‘I was medevacked out of Freetown’

media

noun, noun, proper noun
--Meanings--

An ancient region of Asia to the south-west of the Caspian Sea, corresponding approximately to present-day Azerbaijan, north-western Iran, and north-eastern Iraq. Originally inhabited by the Medes, the region was conquered in 550 BC by Cyrus the Great of Persia.

--Word--
median 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Denoting or relating to a value or quantity lying at the midpoint of a frequency distribution of observed values or quantities, such that there is an equal probability of falling above or below it.
Denoting the middle term (or mean of the middle two terms) of a series arranged in order of magnitude. For example, the median number of the series 55, 62, 76, 85, 93 is 76.
Situated in the middle, especially of the body.
The median value of a range of values.
The strip of land between the carriageways of a motorway or other major road; a central reservation.
A straight line drawn from any vertex of a triangle to the middle of the opposite side.
Relating to Media, an ancient region of Asia to the south-west of the Caspian Sea.
--Examples--
‘the median duration of this treatment was four months’
‘the median part of the sternum’
‘acreages ranged from one to fifty-two with a median of twenty-four’
‘the Median empire’

median 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Denoting or relating to a value or quantity lying at the midpoint of a frequency distribution of observed values or quantities, such that there is an equal probability of falling above or below it.
Denoting the middle term (or mean of the middle two terms) of a series arranged in order of magnitude. For example, the median number of the series 55, 62, 76, 85, 93 is 76.
Situated in the middle, especially of the body.
The median value of a range of values.
The strip of land between the carriageways of a motorway or other major road; a central reservation.
A straight line drawn from any vertex of a triangle to the middle of the opposite side.
Relating to Media, an ancient region of Asia to the south-west of the Caspian Sea.
--Examples--
‘the median duration of this treatment was four months’
‘the median part of the sternum’
‘acreages ranged from one to fifty-two with a median of twenty-four’
‘the Median empire’
