--Word--
mediate 
--Type--
verb, adjective
--Meanings--
Intervene in a dispute in order to bring about an agreement or reconciliation.
Intervene in (a dispute) to bring about an agreement.
Bring about (an agreement or solution) by intervening in a dispute.
Bring about (a result such as a physiological effect)
Be a means of conveying.
Form a link between.
Connected indirectly through another person or thing; involving an intermediate agency.
--Examples--
‘Wilson attempted to mediate between the powers to end the war’
‘set up a tribunal to arbitrate and mediate disputes’
‘efforts to mediate a peaceful resolution of the conflict’
‘the right hemisphere plays an important role in mediating tactile perception of direction’
‘this important ministry of mediating the power of the word’
‘structures which mediate gender divisions’
‘public law institutions are a type of mediate state administration’
--Word--
mediate 
--Type--
verb, adjective
--Meanings--
Intervene in a dispute in order to bring about an agreement or reconciliation.
Intervene in (a dispute) to bring about an agreement.
Bring about (an agreement or solution) by intervening in a dispute.
Bring about (a result such as a physiological effect)
Be a means of conveying.
Form a link between.
Connected indirectly through another person or thing; involving an intermediate agency.
--Examples--
‘Wilson attempted to mediate between the powers to end the war’
‘set up a tribunal to arbitrate and mediate disputes’
‘efforts to mediate a peaceful resolution of the conflict’
‘the right hemisphere plays an important role in mediating tactile perception of direction’
‘this important ministry of mediating the power of the word’
‘structures which mediate gender divisions’
‘public law institutions are a type of mediate state administration’
--Word--
mediately 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
mediateness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being mediate or mediated; indirectness, lack of immediacy.

--Word--
mediatization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In Germany under the Holy Roman Empire: the action of reducing a prince or state in position or power; the condition of being mediatized. Now historical.
More generally: reduction in power or effect by the interposition of a mediating agent, or as a function of a medium of transmission; the action or process of making something indirect in its application.
Specifically. The action or process whereby the mass media comes to control or affect something.
--Examples--
--Word--
mediatize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
In Germany under the Holy Roman Empire: to reduce (a prince or state) from the position of an immediate vassal of the Empire to that of a mediate vassal (now historical). Hence: to annex (a state) leaving the former government or ruler a title and (usually) some authority; also in extended use.
More generally: to reduce (something) in power or effect by interposing a mediating agent. In recent use also: to render subject to interpretation or exploitation by the mass media; (of the mass media) to control or otherwise affect (an event, etc.).
--Examples--
--Word--
mediatized 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a prince or state: reduced in power or position. Compare mediatize. Now historical.
Mediated; reduced in power or effect by the interposition of a mediating agent. By extension: rendered subject to the controlling influence of the mass media.
--Examples--
--Word--
mediative 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That mediates, that has the quality of mediating.
--Examples--

--Word--
Medicean 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the Medici family.
--Examples--
--Word--
Medici 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A powerful Italian family of bankers and merchants whose members effectively ruled Florence for much of the 15th century and from 1569 were grand dukes of Tuscany. Cosimo and Lorenzo de' Medici were notable rulers and patrons of the arts in Florence; the family also provided four popes (including Leo X) and two queens of France (Catherine de' Medici and Marie de Médicis).

--Word--
medicine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The science or practice of the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of disease (in technical use often taken to exclude surgery)
A drug or other preparation for the treatment or prevention of disease.
(especially among some North American Indian peoples) a spell, charm, or fetish believed to have healing, protective, or other power.
--Examples--
‘he made distinguished contributions to pathology and medicine’
‘the remarkable achievements of modern medicine’
‘give her some medicine’
‘your doctor will be able to prescribe medicines’
‘Fleur was murdering him by use of bad medicine’

medimnus

--Examples--
--Word--
medin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A coin of low denomination formerly used in Egypt and the Ottoman Empire: (originally) a silver half-dirham first issued in 1415 by the Mamluk Sultan al-Mu'ayyad Shaykh (at an initial weight of around 1.3 grams, but successively reduced in weight and silver content after the Ottoman conquest of Egypt in 1517); (later) a copper coin current in Egypt, Syria, etc., of approx. 6 grams, and valued at 1/40 of a piastre, or 1/20 of a penny, corresponding to the Turkish para.
--Examples--
--Word--
medina 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
The old walled part of a North African town.
A city in western Saudi Arabia, around an oasis some 320 km (200 miles) north of Mecca; population 1,010,000 (est. 2007).

--Word--
meditate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Focus one's mind for a period of time, in silence or with the aid of chanting, for religious or spiritual purposes or as a method of relaxation.
Think deeply about (something)
Plan mentally; consider.
--Examples--
‘I set aside time every day to write and meditate’
‘it was here that the monk spent much of the day reading and meditating on Scripture’
‘he went off to meditate on the new idea’
‘they had suffered severely, and they began to meditate retreat’

--Word--
Mediterranean 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or characteristic of the Mediterranean Sea, the countries bordering it, or their inhabitants.
Relating to or denoting a dark-complexioned human physical type found in some Mediterranean countries.
The Mediterranean Sea or the countries bordering it.
A native of a Mediterranean country.
--Examples--
‘a leisurely Mediterranean cruise’
‘our temperatures are Mediterranean’
‘she had curly hair and warm Mediterranean colouring’
‘a permanent American naval presence in the Mediterranean’
‘feta is made throughout the eastern Mediterranean’
‘an admiring audience of Mediterraneans’

--Examples--
--Word--
medium 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An agency or means of doing something.
A means by which something is communicated or expressed.
The intervening substance through which sensory impressions are conveyed or physical forces are transmitted.
The substance in which an organism lives or is cultured.
A liquid (e.g. oil or water) with which pigments are mixed, with a binder, to make paint.
A particular form of storage material for computer files, such as magnetic tape or discs.
The material or form used by an artist, composer, or writer.
A person claiming to be in contact with the spirits of the dead and to communicate between the dead and the living.
The middle quality or state between two extremes; a reasonable balance.
About halfway between two extremes of size or another quality; average.
--Examples--
‘using the latest technology as a medium for job creation’
‘their primitive valuables acted as a medium of exchange’
‘here the Welsh language is the medium of instruction’
‘radio communication needs no physical medium between the two stations’
‘these cells are grown in a nutrient-rich medium’
‘oil paint is the most popular medium for glazing’
‘there is a medium between being modest and boastful’
‘John is six feet tall, of medium build’
‘plan for the medium term’
‘medium-length hair’
--Word--

--Word--
medium 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An agency or means of doing something.
A means by which something is communicated or expressed.
The intervening substance through which sensory impressions are conveyed or physical forces are transmitted.
The substance in which an organism lives or is cultured.
A liquid (e.g. oil or water) with which pigments are mixed, with a binder, to make paint.
A particular form of storage material for computer files, such as magnetic tape or discs.
The material or form used by an artist, composer, or writer.
A person claiming to be in contact with the spirits of the dead and to communicate between the dead and the living.
The middle quality or state between two extremes; a reasonable balance.
About halfway between two extremes of size or another quality; average.
--Examples--
‘using the latest technology as a medium for job creation’
‘their primitive valuables acted as a medium of exchange’
‘here the Welsh language is the medium of instruction’
‘radio communication needs no physical medium between the two stations’
‘these cells are grown in a nutrient-rich medium’
‘oil paint is the most popular medium for glazing’
‘there is a medium between being modest and boastful’
‘John is six feet tall, of medium build’
‘plan for the medium term’
‘medium-length hair’

--Meanings--
Moderately; to a medium or average extent.

medley 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A varied mixture of people or things.
A collection of songs or other musical items performed as a continuous piece.
A swimming race in which contestants swim sections in different strokes, either individually or in relay teams.
Mixed; motley.
Make a medley of; intermix.
--Examples--
‘an interesting medley of flavours’
‘a medley of Beatles songs’
‘the 400 m individual medley’
‘the junior 4x50 m medley relay’
‘a medley range of vague and variable impressions’
‘the medlied establishments of the native chiefs’

medulla 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The inner region of an organ or tissue, especially when it is distinct from the outer region or cortex (as in a kidney, an adrenal gland, or hair)
The soft internal tissue or pith of a plant.
--Examples--

‘the main bulk of the potato tuber is pith or medulla’
--Word--
medullary 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

Relating to the continuation of the spinal cord within the skull.

--Examples--

‘bone marrow in the medullary cavity’
‘lateral medullary strokes’
‘the medullary sheath is an essential organ in the early age of a shoot’
--Word--

--Type--
noun

The inner region of an organ or tissue, especially when it is distinct from the outer region or cortex (as in a kidney, an adrenal gland, or hair)
The soft internal tissue or pith of a plant.

‘the main bulk of the potato tuber is pith or medulla’

--Word--
medullated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Histology and Physiology. Of a nerve or nerve fibre: myelinated.
Botany. Especially of a plant stem or stele: having a distinct medulla or pith.
Of a hair: having a medulla.
--Examples--
--Word--
medullation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Histology and Physiology= "myelination". Compare "medulla". Now rare.
Botany. The presence or development of a medulla in a stele; the condition of having such a medulla.
The presence of a medulla in a hair or feather; the nature or size of the medulla in hairs; the condition of having medullated hairs; the degree to which the hairs (of an animal, type of wool, etc.) are medullated.
--Examples--

medullitis

noun
--Meanings--

medullose

adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
medusa 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A free-swimming sexual form of a coelenterate such as a jellyfish, typically having an umbrella-shaped body with stinging tentacles around the edge. In some species, medusae are a phase in the life cycle which alternates with a polypoid phase.
A jellyfish.
The only mortal gorgon, whom Perseus killed by cutting off her head.
--Examples--

Meerut 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in northern India, in Uttar Pradesh north-east of Delhi; population 1,365,100 (est. 2009). It was the scene in May 1857 of the first uprising against the British in the Indian Mutiny.

--Word--
meet 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Arrange or happen to come into the presence or company of (someone)
Make the acquaintance of (someone) for the first time.
(of a group of people) assemble for a purpose.
Have a meeting with (someone)
Go to a place and wait there for (a person or their means of transport) to arrive.
Come together as opponents in a competition.
Encounter or experience (a particular situation or attitude)
Have (a particular reaction) to.
Receive (a particular reaction)
Touch; join.
Fulfil or satisfy (a need, requirement, or condition)
Pay (a financial claim or obligation)
A gathering of riders and hounds before a hunt begins.
An organized event at which a number of races or other athletic contests are held.
A meeting, typically one with an illicit purpose.
--Examples--
‘a week later I met him in the street’
‘we met for lunch’
‘they arranged to meet up that afternoon’
‘she took Paul to meet her parents’
‘we met at an office party’
‘the committee meets once a fortnight’
‘he met with the president on September 16’
‘Stuart met us off the boat’
‘in the final group match, England will meet the Australians’
‘the teams will meet in the European Cup final at Wembley’
‘he met his death in 1946’
‘we met with a slight setback’
‘the announcement was met with widespread protests’
‘I'm sorry if it doesn't meet with your approval’
‘icebergs are created when glaciers meet the sea’
‘the curtains failed to meet in the middle’
‘our eyes met across the table’
‘this policy is doing nothing to meet the needs of women’
‘all your household expenses will still have to be met’
‘she fell from her horse during a weekend meet’
‘major meets such as national championships’
‘the meet with Frank is on for 10 o'clock’

megakaryocyte 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A giant cell with a large, irregularly lobed, polyploid nucleus, which occurs in small numbers in normal bone marrow and gives rise to blood platelets by fragmentation of its cytoplasm.

--Word--
megalithic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting prehistoric monuments made of or containing large stones.
Relating to or denoting prehistoric cultures characterized by the erection of monuments made of large stones.
Massive or monolithic.
--Examples--

‘the resident Megalithic peoples’
‘megalithic corporations’
‘the megalithic prison system’

megalops 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Now in form Megalops. A genus of marine fishes including the Indo-Pacific or ox-eye tarpon, Megalops cyprinoides, and the Atlantic tarpon, M. atlanticus (family Megalopidae).
A free-swimming larval stage in the developments of crabs, following the zoea stage and having the adult number of trunk segments and legs, and large eyes; a crab in this stage.
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--

Meghalaya 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A small state in the extreme north-east of India, on the northern border of Bangladesh; capital, Shillong. It was created in 1970 from part of Assam.
--Examples--
--Word--
Megiddo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient city of north-western Palestine, situated to the south-east of Haifa in present-day Israel. Its commanding location made the city the scene of many early battles, and from its name the word Armageddon (‘hill of Megiddo’) is derived. It was the scene in 1918 of the defeat of Turkish forces by the British under General Allenby.
--Examples--
--Word--
Megillah 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A book of the Hebrew scriptures (the Song of Solomon, Ruth, Lamentations, Ecclesiastes, and Esther) appointed to be read on certain Jewish notable days, especially the Book of Esther, read at the festival of Purim.
Something in its entirety, especially a complicated set of arrangements or a long-winded story.
--Examples--
‘you usually get the whole megillah, complete to the last screw’

Mehta, Zubin 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1936), Indian symphony conductor. Often heading more than one orchestra at the same time, he has been music director of the Montreal Symphony Orchestra 1961–67, the Los Angeles Philharmonic 1962–78, the New York Philharmonic 1978–91, the Israel Philharmonic since 1977 (appointed for life), and the Bavarian State Opera 1998–2006.
--Examples--
--Word--

noun
--Meanings--
In South Asia: a house-sweeper, a scavenger; the lowest-ranking house-servant.
(The title of) the ruler of the former kingdom of Chitral in the Hindu Kush (annexed to Pakistan in 1974).
--Examples--

--Word--
Schlesinger, Arthur Meier 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
(1888–1965), US historian. He wrote The Colonial Merchants and the American Revolution, 1763–1776 (1918), New Viewpoints in American History (1922), and The American Reformer (1950).
(1917–2007), US historian; full name Arthur Meier Schlesinger, Jr.. A professor at Harvard University 1946–61 and advisor to Presidents Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson, he wrote The Age of Jackson (1945), The Age of Roosevelt in three volumes (1957–60), A Thousand Days: John F. Kennedy in the White House (1965), and The Imperial Presidency (1973).
--Examples--
--Word--
Meyer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In full "Meyer lemon". A small, relatively hardy type of lemon (variously regarded as a species, Citrus meyeri, or a cultivar of C. limon), originally discovered in China but now widely cultivated commercially and as a garden plant.
--Examples--
--Word--
Meyerbeer, Giacomo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1791–1864), German composer; born Jakob Liebmann Beer. He settled in Paris, establishing himself as a leading exponent of French grand opera with a series of works including Les Huguenots (1836).
--Examples--
--Word--
Meyerhof, Otto Fritz 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1884–1951), German-born American biochemist. He worked on the biochemical processes involved in muscle action and provided the basis for understanding the process by which glucose is broken down to provide energy. Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine (1922).
--Examples--
--Word--
meyerhofferite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hydrated calcium borate crystallizing in the triclinic system, occurring chiefly as colourless to white prismatic crystals or fibrous masses as an alteration product of inyoite.

--Type--

--Meanings--

meiosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of cell division that results in four daughter cells each with half the number of chromosomes of the parent cell, as in the production of gametes and plant spores.
--Examples--
‘the sporophytes of green algae form spores only by meiosis’
‘no recombinants were observed in over 100 meioses’

Meir, Golda 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1898–1978), Israeli stateswoman, prime minister 1969–74; born Goldie Mabovich. Born in Ukraine, she emigrated to the US in 1907 and in 1921 to Palestine. Following Israel's independence she served in ministerial posts from 1949 to 1966 before being elected prime minister.

Meissen 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
A city in eastern Germany, in Saxony, on the River Elbe north-west of Dresden; population 28,100 (est. 2006). It is famous for its porcelain.
Fine hard-paste porcelain produced in Meissen since 1710, in Britain often called Dresden china.
--Examples--
--Word--
Meistersinger 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of one of the guilds of German lyric poets and musicians which flourished from the 12th to 17th century, known for their elaborate technique.
--Examples--
--Word--
Meistersinger 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of one of the guilds of German lyric poets and musicians which flourished from the 12th to 17th century, known for their elaborate technique.
--Examples--
--Word--
meith 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly Orkney and Shetland. A land feature used to take bearings at sea, frequently in order to demarcate fishing grounds; a seamark. Also (in extended use): any mark or distinguishing feature facilitating orientation on land or at sea.
A bearing, course, direction; frequently with take. Also: a measurement taken from a mark (rare). Chiefly in plural (occasionally with singular concord).
Figurative. A distinctive mark or sign; an indication; a point of reference.
--Examples--
--Word--
Meithei 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a people inhabiting the state of Manipur in Assam, north-east India; (more generally) a Manipuri.
The Tibeto-Burman language of the Meithei; Manipuri.
--Examples--
--Word--
Meitner, Lise 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1878–1968), Austrian-born Swedish physicist. She worked in the field of radiochemistry with Otto Hahn, discovering the element protactinium with him in 1917. She also formulated the concept of nuclear fission with her nephew Otto Frisch.
--Examples--
--Word--
meizoseismal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the points of maximum disturbance in an earthquake; specifically designating a region that has undergone maximum disturbance in an earthquake. Also as noun (rare).
--Examples--
--Word--
Mechitarist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a congregation of Uniate Armenian monks devoted especially to the study and publication of texts in Armenian, founded by Mechitar in 1701.
Of or belonging to the Mechitarists.
--Examples--
--Word--
Meknès 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in northern Morocco, in the Middle Atlas mountains west of Fez; population 713,609 (2004). In the 17th century it was the residence of the Moroccan sultan.
--Examples--
--Word--
mekometer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Also Mekometer. An instrument for the accurate measurement of distances by means of reflected polarized light.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mekong 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river of SE Asia which rises in Tibet and flows south-east and south for 4,180 km (2,600 miles) through southern China, Laos, Cambodia, and Vietnam to its extensive delta on the South China Sea. It forms the boundary between Laos and its western neighbours Burma and Thailand.
--Examples--
--Word--
mel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A unit of subjective pitch, on a scale that is proportional to the pitch of a sound, the pitch of a note of frequency 1000 Hz being equal to 1000 mels.

Melaka 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state of Malaysia, on the south-western coast of the Malay Peninsula, on the Strait of Malacca.
The capital and chief port of Melaka; population 194,400 (est. 2009). Conquered by the Portuguese in 1511, it played an important role in the development of trade between Europe and the East, especially China.

melancholy 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A feeling of pensive sadness, typically with no obvious cause.
Having a feeling of melancholy; sad and pensive.
Causing or expressing sadness; depressing.
--Examples--
‘an air of melancholy surrounded him’
‘he had an ability to convey a sense of deep melancholy and yearning through much of his work’
‘at the centre of his music lies a profound melancholy and nostalgia’
‘she felt a little melancholy’
‘a dark, melancholy young man with deep-set eyes’
‘the melancholy tone of her writing’

‘he was treated for melancholia and insomnia’

Melanchthon, Philipp 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1497–1560), German Protestant reformer; born Philipp Schwarzerd. He succeeded Luther as leader of the Reformation movement in Germany in 1521 and drew up the Augsburg Confession (1530).
--Examples--

Melanesia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A region of the western Pacific to the south of Micronesia and west of Polynesia. It contains the Bismarck Archipelago, the Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, New Caledonia, Fiji, and the intervening islands.
--Examples--
--Word--
Melanesian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Melanesia, its peoples, or their languages.
A native or inhabitant of any of the islands of Melanesia.
Any of the languages of Melanesia, mostly Austronesian languages related to Malay but also including Neo-Melanesian (or Tok Pisin), an English-based pidgin.

Klein, Melanie 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1882–1960), Austrian-born psychoanalyst. Klein was the first psychologist to specialize in the psychoanalysis of small children. Her discoveries led to an understanding of the more severe mental disorders found in children.

melanin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dark brown to black pigment occurring in the hair, skin, and iris of the eye in people and animals. It is responsible for tanning of skin exposed to sunlight.

melanized 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a person: having a dark skin colour. rare.
Biology. Characterized by the production or accumulation of melanin; darkened as a result of this.
Soil Science. Of soils: very dark brown or black owing to the presence of incorporated humus.

melanose 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant disease characterized by blackening of tissue; specifically (a) a disease of grapevines caused by the fungus Septoria ampelina, which causes a blackish-brown leaf spot; (b) a disease of citrus trees caused by the fungus Diaporthe citri, which causes fruit rot, and blackish-brown spots on twigs, leaves, and fruit.

noun
--Meanings--

Melbourne 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Victoria, south-eastern Australia, on the Bass Strait opposite Tasmania; population 3,892,419 (2008). It became state capital in 1851 and was capital of Australia from 1901 until 1927. It is a major port and the second largest city in Australia.

meld 
--Type--
verb, noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Blend; combine.
A thing formed by melding; a combination.
(in rummy, canasta, and other card games) lay down or declare (a combination of cards) in order to score points.
A completed set or run of cards in rummy, canasta, and other card games.
--Examples--
‘Australia's winemakers have melded modern science with traditional art’
‘the nylon bristles shrivel and meld together’
‘a meld of many contributions’
‘a player has melded four kings’
‘his meld was poor and he lost’

noun
--Meanings--
In Polynesia, especially Hawaii: a chant with a unique vocal melody, composed and performed by a professional chanter, often to commemorate a significant cultural event or to praise a leader.
--Examples--
--Word--
Meletian 
--Type--
noun, adjective, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a schismatic Church founded in Egypt in the early 4th cent. by Melitius, bishop of Lycopolis, who objected to the return to the church of Christians who had temporarily renounced their faith under persecution.
Of or relating to this sect.
A member of a party in the Church of Antioch comprising those Orthodox Christians who continued to accept the authority of St Meletius (consecrated bishop in a.d. 360), despite the deposition and exile which he suffered early in his episcopate.
Of or relating to this party.
--Examples--
--Word--
melezitose 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A trisaccharide sugar, C₁₈H₃₂O₁₆, consisting of one fructose and two glucose units, originally isolated from the sap of larches.
--Examples--
--Word--
Melia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of trees (the type genus of the family Meliaceae), with pinnate or bipinnate leaves and axillary panicles of white or purple flowers; (also melia) a tree of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
meliaceous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the family Meliaceae, which includes mainly tropical trees, some grown for their bark, fruit, or timber (notably mahogany, genus Swietana).
--Examples--
--Word--
Melian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Melos.
Of or relating to the island of Melos.
--Examples--
--Word--
Melianthus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of flowering plants, now restricted to certain South African shrubs of the family Melianthaceae, but formerly apparently interpreted more widely; (also melianthus) a plant of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
melibiose 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A disaccharide crystalline sugar, C₁₂H₂₂O₁₁, consisting of one glucose and one galactose unit, and obtainable by partial hydrolysis of raffinose.
--Examples--
--Word--
melic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of an ancient Greek lyric poem) meant to be sung.
--Examples--
--Word--
melilite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tetragonal silicate of calcium and aluminium, occurring as honey-yellow crystals in igneous and metamorphic rocks and many slags. Also: any of a group of related minerals which includes this species, having the general formula A₂BZSiO₇ (where A = Na or Ca, B = Al, Be, Mg, or Zn, and Z = Al or Si).
--Examples--
--Word--
melilite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tetragonal silicate of calcium and aluminium, occurring as honey-yellow crystals in igneous and metamorphic rocks and many slags. Also: any of a group of related minerals which includes this species, having the general formula A₂BZSiO₇ (where A = Na or Ca, B = Al, Be, Mg, or Zn, and Z = Al or Si).
--Examples--
--Word--
melilite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tetragonal silicate of calcium and aluminium, occurring as honey-yellow crystals in igneous and metamorphic rocks and many slags. Also: any of a group of related minerals which includes this species, having the general formula A₂BZSiO₇ (where A = Na or Ca, B = Al, Be, Mg, or Zn, and Z = Al or Si).
--Examples--
--Word--
Melilla 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Spanish enclave on the Mediterranean coast of Morocco; population 71,448 (2008). It was occupied by Spain in 1497.
--Examples--
--Word--
melilot 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fragrant herbaceous plant of the pea family, which is native to Eurasia and north Africa and is sometimes grown as forage or green manure.
--Examples--
--Word--
melilot 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
Mercouri, Melina 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1925–94), Greek actress and politician; born Anna Amalia Mercouri. Her films include Never on Sunday (1960). She was exiled for opposing the military junta who took power in Greece in 1967, but was elected to Parliament in the socialist government of 1978, becoming Minister of Culture in 1985.
--Examples--
--Word--
melinite 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A poorly characterized clay resembling yellow ochre and containing ferric iron.
A high explosive, first developed in France, based on picric acid and similar to lyddite.
--Examples--

meliphanite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tetragonal aluminosilicate of calcium, sodium, and beryllium (also containing fluoride and hydroxide) that belongs to the melilite group and occurs as transparent yellow or colourless crystals.

melissa 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant of the genus Melissa (family Lamiaceae (Labiatae)), especially lemon balm, M. officinalis, chiefly as used medicinally; an extract of this herb. Also (in form Melissa): the genus itself.
--Examples--
--Word--
melissyl alcohol 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(Originally) any of several mixtures of straight-chain primary alcohols obtained from beeswax and other waxes and containing between 30 and 34 carbon atoms; (now usually) specifically n-triacontanol, CH₃(CH₂)₂₈CH₂OH; also called myricyl alcohol.
--Examples--
--Word--
melitose 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Raffinose.
--Examples--
--Word--
mellituria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: the presence of sugar in the urine. Later: specifically the presence of a sugar other than glucose in the urine; an instance of this.
--Examples--
--Word--
melkhout 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several trees of the family Sapotaceae with milky sap; especially (a) (more fully "white melkhout") the white milkwood, Sideroxylon inerme; the pale timber of this tree; (b) (more fully "red melkhout") the red milkwood, Mimusops obovata.
--Examples--
--Word--
Melkite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An Orthodox or Uniate Christian belonging to the patriarchate of Antioch, Jerusalem, or Alexandria.
An Eastern Christian adhering to the Orthodox faith as defined by the councils of Ephesus (AD 431) and Chalcedon (AD 451) and as accepted by the Byzantine emperor.
--Examples--
--Word--
mell 
--Type--
noun, verb, verb
--Meanings--
A heavy hammer or beetle of metal or wood; = "maul". In early use: †a mace or club.
To mix, associate, have dealings. Usually with with. Now chiefly Scottish.
To mix, mingle, combine, blend.
To mingle, combine, blend. Now rare (Scottish in later use).
To strike or beat with a mallet or hammer; to hammer or pound; (hence) to beat severely.
--Examples--
--Word--
mellah 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Jewish quarter in a Moroccan town or city. Also (rarely in extended use) a similar quarter outside Morocco.
--Examples--
--Word--
mellay 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A battle or engagement at close quarters; fighting, especially hand-to-hand fighting; specifically a tournament involving two groups of combatants; a hand-to-hand fight.

= mellitate.

mel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A unit of subjective pitch, on a scale that is proportional to the pitch of a sound, the pitch of a note of frequency 1000 Hz being equal to 1000 mels.

mellite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Hydrated aluminium mellitate, Al₂[C₆(COO)₆].18H₂O, a tetragonal mineral occurring naturally as honey-yellow crystals, especially in lignite.
--Examples--
--Word--
mellitic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A colourless crystalline acid obtained from mellite or by oxidizing carbon with nitric acid; benzenehexacarboxylic acid, C₆(COOH)₆.

mellivorous

adjective
--Meanings--
Of an animal, especially a bird: feeding on honey or nectar.

--Word--
Mellon, Andrew 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1855–1937), American financier and philanthropist; full name Andrew William Mellon. He donated his art collection to establish the National Gallery of Art in Washington DC, opened in 1941.
--Examples--
--Word--
mellophone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A brass instrument similar to the orchestral French horn, played in military and concert bands.
--Examples--
--Word--
mellow 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
(especially of a sound, flavour, or colour) pleasantly smooth or soft; free from harshness.
(of wine) well-matured and smooth.
(of fruit) ripe, sweet, and juicy.
(of a person's character) tempered by maturity or experience.
Relaxed and good-humoured.
Relaxed and cheerful through being slightly drunk.
(of earth) rich and loamy.
Make or become mellow.
Relax and enjoy oneself.
--Examples--
‘she was hypnotized by the mellow tone of his voice’
‘slow cooking gives the dish a sweet, mellow flavour’
‘a mellow, richly flavoured Shiraz’
‘one dish of mellow apples’
‘a more mellow personality’
‘Jean-Claude was feeling mellow’
‘everybody got very mellow and slept well’
‘to most farmers, soil has good tilth when it is mellow and granular and crumbles easily in the hand’
‘even a warm sun could not mellow the North Sea breeze’
‘fuller-flavoured whiskies mellow with wood maturation’
‘I need to mellow out, I need to calm down’

‘Jean-Claude was feeling mellow’
‘everybody got very mellow and slept well’
‘to most farmers, soil has good tilth when it is mellow and granular and crumbles easily in the hand’
‘even a warm sun could not mellow the North Sea breeze’
‘fuller-flavoured whiskies mellow with wood maturation’
‘I need to mellow out, I need to calm down’
--Word--
mellow 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
(especially of a sound, flavour, or colour) pleasantly smooth or soft; free from harshness.
(of wine) well-matured and smooth.
(of fruit) ripe, sweet, and juicy.
(of a person's character) tempered by maturity or experience.
Relaxed and good-humoured.
Relaxed and cheerful through being slightly drunk.
(of earth) rich and loamy.
Make or become mellow.
Relax and enjoy oneself.
--Examples--
‘she was hypnotized by the mellow tone of his voice’
‘slow cooking gives the dish a sweet, mellow flavour’
‘a mellow, richly flavoured Shiraz’
‘one dish of mellow apples’
‘a more mellow personality’
‘Jean-Claude was feeling mellow’
‘everybody got very mellow and slept well’
‘to most farmers, soil has good tilth when it is mellow and granular and crumbles easily in the hand’
‘even a warm sun could not mellow the North Sea breeze’
‘fuller-flavoured whiskies mellow with wood maturation’
‘I need to mellow out, I need to calm down’

--Word--
mell 
--Type--
noun, verb, verb
--Meanings--
A heavy hammer or beetle of metal or wood; = "maul". In early use: †a mace or club.
To mix, associate, have dealings. Usually with with. Now chiefly Scottish.
To mix, mingle, combine, blend.
To mingle, combine, blend. Now rare (Scottish in later use).
To strike or beat with a mallet or hammer; to hammer or pound; (hence) to beat severely.
--Examples--

--Word--
Melocactus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of Central and South American cacti which are often hemispherical in shape, and prominently ribbed, with the flowers borne on a woolly terminal structure; (also melocactus) a cactus of this genus (also called melon-cactus, melon-thistle, Turk's cap).

--Word--
melody 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sequence of single notes that is musically satisfying; a tune.
The aspect of musical composition concerned with the arrangement of single notes to form a satisfying sequence.
The principal part in harmonized music.
Sweet music; tunefulness.
--Examples--
‘he picked out an intricate melody on his guitar’
‘her great gift was for melody’
‘we have the melody and bass of a song composed by Strozzi’
--Word--
melodia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In a pipe organ: a stop of the same type as the hohl-flute, having a flute-like tone and closely resembling the clarabella.
In an American reed organ: a stop giving a flute-like sound.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Word--
melodrama 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sensational dramatic piece with exaggerated characters and exciting events intended to appeal to the emotions.
The genre of melodrama.
Behaviour or events that resemble melodrama.
A play interspersed with songs and orchestral music accompanying the action.
--Examples--
‘he gloated like a villain in a Victorian melodrama’
‘he abandoned melodrama for realism’
‘what little is known of his early life is cloaked in melodrama’

--Word--
melograph 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Any of several devices which automatically record the notes of the tune played on a pianoforte, harpsichord, or similar musical instrument.
An electronic device which provides a continuous graphic record of melody, speech, etc., usually showing how pitch and loudness vary with time.

melographic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

melolonthid

adjective, noun

Of, relating to, or designating a chafer (beetle) of the family Melolonthidae (now regarded as the subfamily Melolonthinae, family Scarabaeidae).

melon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The large round fruit of a plant of the gourd family, with sweet pulpy flesh and many seeds.
A woman's breasts.
The Old World plant which yields the melon.
A waxy mass in the head of dolphins and other toothed whales, thought to focus acoustic signals.

‘a slice of melon’
--Word--
bulb 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A rounded underground storage organ present in some plants, notably those of the lily family, consisting of a short stem surrounded by fleshy scale leaves or leaf bases, lying dormant over winter.
A light bulb.
An expanded part of a glass tube such as that forming the reservoir of a thermometer.
A hollow flexible container with an opening through which the air can be expelled by squeezing, such as that used to fill a syringe.
A spheroidal dilated part at the end of an anatomical structure.

melopoeia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Prosody. Ezra Pound's term for: the musical and rhythmic qualities of poetic language, especially as suited to the tone or mood of the text.

--Examples--
--Word--
Melos 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Greek island in the Aegean Sea, in the south-west of the Cyclades group. It was the centre of a flourishing civilization in the Bronze Age and is the site of the discovery in 1820 of a Hellenistic marble statue of Aphrodite, the Venus de Milo.
--Examples--
--Word--
melotrope 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device for playing music automatically on a keyboard instrument, using a stencil of perforated cardboard strips made by a melograph.
--Examples--
--Word--
Melpomene 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The Muse of tragedy.
--Examples--
--Word--
mel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A unit of subjective pitch, on a scale that is proportional to the pitch of a sound, the pitch of a note of frequency 1000 Hz being equal to 1000 mels.
--Examples--
--Word--
melt 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make or become liquefied by heating.
Melt a metal article so as to reuse the raw material.
Dissolve in liquid.
(of a person) suffer extreme heat.
Make or become more tender or loving.
Disappear or disperse.
Change or merge imperceptibly into (another form or state)
An act or period of melting.
Metal or other material in a melted condition.
A quantity of metal melted at one operation.
A sandwich, hamburger, or other dish containing or topped with melted cheese.
--Examples--
‘the hot metal melted the wax’
‘place under a hot grill until the cheese has melted’
‘beautiful objects are being melted down and sold for scrap’
‘add 400g sugar and boil until the sugar melts’
‘Richard gave her a smile which melted her heart’
‘she was so beautiful that I melted’
‘the compromise was accepted and the opposition melted away’
‘the cheers melted into gasps of admiration’
‘the precipitation falls as snow and is released during the spring melt’
‘a tuna melt’

--Word--
meltdown 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A disastrous collapse or breakdown.
An uncontrolled emotional outburst or a mental collapse.
An accident in a nuclear reactor in which the fuel overheats and melts the reactor core or shielding.
--Examples--
‘the global financial system suffered a major meltdown’
‘the story will revolve around her meltdown following the accident’

--Word--
melt 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make or become liquefied by heating.
Melt a metal article so as to reuse the raw material.
Dissolve in liquid.
(of a person) suffer extreme heat.
Make or become more tender or loving.
Disappear or disperse.
Change or merge imperceptibly into (another form or state)
An act or period of melting.
Metal or other material in a melted condition.
A quantity of metal melted at one operation.
A sandwich, hamburger, or other dish containing or topped with melted cheese.
--Examples--
‘the hot metal melted the wax’
‘place under a hot grill until the cheese has melted’
‘beautiful objects are being melted down and sold for scrap’
‘add 400g sugar and boil until the sugar melts’
‘Richard gave her a smile which melted her heart’
‘she was so beautiful that I melted’
‘the compromise was accepted and the opposition melted away’
‘the cheers melted into gasps of admiration’
‘the precipitation falls as snow and is released during the spring melt’
‘a tuna melt’

--Word--
Meltonian 
--Type--
noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
A person who hunts at Melton Mowbray; (hence) a skilled or experienced fox-hunter. Now historical.
Of or belonging to Melton Mowbray; especially of, relating to, or characteristic of fox-hunting as practised around Melton Mowbray.
A trademark for: any of various polishes, waxes, etc., for shoes and boots. Especially in "Meltonian cream".

Dewey, Melvil 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1851–1931), US librarian. He devised a decimal system of classifying books that used ten main subject categories.
--Examples--
--Word--
Melville, Herman 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1819–91), American novelist and short-story writer. His experiences on a whaling ship formed the basis of several novels, notably Moby Dick (1851). Other notable works: Billy Budd (first published in 1924).
--Examples--
--Word--
Calvin, Melvin 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1911–97), American biochemist, who investigated photosynthesis and discovered the cycle of reactions (the Calvin cycle) which constitute the dark reaction. Nobel Prize for Chemistry (1961).

--Word--
member 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person, animal, or plant belonging to a particular group.
A person, country, or organization that has joined a group, society, or team.
A person formally elected to certain legislative bodies.
Used in the title awarded to a person admitted to certain honours.
A constituent piece of a complex structure, especially a component of a load-bearing structure.
A part of a sentence, equation, mathematical set, etc.
A part of the body, especially a limb.
Used euphemistically to refer to the penis.
--Examples--
‘interest from members of the public’
‘a member of the lily family’
‘the bird is the sole member of its species left in the wild’
‘she's an active member of Greenpeace’
‘the EU's member countries’
‘Member of Parliament for Stretford’
‘Member of the Order of the British Empire’
‘the main member that joins the front and rear axles’

--Word--
private member's bill 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in the UK, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand) a legislative bill that is introduced by a private Member of Parliament and is not part of a government's planned legislation. Such bills rarely become law.

membrane 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A thin sheet of tissue or layer of cells acting as a boundary, lining, or partition in an organism.
A thin pliable sheet of material forming a barrier or lining.
A microscopic double layer of lipids and proteins forming the boundary of cells or organelles.

‘the mucous membrane’
‘the concrete should include a membrane to prevent rising damp’

membranelle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In some ciliates and rotifers: a flattened triangular or fan-shaped organ formed from two or three short rows of cilia which behave as though fused together, used for locomotion or feeding. Usually in plural.

--Word--
Memel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A former district of East Prussia, centred on the city of Memel (Klaipeda). It became an autonomous region of Lithuania in 1924. In 1938 it was taken by Germany, but it was restored to Lithuania by the Soviet Union in 1945.
The River Neman in its lower course.

--Examples--
--Word--
memory 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The faculty by which the mind stores and remembers information.
The mind regarded as a store of things remembered.
Something remembered from the past.
The remembering or commemoration of a dead person.
The length of time over which a person or event continues to be remembered.
The part of a computer in which data or program instructions can be stored for retrieval.
A computer's capacity for storing information.
--Examples--
‘I've a great memory for faces’
‘the brain regions responsible for memory’
‘he searched his memory frantically for an answer’
‘one of my earliest memories is of sitting on his knee’
‘the mind can bury all memory of traumatic abuse’
‘clubs devoted to the memory of Sherlock Holmes’
‘the worst slump in recent memory’
‘the module provides 16Mb of memory’

memorial 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

A record or memoir.

‘a memorial service in the dead man's honour’
‘the Council sent a strongly worded memorial to the Chancellor of the Exchequer’
‘Mrs Carlyle's Letters and Memorials’

--Examples--
--Word--
Memphian 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Memphis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient city of Egypt, whose ruins are situated on the River Nile about 15 km (nearly 10 miles) south of Cairo. It is thought to have been founded as the capital of the Old Kingdom of Egypt c.3100 BC and is the site of the pyramids of Saqqara and Giza and of the Sphinx.
A river port on the Mississippi River in south-western Tennessee; population 669,651 (est. 2008). Founded in 1819, it was the home of blues music in the late 19th century and the scene of the assassination of Martin Luther King in 1968. It is also the childhood home and burial place of Elvis Presley.
--Examples--
--Word--
Memphite 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Memphian.
--Examples--
--Word--
Memphitic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the ancient Egyptian city of Memphis; = "Memphian". In later use chiefly: specifically relating to or designating the dialect of Coptic (now generally known as Bohairic) formerly spoken there.
--Examples--
--Word--
MEMS 
--Type--

--Meanings--

memsahib 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A married white or upper-class woman (often used as a respectful form of address by non-whites)
--Examples--
‘‘Memsahib, what will huzoor desire for dinner?’’

--Word--
menace 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A person or thing that is likely to cause harm; a threat or danger.
A threatening quality or atmosphere.
Threatening words or actions.
A person or thing that causes trouble or annoyance.
Be a threat or possible danger to.
--Examples--
‘a new initiative aimed at beating the menace of drugs’
‘the snakes are a menace to farm animals’
‘he spoke the words with a hint of menace’
‘a demand of money with menaces’
‘Africa's elephants are still menaced by poaching’
--Word--
menacing 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Suggesting the presence of danger; threatening.
--Examples--
‘our officers encountered menacing looks from teenagers’

--Word--
menil 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Formerly generally: (of an animal) spotted, speckled, dappled. Now only: specifically (of a deer) having pale fawn fur with white spots (also in extended use). Also as noun: a deer with such colouring.
--Examples--
--Word--
Menander 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.342–292 BC), Greek playwright. His comic plays deal with domestic situations and capture colloquial speech patterns. The sole complete extant play is Dyskolos.
--Examples--
--Word--
menaquinone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
One of the K vitamins, a compound produced by bacteria in the large intestine and essential for the blood-clotting process. It is an isoprenoid derivative of menadione.

--Word--
Mencius 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.371–c.289 BC), Chinese philosopher; Latinized name of Meng-tzu or Mengzi (‘Meng the Master’). Noted for developing Confucianism, he believed that rulers should provide for the welfare of the people and that human nature is intrinsically good.
One of the Four Books of Confucianism, containing the teachings of Mencius.

mend 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Repair (something that is broken or damaged)
Return to health; heal.
Improve (an unpleasant situation)
Add fuel to (a fire)
A repair in a material.
--Examples--
‘workmen were mending faulty cabling’
‘foot injuries can take months to mend’
‘quarrels could be mended by talking’
‘he mended the fire and turned the meat on the greenwood racks’
‘the mend was barely visible’

Mende 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a people inhabiting Sierra Leone in West Africa.
The language of the Mende, belonging to the Mande group. It has over 1 million speakers.
Relating to or denoting the Mende or their language.

Mendeleev, Dmitri 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1834–1907), Russian chemist; full name Dmitri Ivanovich Mendeleev. He developed the periodic table and successfully predicted the discovery of several new elements.
--Examples--
--Word--
mendelevium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 101, a radioactive metal of the actinide series. It does not occur naturally and was first made in 1955 by bombarding einsteinium with helium ions.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
Mendelssohn, Felix 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1809–47), German composer and pianist; full name Jakob Ludwig Felix Mendelssohn-Bartholdy. His romantic music is elegant, light, and melodically inventive. Notable works include the overture Fingal's Cave (1830–2) and the oratorio Elijah (1846) and eight volumes of Lieder ohne Worte (Songs Without Words) for piano.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mendelssohnian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, characteristic of, or reminiscent of Mendelssohn or his music.
--Examples--

--Word--
Menderes 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river of south-western Turkey. Rising in the Anatolian plateau, it flows for some 384 km (240 miles), entering the Aegean Sea south of the Greek island of Samos. Known in ancient times as the Maeander, and noted for its winding course, it gave its name to the verb meander.

meneghinite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

menehune 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In Hawaii: a member of a mythical race of small people supposed in ancient times to have been capable of great feats of construction, and to have built fish ponds, roads, temples, etc., overnight; also in extended use.

Menelaus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
King of Sparta, husband of Helen and brother of Agamemnon. Helen was stolen from him by Paris, an event which provoked the Trojan War.

Menevian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating a group of fossiliferous rocks of Cambrian age found near St David's in South Wales, and also near Dolgellau and Maentwrog in North Wales.
The Menevian formation.

meninges 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
The three membranes (the dura mater, arachnoid, and pia mater) that line the skull and vertebral canal and enclose the brain and spinal cord.
--Examples--
--Word--
meningioma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tumour, usually benign, arising from meningeal tissue of the brain.

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
meningitis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A serious disease in which there is inflammation of the meninges, caused by viral or bacterial infection, and marked by intense headache and fever, sensitivity to light, and muscular rigidity.
--Examples--

--Meanings--
A protrusion of the meninges through a gap in the spine due to a congenital defect.

--Word--
menisperm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any plant of the family Menispermaceae, the moonseed family.
--Examples--
--Word--
menispermaceous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Belonging to the family Menispermaceae (the moonseed family), which comprises chiefly tropical dioecious lianas and climbing shrubs, many containing toxic alkaloids (e.g. Chondodendron tomentosum, the source of curare, and Anamirta cocculus, the source of cocculus indicus).
--Examples--
--Word--
menispermine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A colourless crystalline alkaloid, C₁₈H₂₄N₂O₂, obtained from the fruit of cocculus indicus, Anamirta (formerly Menispermum) cocculus, and the moonseed, Menispermum canadense.
--Examples--
--Word--
Menlo Park 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in north central California, south of San Francisco; population 30,087 (est. 2008).
A historic community in central New Jersey, in the township of Edison, northeast of New Brunswick, the site of the laboratory of Thomas Edison.
--Examples--
--Word--
Menninger, Karl Augustus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1893–1990), US psychiatrist. With his father he cofounded the Menninger Clinic in Topeka, Kansas, 1920, where psychiatrists received training in psychoanalysis. In 1941, the Menninger Foundation, which he headed until 1990, was established.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mennonite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a Protestant sect originating in Friesland in the 16th century and now mainly located in the US and Canada, emphasizing adult baptism and rejecting Church organization, military service, and public office.

Menopoma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus (now usually included in the genus Cryptobranchus) of tailed amphibians of the family Cryptobranchidae, comprising only the North American hellbender; (also menopoma) an amphibian of this genus, a hellbender.

--Word--
mense 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Propriety, decorum, kindness, tact; discretion, intelligence, common sense.
"to have both one's meat and mense" and variants: to have the credit of being considered generous (in regard to food, etc.) without the expense (as by giving an invitation which is not accepted). Similarly "to lose both one's meat and mense", etc.
English regional. Neatness, tidiness; newness, gloss.
A large amount or quantity. Usually with of.
Treated as plural. People; (frequently) specifically. Afrikaners. Often as a form of address.
--Examples--
--Word--
men's work 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Work traditionally undertaken by, and regarded as suited to, men, especially heavy manual work.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mensa 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A small, faint southern constellation (the Table or Table Mountain), lying between Dorado and the south celestial pole. It contains part of the Large Magellanic Cloud.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Mensa.
An international organization founded in England in 1945 whose members must achieve very high scores in IQ tests to be admitted.
--Examples--
‘the star Alpha Mensae’
--Word--
mensal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
In Scotland and Ireland before the Reformation, and later in the Roman Catholic Church in Ireland: designating a church, benefice, etc., appropriated to defray the expenses of a bishop or other cleric.

--Word--
menstruation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process in a woman of discharging blood and other material from the lining of the uterus at intervals of about one lunar month from puberty until the menopause, except during pregnancy.

Mentha 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of the family Lamiaceae (Labiatae), consisting of various strongly aromatic plants, especially herbs, with spikes or whorls of small lilac flowers having four equal stamens and a four-lobed corolla; (also mentha) a plant of this genus, a mint.

noun
--Meanings--
Any of three isomeric saturated cyclic liquid hydrocarbons, CH₃·C₆H₁₀·CH(CH₃)₂ (methylisopropylcyclohexane); especially the para-isomer, on whose carbon skeleton many terpenes are based.

--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Refer to (something) briefly and without going into detail.
Refer to (someone) as being noteworthy, especially as a potential candidate for a post.
A reference to someone or something.
A formal acknowledgement of something noteworthy.
An instance of being mentioned in dispatches.
--Examples--
‘I haven't mentioned it to William yet’
‘I mentioned that my father was meeting me later’
‘he is still regularly mentioned as a possible secretary of state’
‘their eyes light up at a mention of Sartre’
‘she made no mention of her disastrous trip to Paris’
‘he received a special mention and a prize of £100’
‘two other points are worthy of mention’
‘the unit was awarded fifteen mentions’

--Meanings--
The characteristic crying sound of a cat.
(of a cat) make a miaow.
--Examples--
‘with a miaow the brown kitten jumped down’
‘the cat miaowed again piteously’

merbromin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A greenish iridescent crystalline compound which dissolves in water to give a red solution used as an antiseptic. It is a fluorescein derivative containing bromine and mercury.

mercantilism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Belief in the benefits of profitable trading.
The economic theory that trade generates wealth and is stimulated by the accumulation of profitable balances, which a government should encourage by means of protectionism.

mercaptal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a series of compounds with the general formula RCH(SR′)₂, formed by the acid-catalysed reaction of a thiol (mercaptan) with an aldehyde.

mercaptopurine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various thiol derivatives of purine; specifically 6-mercaptopurine, C₅H₄N₄S, an antineoplastic agent given orally in the treatment of leukaemia.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mercator projection 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A projection of a map of the world on to a cylinder in such a way that all the parallels of latitude have the same length as the equator, used especially for marine charts and certain climatological maps.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mercatorial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or derived from Mercator's projection or chart.
--Examples--
--Word--
Cunningham, Merce 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1919–2009), American dancer and choreographer. A dancer with the Martha Graham Dance Company (1939–45), he formed his own company in 1953 and explored new abstract directions for modern dance.
--Examples--
--Word--
Merced 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in central California, in the San Joaquin Valley; population 77,160 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
Mercedarian 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of the Order of Our Lady of Mercy (also called Our Lady of Ransom), a religious institution founded by St Peter Nolasco in Barcelona in the early 13th century to free Christians taken prisoner by the Muslims, which subsequently turned chiefly to charitable activities, such as hospital work.
--Examples--
--Word--
mercenary 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Primarily concerned with making money at the expense of ethics.
A professional soldier hired to serve in a foreign army.
A person primarily motivated by personal gain.
--Examples--
‘she's nothing but a mercenary little gold-digger’
‘he had planned to seize power with the aid of a group of mercenaries’
‘cricket's most infamous mercenary’

mercerization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process of treating cotton yarn or fabric (often under tension) with a concentrated solution of sodium hydroxide or other base, in order to impart strength and lustre and to increase affinity for dyes.
--Examples--
--Word--
mercerize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Treat (cotton fabric or thread) under tension with caustic alkali to impart strength and lustre.
--Examples--
‘shorts in white mercerized cotton’

--Word--
merchandising 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The activity of promoting the sale of goods, especially by their presentation in retail outlets.
Branded products used to promote a film, pop group, etc., or linked to a fictional character.
--Examples--
‘problems rooted in poor merchandising’
‘the characters are still popular and found on a wide variety of merchandising’
--Word--
merchandisable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
merchandise 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Goods to be bought and sold.
Branded products used to promote a film, pop group, etc., or linked to a fictional character; merchandising.
Promote the sale of (goods), especially by their presentation in retail outlets.
Promote or publicize (an idea or person)
Engage in the business of a merchant.
Trade or traffic in (something), especially inappropriately.
--Examples--
‘shops which offered an astonishing range of merchandise’
‘the official merchandise for the film’
‘a new breakfast food can easily be merchandised’
‘they are merchandising ‘niceness’ to children’
‘anyone who is not of that Guild may not merchandise with them’
‘it if be below great men to be kind of recompense, and merchandise their Power’

--Word--
merchant 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person or company involved in wholesale trade, especially one dealing with foreign countries or supplying goods to a particular trade.
A retail trader.
A person who deals in something unpleasant.
(in historical contexts) a person involved in trade or commerce.
A person who has a liking for a particular activity.
(in historical contexts) relating to merchants or commerce.
(of ships, sailors, or shipping activity) involved with commerce rather than military activity.
--Examples--
‘a builders' merchant’
‘a tea merchant’
‘the credit cards are accepted by 10 million merchants worldwide’
‘a merchant of death’
‘prosperous merchants and clothiers had established a middle class’
‘his driver was no speed merchant’
‘the growth of the merchant classes’
‘a merchant seaman’
--Word--
merchantability 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The condition, state, or quality of being merchantable; saleability. (Chiefly in legal contexts.).
--Examples--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

‘goods must be of merchantable quality’
--Word--
merchantly 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or having the characteristics of a merchant. Occasionally depreciative.
--Examples--
--Word--
merchant adventurer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A merchant engaged in the organization and dispatch of trading expeditions overseas, and the establishment of factories and trading stations in foreign countries. Hence: a member of an association of such merchants incorporated by royal charter or other lawful authority.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
merchant's mark 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An emblem or other distinctive figure or device adopted by a merchant and placed on the goods sold by him (in the Middle Ages often used as a quasi-heraldic cognizance, e.g. on seals or monuments).
--Examples--
--Word--
merchant tailor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tailor whose business includes buying cloth as well as manufacturing garments. Hence (usually in form Merchant Taylor): a member of the Worshipful Company of Merchant Taylors.
British. In form Merchant Taylor. A person educated at a Merchant Taylors' school, specifically the one (still in existence) founded in London in 1561. Also (occasionally) "Merchant Taylor man". Now usually "Old Merchant Taylor".
--Examples--
--Word--
merchant venturer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= merchant adventurer.
--Examples--
--Word--
merchet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fine paid by a tenant or bondsman to his overlord for the right to give his daughter in marriage.
--Examples--
--Word--
mercy 
--Type--
noun, exclamation
--Meanings--
Compassion or forgiveness shown towards someone whom it is within one's power to punish or harm.
An event to be grateful for, because it prevents something unpleasant or provides relief from suffering.
(especially of a journey or mission) performed out of a desire to relieve suffering.
Used in expressions of surprise or fear.
--Examples--
‘the boy was screaming and begging for mercy’
‘the mercies of God’
‘his death was in a way a mercy’
‘mercy missions to refugees caught up in the fighting’
‘‘Mercy me!’ uttered Mrs Diggory’
--Word--
Mercia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A former kingdom of central England. It was established by invading Angles in the 6th century AD in the border areas between the new Anglo-Saxon settlements in the east and the Celtic regions in the west.
Used in names of modern organizations to refer to parts of the English midlands.
--Examples--
‘West Mercia Police’

Mercian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of Mercia, a former kingdom in cental Engand, or its inhabitants.

--Examples--

‘his successor was a Mercian’

mercilessness

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Mercy seat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Theology. The lid of gold, decorated with two winged cherubim, covering the Ark of the Covenant, upon which God is said to have been enthroned, and taken as representing the divine presence in the world; (hence) the throne of God in heaven.
Christian Church (originally and chiefly US). A seat or rail occupied at a religious meeting by penitents or those wishing to testify.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mercouri, Melina 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1925–94), Greek actress and politician; born Anna Amalia Mercouri. Her films include Never on Sunday (1960). She was exiled for opposing the military junta who took power in Greece in 1967, but was elected to Parliament in the socialist government of 1978, becoming Minister of Culture in 1985.
--Examples--
--Word--
mercurate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To introduce mercury into (a compound).
--Examples--
--Word--
mercuration 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of introducing mercury into a compound.
--Examples--
--Word--
mercury 
--Type--
noun, noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 80, a heavy silvery-white metal which is liquid at ordinary temperatures.
The column of mercury in a thermometer or barometer, or its height as indicating atmospheric temperature or pressure.
Mercury or one of its compounds used medicinally, especially to treat syphilis.
A plant of a genus which includes dog's mercury.
The Roman god of eloquence, skill, trading, and thieving, herald and messenger of the gods, who was identified with Hermes.
Used in names of newspapers and journals.
A small planet that is the closest to the sun in the solar system, sometimes visible to the naked eye just after sunset.
--Examples--
‘coastal sunshine sends mercury soaring’
‘one wonders how many unfortunates owed their demise to his prescription of mercury to clarify the spleen’
‘the Leicester Mercury’
--Word--
mercurial 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Subject to sudden or unpredictable changes of mood or mind.
Of or containing the element mercury.
Of the planet Mercury.
A drug or other compound containing mercury.
--Examples--
‘his mercurial temperament’
‘gels containing organic mercurial compounds’
‘for twenty years organic mercurials were the most potent diuretics in clinical use’
--Word--
mercurialize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Medicine. To treat with a mercurial preparation. Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
mercurialism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Poisoning caused by mercury or a compound of mercury.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mercurialist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person born under the influence of the planet Mercury; a person having the qualities attributed to such a birth, especially eloquence, ingenuity, or aptitude for trade. Also occasionally with unfavourable connotation: a sharper, a thief.
--Examples--
--Word--
mercuriality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
mercurialness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mercurial quality; liveliness, sprightliness; volatility.
--Examples--

--Word--
mercury 
--Type--
noun, noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 80, a heavy silvery-white metal which is liquid at ordinary temperatures.
The column of mercury in a thermometer or barometer, or its height as indicating atmospheric temperature or pressure.
Mercury or one of its compounds used medicinally, especially to treat syphilis.
A plant of a genus which includes dog's mercury.
The Roman god of eloquence, skill, trading, and thieving, herald and messenger of the gods, who was identified with Hermes.
Used in names of newspapers and journals.
A small planet that is the closest to the sun in the solar system, sometimes visible to the naked eye just after sunset.
--Examples--
‘coastal sunshine sends mercury soaring’
‘one wonders how many unfortunates owed their demise to his prescription of mercury to clarify the spleen’
‘the Leicester Mercury’

mere 
--Type--
adjective, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Used to emphasize how small or insignificant someone or something is.
Used to emphasize that the fact of something being present in a situation is enough to influence that situation.
A lake or pond.
A Maori war club, especially one made of greenstone.
--Examples--
‘questions that cannot be answered by mere mortals’
‘the city is a mere 20 minutes from some stunning countryside’
‘his stomach rebelled at the mere thought of food’
‘the stream widens into a mere where hundreds of geese gather’
‘Hornsea Mere’

Meredith, James 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1933), US civil rights activist; full name James Howard Meredith. In 1962, he became the first African American to attend the University of Mississippi after 3,000 troops quelled riots. He wrote Three Years in Mississippi (1966) and Mississippi: A Volume of Eleven Books (1995).

merge 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Combine or cause to combine to form a single entity.
Blend or cause to blend gradually into something else so as to become indistinguishable from it.
Absorb (a title or estate) in another.
--Examples--
‘the merchant bank merged with another broker’
‘he agreed to merge his broadcasting company with a multinational concern’
‘he crouched low and endeavoured to merge into the darkness of the forest’
‘he placed a sheet of paper over the fresh paint to merge the colours’

--Word--
mericarp 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of the one-seeded units into which a schizocarp separates at maturity, each unit forming a dry indehiscent fruit; especially either of the halves of the fruit (cremocarp) of a plant of the family Apiaceae (Umbelliferae).
--Examples--
--Word--
merycism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A medical condition in which food is regurgitated after a short period in the stomach, and is then either swallowed again (with or without re-chewing) or spat out.

--Word--
meridian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A circle of constant longitude passing through a given place on the earth's surface and the terrestrial poles.
A circle passing through the celestial poles and the zenith of a given place on the earth's surface.
(in acupuncture and Chinese medicine) each of a set of pathways in the body along which vital energy is said to flow.
Relating to or situated at a meridian.
--Examples--
‘the European Broadcasting Area extends from the Atlantic to the meridian 40°E’
‘at the end of February Jupiter transits the meridian, due south, at 6.15 a.m’
‘the slow movements and postures of t'ai chi open up and align the meridians of the body’
‘the meridian moon’
--Word--
meridian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A circle of constant longitude passing through a given place on the earth's surface and the terrestrial poles.
A circle passing through the celestial poles and the zenith of a given place on the earth's surface.
(in acupuncture and Chinese medicine) each of a set of pathways in the body along which vital energy is said to flow.
Relating to or situated at a meridian.
--Examples--
‘the European Broadcasting Area extends from the Atlantic to the meridian 40°E’
‘at the end of February Jupiter transits the meridian, due south, at 6.15 a.m’
‘the slow movements and postures of t'ai chi open up and align the meridians of the body’
‘the meridian moon’
--Word--
post meridiem 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
After midday; applied to the hours between noon and midnight. Usually abbreviated P.M., p.m., or pm.
--Examples--

méridienne

noun
--Meanings--

meridional 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or in the south; southern.
Relating to or characteristic of the inhabitants of southern Europe, especially the South of France.
Relating to a meridian.
(of winds and air flow) aligned with lines of longitude.
A native or inhabitant of southern Europe, especially the south of France.
--Examples--
‘the meridional leg of the journey’
‘she was meridional in temperament’
‘the meridional line of demarcation’
‘the spinning of a planet on its axis deflects the meridional winds sideways’

Merist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a Jewish sect, in existence by the 2nd cent. a.d., said by St Isidore to have believed that the Scriptures were not all inspired alike by God, and supposed by some modern scholars to have believed that God was not a single being.

--Word--
meristem 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A region of plant tissue, found chiefly at the growing tips of roots and shoots and in the cambium, consisting of actively dividing cells forming new tissue.
--Examples--
‘the apical meristem of the shoot produces the embryonic seed leaves’
--Word--
meristematic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a region of plant tissue consisting of actively dividing cells forming new tissue.
--Examples--
‘meristematic cells located in the tip of the root’
--Word--
meristematically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In the manner of a meristem; by means of meristematic cell division.

merit 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The quality of being particularly good or worthy, especially so as to deserve praise or reward.
A good feature or point.
A pass grade in an examination denoting above-average performance.
The intrinsic rights and wrongs of a case, outside of any other considerations.
Good deeds entitling someone to a future reward from God.
Deserve or be worthy of (reward, punishment, or attention)
--Examples--
‘composers of outstanding merit’
‘the relative merits of both approaches have to be considered’
‘if you expect to pass, why not go for a merit or a distinction?’
‘a plaintiff who has a good arguable case on the merits’
‘the results have been encouraging enough to merit further investigation’

meritocracy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Government or the holding of power by people selected according to merit.
A society governed by people selected according to merit.
A ruling or influential class of educated or able people.
--Examples--
‘progress towards meritocracy was slow’
‘Britain is a meritocracy, and everyone with skill and imagination may aspire to reach the highest level’
‘the relentless advance of the meritocracy’

--Word--
Lewis, Meriwether 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1774–1809), American explorer. Together with William Clark he led an expedition to explore the newly acquired Louisiana Purchase (1804–6). They travelled from St Louis to the Pacific Coast and back.

merocyte 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A cell or nucleus formed by division in a meroblastic ovum; specifically any of numerous small nuclei formed by the repeated division of supernumerary sperm nuclei in fertilized eggs, especially those of birds, reptiles, and selachian fishes.

Meroe 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient city on the River Nile, in present-day Sudan north-east of Khartoum. Founded in c.750 BC, it was the capital of the ancient kingdom of Cush from c.590 BC until it fell to the invading Aksumites in the early 4th century AD.
--Examples--
--Word--
merogamy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: the production of gametes that are smaller and of a different structure than vegetative cells of the same organism (obsolete). In later use: merogony, especially that resulting in the production of gametes or gamonts.
--Examples--
--Word--
merogony 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Embryonic development occurring in a fragment of an ovum (originally specifically in an enucleated ovum containing a male pronucleus).
Asexual reproduction of protists by multiple fission (schizogony), specifically that resulting in the production of merozoites; an instance of this.
--Examples--
--Word--
merogonic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or produced by merogony.
--Examples--

merohedral 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a crystal or crystal form: having one half, a quarter, or one eighth of the maximum number of faces possible for its crystal class; merosymmetric.

--Word--
meromyosin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Either of the two fractions obtained from myosin by the action of trypsin and certain other proteolytic enzymes, of which the heavier fraction (in full "heavy meromyosin") consists of the globular heads and a small section of the helical tail of the myosin molecule, and the lighter fraction (in full "light meromyosin") consists of the remainder of the tail.
--Examples--
--Word--
meromorphic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a complex function: analytic everywhere on a given domain except at a set of isolated points.
--Examples--

merozoite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In many sporozoans: any of the individuals produced by schizogony (merogony) in the asexual phase of the life cycle, which infect further host cells and in turn form meronts or gamonts.

mesarch 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Botany. Of primary xylem: developing from both the centre of the stem and the periphery, so that the oldest elements (protoxylem) are in the centre of the xylem strand, and maturation of the cells takes place both centrifugally and centripetally.
Ecology. Of a succession of plant communities: originating in a mesic or moderately moist habitat.
