--Word--
mese 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In ancient Greek music: the highest note of the lower of a pair of tetrachords, identical in some scales with the lowest note of the higher tetrachord. Hence, in the two-octave scale known as the Greater Perfect System: the middle note, which is also the highest note of the second lowest of the four tetrachords.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesectoderm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mesenchyme that is derived from ectoderm or the neural crest rather than from mesoderm. Also: the outer layer of blastoderm before its differentiation into ectoderm and mesoderm.
--Examples--
--Word--
mese 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In ancient Greek music: the highest note of the lower of a pair of tetrachords, identical in some scales with the lowest note of the higher tetrachord. Hence, in the two-octave scale known as the Greater Perfect System: the middle note, which is also the highest note of the second lowest of the four tetrachords.

mesenterical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Mesenteric; mesenterial.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesenterically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a manner characteristic of the mesentery; in or through the mesentery.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesentery 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fold of the peritoneum which attaches the stomach, small intestine, pancreas, spleen, and other organs to the posterior wall of the abdomen.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesenteritis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
mesenterium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mesentery.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesenteron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The middle section of the intestine, especially in an embryo or arthropod.
--Examples--

mesenteronic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= mesendoderm.

mesethmoid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The ethmoid bone.
Of, relating to, or of the nature of the ethmoid bone.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesh 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Material made of a network of wire or thread.
The spacing between the individual strands that form mesh.
Used with reference to a complex or constricting situation.
An interlaced structure.
A representation of a given shape or form, consisting of an arrangement of a finite set of geometric components.
A computer network in which each computer or processor is connected to a number of others, especially so as to form a multidimensional lattice.
(of the teeth of a gearwheel) be engaged with another gearwheel.
Make or become entangled or entwined.
Be in or bring into harmony.
Represent a geometric object as a set of finite elements.
--Examples--
‘mesh for fishing nets’
‘finer wire meshes are used for smaller particles’
‘if the mesh is too big, small rabbits can squeeze through’
‘you are just common people going about your lives caught in the common mesh of history’
‘cell fragments which agglutinate and form intricate meshes’
‘multiple boards can be arranged in various multiprocessing architectures, including 3-D mesh, ring, or hypercube’
‘one gear meshes with the input gear’
‘their fingers meshed’
‘I don't want to get meshed in the weeds’
‘her memory of events doesn't mesh with the world around her’
‘choosing the icon allows you to automatically mesh your design’
--Word--
meshed 
--Type--
adjective, proper noun
--Meanings--
Having the form or appearance of a mesh or network.
(of a geometric object) represented by an arrangement of a finite number of geometric components.
(of a computer network) consisting of nodes which are each linked to the network via two or more connections, each node typically being connected (directly or indirectly) to every other node.
--Examples--
‘a meshed grille’
‘fine-meshed sieves’
‘a meshed sphere’
‘meshed wireless networks’
--Word--
mesh 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Material made of a network of wire or thread.
The spacing between the individual strands that form mesh.
Used with reference to a complex or constricting situation.

Be in or bring into harmony.
Represent a geometric object as a set of finite elements.

mesic 
--Type--
adjective, adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
mesityl 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A cyclic hydrocarbon group or radical derived from mesitylene, either (CH₃)₂C₆H₃CH₂— (3,5-dimethylbenzyl) or (now usually) specifically (CH₃)₃C₆H₃— (2,4,6-trimethylphenyl). Usually attributive or as a formative element in chemical names.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesitylene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A colourless aromatic hydrocarbon, isomeric with cumene, obtainable from petroleum or by distillation of acetone with sulphuric acid; 1,3,5-trimethylbenzene, C₆H₃(CH₃)₃.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesitylenic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Derived from mesitylene.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesitite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A ferroan variety of magnesite (originally regarded as a different species) occurring as transparent yellowish crystals.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mesmer, Franz Anton 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1734–1815), Austrian physician. Mesmer is chiefly remembered for introducing a therapeutic technique involving hypnotism; it was bound up with his ideas about ‘animal magnetism’, however, and steeped in sensationalism.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesmerian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or of the nature of mesmerism.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesmeric 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Causing a person to become completely transfixed and unaware of their surroundings.
Relating to or produced by mesmerism.
--Examples--
‘she found herself staring into his mesmeric gaze’
‘mesmeric anaesthesia’

mesocoel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Anatomy and Zoology. In forms mesocele, mesocoele. The cerebral aqueduct or its embryonic precursor. rare.
Zoology. The middle division of a tripartite coelom; (in hemichordates) the coelomic compartment of the mesosoma or collar; (in echinoderms) the part of the coelom forming the water-vascular system.

--Word--
mesogloea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Botany. Usually in form Mesogloia. A genus of brown algae (family Chordariaceae); an alga of this genus.
Zoology. In coelenterates and ctenophores: a layer between the endoderm and the ectoderm, lacking organized cellular structure and often gelatinous in consistency.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesogloea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Botany. Usually in form Mesogloia. A genus of brown algae (family Chordariaceae); an alga of this genus.
Zoology. In coelenterates and ctenophores: a layer between the endoderm and the ectoderm, lacking organized cellular structure and often gelatinous in consistency.

mesolite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An orthorhombic hydrated aluminosilicate of calcium and sodium, occurring as colourless to white needle-like or fibrous crystals, structurally intermediate between natrolite and scolecite.

mesomere 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Zoology. Each of a series of axial elements in the primitive vertebrate fin (archipterygium) or forelimb.
Embryology. A mesodermal segment or somite; a protovertebra.
Embryology. A blastomere of medium size, produced by some forms of embryonic cleavage.

mesometrium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fold of peritoneum connecting the lateral wall of the uterus or (in birds) the oviduct with the pelvic wall.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesomyodian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a bird: having a syrinx whose muscles are attached to the middle of the bronchial semi-rings; specifically (in Garrod's scheme) belonging to the division Mesomyodi of passerine birds, closely corresponding to the suborder Deutero-Oscines (the suboscine passerines).
--Examples--
--Word--
mesomyodous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
= mesomyodian.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--

mesomorphism

mesomorphous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Botany= "mesomorphic". rare.

--Examples--
--Word--
meson 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A subatomic particle which is intermediate in mass between an electron and a proton and transmits the strong interaction that binds nucleons together in the atomic nucleus.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesonephric 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the mesonephros. Especially in "mesonephric duct".
--Examples--
--Word--
mesonephros 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The part of the nephrogenic tissue of a vertebrate embryo that develops after the pronephros and forms the adult kidney of fishes and amphibians, but is succeeded by the metanephros in humans and other amniotes and persists only as the epididymis (in males) and the epoophoron (in females).
--Examples--
--Word--
mesonic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
mesonotal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the mesonotum of an insect.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesonotum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The dorsal sclerite or tergum of the mesothorax of an insect.
--Examples--
--Word--
meson 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A subatomic particle which is intermediate in mass between an electron and a proton and transmits the strong interaction that binds nucleons together in the atomic nucleus.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesopause 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The boundary in the earth's atmosphere between the mesosphere and the thermosphere, at which the temperature stops decreasing with increasing height and begins to increase.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesopelagic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of fish and other organisms) inhabiting the intermediate depths of the sea, between about 200 and 1,000 metres (approximately 650 and 3,300 ft) down.
--Examples--
‘many mesopelagic fish species have swim bladders’

--Meanings--

mesophilic

adjective
--Meanings--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In certain insects: an inward extension of the exoskeleton which forms a transverse partition separating the mesothorax from the metathorax.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesopic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Physiology. Of, relating to, or designating vision in moderate levels of light (intermediate between scotopic and photopic).
--Examples--
--Word--
mesoplankton 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Plankton inhabiting the region between about 200 metres (approx. 670 feet) from the sea floor and 200 metres from the surface. More generally: relatively large microplankton.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesoplast 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Cell Biology. In algal cells: a type of phycoplast which develops among the remnants of the interzonal spindle after mitosis, and is not associated with the centrioles. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesoplastral 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating a bone which forms the mesoplastron (of a turtle).
--Examples--
--Word--
mesoplastron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dermal bone present in the plastron of certain turtles (including most extant pelomedusids).
--Examples--

mesopleural 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the mesopleura.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesopleuron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Either of the pleura of the mesothorax of an insect.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesopodial 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Designating any of a series of small bones which make up the carpus or the tarsus of a tetrapod (especially a reptile or amphibian); of or relating to this series of bones.
Of or relating to the mesopodium of a mollusc.
Botany. Of or relating to the mesopodium of a leaf or inflorescence.
A mesopodial bone.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesopodium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Zoology. The middle lobe of the foot of a mollusc.
Botany. Originally; the region of a leaf primordium corresponding to the petiole; the petiole itself. Later also: an internode between prophylls in certain compound inflorescences.
Zoology. The section of a tetrapod limb (especially of an amphibian or reptile) constituted by the carpus (in the forelimb) or the tarsus (in the hind limb); the mesopodial bones collectively.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mesopotamia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient region of south-western Asia in present-day Iraq, lying between the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers. Its alluvial plains were the site of the civilizations of Akkad, Sumer, Babylonia, and Assyria.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mesopotamian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the ancient south-western Asian region of Mesopotamia or its inhabitants.
A native or inhabitant of the ancient south-western Asian region of Mesopotamia.
--Examples--
‘priceless Mesopotamian artefacts’
‘gambling was invented in 3948 BC by a Mesopotamian’

Mesopotamic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating an area of land between two rivers; specifically of or relating to Mesopotamia.

mesopterygium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In elasmobranch fishes: the central portion of the cartilaginous skeleton at the base of each pectoral fin.

mesopterygoid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Anatomy and Zoology"mesopterygoid fossa"noun the cavity between the two pterygoid bones of the skull.
Ichthyology. A thin bony lamina in the skull of teleostean fishes which fits against the upper edge of the pterygoid bone.

mesorchium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The mesentery that supports the testis in the embryo or (in some taxa) adult male vertebrate; a residual fold of peritoneum between the testis and epididymis in other adult male vertebrates.

mesosphere

noun

mesospore 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Botany and Mycology. The middle layer of the wall of any of several types of three-layered spores (e.g. the megaspore of a clubmoss or the zygospore of a zygnemaceous alga).
Mycology. A one-celled teleutospore occurring in species of rust fungus which normally produce two-celled teleutospores.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesosporium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The middle layer of the wall of any of several types of three-layered spores, especially of the ascospore of a fungus.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesostasis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The most recently formed interstitial substance (whether glassy or cryptocrystalline) in an igneous rock.

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
mesosternum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Entomology. The sternum of the mesothorax of an insect or (especially formerly) an equivalent or associated part. Also (in Zoology): the middle plate of the sternum in brachyuran crabs.
Anatomy and Zoology. The body of the sternum, situated between the manubrium and the xiphisternum.

noun
--Meanings--
In certain insects: a region of the ventral part of the metathorax, just in front of the coxae of the posterior legs.

--Word--
mesothermal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Chiefly Ecology. Of an environment: characterized by moderate temperatures; (of an organism) inhabiting such an environment.
Geology. Of, relating to, or designating mineral and ore deposits formed by hydrothermal action at intermediate temperature and pressure.
Physics. Of the speed of an object in a plasma: less than that of the ambient electrons but higher than that of the ions.

--Word--
mesothorax 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The middle segment of the thorax of an insect, bearing the forewings or elytra.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesothorium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Either of two radioactive nuclides in the thorium series: "mesothorium I" (symbol MsThI), the isotope of radium with mass number 228, produced by the alpha decay of thorium 232, or "mesothorium II" (symbol MsThII), the isotope of actinium with mass number 228, produced by the beta decay of mesothorium I.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesotympanic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Anatomy. Of, relating to, or designating the portion of the ear medial to the tympanic membrane (one of the four described regions of the middle ear space).
--Examples--
--Word--
mesotype 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A zeolite mineral originally regarded as a single species but later resolved into several distinct species, including natrolite, mesolite, scolecite, and thomsonite (members of the natrolite group); these minerals collectively.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesotrocha 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Treated as plural. The ciliated larvae (collectively) of certain polychaete worms, characterized by one or more rows of cilia encircling the middle of the body.

--Word--
Mesozoa 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Treated as plural: a group of minute worms with no body cavity or organs other than reproductive cells, which are internal parasites of marine invertebrates and absorb dissolved nutrients directly from the host's tissues; (also mesozoa) worms of this group collectively.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesozoan 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A minute worm which is an internal parasite of marine invertebrates. It lacks any internal organs other than reproductive cells, and dissolved nutrients are absorbed directly from the host's tissues.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mesozoic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the era between the Palaeozoic and Cenozoic eras, comprising the Triassic, Jurassic, and Cretaceous periods.
The Mesozoic era or the system of rocks deposited during it.
--Examples--

snowy mespilus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

mesquita 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
mesquite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A spiny tree or shrub of the pea family, native to arid regions of south-western US and Mexico. It yields useful timber, tanbark, medicinal products, and edible pods. The timber is used for fencing and flooring, and burned in barbecues as flavouring.
--Examples--
--Word--
mesquite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A spiny tree or shrub of the pea family, native to arid regions of south-western US and Mexico. It yields useful timber, tanbark, medicinal products, and edible pods. The timber is used for fencing and flooring, and burned in barbecues as flavouring.
--Examples--
--Word--
mess 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A dirty or untidy state of things or of a place.
A thing or collection of things causing a dirty or untidy state.
A person who is dirty or untidy.
Used euphemistically to refer to the excrement of a domestic animal.
A situation that is confused and full of problems.
A person whose life is confused and full of problems.
A portion of semi-liquid food.
A building or room providing meals and recreational facilities for members of the armed forces.
A large amount or quantity of.
Make untidy or dirty.
(of a domestic animal) defecate.
Make dirty by defecating.
Have one's meals with a particular person, especially as a member of an armed forces' mess.
--Examples--
‘she made a mess of the kitchen’
‘my hair was a mess’
‘she replaced the jug and mopped up the mess’
‘I look a mess’
‘dog mess’
‘the economy is still in a terrible mess’
‘he needs treatment of some kind—he's a real mess’
‘a mess of mashed black beans and rice’
‘the sergeants' mess’
‘big-time outfits that do a mess of printing’
‘you've messed up my beautiful carpet’
‘they had some problems with dogs messing in the store’
‘he feared he would mess the bed’
‘I messed at first with Harry, who became a lifelong friend’
--Word--
message 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A verbal, written, or recorded communication sent to or left for a recipient who cannot be contacted directly.
An email or similar electronic communication.
An electronic communication generated automatically by a computer program and displayed on a screen.
A communication from a prophet or preacher, believed to be inspired by God.
A television or radio advertisement.
A significant political, social, or moral point that is being conveyed by a film, speech, etc.
An errand.
Things bought on an errand; shopping.
Send a message to (someone), especially by email.
--Examples--
‘if I'm not there leave a message on the answerphone’
‘select an option to delete your mail messages’
‘an error message’
‘Jesus and his followers were promulgating a specifically Judaic message for Judaic adherents’
‘we'll be back after these messages’
‘a campaign to get the message about home security across’
‘he would run those interminable messages after school to the bookie’
‘I was messaged by a Californian contact for some information’
‘the software package incorporates messaging, scheduling, and workflow functions’

--Meanings--
A person who carries a message or is employed to carry messages.

--Word--
Messalian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a Christian movement of dualistic tendency of 4th-cent. Near Eastern origin, frequently regarded as heretical, which rejected the efficacy of the sacraments and good works, regarding prayer as essential to salvation; a member of one of the later heterodox or marginal movements supposedly related to this.
Of, relating to, or characteristic of the Messalians.
--Examples--
--Word--
Messalina, Valeria 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.22–48 AD), Roman empress, third wife of Claudius. She became notorious in Rome for the murders she instigated in court and for her extramarital affairs, and was executed on Claudius' orders.
--Examples--
--Word--
messaline 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A soft, lightweight, and lustrous twilled-silk fabric.

--Meanings--

--Word--
Messapian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or relating to Messapia, an ancient region of south-eastern Italy (modern Apulia), its pre-Roman inhabitants, or their language.
A native or inhabitant of Messapia.
= Messapic.
--Examples--
--Word--
Messapic 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A pre-Roman language known from several hundred inscriptions (mostly funerary) found in the Salentine peninsula of south-eastern Italy (modern Apulia), which are written in two similar alphabets, both of Greek origin.
Of or relating to Messapic or the ancient region of Messapia.
--Examples--
--Word--

messer 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A title of courtesy prefixed to the first name (sometimes with the surname also) of an Italian man (equivalent to the English Mr).
A person who makes a mess, or who messes about; a muddler, a bungler.
Irish English and US. A troublemaker, a thug.
--Examples--
--Word--
Messerschmitt 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several types of military aircraft, especially fighters, designed by Messerschmitt and manufactured by his company, which were used by the German Luftwaffe during the Second World War (1939–45).

A person whose life is confused and full of problems.
A portion of semi-liquid food.
A building or room providing meals and recreational facilities for members of the armed forces.
A large amount or quantity of.
Make untidy or dirty.
(of a domestic animal) defecate.
Make dirty by defecating.
Have one's meals with a particular person, especially as a member of an armed forces' mess.
--Examples--
‘she made a mess of the kitchen’
‘my hair was a mess’
‘she replaced the jug and mopped up the mess’
‘I look a mess’
‘dog mess’
‘the economy is still in a terrible mess’
‘he needs treatment of some kind—he's a real mess’
‘a mess of mashed black beans and rice’
‘the sergeants' mess’
‘big-time outfits that do a mess of printing’
‘you've messed up my beautiful carpet’
‘they had some problems with dogs messing in the store’
‘he feared he would mess the bed’
‘I messed at first with Harry, who became a lifelong friend’
--Word--
messy 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Untidy or dirty.
Generating or involving mess.
(of a situation) confused and difficult to deal with.
--Examples--
‘his messy hair’
‘stripping wallpaper can be a messy, time-consuming job’
‘a messy divorce’
--Word--
Messiaen, Olivier 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1908–92), French composer; full name Olivier Eugène Prosper Charles Messiaen. His music was influenced by Greek and Hindu rhythms, birdsong, Stravinsky and Debussy, and the composer's Roman Catholic faith. Notable works: Quartet for the End of Time (1941).
--Examples--
--Word--
messiah 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The promised deliverer of the Jewish nation prophesied in the Hebrew Bible.
Jesus regarded by Christians as the Messiah of the Hebrew prophecies and the saviour of humankind.
A leader regarded as the saviour of a particular country, group, or cause.
--Examples--
‘the club's supporters have been tempted to regard him as a messiah rather than a manager’

Messina 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in north-eastern Sicily; population 234,700 (est. 2009). Founded in 730 BC by the Greeks, it is situated on the Strait of Messina.

--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
Denoting a change of position or condition.
Denoting position behind, after, or beyond.
Denoting something of a higher or second-order kind.

--Word--
metabasis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Philosophy. The transferral of an argument from one subject, case, etc., to another of the same kind; an inference or connection based on (usually spurious) analogy.
Medicine. A change in the signs, symptoms, or treatment of a disease. Compare metabole. Now historical or rare.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

metabiosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A form of ecological dependence in which modification of the environment by an organism, especially a microorganism, provides conditions that enable one or more different kinds of organism to grow and multiply. Also: the alteration of the environment brought about by such a relationship.

metaborate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a class of borates that are relatively less hydrated than the orthoborates; (equivalently) any borate containing the anion BO₂ −; the anion itself; a polyanion with this general formula, especially B₃O₆ 3−.

metaboric acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The least hydrated of the oxoacids of boron, obtained by heating (ortho)boric acid, and occurring in several forms with the general formula HBO₂; especially B₃O₃(OH)₃.

metacyclic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Mathematics. Of or relating to the permutation of a set of elements in a cycle; (of a group G) containing a normal subgroup N that is cyclic, such that the quotient G/N is cyclic.
Medicine and Zoology. Of, relating to, or designating the final stage of development of trypanosomes in the intermediate (invertebrate) host, at which stage they are infective to the vertebrate host.
Zoology and Medicine. A metacyclic trypanosome.

--Examples--
--Word--
metagrobolize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To puzzle, mystify, confound.
To puzzle out. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
métayage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A system of land tenure in which the farmer pays a certain proportion (usually half) of the produce to the landowner as rent, and the owner provides (a part of) the stock and seed. Also more generally: any form of sharecropping.
--Examples--
--Word--
métayer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A farmer who holds land under the métayage system.
--Examples--
--Word--
Metairie 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A community in southeastern Louisiana, northwest of New Orleans; population 146,136 (2000).
--Examples--
--Word--
metakinesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The separation of sister chromatids and their movement to opposite poles in anaphase of mitosis. Now rare and historical.
The movement of chromosomes to the spindle equator early in metaphase of mitosis.
Biology. The property of being metakinetic. Compare earlier "metakinetism".
--Examples--
--Word--
metakinetic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Biology. Designating, relating to, or possessing a movable joint in the posterior portion of the skull (as between the brain case and skull roof).
--Examples--
--Word--
metal 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A solid material which is typically hard, shiny, malleable, fusible, and ductile, with good electrical and thermal conductivity (e.g. iron, gold, silver, and aluminium, and alloys such as steel)
The steel tracks of a railway.
Gold and silver (as tinctures in blazoning).
Broken stone for use in making roads.
Molten glass before it is blown or cast.
Heavy metal or similar rock music.
Made from or coated with metal.
Make or mend (a road) with road metal.
--Examples--
‘an adjustable pole made of metal’
‘being a metal, aluminium readily conducts heat’
‘the locomotive is presently being made ready for operation over Network SouthEast metals’
‘the work also involves dealing with rock aggregates for potential use as suitable road metal’
‘industrial music is also a blend of metal and techno’
‘crunching power-trio metal’
‘a range of metalled key rings’
‘follow the metalled road for about 200 yards’
‘the road was metalled and tolls charged for the upkeep’
--Word--
metal. 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Metallurgical or metallurgy.
--Examples--
--Word--
metalanguage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A form of language or set of terms used for the description or analysis of another language.
A system of propositions about propositions.
--Examples--
--Word--
metalaw 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hypothetical legal code based on the principles underlying existing legal codes and designed to be applicable in a context or place (originally, space or outer space) not currently subject to legal regulation. Also, more generally: any law that operates beyond and outside known laws; a second or higher order of law.
--Examples--
--Word--
bearing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person's way of standing or moving.
The way a person behaves or conducts themselves.
Relation; relevance.
The ability to tolerate something bad or to be tolerated.
A part of a machine that allows one part to rotate or move in contact with another part with as little friction as possible.
The direction or position of something, or the direction of movement, relative to a fixed point. It is usually measured in degrees, typically with magnetic north as zero.
Awareness of one's position relative to one's surroundings.
A device or charge.
--Examples--
‘a man of precise military bearing’
‘she has the bearing of a First Lady’
‘the case has no direct bearing on the issues being considered’
‘school was bad enough, but now it's past bearing’
‘the Point is on a bearing of 015°’
‘there were no steeples or bridges from which to take a bearing’
‘he flashed the torch around, trying to get his bearings’
‘armorial bearings’
--Word--
metal-bending 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The bending of metal, especially as part of a manufacturing process (frequently attributive or as adjective).
Informal (chiefly North American) = "manufacturing".
The act of bending metal using telekinetic powers.
--Examples--
--Word--
boring 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Not interesting; tedious.
--Examples--
‘I've got a boring job in an office’
--Word--
bound 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Walk or run with leaping strides.
(of an object) rebound from a surface.
A leaping movement towards or over something.
A territorial limit; a boundary.
A limitation or restriction on feeling or action.
A limiting value.
Form the boundary of; enclose.
Place within certain limits; restrict.
--Examples--
‘Louis came bounding down the stairs’
‘shares bounded ahead in early dealing’
‘bullets bounded off the veranda’
‘I went up the steps in two effortless bounds’
‘the ancient bounds of the forest’
‘it is not beyond the bounds of possibility that the issue could arise again’
‘enthusiasm to join the union knew no bounds’
‘an upper bound on each modulus’
‘the ground was bounded by a main road on one side and a meadow on the other’
‘freedom of action is bounded by law’
--Word--
broach 
--Type--
verb, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Raise (a difficult subject) for discussion.
Pierce (a cask) to draw out liquid.
Open and start using the contents of (a bottle or other container)
(of a fish or sea mammal) rise through the water and break the surface.
(of a ship) veer and pitch forward, presenting a side to the wind and waves and losing steerage control.
A sudden and unwelcome veering of a ship that causes it to broach.
--Examples--
‘he broached the subject he had been avoiding all evening’
‘he watched a pot boy broach a new cask’
‘boxed wines will remain in good condition for up to four months once broached’
‘the salmon broach, then fall to slap the water’
‘we had broached badly, side on to the wind and sea’
‘the helmsman was forced to use the engines in conjunction with the wheel to prevent a broach’
--Word--
bushed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Tired out; exhausted.
Lost in the bush.
Flummoxed or bewildered.
Psychologically disturbed on account of isolation.
--Examples--
‘unless you're totally bushed, it's best to press on’
‘unused to solitude, he went bushed’
--Word--
clad 
--Type--
verb, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Clothed.
Covered with cladding.
Encase (a structure) with a covering or coating.
--Examples--
‘they were clad in T-shirts and shorts’
‘leather-clad boys’
‘copper-clad boards’
‘he cladded the concrete-frame structure in stainless steel’

--Word--
cutting 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The action of cutting something.
A piece cut off from something, especially what remains when something is being trimmed or prepared.
An article or other piece cut from a newspaper or periodical.
A piece cut from a plant for propagation.
An open passage excavated through higher ground for a railway, road, or canal.
Capable of cutting something.
(of a comment) causing emotional pain; hurtful.
(of the wind) bitterly cold.
--Examples--
‘the cutting of the cake’
‘tax-cutting’
‘grass cuttings’
‘an archive of newspaper cuttings’
‘take cuttings of Christmas cactus and pot them on’
‘they found the cutting and scrambled down the slope’
‘the cutting blades of the hedge trimmer’
‘a cutting remark’
‘cutting winter winds’
--Word--
Decorated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Denoting a stage of English Gothic church architecture typical of the 14th century (between Early English and Perpendicular), with increasing use of decoration and geometrical, curvilinear, and reticulated tracery.
--Examples--
‘fine Decorated Gothic facades can be seen at Exeter and York’
--Word--
metaldehyde 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A solid made by polymerizing acetaldehyde, used in slug pellets and as a fuel for portable stoves.
--Examples--
--Word--
skin-drying 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Founding drying of the surface of a greensand mould before casting.
That dries a person's skin.
--Examples--
--Word--
drilling 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
The action of making a hole in something by boring with a drill.
The action of sinking a borehole in order to obtain oil or water.
The action of cutting away part of a tooth before filling it.
Instruction or training in military exercises.
The action of planting the ground in furrows.
--Examples--
‘the windows vibrated all day from the sound of drilling’
‘drilling should begin next year’
‘some new dental technologies have eliminated the use of drilling’
‘our days often began with military drilling’
‘accurate ridging and drilling make hoeing much easier’
--Word--
metal 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A solid material which is typically hard, shiny, malleable, fusible, and ductile, with good electrical and thermal conductivity (e.g. iron, gold, silver, and aluminium, and alloys such as steel)
The steel tracks of a railway.
Gold and silver (as tinctures in blazoning).
Broken stone for use in making roads.
Molten glass before it is blown or cast.
Heavy metal or similar rock music.
Made from or coated with metal.
Make or mend (a road) with road metal.
--Examples--
‘an adjustable pole made of metal’
‘being a metal, aluminium readily conducts heat’
‘the locomotive is presently being made ready for operation over Network SouthEast metals’
‘the work also involves dealing with rock aggregates for potential use as suitable road metal’
‘industrial music is also a blend of metal and techno’
‘crunching power-trio metal’
‘a range of metalled key rings’
‘follow the metalled road for about 200 yards’
‘the road was metalled and tolls charged for the upkeep’

adjective

(of an implement or weapon) having a sharpened blade for cutting.
--Examples--
‘a regular square-edged tile’
‘edged tools used by carpenters’
‘a single-edged razor blade’

--Word--
metalepsis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The rhetorical figure consisting in the metonymical substitution of one word for another which is itself a metonym; (more generally) any metaphorical usage resulting from a series or succession of figurative substitutions.
--Examples--
--Word--
metaleptic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Rhetoric. Relating to or of the nature of the figure of metalepsis.
--Examples--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
= metaleptic (specifically in Rhetoric).
--Examples--

metaleptically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--

--Word--
metallic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or resembling metal or metals.
(of sound) resembling that produced by metal objects striking each other; sharp and ringing.
(of a person's voice) emanating via an electronic medium.
Having the lustre of metal; iridescent.
A paint, fabric, or colour with a metallic sheen.
--Examples--
‘metallic alloys’
‘a curious metallic taste’
‘the blade locked into place with a heavy metallic clunk’
‘a metallic voice rasped tinnily from a speaker’
‘a beautiful metallic green sports car’
‘ultra-bright solid colours, pearls, metallics, and more’
--Word--
metallicity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The property of being metallic.
The proportion of the material of a star or other celestial object that is an element other than hydrogen or helium.
--Examples--
‘another study of these galaxies shows that they have very low metallicities’

--Word--
metallism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The theory that all currency should be in the form of metal coins. Also: the theory that any currency should consist of a commodity (usually some metal) so that the exchange value and purchasing power of the commodity (considered independently of its monetary role) determines that of the currency.
--Examples--
--Word--
metallist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Economics. An advocate of metal coinage as the principal or sole currency; specifically an adherent of the theory of metallism.
--Examples--
--Word--
lithography 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process of printing from a flat surface treated so as to repel the ink except where it is required for printing.
A method analogous to lithography, used in making printed circuits.
--Examples--

--Word--
metallocene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a group of organometallic compounds that consist of a metal atom bonded between two cyclopentadienyl (or similar aromatic) rings in a sandwich structure, used especially as catalysts in polymer synthesis.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Meanings--

metalloid

noun
--Meanings--

metal. 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Metallurgical or metallurgy.
--Examples--
--Word--
metalogic 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Logic. The study of the structure and formal properties of logical theories and systems.
--Examples--
--Word--
metalogical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That lies outside the scope or boundaries of logical analysis; specifically that exists prior to or at a more fundamental level than conceptual understanding.
Logic. Of or relating to metalogic.
--Examples--
--Word--
metaloph 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(In some mammalian orders) the posterior ridge of a molar or premolar tooth; compare "ectoloph", lopho-.

--Word--
perforating ulcer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
piercing 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having or showing shrewdness or keen intelligence.
(of a sound) extremely high or loud.
(of wind or extreme cold) seeming to cut through one.
(of a feeling) intense, typically in a distressing way.
A small hole in a part of the body, typically other than the ears, made so as to insert a ring, stud, or other piece of jewellery.
A ring, stud, or other piece of jewellery worn in a pierced part of the body.
--Examples--
‘her piercing analysis’
‘a tall blonde with piercing eyes’
‘she let out a piercing scream’
‘the piercing cold of winter’
‘I recall one moment of piercing sadness’
‘this is the place to get your tattoo or piercing done’
‘two months ago, I decided to take out all my piercings’
--Word--
metal 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A solid material which is typically hard, shiny, malleable, fusible, and ductile, with good electrical and thermal conductivity (e.g. iron, gold, silver, and aluminium, and alloys such as steel)
The steel tracks of a railway.
Gold and silver (as tinctures in blazoning).
Broken stone for use in making roads.
Molten glass before it is blown or cast.
Heavy metal or similar rock music.
Made from or coated with metal.
Make or mend (a road) with road metal.
--Examples--
‘an adjustable pole made of metal’
‘being a metal, aluminium readily conducts heat’
‘the locomotive is presently being made ready for operation over Network SouthEast metals’
‘the work also involves dealing with rock aggregates for potential use as suitable road metal’
‘industrial music is also a blend of metal and techno’
‘crunching power-trio metal’
‘a range of metalled key rings’
‘follow the metalled road for about 200 yards’
‘the road was metalled and tolls charged for the upkeep’
--Word--
metally 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Metallic, metalline. Now chiefly informal.
--Examples--
--Word--
noise-shaping 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various processes which alter the frequency distribution of the noise associated with a signal; specifically a noise-reduction technique used in the quantization of analogue signals.
--Examples--
--Word--
sheathe 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Put (a weapon such as a knife or sword) into a sheath.
Encase (something) in a close-fitting or protective covering.
--Examples--
‘I sheathed my dagger’
‘when lion cubs strike out at one another, they keep their claws sheathed’
‘her legs were sheathed in black stockings’

--Word--
metamorphic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Denoting or relating to rock that has undergone transformation by heat, pressure, or other natural agencies, e.g. in the folding of strata or the nearby intrusion of igneous rocks.
Of or marked by metamorphosis.
--Examples--
‘metamorphic gneisses’
‘the supermodels' metamorphic ability to bend their looks’
--Word--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Exhibiting or characterized by metamorphosis.
--Examples--
--Word--
metamorphism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Alteration of the composition or structure of a rock by heat, pressure, or other natural agency.
--Examples--
‘all the rocks were subjected to several phases of metamorphism and deformation’

metamorphism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--

--Word--
metamorphize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To change the form or character of (something); to cause to undergo metamorphosis or metamorphism.
Metamorphose.
--Examples--
--Word--
metamorphopsia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Defective visual perception in which objects appear distorted in shape, size, etc.
--Examples--
--Word--
metamorphosize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To cause to undergo a change of form, nature, or character; to metamorphose (a person or thing).
To undergo a change of form, nature, or character; to metamorphose.
--Examples--
--Word--
metamorphose 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of an insect or amphibian) undergo metamorphosis, especially into the adult form.
Change or cause to change completely in form or nature.
Subject (rock) to metamorphism.
--Examples--
‘feed the larvae to your fish before they metamorphose into adults’
‘overnight, family houses metamorphose into bed and breakfast as 7,000 visitors roll into town’
‘the extreme heat metamorphosed the sandstone, baking it white and producing a quartzite rock’
--Word--
metamorphosed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of an insect or amphibian) having undergone metamorphosis, especially into the adult form.
(of rock) subjected to metamorphism.
--Examples--
‘the metamorphosed larvae leave the water by climbing plants’
‘a metamorphosed sandstone’

--Word--
metamorphosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in an insect or amphibian) the process of transformation from an immature form to an adult form in two or more distinct stages.
A change of the form or nature of a thing or person into a completely different one.
--Examples--
‘the persistence of the larval tail during metamorphosis’
‘in insects with a complete metamorphosis the wings arise from thickenings of the epidermis’
‘his metamorphosis from presidential candidate to talk-show host’

--Word--
metanalysis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process by which the division between words or parts of words is changed, resulting in the creation of a new word (as in the development of an apron from a napron)
--Examples--
‘these forms probably arose through metanalysis’

metanephros 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The most caudal and latest-developing part of the nephrogenic tissue of vertebrate embryos, which becomes the permanent kidney in amniotes.

--Examples--
--Word--
metaphysicize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
metaphysics 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
The branch of philosophy that deals with the first principles of things, including abstract concepts such as being, knowing, identity, time, and space.
Abstract theory with no basis in reality.
--Examples--
‘they would regard the question of the initial conditions for the universe as belonging to the realm of metaphysics or religion’
‘his concept of society as an organic entity is, for market liberals, simply metaphysics’

metaphor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A figure of speech in which a word or phrase is applied to an object or action to which it is not literally applicable.
A thing regarded as representative or symbolic of something else.
--Examples--
‘when we speak of gene maps and gene mapping, we use a cartographic metaphor’
‘her poetry depends on suggestion and metaphor’
‘the amounts of money being lost by the company were enough to make it a metaphor for an industry that was teetering’

metaphrast 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who paraphrases a literary work or puts a composition into a different literary form, e.g. by turning prose into verse, or one metre into another. Also: a translator, especially one who makes a literal, word-for-word translation.

--Word--
metaplasm 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Grammar. Usually with reference to classical languages: the alteration of a word by addition, removal, or transposition of letters or syllables; an instance of this.
Rhetoric. The transposition of words from their usual or natural order. Now rare.
Originally: the granular (as opposed to the hyaline) portion of cytoplasm, containing various inclusions. Later also: granular substance within a nucleus, especially that of a plant oocyte or ovum.
--Examples--
--Word--
metaplastic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or characterized by abnormal change in the nature of a tissue.
--Examples--
‘metaplastic breast carcinoma’
‘metaplastic bone formation’

--Word--
metapodium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Anatomy and Zoology. Originally: the metatarsus. Later also: the metatarsus or metacarpus; (occasionally) a metapodial bone.
Zoology. The posterior lobe of the foot in certain molluscs.

metarule

A rule governing the content, form, or application of other rules.
--Examples--
‘three particular metarules of international law provide especially weak support’
--Word--
meta 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
(of a creative work) referring to itself or to the conventions of its genre; self-referential.
--Examples--
‘the enterprise is inherently ‘meta’, since it doesn't review movies, for example, it reviews the reviewers who review movies’

--Word--
metasilicate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: the anion SiO₃ 2−; a salt or mineral containing this. Later: any compound or mineral having cyclic or very long chain anions of formula (SiO₃ 2−)ₙ.
--Examples--
--Word--
metasilicic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An oxoacid of silicon obtained by partial dehydration of orthosilicic acid and having the general formula H₂SiO₃, now believed not to exist in a monomeric state but to contain long-chain polyanions.
--Examples--
--Word--
metasoma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The posterior section of the body in various invertebrates that have a body divided into two or three distinct sections (e.g. arachnids, cephalopods, hemichordates, lophophorates, etc.); (Entomology) the broad or swollen part of the abdomen behind the petiole of many hymenoptera.
--Examples--

metasomatism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Change in the composition of a rock as a result of the introduction or removal of chemical constituents.
--Examples--
--Word--
metasomatosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Metasomatism.
--Examples--
--Word--
metasome 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Zoology. Originally: a metasoma. Later also: the segment of the body of copepods and certain other crustaceans that is situated between the cephalothoracic portion (cephalosome) and the urosome, anterior to the body's major articulation.
Geology. Originally: a mineral or rock formed by metasomatism (now rare). Later: a metasomatized layer of the upper mantle.

metastability 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
metastable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a state of equilibrium) stable provided it is subjected to no more than small disturbances.
(of a substance or particle) theoretically unstable but so long-lived as to be stable for practical purposes.
--Examples--
‘the amount of supercooling a liquid can accept while remaining in metastable equilibrium is limited’
‘the occurrence of metastable olivine and deep earthquakes in subducting lithosphere’
--Word--
metastably 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a metastable state or manner.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

A metastatic growth.
--Examples--
‘an increased risk of metastasis’
‘the patient developed pleural and liver metastases’

combining form

Denoting a change of position or condition.

--Word--
metel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "nut metel", "metel nut", "nut of metel". A poisonous fruit or seed with narcotic properties, variously identified with nux vomica (the fruit of Strychnos nux-vomica) or with the fruit of a species of thorn apple (genus Datura). Now historical.

--Word--
meteorite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A piece of rock or metal that has fallen to the earth's surface from outer space as a meteor. Over 90 per cent of meteorites are of rock while the remainder consist wholly or partly of iron and nickel.

--Word--
candle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A cylinder or block of wax or tallow with a central wick which is lit to produce light as it burns.
A unit of luminous intensity, superseded by the candela.
(of a poultry breeder) test (an egg) for freshness or fertility by holding it to the light.
--Examples--
‘the candle flickered in the cold night air’
‘an iced cake with nine lighted candles on it’
‘the egg was candled—it was fertile’

--Word--
metoestrus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A short period following oestrus in many mammals, marked by the cessation of sexual behaviour and corresponding to the early period of corpus luteum development.
--Examples--
--Word--
metewand 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A measuring rod; = "meteyard". regional and historical in later use.
Literary. A standard by which something is measured or judged; a criterion. Now archaic.
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A colourless, low-melting solid which polymerizes when distilled and is used in the manufacture of synthetic resins.

methadone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A powerful synthetic analgesic drug which is similar to morphine in its effects but less sedative and is used as a substitute drug in the treatment of morphine and heroin addiction.

methantheline 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "methantheline bromide". An anticholinergic drug used to treat peptic ulcer, hyperhidrosis, and bladder spasm; N,N- diethyl-N-methyl-2-[(9H-xanthen-9-ylcarbonyl)oxy]ethanaminium bromide), C₂₁H₂₆BrNO₃. [International Nonproprietary Name (1996) and British Approved Name (1997): methanthelinium bromide.]

methenamine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly Pharmacology. The compound hexamethylenetetramine, (CH₂)₆N₄, or a derivative of this (often with mandelic acid), especially when used as a urinary antiseptic.
Pathology. In full "methenamine silver". A solution of methenamine and silver nitrate, used in several histological stains.

mether 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A wooden vessel used for measuring liquids; a square wooden drinking vessel, frequently used as a measure of liquor. Also (Scottish): a similar vessel used for holding or measuring grain (rare).

methicillin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A semi-synthetic form of penicillin used against staphylococci which produce penicillinase.
--Examples--
--Word--
methide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The methyl anion CH₃ −, originally specifically in a compound with a metal atom. Later also: any compound that contains this anion or a substituted derivative of it.
More fully "quinone methide". A quinone derivative with a methylene group in place of one of the oxygen atoms.
A carbide whose anion is a single carbon atom (C4−), and which gives methane on hydrolysis.

methylamine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of the three compounds that can be formed by replacing one or more of the hydrogen atoms in ammonia with a methyl group or groups; especially CH₃NH₂ (monomethylamine), a colourless, flammable gas with a fishy or ammonia-like odour.
--Examples--
--Word--
methylaniline 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An aniline derivative, C₆H₅NHCH₃, that is methylated on the nitrogen atom and that is a basic, colourless liquid that turns brown on exposure to air.

noun

methylmalonic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Chemistry and Biochemistry"methylmalonic acid"noun a dicarboxylic acid isomeric with succinic acid, (CH₃)CH(COOH)₂.
Medicine"methylmalonic aciduria"noun the presence of an abnormally large amount of methylmalonic acid in the urine, especially as a manifestation of an inborn error of metabolism; an instance of this.
Medicine"methylmalonic acidaemia"noun any of several inherited metabolic disorders characterized by the presence of an abnormally large quantity of methylmalonic acid in the blood and urine.

methine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A trivalent group or radical consisting of a carbon and a hydrogen atom, specifically the group =CH—; also called methene or methenyl. Also (especially in Dye Chemistry): designating a dye, pigment, etc., containing one or more such groups.

methionic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

methionine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sulphur-containing amino acid which is a constituent of most proteins and is essential to the diet of vertebrates.

--Word--
methysergide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A lysergic acid derivative that acts as a selective serotonin receptor antagonist, and is sometimes used, usually in the form of its maleate, for the prevention of severe migraine and cluster headaches; 1-methyl-d-lysergic acid butanolamide, C₂₁H₂₈N₃O₂.

method 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A particular procedure for accomplishing or approaching something, especially a systematic or established one.
The quality of being well organized and systematic in thought or action.
--Examples--
‘a method for software maintenance’
‘labour-intensive production methods’
‘historical study is the rigorous combination of knowledge and method’
‘Paula was at least hip to the Method’
‘reliance on Method technique’

--Word--
Methow 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a North American Indian people formerly inhabiting the Methow Valley in north central Washington state and a small area on the other side of the Okanogan River just south of Mallott, and now one of the Colville Confederated Tribes, mainly living on the Colville Reservation in the same area.
The Interior Salishan language of the Methows, a dialect of Okanagan. Now historical.
--Examples--

methoxychlor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An organochlorine insecticide of similar chemical structure to DDT, but with lower toxicity and persistence in the environment; 1,1,1-trichloro-2,2-bis(p-methoxyphenyl)ethane, (C₆H₄OCH₃)₂CHCCl₃.

methuselah 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A wine bottle of eight times the standard size.
(in the Bible) a patriarch, the grandfather of Noah, who is said to have lived for 969 years (Gen. 5:27).
Used to refer to a very old person.
--Examples--
‘I'm feeling older than Methuselah’

Metis 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
(especially in western Canada) a person of mixed indigenous and Euro-American ancestry, in particular one of a group of such people who in the 19th century constituted the so-called Metis nation in the areas around the Red and Saskatchewan rivers.
Relating to the Metis.

metoestrum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= metoestrus. Now chiefly in "metoestrum cell".
--Examples--
--Word--
metoestrus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A short period following oestrus in many mammals, marked by the cessation of sexual behaviour and corresponding to the early period of corpus luteum development.

--Word--
metol 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A soluble white compound used as a photographic developer.
--Examples--
--Word--
Metonic cycle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A period of 19 years (235 lunar months), after which the new and full moons return to the same day of the year. It was the basis of the ancient Greek calendar, and is still used for calculating movable feasts such as Easter.
--Examples--
--Word--
metonym 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A word, name, or expression used as a substitute for something else with which it is closely associated. For example, Washington is a metonym for the US government.

--Word--
me-too 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the adoption or imitation of another person's views or policies, often for political advantage.
(of a product) designed to emulate or rival another which has already been successful.
--Examples--
‘he has been a me-too liberal on many of the issues that matter most’
‘me-too drugs’
--Word--
me-tooism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The practice of adopting or imitating a policy successfully or popularly proposed by a (usually rival) person or party; (more widely) the practice of following a popular trend.
--Examples--
--Word--
metope 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A square space between triglyphs in a Doric frieze.
--Examples--
--Word--
metope 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A square space between triglyphs in a Doric frieze.
--Examples--
--Word--
metopic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Physical Anthropology, Anatomy, and Medicine. Designating the suture between the two halves of the frontal bone of the skull (also called frontal suture); of or relating to this suture. Also (of a skull): exhibiting metopism.
--Examples--
--Word--
metopion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In craniometry: the midpoint of a line drawn to connect the frontal tuberosities.
--Examples--
--Word--
metopism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Persistence of the frontal (metopic) suture of the skull (which commonly undergoes closure and obliteration in childhood).
--Examples--
--Word--
metopomancy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Divination by the (lines on the) forehead or face.
--Examples--
--Word--
metopon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A narcotic analgesic derived from morphine, usually administered as the hydrochloride; dihydromethylmorphinone, C₁₈H₂₁NO₃.

--Word--
metre 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
The fundamental unit of length in the metric system, equal to 100 centimetres or approximately 39.37 inches.
A race over a specified number of metres.
The rhythm of a piece of poetry, determined by the number and length of feet in a line.
The basic rhythmic pattern of beats in a piece of music.
--Examples--
‘sit two metres away from the TV screen’
‘the wall was less than a metre high’
‘the 200 metres’
‘the Horatian ode has an intricate governing metre’
‘unexpected changes of stress and metre’
‘a dance song in fast quadratic metre’
‘Prokofiev's complex metres’
--Word--
metre-candle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Lux.
--Examples--
--Word--
metred 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Composed in metre; metrical. Also (more generally): rhythmical.
--Examples--
--Word--
metre-kilogram-second 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Denoting a system of measure using the metre, kilogram, and second as the basic units of length, mass, and time.
--Examples--
--Word--
metreless 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Without metre.
--Examples--
--Word--
metre 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
The fundamental unit of length in the metric system, equal to 100 centimetres or approximately 39.37 inches.
A race over a specified number of metres.
The rhythm of a piece of poetry, determined by the number and length of feet in a line.
The basic rhythmic pattern of beats in a piece of music.
--Examples--
‘sit two metres away from the TV screen’
‘the wall was less than a metre high’
‘the 200 metres’
‘the Horatian ode has an intricate governing metre’
‘unexpected changes of stress and metre’
‘a dance song in fast quadratic metre’
‘Prokofiev's complex metres’

--Word--
-metry 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
In nouns denoting procedures and systems corresponding to names of instruments ending in -meter (such as calorimetry corresponding to calorimeter).
--Examples--
--Word--
metric 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or based on the metre as a unit of length.
Relating to or using the metric system.
Relating to or denoting a metric.
A system or standard of measurement.
(in business) a set of figures or statistics that measure results.
A binary function of a topological space which gives, for any two points of the space, a value equal to the distance between them, or to a value treated as analogous to distance for the purpose of analysis.
The metric system.
Relating to or composed in a poetic metre.
The metre of a poem.
--Examples--
‘all measurements are given in metric form’
‘we should have gone metric years ago’
‘the metric equation of Minkowski space–time’
‘the levels of branching are arbitrary and no precise metric is applied to distance between the nodes’
‘the external structure of space–time is described by the Schwarzschild metric’
‘it's easier to work in metric’
‘the public recitation of metric, rhyming verse’
--Word--
metrical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or composed in poetic metre.
Of or involving measurement.
--Examples--
‘metrical translations of the Psalms’
‘a metrical analysis of male and female scapulae’

--Word--
metric 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or based on the metre as a unit of length.
Relating to or using the metric system.
Relating to or denoting a metric.
A system or standard of measurement.
(in business) a set of figures or statistics that measure results.
A binary function of a topological space which gives, for any two points of the space, a value equal to the distance between them, or to a value treated as analogous to distance for the purpose of analysis.
The metric system.
Relating to or composed in a poetic metre.
The metre of a poem.
--Examples--
‘all measurements are given in metric form’
‘we should have gone metric years ago’
‘the metric equation of Minkowski space–time’
‘the levels of branching are arbitrary and no precise metric is applied to distance between the nodes’
‘the external structure of space–time is described by the Schwarzschild metric’
‘it's easier to work in metric’
‘the public recitation of metric, rhyming verse’

metrizable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a topological space: capable of being assigned a metric which makes it a metric space with the same topology as the original space.
--Examples--

metron

noun
--Meanings--

metropathia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A disease of the uterus; an instance of this; chiefly in "metropathia haemorrhagica", a condition characterized by irregular and excessive uterine bleeding associated with cystic hyperplasia of the endometrium, seen especially in perimenopausal women.

--Word--
metropolis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The capital or chief city of a country or region.
A very large and busy city.
--Examples--
‘he preferred the peaceful life of the countryside to the bustle of the metropolis’
‘by the late eighteenth century Edo had grown to a metropolis with a population of nearly one million’
--Word--
metropolitan 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a metropolis.
Relating to or denoting the parent state of a colony.
Relating to or denoting a metropolitan or his see.
A bishop having authority over the bishops of a province, in particular (in Orthodox Churches) one ranking above archbishop and below patriarch.
An inhabitant of a metropolis.
--Examples--
‘the Boston metropolitan area’
‘metropolitan Spain’
‘a metropolitan bishop’
‘the post of Metropolitan of Moldavia and Bucovina’
‘Metropolitan Aleksei of Leningrad and Novgorod’
‘a sophisticated metropolitan’

Metternich 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Klemens Wenzel Nepomuk Lothar, Prince of Metternich-Winneburg-Beilstein (1773–1859), Austrian statesman. As Foreign Minister (1809–48), he was one of the organizers of the Congress of Vienna (1814–15), which devised the settlement of Europe after the Napoleonic Wars.

--Word--
metump 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly amongst North American Indians: a strap for bearing or supporting a weight; specifically a band passed across the forehead or chest and used to haul a burden; = "tump-line". Also (occasionally): the burden so supported.
--Examples--
--Word--
metump 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly amongst North American Indians: a strap for bearing or supporting a weight; specifically a band passed across the forehead or chest and used to haul a burden; = "tump-line". Also (occasionally): the burden so supported.

metewand 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A measuring rod; = "meteyard". regional and historical in later use.
Literary. A standard by which something is measured or judged; a criterion. Now archaic.

--Word--
meum 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
The herb spignel, Meum athamanticum. Now chiefly (in form Meum): the monospecific genus of the family Apiaceae (Umbelliferae) containing this herb.
The principle that a person has sole rights to his or her own property, and no rights to another's. Chiefly in the phrase "meum and tuum"noun (the distinction between) what is mine or one's own and what is yours or another's.
--Examples--

--Word--
mew 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
(of a cat or gull) make a characteristic high-pitched crying noise.
The high-pitched cry of a cat or gull.
A cage or building for trained hawks, especially while they are moulting.
(of a trained hawk) moult.
Confine (a trained hawk) to a cage or building while moulting.
Confine (someone) in a restricting place or situation.
--Examples--
‘cats mewing to be fed’
‘a kitten's mew’
‘the eyasses clung dully to their leashes as if they were mewing’
‘Raoul orders his tent to be pitched and his hawks to be mewed’
‘he was mewed up in close low stuffy rooms’

adverb
--Meanings--
Without preposition: towards me; in my direction. Now rare.

‘urban scenes depicting the daily life of Mexicans’
--Word--
Mexico 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A country in North America, with extensive coastlines on the Gulf of Mexico and the Pacific Ocean, bordered by the US to the north; population 127,000,000 (estimated 2015); official language, Spanish; capital, Mexico City.
A state of central Mexico, to the west of Mexico City; capital, Toluca de Lerdo.

mezzanine 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A low storey between two others in a building, typically between the ground and first floors.
The lowest balcony of a theatre, cinema, etc., or the front rows of the balcony.
Relating to or denoting unsecured, higher-yielding loans that are subordinate to bank loans and secured loans but rank above equity.
--Examples--
‘a mezzanine floor’
‘he came up to bat and was greeted with little optimism by the experienced fans in my sector of the mezzanine’
‘the company received $9.1 m in mezzanine financing’

--Word--
mezzotint 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A print made from an engraved copper or steel plate, the surface of which has been scraped and polished to give areas of shade and light respectively. The technique was much used in the 17th, 18th, and early 19th centuries for the reproduction of paintings.
The technique or process of making mezzotints.
Engrave (a picture) in mezzotint.
--Examples--
‘a series of mezzotints produced in the early 19th century’
‘his portrait was engraved in mezzotint by John Dixon’
‘he practised engraving, mezzotinting, and water colouring’
--Word--

hum 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make a low, steady continuous sound like that of a bee.
Sing with closed lips.
(of a place) be filled with a low, steady continuous sound.
Be in a state of great activity.
Smell unpleasant.
A low, steady continuous sound.
An unwanted low-frequency noise in an amplifier caused by variation of electric current, especially the alternating frequency of the mains.
--Examples--
‘the computers hummed’
‘he hummed softly to himself’
‘she was humming a cheerful tune’
‘the room hummed with an expectant murmur’
‘the house was humming with preparations for the dance’
‘when the wind drops this stuff really hums’
‘the hum of insects’
‘a low hum of conversation’

--Word--
MI5 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(in the UK) the governmental agency responsible for dealing with internal security and counter-intelligence on British territory. Formed in 1909, the agency was officially named the Security Service in 1964, but the name MI5 remains in popular use.
--Examples--
--Word--
MI6 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(in the UK) the governmental agency responsible for dealing with matters of internal security and counter-intelligence overseas. Formed in 1912, the agency was officially named the Secret Intelligence Service in 1964, but the name MI6 remains in popular use.

Miami 
--Type--
proper noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A city and port in south-eastern Florida; population 413,201 (est. 2008). Its subtropical climate and miles of beaches make this and the resort island of Miami Beach, separated from the mainland by Biscayne Bay, a year-round holiday resort.
A member of a North American people formerly living mainly in Illinois, Indiana, and Wisconsin and more recently inhabiting areas of Ohio, Kansas, and Oklahoma.
The dialect of Illinois formerly spoken by the Miami but now extinct.
Relating to the Miami or their language.

miargyrite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A monoclinic sulphide of silver and antimony, AgSbS₂, a minor ore of silver which usually occurs as thick, tabular, steel-grey to black crystals, and contains less silver than the related minerals proustite and pyrargyrite.

--Examples--
--Word--
Mycenae 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient city in Greece, situated near the coast in the north-eastern Peloponnese, the centre of the late Bronze Age Mycenaean civilization. The capital of King Agamemnon, it was at its most prosperous c.1400–1200 BC; systematic excavation of the site began in 1840.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mycenaean 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a late Bronze Age civilization in Greece represented by finds at Mycenae and other ancient cities of the Peloponnese.
An inhabitant of Mycenae or member of the Mycenaean people.
--Examples--
--Word--
mycete 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fungus; especially a microscopic or pathogenic fungus.
--Examples--
--Word--
mycetes 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Treated as plural. Originally: fungi and bacteria (considered as a division of the vegetable kingdom). Now: specifically fungi, especially microscopic pathogenic fungi.
--Examples--
--Word--
mycetism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Poisoning caused by the ingestion of toxic mushrooms; an instance of this.
--Examples--
--Word--
mycetocyte 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of the large cells found in certain insects, especially homopteran bugs and bird lice, which contain symbiotic microorganisms, usually yeasts or bacteria, and sometimes form a distinct organ (a mycetome).
--Examples--
--Word--
mycetogenous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Caused by fungi.
--Examples--
--Word--
mycetoma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chronic inflammation of the tissues caused by infection with a fungus or with certain bacteria.
--Examples--
--Word--
mycetoma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chronic inflammation of the tissues caused by infection with a fungus or with certain bacteria.

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the nature of or affected by (a) mycetoma.

mycetome 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An organ consisting of an aggregation of mycetocytes, found in certain insects.

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
= mycophagous.

--Word--
mycetophilid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A fly of the dipteran family Mycetophilidae comprising the fungus gnats, whose larvae feed chiefly on fungi.
Of or relating to the family Mycetophilidae.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mycetozoa 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
With singular concord: a taxon comprising slime moulds. Treated as plural: members of this taxon collectively. Compare earlier Myxogastres, "Myxomycetes".
--Examples--
--Word--
mycetozoan 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A slime mould; specifically a member of the taxon Mycetozoa.
Of or relating to the taxon Mycetozoa; caused by mycetozoans.
--Examples--
--Word--
mycetozoon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= mycetozoan.

Ney, Michel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1768–1815), French marshal. One of Napoleon's leading generals, he commanded the French cavalry at Waterloo (1815), but after Napoleon's overthrow was executed by the Bourbons.
--Examples--
--Word--
Michelangelesque 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or characteristic of Michelangelo; after the manner of Michelangelo's work, especially in being solid, bold, or statuesque.
--Examples--
--Word--
Michelangelo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1475–1564), Italian sculptor, painter, architect, and poet; full name Michelangelo Buonarroti.
--Examples--
--Word--
Michelin 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
André (1853–1931) and Édouard (1859–1940), French industrialists. They founded the Michelin Tyre Company in 1888 and pioneered the use of pneumatic tyres on motor vehicles.
--Examples--
--Word--
Michelozzo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1396–1472), Italian architect and sculptor; full name Michelozzo di Bartolommeo. In partnership with Ghiberti and Donatello he led a revival of interest in Roman architecture.
--Examples--
--Word--
Michelson interferometer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of interferometer for measuring small distances in which a beam of light is split by a half-silvered mirror into two beams that travel by different paths, are reflected by different mirrors (one fixed, one movable), and are then recombined to give an interference pattern.
--Examples--
--Word--
Michener, James 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1907–97), US writer; full name James Albert Michener. He wrote Tales of the South Pacific (1947), which was made into the Broadway musical South Pacific (1949). He was also known for other fictionalized histories that include Hawaii (1959), Chesapeake (1978), Texas (1985), Alaska (1988), and A Miracle in Seville (1995).

michi 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= Klaas's cuckoo, Chrysococcyx klaas.
--Examples--
--Word--
Michigan 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state in the northern US, bordered on the west, north, and east by Lakes Michigan, Superior, Huron, and Erie; population 10,003,422 (est. 2008); capital, Lansing. It was acquired from Britain by the US in 1783, becoming the 26th state in 1837.

--Word--
Mycoderma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of fungi including yeasts that form pellicles or skins on the surfaces of certain liquids, and that are involved in the fermentation of alcoholic liquids into vinegar, and formerly including other pellicle-forming organisms (especially mother of vinegar), organisms causing certain diseases of the skin or mucous membranes, and organisms believed to be responsible for nitrogen fixation in soil; (also mycoderma) a fungus of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
mycodermic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the genus Mycoderma; consisting of organisms of this genus.

--Word--
microbacterium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any small, especially rod-shaped, bacterium. Now rare.
Specifically. Any member of the genus Microbacterium, comprising very small, chiefly saprophytic, coryneform Gram-positive rods; especially M. lacticum, a heat-resistant member of the bacterial flora of milk. Also (in form Microbacterium): the genus itself.

microcyst 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mycology and Microbiology. Originally: an encysted myxamoeba with a thick, protective cell wall. Later also: a small, encapsulated resting cell produced by many myxobacteria.
Pathology. A microscopic or very small cyst.

microcyte 
--Type--

--Meanings--

microcythaemia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= microcytosis. Also: a disease characterized by microcytosis; specifically thalassaemia (now rare, perhaps obsolete).
--Examples--
--Word--
microcytic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
microcytosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The presence of an abnormally large number of microcytes in the blood; reduction in the size of red blood cells.
--Examples--
--Word--
microclastic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
microclimate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The climate of a very small or restricted area, especially when this differs from the climate of the surrounding area.
--Examples--
‘the microclimate of the valley is fairly mild’

--Examples--
--Word--
microcosm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A community, place, or situation regarded as encapsulating in miniature the characteristics of something much larger.
Humankind regarded as the representation in miniature of the universe.
--Examples--
‘the city is a microcosm of modern Malaysia’
‘the belief in correspondences between the Universe and Man—between microcosm and macrocosm’
--Word--
microcosmal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or of the nature of a microcosm or microcosms.

microcosmography 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The description of a microcosm, or of man as a microcosm; an instance of this. Also nonce-use: a microcosmic representation.
--Examples--

--Examples--
--Word--
microlite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mineralogy. Any of a subgroup of minerals of the pyrochlore group, found in various pegmatites, that are complex oxides of tantalum and niobium with sodium and calcium, often with small amounts of other elements such as uranium and titanium, crystallizing in the cubic system as yellow, brownish, or blackish translucent crystals.
Geology. A microscopic acicular crystal with determinable optical properties, found in microcrystalline rocks and groundmasses.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--

micromolar 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating an amount, or a molar concentration, of the order of micromoles.
--Examples--
--Word--
micromole 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
One millionth of a mole.
--Examples--
--Word--
micromorph 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A small, or relatively small, form or variety of an organism; (Botany) a true-breeding small variant of a species.
Designating a fossil fauna consisting of micromorphs.
--Examples--
--Word--
micromorphology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The microscopic study of form or structure; form or structure (later especially surface topography) on a microscopic scale.
--Examples--
--Word--
micromorphological 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to micromorphology; apparent under micromorphological investigation.

micromorphological 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Meanings--
