--Examples--
--Word--
micromotion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Motion on a small scale; (originally specifically) small muscular movements, especially as recorded cinematographically for ergonomic studies (usually attributive).
--Examples--
--Word--
micro- 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
Small.
Of reduced or restricted size.
(used in units of measurement) denoting a factor of one millionth (10^-6)
--Examples--
‘microcar’
‘microdot’
‘microfarad’
--Word--
micron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A unit of length equal to one millionth of a metre, used in many technological and scientific fields.
--Examples--
--Word--
microneedle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A very fine needle used in micromanipulation.
--Examples--
--Word--
Micronesia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A region of the western Pacific to the north of Melanesia and north and west of Polynesia. It includes the Mariana, Caroline, and Marshall island groups and Kiribati.
A country in the western Pacific to the north of the equator, composed of hundreds of islands in the Caroline Islands group; population 104,000 (estimated 2015); languages, English (official), Austronesian languages; capital, Palikir. The islands were administered by the US as part of the Pacific Islands Trust Territory from 1947 and entered into free association with the US as an independent state in 1986.
--Examples--
--Word--
Micronesian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Micronesia, its people, or their languages.
A native of Micronesia.
The group of Austronesian languages spoken in Micronesia.

--Examples--
--Word--
micronucleus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: the smaller of the two types of nucleus of ciliate protozoans, which is involved in sexual reproduction. Later also: any relatively or abnormally small nucleus.
--Examples--
--Word--
micronutrient 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A chemical element or substance required in trace amounts for the normal growth and development of living organisms.

micropyle

noun

--Word--
Microscopium 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A small and inconspicuous southern constellation (the Microscope), between Piscis Austrinus and Sagittarius.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Microscopium.
--Examples--
‘the star Gamma Microscopii’

--Word--
microsomia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Abnormally small size of the body (dwarfism); (in full "microsomia fetalis") abnormally small size of the fetus for gestational age. Compare macrosomiarare. Perhaps Obsolete.
With distinguishing word: underdevelopment of part of the face, as a congenital malformation.
--Examples--
--Word--
microsommite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A trigonal aluminosilicate of sodium, calcium, and potassium which occurs as colourless crystals in volcanic rocks.

--Word--
microspecies 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A species differing only in minor characteristics from others of its group, typically one of limited geographical range forming part of an aggregate species.

noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A rodent of the subfamily Microtinae (family Muridae) of rodents, which includes voles, lemmings, muskrats, and mole-voles.
Belonging to the subfamily Microtinae; of or relating to rodents of this subfamily.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
microwave 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An electromagnetic wave with a wavelength in the range 0.001–0.3 m, shorter than that of a normal radio wave but longer than those of infrared radiation. Microwaves are used in radar, in communications, and for heating in microwave ovens and in various industrial processes.
An oven that uses microwaves to cook or heat food.
Cook (food) in a microwave oven.
--Examples--
‘microwave radiation’
‘a cheesecake was defrosting in the microwave’
‘he microwaved some steak out of the freezer’
--Word--

noun, verb

mid-body 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The middle or middle segment of the body of an animal or human; (Zoology) the mesosoma or thorax of an invertebrate.
Cell Biology. A structure found in the cleavage furrow between two daughter cells towards the end of telophase in animal cells, containing the remains of the spindle microtubules.
Situated in or forming the middle portion of the body of an organism; of or relating to this part.

--Word--
crowd 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large number of people gathered together in a disorganized or unruly way.
An audience, especially one at a sporting event.
A group of people who are linked by a common interest or activity.
The mass or multitude of ordinary people.
A large number of things regarded collectively.
(of a number of people) fill (a space) almost completely, leaving little or no room for movement.
(of a number of people) move into (a restricted space)
(of a group of people) form a tightly packed mass around.
Move too close to (someone)
Overwhelm and preoccupy (someone)
Exclude someone or something by taking their place.
--Examples--
‘a huge crowd gathered in the street outside’
‘they played before a 25,000 crowd’
‘a match marred by crowd trouble’
‘I've broken away from that whole junkie crowd’
‘you have to set yourself apart from the crowd’
‘free-thinkers who don't follow the crowd’
‘he'd become just another face in the crowd’
‘the crowd of tall buildings’
‘the dance floor was crowded with revellers’
‘they crowded into the cockpit’
‘photographers crowded round him’
‘don't crowd her, she needs air’
‘as demands crowd in on you it becomes difficult to keep things in perspective’
‘rampant plants will crowd out the less vigorous’

current 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Belonging to the present time; happening or being used or done now.
In common or general use.
A body of water or air moving in a definite direction, especially through a surrounding body of water or air in which there is less movement.
A flow of electricity which results from the ordered directional movement of electrically charged particles.
A quantity representing the rate of flow of electric charge, usually measured in amperes.
The general tendency or course of events or opinion.
--Examples--
‘keep abreast of current events’
‘I started my current job in 2001’
‘the other meaning of the word is still current’
‘ocean currents’
‘this completes the circuit so that a current flows to the lamp’
‘magnetic fields are produced by currents flowing in the cables’
‘at high currents there is wasteful power dissipation’
‘the student movement formed a distinct current of protest’

dish 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A shallow, flat-bottomed container for cooking or serving food.
The food contained or served in a dish.
A particular variety or preparation of food served as part of a meal.
All the items that have been used in the preparation, serving, and eating of a meal.
A shallow, concave receptacle, especially one intended to hold a particular substance.
A bowl-shaped radio aerial.
A sexually attractive person.
A thing that one enjoys or does well.
Information which is not generally known or available.
Concavity of a spoked wheel resulting from a difference in spoke tension on each side and consequent sideways displacement of the rim in relation to the hub.
Put food on to a plate or plates before a meal.
Dispense something in a casual or indiscriminate way.
Offer or present something, especially something regarded as substandard.
Subject others to criticism or punishment.
Gossip or share intimate information.
Utterly destroy or defeat.
Give concavity to (a wheel) by tensioning the spokes.
--Examples--
‘an ovenproof dish’
‘a dish of sauté potatoes’
‘fresh fish dishes’
‘I left the children to do the dishes’
‘the cats' water dish’
‘other channels are available with a larger dish’
‘I gather he's quite a dish’
‘as a public relations man this was my dish and the campaign was right up my street’
‘if he has the real dish I wish he'd tell us’
‘Steve was dishing up vegetables’
‘the banks dished out loans to all and sundry’
‘is your ISP short-changing you by dishing up outdated and perhaps incorrect information?’
‘you can dish it out but you can't take it’
‘groups gather to dish about romances’
‘the election interview dished Labour's chances’
‘this tool accurately checks for proper dishing of a wheel’

--Examples--
--Word--
middle 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
The point or position at an equal distance from the sides, edges, or ends of something.
The point at or around the centre of a period of time, activity, etc.
A person's waist and stomach.
The form or voice of a verb expressing reflexive or reciprocal action.
At an equal distance from the extremities of something; central.
(of a member of a group or sequence) placed so as to have the same number of members on each side.
Intermediate in rank, quality, or ability.
(of a language) of the period between the old and modern forms.
Denoting a voice of verbs in some languages, such as Greek, which expresses reciprocal or reflexive action.
Denoting a transitive verb in English which does not have an equivalent passive, e.g. had in he had an idea.
(in cricket, tennis, etc.) strike (the ball) with the middle of the bat, racket, or club.
--Examples--
‘she stood alone in the middle of the street’
‘we were married in the middle of December’
‘he had a towel round his middle’
‘the early and middle part of life’
‘middle and eastern Europe’
‘the woman was in her middle forties’
‘there is a dearth of talent at middle level’
‘Middle High German’
‘every shot he took on, he middled’

--Word--
burst 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Break open or apart suddenly and violently, especially as a result of an impact or internal pressure.
Cause to burst.
Be so full as almost to break open.
Feel a very strong or irrepressible emotion or impulse.
Issue suddenly and uncontrollably.
Open suddenly and forcibly.
Move suddenly and violently.
Suddenly begin doing or producing something.
Separate (continuous stationery) into single sheets.
An instance of breaking or splitting as a result of internal pressure or puncturing; an explosion.
A sudden brief outbreak.
A sudden issuing forth.
A period of continuous and intense effort.
--Examples--
‘one of the balloons burst’
‘the dam burst after days of torrential rain’
‘he burst the balloon’
‘the swollen river was expected to burst its banks’
‘the wardrobe was bursting with piles of clothes’
‘he was bursting with joy and excitement’
‘she was bursting to say something’
‘the words burst from him in an angry rush’
‘a door burst open and a girl raced out’
‘he burst into the room without knocking’
‘she burst on to the British art scene in 1985’
‘Sophie burst out laughing’
‘she burst into tears’
‘the aircraft burst into flames’
‘the mortar bursts were further away than before’
‘a burst of activity’
‘bursts of laughter’
‘her breath was coming in short bursts’
‘he sailed 474 miles in one 24-hour burst’

The social group between the upper and working classes, including professional and business people and their families.
Relating to the middle class.
Characteristic of the middle class, especially in attaching importance to convention, security, and material comfort.
--Examples--
‘the urbanization and expansion of the middle class’
‘commerce brought ever-increasing wealth to the middle classes’
‘a middle-class suburb’
‘a rebellion against middle-class values’
--Word--
middle-classdom 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The middle classes as a whole; the property of being middle class.
--Examples--
--Word--
middle-classism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= middle-classdom.

middle-classness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
middle 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
The point or position at an equal distance from the sides, edges, or ends of something.
The point at or around the centre of a period of time, activity, etc.
A person's waist and stomach.
The form or voice of a verb expressing reflexive or reciprocal action.
At an equal distance from the extremities of something; central.
(of a member of a group or sequence) placed so as to have the same number of members on each side.
Intermediate in rank, quality, or ability.
(of a language) of the period between the old and modern forms.
Denoting a voice of verbs in some languages, such as Greek, which expresses reciprocal or reflexive action.
Denoting a transitive verb in English which does not have an equivalent passive, e.g. had in he had an idea.
(in cricket, tennis, etc.) strike (the ball) with the middle of the bat, racket, or club.
--Examples--
‘she stood alone in the middle of the street’
‘we were married in the middle of December’
‘he had a towel round his middle’
‘the early and middle part of life’
‘middle and eastern Europe’
‘the woman was in her middle forties’
‘there is a dearth of talent at middle level’
‘Middle High German’
‘every shot he took on, he middled’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
middle earth 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The world, the earth, regarded as a middle region between heaven and hell, or as occupying the centre of the universe. Sometimes also: the inhabitants or things of the world, especially as opposed to those of heaven; worldly things as opposed to divine or spiritual things. In later use chiefly archaic or literary.
--Examples--

--Word--
rate 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A measure, quantity, or frequency, typically one measured against another quantity or measure.
The speed with which something moves or happens.
A fixed price paid or charged for something.
The amount of a charge or payment expressed as a percentage of another amount, or as a basis of calculation.
(in the UK) a tax on commercial land and buildings paid to a local authority; (in Northern Ireland and formerly in the UK) a tax levied on private property.
Assign a standard or value to (something) according to a particular scale.
Assign a standard, optimal, or limiting rating to (a piece of equipment)
(in the UK) assess the value of (a property) for the purpose of levying a local tax.
Consider to be of a certain quality or standard.
Be regarded in a specified way.
Have a high opinion of.
Be worthy of; merit.
--Examples--
‘the island has the lowest crime rate in the world’
‘buying up sites at a rate of one a month’
‘the band is shedding vocalists at an alarming rate’
‘your heart rate’
‘a £3.40 minimum hourly rate of pay’
‘advertising rates’
‘you'll find our current interest rate very competitive’
‘they were asked to rate their ability at different driving manoeuvres’
‘the hotel, rated four star, had no hot water’
‘the average life of the new bulb is rated at approximately 500 hours’
‘Atkinson rates him as Europe's top defender’
‘the program has been rated a great success’
‘Jeff still rates as one of the nicest people I have ever met’
‘Mike certainly rated her, goodness knows why’
‘the ambassador rated a bulletproof car and a police escort’

--Word--
tone 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A musical or vocal sound with reference to its pitch, quality, and strength.
A modulation of the voice expressing a particular feeling or mood.
A musical note or other sound used as a signal on a telephone or answering machine.
The general character or attitude of a place, piece of writing, situation, etc.
An atmosphere of respectability or class.
A basic interval in classical Western music, equal to two semitones and separating, for example, the first and second notes of an ordinary scale (such as C and D, or E and F sharp); a major second.
The particular quality of brightness, deepness, or hue of a shade of a colour.
The general effect of colour or of light and shade in a picture.
A slight degree of difference in the intensity of a colour.
(in some languages, such as Chinese) a particular pitch pattern on a syllable used to make semantic distinctions.
(in some languages, such as English) intonation on a word or phrase used to add functional meaning.
The normal level of firmness or slight contraction in a resting muscle.
The normal level of activity in a nerve fibre.
Give greater strength or firmness to (the body or a muscle)
(of a muscle or other bodily part) became stronger or firmer.
Harmonize with (something) in terms of colour.
Give (a monochrome picture) an altered colour in finishing by means of a chemical solution.
tone something down
Make something less harsh in sound or colour.
Make something less extreme or intense.
--Examples--
‘they were speaking in hushed tones’
‘the piano tone appears lacking in warmth’
‘a firm tone of voice’
‘my friend and I lowered the tone with our oafish ways’
‘there was a general tone of ill-concealed glee in the reporting’
‘they don't feel he gives the place tone’
‘the B flat clarinet's part is written one tone higher than the pitch required’
‘stained glass in vivid tones of red and blue’
‘an attractive colour which is even in tone and texture’
‘a reduction of muscle tone’
‘a certain amount of daily exercise is essential to maintain proper body tone and function’
‘vagal tone’
‘exercise tones up the muscles’
‘his leg muscles had toned up’
‘the rich orange colour of the wood tones beautifully with the yellow roses’
‘it's a good idea to sepia tone the whole print first’
‘a green-tinged moisturizer helps to tone down a ruddy complexion’
‘I just hope we can now begin to tone down the rhetoric’

flight

noun, verb

The action or process of flying through the air.

The swift passage of time.
A flock or large body of birds or insects in the air, especially when migrating.
A group of aircraft operating together, especially an RAF or USAF unit of about six aircraft.
The action of fleeing.
The selling of currency or shares by many investors.
A series of steps between floors or levels.
A series of hurdles across a racetrack.
A sequence of locks by which a canal ascends an incline.
An extravagant or far-fetched idea or thought process.
The tail of a dart.
(in soccer, cricket, etc.) deliver (a ball) with well-judged trajectory and pace.
Provide (an arrow or dart) with feathers or vanes.
Shoot (wildfowl) in flight.

forty 
--Type--
cardinal number
--Meanings--
The number equivalent to the product of four and ten; ten less than fifty; 40.
The numbers from forty to forty-nine, especially the years of a century or of a person's life.
Forty years old.
Forty miles an hour.
A size of garment or other merchandise denoted by forty.
The third point won by a player in a game.
The central North Sea between Scotland and southern Norway, so called from its prevailing depth of forty fathoms or more.
A shipping forecast area covering the central North Sea east of Scotland.

‘a tall woman of about forty’

‘up forty-love on his serve, he hit two double faults’
--Word--
front 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
The side or part of an object that presents itself to view or that is normally seen or used first; the most forward part of something.
The position directly ahead of someone or something; the most forward position or place.
The forward-facing part of a person's body, on the opposite side to their back.
The part of a garment covering a person's front.
A woman's bust or cleavage.
Any face of a building, especially that of the main entrance.
The foremost line or part of an armed force; the furthest position that an army has reached and where the enemy is or may be engaged.
The direction towards which a line of troops faces when formed.
A particular formation of troops for battle.
A particular situation or sphere of operation.
An organized political group.
The forward edge of an advancing mass of air.
An appearance or form of behaviour assumed by a person to conceal their genuine feelings.
A person or organization serving as a cover for subversive or illegal activities.
Boldness and confidence of manner.
A person's face or forehead.
Of or at the front.
(of a vowel sound) formed by raising the tongue, excluding the blade and tip, towards the hard palate.
(of a building or piece of land) have the front facing or directed towards.
Be or stand in front of.
Provide (something) with a front or facing of a particular type or material.
Lead or be the most prominent member in (an organization, group, or activity)
Present or host (a television or radio programme)
Act as a front or cover for illegal or secret activity.
Adopt a particular expression or form of behaviour to conceal one's genuine feelings.
Make an appearance; turn up.
Stand face to face with; confront.
Articulate (a vowel sound) with the tongue further forward.
Place (a sentence element) at the beginning of a sentence instead of in its usual position, typically for emphasis or as a feature of some dialects, as in horrible it was.
--Examples--
‘a page at the front of the book had been torn out’
‘he sealed the envelope and wrote on the front’
‘she quickly turned her head to face the front’
‘she rolled over on to her front’
‘porridge slopped from the tray on to his shirt front’
‘get your eyes off my front, meathead’
‘the west front of the Cathedral’
‘his regiment was immediately sent to the front’
‘the Spartans preserving an even and unbroken front’
‘there was some good news on the jobs front’
‘the National Progressive Patriotic Front’
‘she put on a brave front’
‘the CIA identified the company as a front for a terrorist group’
‘he's got a bit of talent and a lot of front’
‘the mark of fool set on his front’
‘the front cover of the magazine’
‘she was in the front garden’
‘the flats which fronted Crow Road’
‘both properties fronted on to the beach’
‘they reached the hedge fronting the garden’
‘a metal box fronted by an alloy panel’
‘a glass-fronted bookcase’
‘the group is fronted by two girl singers’
‘she is set to front a new BBC show’
‘he fronted for them in illegal property deals’
‘I can't front, I never really listened to much of his music’
‘parents get a bit worried if you don't front up now and then’
‘Tom fronted him with unwavering eyes’
‘the three velar consonants are normally fronted to some degree’
‘the fronting of /au/ was completed a couple of generations ago’

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
hour 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A period of time equal to a twenty-fourth part of a day and night and divided into 60 minutes.
A more indefinite period of time.
The distance travelled in one hour.
A time of day specified as an exact number of hours from midnight or midday.
A time specified on the twenty-four-hour clock.
The time as formerly reckoned from sunrise.
A fixed period of time for an activity, such as work, use of a building, etc.
A particular point in time.
(in the Western (Latin) Church) a short service of psalms and prayers to be said at a particular time of day, especially in religious communities.
15° of longitude or right ascension (one twenty-fourth part of a circle).
--Examples--
‘an extra hour of daylight in the winter evenings’
‘rates of pay were low, starting at £3.20 an hour’
‘a two-hour operation’
‘during the early hours of the morning’
‘Ocean City is less than an hour away’
‘the clock in the sitting room struck the hour’
‘the first bomb fell at 0051 hours’
‘it was about the ninth hour’
‘the dinner hour’
‘licensing hours’
‘opening hours’
‘I wondered if my last hour had come’
‘you can't turn him away at this hour’
‘an organized life of prayer including the canonical hours’

--Word--
link 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A relationship between two things or situations, especially where one affects the other.
A relationship or connection between people, countries, or organizations.
Something that enables communication between people.
A means of contact, travel, or transport between two places.
A code or instruction which connects one part of a program or an element in a list to another.
A ring or loop in a chain.
A unit of measurement of length equal to one hundredth of a surveying chain (7.92 inches).
Make, form, or suggest a connection with or between.
Connect or join physically.
Create a hyperlink between (web pages or hypertext documents)
Clasp; intertwine.
A torch of pitch and tow for lighting the way in dark streets.
--Examples--
‘a commission to investigate a link between pollution and forest decline’
‘he retained strong links with the media’
‘sign language interpreters represent a vital link between the deaf and hearing communities’
‘they set up a satellite link with Tokyo’
‘a high-speed rail link to the Channel Tunnel’
‘a chain made of steel links’
‘ministers are the vital link in the chain between the civil service and Parliament’
‘rumours that linked his name with Judith’
‘foreign and domestic policy are linked’
‘she linked up with an artistic group’
‘a network of routes linking towns and villages’
‘the cows are linked up to milking machines’
‘I've had problems linking my blog to other websites’
‘it turns out he reads my blogs and was very pleased I'd linked to his article’
‘once outside he linked arms with her’

may 
--Type--
modal verb
--Meanings--
Expressing possibility.
Used when admitting that something is so before making another, more important point.
Used to ask for or to give permission.
Expressing a wish or hope.
--Examples--
‘that may be true’
‘he may well win’
‘they may have been old-fashioned but they were excellent teachers’
‘you may confirm my identity with your Case Officer, if you wish’

--Word--
march 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Walk in a military manner with a regular measured tread.
Walk quickly and with determination.
Force (someone) to walk somewhere quickly.
Walk along public roads in an organized procession as a form of protest.
(of something abstract) proceed or advance inexorably.
An act or instance of marching.
A piece of music composed to accompany marching or with a rhythm suggestive of marching.
A procession organized as a protest.
The steady and inevitable development or progress of something.
--Examples--
‘thousands marched behind the coffin’
‘without a word she marched from the room’
‘she gripped Rachel's arm and marched her through the door’
‘unemployed workers marched from Jarrow to London’
‘they planned to march on Baton Rouge’
‘time marches on’
‘the relieving force was more than a day's march away’
‘he began to hum a funeral march’
‘a protest march’
‘the march of history’

--Word--
mid-parent 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a hypothetical parent of composite sex whose height is the average of the actual height of the father, and the height of the mother multiplied by the ratio of male to female height in the population. Later: a notional individual having the value of some property or trait equal to the average of the value of each parent.
--Examples--
--Word--
mid-parental 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--

--Word--
period 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A length or portion of time.
A portion of time in the life of a nation, civilization, etc. characterized by the same prevalent features or conditions.
A major division of geological time that is a subdivision of an era and is itself subdivided into epochs.
Each of the set divisions of the day in a school allocated to a lesson or other activity.
Each of the divisions of the playing time of a sporting event.
The interval of time between successive occurrences of the same state in an oscillatory or cyclic phenomenon, such as a mechanical vibration, an alternating current, a variable star, or an electromagnetic wave.
The time taken by a celestial object to rotate about its axis, or to make one circuit of its orbit.
The interval between successive equal values of a periodic function.
A flow of blood and other material from the lining of the uterus, lasting for a few days and occurring in sexually mature women who are not pregnant at intervals of about one lunar month until the menopause.
A punctuation mark (.) used at the end of a sentence or an abbreviation; a full stop.
Added to the end of a statement to indicate that no further discussion is possible or desirable.
A set of elements occupying a horizontal row in the periodic table.
A complex sentence, especially one consisting of several clauses, constructed as part of a formal speech or oration.
A complete idea, typically consisting of two or four phrases.
Belonging to or characteristic of a past historical time, especially in style or design.
--Examples--
‘he had long periods of depression’
‘the period 1977–85’
‘the training period is between 16 and 18 months’
‘the early medieval period’
‘the Cretaceous period’
‘two periods of PE are allocated on the timetable’
‘he interviewed the teachers when they had a free period’
‘the Lightnings ran at the Leafs hard in a very rough first period’
‘she's got her period’
‘period pains’
‘he is the sole owner of the trademark, period’
‘an attractive and beautifully modernized period house’
‘a splendid selection of period furniture’

midsummer men 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

Move or cause to move back and forth or from side to side while suspended or on an axis.

Succeed in bringing about.

(of music) be played with a flowing but vigorous rhythm.

Engage in group sex or swap sexual partners within a group, especially on a habitual basis.

The motion of swinging.

Move at a regular pace by lifting and setting down each foot in turn, never having both feet off the ground at once.

--Meanings--
Attributive and in the genitive. Designating concepts and phenomena described by Mie or arising from his work, especially in relation to the scattering of light; "Mie scattering"noun the scattering of light by particles whose size is comparable to the wavelength of the light; compare "Rayleigh scattering". myelinogenetic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to myelination; myelinogenic.
--Examples--
--Word--
myelin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mixture of proteins and phospholipids forming a whitish insulating sheath around many nerve fibres, which increases the speed at which impulses are conducted.
--Examples--
--Word--
myelitic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the nature of myelitis; of, relating to, or characteristic of myelitis.
--Examples--
--Word--
myelitis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Inflammation of the spinal cord.
--Examples--
--Word--
myeloblast 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A primitive precursor of a white blood cell, normally confined to the bone marrow; specifically the earliest recognizable precursor of the granulocytic series, maturing into a promyelocyte.
--Examples--
--Word--
myeloblastic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or consisting of myeloblasts. Especially in "myeloblastic leukaemia".
--Examples--
--Word--
myelocele 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Pathology. Originally: meningomyelocele (or myelomeningocele) (now rare or disused). Later: exposure or protrusion of the spinal cord through a defect in the vertebral column, without a meningeal covering, usually as a consequence of spina bifida; an example of this.
--Examples--
--Word--
myelocyte 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A cell normally found in the bone marrow that is derived from the myeloblast and that is the precursor of the granulocytes of the circulating blood.
--Examples--
--Word--
myelocytic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to a myelocyte or myelocytes; involving myelocytes. Especially in "myelocytic leukaemia".
--Examples--
--Word--
myelocoele 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Anatomy. The central canal of the spinal cord.
Pathology= myelocele.
--Examples--
--Word--
myelofibrosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Progressive fibrosis of the bone marrow, typically associated with pancytopenia and with myeloid metaplasia in other organs.
--Examples--
--Word--
myelofibrotic 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Affected or characterized by myelofibrosis.

--Word--
myelomeningocele 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Spina bifida in which the tissue of the spinal cord and its surrounding membranes (the meninges) protrudes through the cleft in the spine, forming a rounded swelling of the skin usually slightly above the base of the spine; the tissue so protruding.

--Word--
myelopoiesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The formation and development of bone marrow cells, or of blood cells derived from these (haematopoiesis); specifically the formation and development of granulocytes.
--Examples--
--Word--
myelopoietic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or involved in myelopoiesis.
--Examples--
--Word--
myeloproliferative 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Characterized by or relating to the abnormal proliferation of cells found in or derived from the bone marrow. Especially in "myeloproliferative disease", "myeloproliferative syndrome".
--Examples--

myelosclerosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Progressive fibrosis of the bone marrow; = myelofibrosis.

--Word--
myelosuppression 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Inhibition of the normal activity of the bone marrow (reduced haematopoiesis), usually as a result of cytotoxic chemotherapy or radiotherapy.

myenteric 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
miersite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tetrahedral iodide of silver and copper, (Ag,Cu)I (with the ratio of silver to copper approximately 4:1), crystallizing in the cubic system and occurring as crusts and aggregates of yellow crystals.
--Examples--

--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--

A petty quarrel or fit of pique.
--Examples--

‘a doctor might be miffed by claims that the cure had no medical explanation’
‘like ladies in a miff who won't explain’

--Examples--
--Word--
might 
--Type--
modal verb
--Meanings--
Used in reported speech, to express possibility or permission.
Expressing a possibility based on an unfulfilled condition.
Expressing annoyance about something that someone has not done.
Expressing purpose.
Used tentatively to ask permission or to express a polite request.
Asking for information, especially condescendingly.
Used to express possibility or make a suggestion.
--Examples--
‘he said he might be late’
‘we might have won if we'd played better’
‘you might have told me!’
‘he avoided social engagements so that he might work’
‘might I just ask one question?’
‘you might just call me Jane, if you don't mind’
‘and who might you be?’
‘this might be true’
‘you might try pain relievers’
--Word--
might-be 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
What might be; a (remote) possibility.
That might occur; postulated; (remotely) possible, potential.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
myriarch 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Ancient History. A commander of ten thousand men.
Asian History. Among the Mongols: a military commander of a large force (notionally, a division of 10,000 men). Also (especially in Tibet): the governor of an administrative district under Mongol rule.
--Examples--
--Word--
myriarchy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Asian History. The force of Mongol troops commanded by a myriarch. Also (especially in Tibet): the area governed by a myriarch; the population of such an area.
--Examples--
--Word--
myrica 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant of the genus Myrica (family Myricaceae) of shrubs and small trees having aromatic foliage; especially bog myrtle, Myrica gale, and wax myrtle, M. cerifera; (in form Myrica) the genus itself.

--Word--
mire 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A stretch of swampy or boggy ground.
Soft mud or dirt.
A wetland area or ecosystem based on peat.
A complicated or unpleasant situation from which it is difficult to extricate oneself.
Cause to become stuck in mud.
Cover or spatter with mud.
Involve someone or something in (a difficult situation)
--Examples--
‘acres of land had been reduced to a mire’
‘the roads retained their winter mire’
‘the service is sinking in the mire of its own regulations’
‘sometimes a heavy truck gets mired down’
‘the horse waded through the red mud that mired it to its hocks’
‘the economy is mired in its longest recession since the war’

--Word--
Loy, Myrna 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1905–93) US actress; born Myrna Williams. She played Nora Charles in the six comedy-crime Thin Man movies (1934–47). Other notable movies include The Best Years of Our Lives (1946), Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House (1948), and Cheaper by the Dozen (1950).

--Word--
Myron 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(fl.c.480–440 BC), Greek sculptor. None of his work is known to survive, but there are two certain copies, one being the Discobolus (c.450 BC), a figure of a man throwing the discus, which demonstrates a remarkable interest in symmetry and movement.
--Examples--
--Word--
myronate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A salt or ester, or the anion, of myronic acid.

myronic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sulphur-containing acidic glycoside, C₁₀H₁₇NO₉S₂, of which sinigrin, obtained from the plant black mustard, is the potassium salt.

myrosin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Biochemistry= myrosinase.
--Examples--
--Word--
myrosinase 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An enzyme present in certain plants which catalyses the hydrolysis of sinigrin and other sulphur-containing glycosides (e.g. in reactions occurring when tissue is damaged).

--Word--
myrrhis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: any of several plants of the family Apiaceae (Umbelliferae); especially (a) cow parsley, Anthriscus sylvestris; (b) rough chervil, Chaerophyllum temulum; (c) sweet cicely, Myrrhis odorata. Later (in form Myrrhis): a genus of the family Apiaceae (Umbelliferae) (now monotypic and restricted to sweet cicely, M. odorata).
--Examples--
--Word--
myrrhophore 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of the women, usually three in number, traditionally represented in art as carrying spices to the sepulchre of Christ.

--Word--
myrrh 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A fragrant gum resin obtained from certain trees and used, especially in the Near East, in perfumery, medicines, and incense.
--Examples--
--Word--
myrrh tree 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various Arabian and African trees of the genus Commiphora (family Burseraceae), especially C. abyssinica and C. myrrha, which yield myrrh.
--Examples--
--Word--
mirror 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A surface, typically of glass coated with a metal amalgam, which reflects a clear image.
A thing regarded as accurately representing something else.
A site on a network which stores the contents copied from another site.
(of a surface) show a reflection of.
Correspond to.
Keep a copy of the contents of (a network site) at another site, typically in order to improve accessibility.
Store copies of data in (two or more hard disks) for protection.
--Examples--
‘he checked his appearance in the mirror’
‘the stage is supposed to be the mirror of life’
‘the company now has a mirror site in Taiwan’
‘the clear water mirrored the sky’
‘his own views mirrored those of his followers’
‘his site was mirrored at several colleges around the United States’
‘the second drive is set up for disk mirroring’
--Word--
mirrored 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a surface like a mirror; reflective.
Fitted with a mirror or mirrors.
--Examples--
‘mirrored sunglasses’
‘the room has wall-to-wall mirrored wardrobes’
--Word--

--Meanings--

Mir 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Soviet space station, launched in 1986 and designed to be permanently manned. It was deliberately brought down into the Pacific Ocean in 2001.

--Word--
mirza 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(A) In Persian-speaking areas: a prince. Also used as a title before or, especially in Iran (Persia), after the name of a prince. (b) In Iran (Persia) and India used as an honorific title for an educated man. Hence: a clerk, secretary, or official.
--Examples--
--Word--
mirza 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(A) In Persian-speaking areas: a prince. Also used as a title before or, especially in Iran (Persia), after the name of a prince. (b) In Iran (Persia) and India used as an honorific title for an educated man. Hence: a clerk, secretary, or official.

--Word--
mis- 
--Type--
prefix, prefix
--Meanings--
(added to verbs and their derivatives) wrongly.
Badly.
Unsuitably.
Occurring in a few words adopted from French expressing a sense with negative force.
--Examples--
‘misapply’
‘mismanage’
‘misname’
‘misadventure’
‘mischief’

--Meanings--

noun

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
misbehave 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of a person, especially a child) fail to conduct oneself in an acceptable way; behave badly.
(of a machine) fail to function correctly.
--Examples--
‘Josh misbehaved, pushing his food off the table’
‘her regularly serviced car was misbehaving’
--Word--
misbehave 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of a person, especially a child) fail to conduct oneself in an acceptable way; behave badly.
(of a machine) fail to function correctly.
--Examples--
‘Josh misbehaved, pushing his food off the table’
‘her regularly serviced car was misbehaving’
--Word--
misbehave 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of a person, especially a child) fail to conduct oneself in an acceptable way; behave badly.
(of a machine) fail to function correctly.
--Examples--
‘Josh misbehaved, pushing his food off the table’
‘her regularly serviced car was misbehaving’

noun
--Meanings--

--Meanings--

misbrand 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(A) To brand (cattle or other stock) incorrectly, especially so as to disguise ownership. (b) Chiefly US Law. To label or describe (a product or commodity) incorrectly, misleadingly, or dishonestly.

--Word--
mithqal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A unit of weight, used chiefly for precious metals in the Islamic world, varying with place and period but now generally taken to be approximately 4.25 grams (65.6 grains); a coin of this weight. Also in Iran: a unit of weight equivalent to approximately 4.6 grams (71 grains).
--Examples--
--Word--
miscalculate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Calculate (an amount or measurement) wrongly.
Assess (a situation) wrongly.
--Examples--
‘they miscalculated the number of new houses that would need to be built’
‘the government has seriously miscalculated the effect of privatization’
‘you miscalculated if you imagined I'd fallen for your little scheme’
--Word--
might-be 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
What might be; a (remote) possibility.
That might occur; postulated; (remotely) possible, potential.
--Examples--
--Word--
might 
--Type--
modal verb
--Meanings--
Used in reported speech, to express possibility or permission.
Expressing a possibility based on an unfulfilled condition.
Expressing annoyance about something that someone has not done.
Expressing purpose.
Used tentatively to ask permission or to express a polite request.
Asking for information, especially condescendingly.
Used to express possibility or make a suggestion.
--Examples--
‘he said he might be late’
‘we might have won if we'd played better’
‘you might have told me!’
‘he avoided social engagements so that he might work’
‘might I just ask one question?’
‘you might just call me Jane, if you don't mind’
‘and who might you be?’
‘this might be true’
‘you might try pain relievers’
--Word--
might-have-been 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An event or situation that could have happened or existed but did not.
--Examples--
‘fretting about might-have-beens won't get us anywhere’
--Word--
mighty 
--Type--
adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
Possessing great and impressive power or strength, especially because of size.
(of an action) performed with or requiring great strength.
Very large.
Extremely.
--Examples--
‘three mighty industrial countries’
‘mighty beasts’
‘a mighty blow’
‘a mighty £450’
‘my ears got cold mighty fast’

mignonette-vine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Now rare, a yellow-flowered plant, Madia elegans (family Asteraceae (Compositae)), of western North America (also called tar-weed).
A liana, Anredera cordifolia (family Basellaceae), with fragrant white flowers and aerial tubers, native to subtropical South America and cultivated for ornament elsewhere.

--Word--
migrator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
migrator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
migrate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of an animal, typically a bird or fish) move from one region or habitat to another according to the seasons.
(of a person) move to a new area or country in order to find work or better living conditions.
Move from one part of something to another.
Change or cause to change from one system to another.
Transfer (programs or hardware) from one system to another.
--Examples--
‘as autumn arrives, the birds migrate south’
‘rural populations have migrated to urban areas’
‘cells that can form pigment migrate beneath the skin’
‘customers are migrating from mainframes to client-server environments’
‘save time by efficiently migrating data to secondary storage systems’
‘the system will allow users to migrate applications across environments’

--Word--
migration 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Seasonal movement of animals from one region to another.
Movement of people to a new area or country in order to find work or better living conditions.
Movement from one part of something to another.
--Examples--
‘this butterfly's annual migration across North America’
‘the extensive rural-to-urban migration has created a severe housing shortage’
‘there is virtually no cell migration in plants’

--Word--
migrationist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who emphasizes the importance of migration in the distribution and evolution of animal and plant species.
Archaeology and Cultural Anthropology. An adherent of the theory of migrationism.
Of, relating to, or involving migration; migrational; (Archaeology and Cultural Anthropology) of or relating to migrationism.

mynheer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
As a polite or respectful form of address to a Dutchman or an Afrikaner: sir, mister (Mr). Also used as a title or sometimes substituted for the name of the man or the pronoun that would stand for this. In British use often humorous or ironic.
A Dutchman, an Afrikaner; especially one who is a gentleman. Occasionally collectively: the Dutch, the Afrikaners.

mike 
--Type--
noun, verb, verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A microphone.
Supply or equip with a microphone.
Idle away one's time.
A period of idleness.
A code word representing the letter M, used in radio communication.
--Examples--
‘the minister was already miked up for the interview’
‘he thundered at anyone he thought was miking’
‘that's a good mike for you, but you'll have plenty to do later on’
--Word--
mikan 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The fruit of any of several species of citrus (family Rutaceae) originally cultivated in Japan; especially a variety of mandarin orange, a satsuma.

--Meanings--
A microphone.
Supply or equip with a microphone.
Idle away one's time.
A period of idleness.
A code word representing the letter M, used in radio communication.
--Examples--
‘the minister was already miked up for the interview’
‘he thundered at anyone he thought was miking’
‘that's a good mike for you, but you'll have plenty to do later on’
--Word--
Kalinin, Mikhail 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1875–1946), Soviet statesman, head of state of the USSR 1919–46; full name Mikhail Ivanovich Kalinin. He founded the newspaper Pravda (1912).
--Examples--
--Word--
Theodorakis, Mikis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1925), Greek composer and politician. He was imprisoned by the military government for his left-wing political activities (1967–70). His compositions include the ballet Antigone (1958), and the score for the film Zorba the Greek (1964).
--Examples--

--Word--
miko 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A priestess or female shaman, frequently a virgin, who acts as oracle for and handmaiden to the deity of a particular shrine and performs sacred ritual dances.

mileage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A number of miles travelled or covered.
Travelling expenses paid according to the number of miles travelled.

--Examples--

‘he was getting a lot of mileage out of the mix-up’

--Word--
Milan 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial city in north-western, the capital of Lombardy region; population 1,295,705 (2008). A powerful city, particularly from the 13th to the 15th centuries, Milan is today a leading financial and commercial center. Italian name Milano /miˈlano/.
--Examples--
--Word--
Milanaise 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
In "à la milanaise": (of a dish) characteristic of Milan and its region; usually involving the use of grated Parmesan cheese, saffron, and butter, and sometimes a coating of breadcrumbs.
Frequently as postpositive: = "à la milanaise".
--Examples--
--Word--
Milanese 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the Italian city of Milan or its inhabitants.
A native or inhabitant of the Italian city of Milan.
--Examples--
‘recognizable Milanese buildings’
‘there is a wonderful bustling atmosphere as the Milanese ponder their choices’
--Word--
Mylar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A form of polyester resin used to make heat-resistant plastic films and sheets. It is made by copolymerizing ethylene glycol and terephthalic acid.
--Examples--
--Word--
milarite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hexagonal silicate, K₂Ca₄Al₂Be₄Si₂₄O₆₀·H₂O, that occurs especially in pegmatites as colourless to pale green prismatic crystals and fibrous aggregates.
--Examples--
--Word--
milch 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Denoting a cow or other domestic mammal giving or kept for milk.
--Examples--
‘the most important milch breed’
--Word--
milch cow 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or organization that is a source of easy profit.
--Examples--
‘governments throughout the world are privatizing their milch cows’
--Word--
milched 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of an animal: (with new, old, stale, etc.) (newly) come into milk, having been in milk (for a long time), etc. Compare new-milch. Now English regional.
--Examples--
--Word--
milchig 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of a dish, product, etc.: containing milk and therefore not allowed to be consumed with or immediately after a meat product; of or relating to such items. Also of a person: that has recently consumed a milk product.
In plural or as a mass noun. Foodstuffs that contain or derive from milk.
--Examples--

--Word--
mild 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Not severe, serious, or harsh.
(of weather) moderately warm, especially less cold than expected.
(of a feeling) not intense or extreme.
(of a medicine or cosmetic) acting gently.
(of food, drink, or tobacco) not sharp, hot, or strong in flavour.
Gentle and not easily provoked.
A kind of dark beer not strongly flavoured with hops.
--Examples--
‘mild criticism’
‘mild flulike symptoms’
‘mild winters’
‘she looked at him in mild surprise’
‘a mild sedative’
‘a mild Italian cheese’
‘she was implacable, despite her mild exterior’

--Word--
mildew 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A thin whitish coating consisting of minute fungal hyphae, growing on plants or damp organic material such as paper.
Affect or be affected with mildew.
--Examples--
‘the flat was very damp and mildewed’
‘there was something depressing about the hundreds of theological volumes mildewing in the damp air’

--Word--
mile 
--Type--
noun, adverb
--Meanings--
A unit of linear measure equal to 1,760 yards (approximately 1.609 kilometres).
A race extending over a mile.
A Roman measure of 1,000 paces (approximately 1,620 yards).
A very long way or a very great amount.
By a great amount or a long way.
--Examples--
‘he rode the fastest mile of his entire career in 1914’
‘vistas which stretch for miles’
‘this is my favourite film by a mile’
‘the second tape is miles better’
--Word--
mileage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A number of miles travelled or covered.
Travelling expenses paid according to the number of miles travelled.
Actual or potential benefit or use to be derived from a situation or event.
--Examples--
‘the car is in good condition, considering its mileage’
‘the mileage rate will be 30p per mile’
‘he was getting a lot of mileage out of the mix-up’

ohm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The SI unit of electrical resistance, transmitting a current of one ampere when subjected to a potential difference of one volt.
--Examples--

milometer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
milepost 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A marker set up to indicate how distant a particular place is.
A post one mile from the finishing post of a race.
A significant stage or event in the development of something; a milestone.
--Examples--
‘the railway's mileposts showed the distance from the junction’
‘they've recently passed mileposts in their careers’

--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c. 1584–1656), American colonist; born in England. He accompanied the Pilgrims to America in 1620 and became the military leader of Plymouth Colony. He is romanticized as the lovelorn suitor in Longfellow's fictional poem The Courtship of Miles Standish (1858).
--Examples--
--Word--
Milesian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of ancient Miletus.
Relating to Miletus or its inhabitants.
--Examples--
--Word--
milestone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A stone set up beside a road to mark the distance in miles to a particular place.
A significant stage or event in the development of something.
--Examples--
‘the speech is being hailed as a milestone in race relations’

ton-mile 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
Miletus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient city of the Ionian Greeks in south-western Asia Minor. In the 7th and 6th centuries BC it was a powerful port, from which more than sixty colonies were founded on the shores of the Black Sea and in Italy and Egypt.
--Examples--
--Word--
mileway 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of the roads lying within a mile of the centre of Oxford, which were maintained with a contribution from local villages. Usually in plural Frequently attributive Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
milfoil 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The common Eurasian yarrow.
A widely distributed aquatic plant with whorls of fine submerged leaves and wind-pollinated flowers.

--Word--
Milhaud, Darius 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1892–1974), French composer. A member of the group Les Six, he composed the music to Cocteau's ballet Le Boeuf sur le toit (1919). Much of his music was polytonal and influenced by jazz.

--Word--
milliarium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In full "golden milliarium": a gilded stone pillar erected during the reign of Augustus in the Forum in Rome below the temple of Saturn, and from which distances from Rome were calculated. Hence: a pillar or other marker serving a similar purpose in another city of the Roman Empire.
--Examples--
--Word--
milice 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Formerly: †military service or training. Subsequently (especially (now historical) in France): a militia or army. Now rare.
French History. Usually in form Milice. A force employed by the Vichy government of 1940–4 to repress internal dissent.
--Examples--

--Word--
myliobatid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A cartilaginous fish of the family Myliobatidae, comprising the eagle rays, which are large marine rays with long pointed pectoral fins, a long tail, and a distinct head.
Of or belonging to the family Myliobatidae.
--Examples--
--Word--
Miliola 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of foraminiferans having an imperforate calcareous shell; (also miliola) a foraminiferan of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
milioline 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or characteristic of the foraminiferan genus Miliola or the suborder Miliolina to which it belongs; designating a form of shell characteristic of many miliolids, having only two elongated chambers in each whorl; (of limestone) composed of the shells of miliolids.
A milioline foraminiferan.
--Examples--
--Word--
miliolite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fossil milioline foraminiferan.
--Examples--
--Word--
miliolitic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Containing or composed of miliolites.

militarism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
militia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A military force that is raised from the civil population to supplement a regular army in an emergency.
A military force that engages in rebel or terrorist activities in opposition to a regular army.
(in the US) all able-bodied civilians eligible by law for military service.
--Examples--
‘creating a militia was no answer to the army's manpower problem’
‘small detachments of militia’
--Word--

--Meanings--

milium

noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
milk 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An opaque white fluid rich in fat and protein, secreted by female mammals for the nourishment of their young.
The milk from cows (or goats or sheep) as consumed by humans.
The white juice of certain plants.
A creamy-textured liquid with a particular ingredient or use.
Draw milk from (a cow or other animal), either by hand or mechanically.
(of an animal, especially a cow) produce milk.
Extract sap, venom, or other substances from.
Exploit or defraud by taking small amounts of money over a period of time.
Get all possible advantage from (a situation)
Elicit a favourable reaction from (an audience) and prolong it.
--Examples--
‘a healthy mother will produce enough milk for her baby’
‘a glass of milk’
‘coconut milk’
‘cleansing milk’
‘two hours later he was up again to milk the cows’
‘I had to start the milking’
‘the breed does seem to milk better in harder conditions’
‘scientists have found a new way of producing an anti-clotting agent—by milking a leech’
‘executives milked the health plan's funds for their personal use’
‘the newspapers were milking the story for every possible drop of drama’
‘he milked the crowd for every last drop of applause’
--Word--
milk-and-water 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Lacking the will or ability to act effectively.
--Examples--
‘a milk-and-water government’
--Word--
watery 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Consisting of, containing, or resembling water.
(of a person's eyes) full of tears.
Thin or tasteless as a result of containing too much water.
Pale or weak, as if diluted by water.
--Examples--
‘a watery fluid’
‘as the smoke blew into her face, her eyes went red and watery’
‘watery coffee’
‘watery sunshine’

waterish

adjective

--Word--
bearing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person's way of standing or moving.
The way a person behaves or conducts themselves.
Relation; relevance.
The ability to tolerate something bad or to be tolerated.
A part of a machine that allows one part to rotate or move in contact with another part with as little friction as possible.
The direction or position of something, or the direction of movement, relative to a fixed point. It is usually measured in degrees, typically with magnetic north as zero.
Awareness of one's position relative to one's surroundings.
A device or charge.
--Examples--
‘a man of precise military bearing’
‘she has the bearing of a First Lady’
‘the case has no direct bearing on the issues being considered’
‘school was bad enough, but now it's past bearing’
‘the Point is on a bearing of 015°’
‘there were no steeples or bridges from which to take a bearing’
‘he flashed the torch around, trying to get his bearings’
‘armorial bearings’

well-blended

adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
milk-bush 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various shrubs or small trees of the southern hemisphere which have a milky sap and are often succulent; especially (a) South African and Indian English, the small tree Euphorbia tirucalli (family Euphorbiaceae), native to Africa and cultivated or naturalized in parts of India and South-East Asia; (b) Australian the shrub Wrightia saligna (family Apocynaceae), formerly used as a fodder plant; (c) Australian the caustic bush, Sarcostemma australe.
--Examples--
--Word--
condensed milk 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Milk that has been thickened by evaporation and sweetened, sold in tins.
--Examples--

adjective

(of a playing card) turned face up.

--Word--
milky 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Containing or mixed with a large amount of milk.
(of a cow) having a high milk yield.
Resembling milk in colour.
Cloudy or opaque.
Weak and compliant.
--Examples--
‘a cup of sweet milky coffee’
‘the milky little Jersey seems to be successful in the tropics’
‘not a blemish marred her milky skin’
‘the old man's milky, uncomprehending eyes’
‘they just talk that way to make you turn milky’

‘executives milked the health plan's funds for their personal use’
‘the newspapers were milking the story for every possible drop of drama’
‘he milked the crowd for every last drop of applause’

--Word--
milk 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An opaque white fluid rich in fat and protein, secreted by female mammals for the nourishment of their young.
The milk from cows (or goats or sheep) as consumed by humans.
The white juice of certain plants.
A creamy-textured liquid with a particular ingredient or use.
Draw milk from (a cow or other animal), either by hand or mechanically.
(of an animal, especially a cow) produce milk.
Extract sap, venom, or other substances from.
Exploit or defraud by taking small amounts of money over a period of time.
Get all possible advantage from (a situation)
Elicit a favourable reaction from (an audience) and prolong it.
--Examples--
‘a healthy mother will produce enough milk for her baby’
‘a glass of milk’
‘coconut milk’
‘cleansing milk’
‘two hours later he was up again to milk the cows’
‘I had to start the milking’
‘the breed does seem to milk better in harder conditions’
‘scientists have found a new way of producing an anti-clotting agent—by milking a leech’
‘executives milked the health plan's funds for their personal use’
‘the newspapers were milking the story for every possible drop of drama’
‘he milked the crowd for every last drop of applause’

--Word--
milkwood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various trees having a milky sap; especially (a) Jamaican the tree Pseudolmedia spuria (family Moraceae); (b) South African any of several trees of the family Sapotaceae, especially (more fully "white milkwood"), Sideroxylon inerme, a low-growing tree bearing creamy flowers and round, purple-black fruit, and (more fully "red milkwood") any of several shrubs and trees of the genus Mimusops, especially M. obovata, M. caffra, and M. zeyheri; compare melkhout; (c) Australian any of several trees of the family Apocynaceae, especially Alstonia scholaris.
--Examples--
--Word--
milkwood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various trees having a milky sap; especially (a) Jamaican the tree Pseudolmedia spuria (family Moraceae); (b) South African any of several trees of the family Sapotaceae, especially (more fully "white milkwood"), Sideroxylon inerme, a low-growing tree bearing creamy flowers and round, purple-black fruit, and (more fully "red milkwood") any of several shrubs and trees of the genus Mimusops, especially M. obovata, M. caffra, and M. zeyheri; compare melkhout; (c) Australian any of several trees of the family Apocynaceae, especially Alstonia scholaris.

mill 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A building equipped with machinery for grinding grain into flour.
A piece of machinery for grinding grain.
A domestic device for grinding a solid substance to powder.
A factory fitted with machinery for a particular manufacturing process.
A piece of manufacturing machinery.
An engine.
A boxing match or a fist fight.
Grind (something) in a mill.
Cut or shape (metal) with a rotating tool.
Produce regular ribbed markings on the edge of (a coin) as a protection against illegal clipping.
(of people or animals) move around in a confused mass.
Thicken (wool or another animal fibre) by fulling it.
--Examples--
‘a direct steam-driven flour mill’
‘a pepper mill’
‘a steel mill’
‘a mill town’
‘hard wheats are easily milled into white flour’
‘in the machine shop we mill and grind the castings’
‘gold and silver coins were milled in order to prevent unscrupulous persons from shaving off the edges’
‘tourists were milling about in the lobby’
‘ordinary wool blankets are made by milling a woven wool fabric’

Millay, Edna St. Vincent 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1892–1950), US poet and writer; pen name Nancy Boyd. Much of her poetry is collected in Renascence and Other Poems (1917), Collected Sonnets (1941), and Collected Lyrics (1943).
--Examples--
--Word--
Millais, Sir John Everett 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1829–96), English painter. A founder member of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, he went on to produce lavishly painted portraits and landscapes. Notable works: Christ in the House of his Parents (1850) and Bubbles (1886).
--Examples--
--Word--
Fillmore, Millard 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1800–74), American Whig statesman, 13th president of the US 1850–3. He was an advocate of compromise on the slavery issue, but his unpopular enforcement of the 1850 Fugitive Slave Act hastened the end of the Whig Party.

millenarian 
--Type--
adjective, noun

Relating to or believing in Christian millenarianism.

--Word--
millenarianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The doctrine of or belief in a future (and typically imminent) thousand-year age of blessedness, beginning with or culminating in the Second Coming of Christ. It is central to the teaching of groups such as Adventists, Mormons, and Jehovah's Witnesses.
Belief in a future utopian period.

millennium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A period of a thousand years, especially when calculated from the traditional date of the birth of Christ.
The prophesied thousand-year reign of Christ at the end of the age (Rev. 20:1–5)
A utopian period of justice, peace, and prosperity.
An anniversary of a thousand years.
The point at which one period of a thousand years ends and another begins.
--Examples--
‘silver first came into use on a substantial scale during the 3rd millennium BC’
‘Archer's treatise predicted that the millennium was close at hand’
‘the people must seize power—the millennium cannot be imposed on them from above’
‘the millennium of the Russian Orthodox Church’
‘as we approach the millennium the only certainty is change’

Denoting or relating to an anniversary of a thousand years.

‘the current increase in hurricanes is only a small fluctuation within this longer millennial cycle’

‘the millennial celebrations in New York's Times Square’
‘most social networking groups are dominated by the millennial generation’
‘the industry brims with theories on what makes millennials tick’
‘generation Xers and millennials have some real gripes about the world their parents constructed’

--Word--
millipede 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A myriapod invertebrate with an elongated body composed of many segments, most of which bear two pairs of legs. Most kinds are herbivorous and shun light, living in the soil or under stones and logs.

--Word--
milliary 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Roman History. In the Roman Army: designating a unit of one thousand men; (also more generally) a large unit; specifically the first (elite) cohort of a legion.
A stone or mark set up by the ancient Romans as a point of departure in measuring distances of a thousand paces; a milestone. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
milliarium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In full "golden milliarium": a gilded stone pillar erected during the reign of Augustus in the Forum in Rome below the temple of Saturn, and from which distances from Rome were calculated. Hence: a pillar or other marker serving a similar purpose in another city of the Roman Empire.
--Examples--
--Word--
millibar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
One thousandth of a bar, the cgs unit of atmospheric pressure equivalent to 100 pascals.
--Examples--
‘peak wind speed was 170 knots and pressure dropped to 993 millibars’

proper noun
--Meanings--
(1868–1953), American physicist. He was the first to give an accurate figure for the electric charge on an electron. Nobel Prize for Physics (1923).
--Examples--

--Word--
millimetric 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the order of a millimetre in length or thickness; relating to or employing electromagnetic radiation having a wavelength of 1 to 10 millimetres; measured or expressed in millimetres.
Generally. As small as a millimetre (in figurative contexts); (of a distinction) very fine; (of accuracy) extreme. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
millimolar 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to a millimole; measured in terms of millimoles.
--Examples--
--Word--
millimole 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
One-thousandth of a mole.
--Examples--
--Word--
milline 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A unit of measurement of the value of advertising space in a newspaper, magazine, etc., calculated by multiplying the cost per line by one million and dividing the result by the circulation of the publication. Frequently attributive, especially in "milline rate".
--Examples--

--Type--
adjective

--Word--
ink 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A coloured fluid or paste used for writing, drawing, printing, or duplicating.
Publicity in the written media.
A tattoo or tattoos.
A black liquid ejected by a cuttlefish, octopus, or squid to confuse a predator.
Mark (words or a design) with ink.
Cover (type or a stamp) with ink before printing.
Obliterate something, especially writing, with ink.
Sign (a contract)
Secure the services of (someone) with a contract.
--Examples--
‘the names are written in ink’
‘a picture executed in coloured inks’
‘the story got lots of ink and plenty of air time’
‘I took my shirt off to display my ink’
‘the cork has the name of the château inked on to the side’
‘a raised image is inked to produce an impression’
‘he carefully inked out each word’
‘she's just inked a deal to host her own talk show’
‘he has been inked as host for next year's ceremony’
‘Eddie Hemmings is already inked in’

--Word--
million 
--Type--
cardinal number
--Meanings--
The number equivalent to the product of a thousand and a thousand; 1,000,000 or 10⁶
The numbers from a million to a billion.
Several million things or people.
An unspecified but very large number or amount of something.
A million pounds or dollars.
The bulk of the population.
--Examples--
‘a million people will benefit’
‘a population of half a million’
‘a cost of more than £20 million’
‘millions of TV viewers’
‘I've got millions of beer bottles in my cellar’
‘you're one in a million’
‘the author is set to make millions’
‘movies for the millions’

--Word--
millionth 
--Type--
ordinal number
--Meanings--
Constituting number one million in a sequence; 1,000,000th.
Constituting an unspecified but very large number in a sequence.
Each of one million equal parts into which something is or may be divided.
--Examples--
‘the museum welcomed its millionth visitor 21 months after opening’
‘I asked the same question for the millionth time’
‘a dot less than a millionth of an inch in diameter’

--Word--
millipede 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A myriapod invertebrate with an elongated body composed of many segments, most of which bear two pairs of legs. Most kinds are herbivorous and shun light, living in the soil or under stones and logs.
--Examples--
--Word--
millipede 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A myriapod invertebrate with an elongated body composed of many segments, most of which bear two pairs of legs. Most kinds are herbivorous and shun light, living in the soil or under stones and logs.

--Word--
lead 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Cause (a person or animal) to go with one by holding them by the hand, a halter, a rope, etc. while moving forward.
Show (someone or something) the way to a destination by going in front of or beside them.
Be a route or means of access to a particular place or in a particular direction.
Be a reason or motive for (someone)
Culminate or result in (a particular event or consequence)
Be in charge or command of.
Organize and direct.
Be the principal player of (a group of musicians)
Set (a process) in motion.
Start.
Make an attack with (a particular punch or fist)
(of a base runner) be in a position to run from a base while standing off the base.
(in card games) play (the first card) in a trick or round of play.
Have the advantage over competitors in a race or game.
Be superior to (competitors or colleagues)
Have or experience (a particular way of life)
The initiative in an action; an example for others to follow.
A piece of information that may help in the resolution of a problem.
Someone or something that may be useful, especially a potential customer or business opportunity.
(in card games) an act or right of playing first in a trick or round of play.
The card played first in a trick or round.
A position of advantage in a contest; first place.
An amount by which a competitor is ahead of the others.
The chief part in a play or film.
The person playing the chief part.
The chief performer or instrument of a specified type.
The item of news given the greatest prominence in a newspaper, broadcast, etc.
The opening sentence or paragraph of a news article, summarizing the most important aspects of the story.
A strap or cord for restraining and guiding a dog or other domestic animal.
A wire that conveys electric current from a source to an appliance, or that connects two points of a circuit together.
The distance advanced by a screw in one turn.
An artificial watercourse leading to a mill.
A channel of water in an ice field.
--Examples--
‘she emerged leading a bay horse’
‘she stood up and led her friend to the door’
‘the door led to a long hallway’
‘a farm track led off to the left’
‘nothing that I have read about the case leads me to the conclusion that anything untoward happened’
‘a fascination for art led him to start a collection of paintings’
‘closing the plant will lead to 300 job losses’
‘fashioning a policy appropriate to the situation entails understanding the forces that led up to it’
‘a military delegation was led by the Chief of Staff’
‘the conference included sessions led by people with personal knowledge of the area’
‘since the forties he has led his own big bands’
‘they are waiting for an expansion of world trade to lead a recovery’
‘the radio news led with the murder’
‘Ned leads off with a general survey of the objectives’
‘Adam led with a left’
‘he led the ace and another heart’
‘he followed up with a break of 105 to lead 3-0’
‘the Wantage jockey was leading the field’
‘there will be specific areas or skills in which other nations lead the world’
‘she's led a completely sheltered life’
‘Britain is now taking the lead in environmental policies’
‘detectives investigating the murder are chasing new leads’
‘I have a lead on a job that sounds really promising’
‘setting up a social networking page can help you get numerous leads’
‘the goal of marketing is to generate leads so the sales people can close them’
‘it's your lead’
‘the ♦8 was an inspired lead’
‘the team burst into life and took the lead’
‘they were beaten 5-3 after twice being in the lead’
‘the team held a slender one-goal lead’
‘she had the lead in a new film’
‘the lead role’
‘he still looked like a romantic lead’
‘a lead guitarist’
‘the ‘pensions revolution’ is the lead in the Times’
‘the lead story on CNN’
‘the newswire will be offering two different leads for certain stories, so editors can pick and choose’
‘the dog is our constant walking companion and is always kept on a lead’

mill-rind 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
mill 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A building equipped with machinery for grinding grain into flour.
A piece of machinery for grinding grain.
A domestic device for grinding a solid substance to powder.
A factory fitted with machinery for a particular manufacturing process.
A piece of manufacturing machinery.
An engine.
A boxing match or a fist fight.
Grind (something) in a mill.
Cut or shape (metal) with a rotating tool.
Produce regular ribbed markings on the edge of (a coin) as a protection against illegal clipping.
(of people or animals) move around in a confused mass.
Thicken (wool or another animal fibre) by fulling it.
--Examples--
‘a direct steam-driven flour mill’
‘a pepper mill’
‘a steel mill’
‘a mill town’
‘hard wheats are easily milled into white flour’
‘in the machine shop we mill and grind the castings’
‘gold and silver coins were milled in order to prevent unscrupulous persons from shaving off the edges’
‘tourists were milling about in the lobby’
‘ordinary wool blankets are made by milling a woven wool fabric’
--Word--
mill-run 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The material produced from a mill before sorting, especially the saleable output of a sawmill. In extended use: a person or thing regarded as average or mediocre.
Designating material produced from a mill before sorting, especially the saleable output of a sawmill. In extended use: lacking unusual or distinctive aspects; average, mundane, mediocre.
--Examples--

--Word--
mill-tail 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The water downstream from a mill which has passed through the mill-wheel; the channel in which water runs away after passing through a mill.
Chiefly US regional. In similative and figurative use, denoting rapid movement, furious activity, or violent, unstoppable force.

Milne, A. A. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1882–1956), English writer for children; full name Alan Alexander Milne. He created the character of the toy bear Winnie-the-Pooh in stories written for his son Christopher Robin (1920–96), published in Winnie-the-Pooh (1926) and The House at Pooh Corner (1928).

mylodon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An extinct giant ground sloth found in Pleistocene ice age deposits in South America. It died out only 11,000 years ago.
--Examples--
--Word--
mylodont 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Any of various extinct gigantic ground sloths constituting the family Mylodontidae or the superfamily Mylodontoidea, known from Miocene and Pleistocene remains found in South America.
Of, relating to, or characteristic of the family Mylodontidae or the superfamily Mylodontoidea.

Milroy's disease 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hereditary (autosomal dominant) form of lymphoedema, in which oedema, particularly involving the lower limbs, is present from birth.

Milton Keynes 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A town in Buckinghamshire, south central England; population 235,280 (est. 2009). It was established as a new town in the late 1960s, and is the site of the headquarters of the Open University.

Milwaukee 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial port and city in south-eastern Wisconsin, on the western shore of Lake Michigan; population 604,477 (est. 2008). It is noted for its brewing industry and is an important port on the St. Lawrence Seaway.

Mimas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A satellite of Saturn, the seventh closest to the planet, which has a crater a third of its whole diameter. It was discovered by William Herschel in 1789 (diameter 390 km).

Mimbres 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Archaeology. Of or relating to an ancient Mogollon culture which flourished in the same area, characterized by distinctive ceramics decorated with black-on-white designs of both geometric and animal figures, which were produced 1000–1150.
The Mimbreño Apache people of south-western New Mexico. Compare Mimbreño. Now historical.
Archaeology. A prehistoric North American people formerly living in the area of the Mimbres mountains.
