noun
--Meanings--
Multiple instruction, multiple data (designating a parallel computer architecture consisting of a number of powerful processors which can each execute streams of individual instructions on distinct streams of data).
--Examples--
--Word--
mime 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The theatrical technique of suggesting action, character, or emotion without words, using only gesture, expression, and movement.
A theatrical performance using mime.
An action or actions intended to convey another action, an idea, or an emotion.
A practitioner of mime or a performer in a mime.
(in ancient Greece and Rome) a simple farcical drama including mimicry.
Use only gesture and movement to act out (a play or role)
Convey or represent (an action, idea, or emotion) by using only gesture and movement.
Pretend to sing or play an instrument as a recording is being played.
--Examples--
‘mime is part of our cultural heritage’
‘the ceremony was followed by a series of precise mimes, dances, and songs’
‘he performed a brief mime of someone fencing’
‘he's a very fine actor and mime artist’
‘a group of mimes pretending to play tennis’
‘the Dorian mimes first began to lay the foundations of the theatre’
‘a mimed play’
‘they've even mimed in a restaurant hall’
‘Eddie mimed an attack of nausea’
‘singers on television often mime to pre-recorded tape tracks’

--Word--
mimesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Imitative representation of the real world in art and literature.
The deliberate imitation of the behaviour of one group of people by another group as a factor in social change.
--Examples--
‘Barth has always detached his use of plot from mimesis’
‘culture is organized in terms of mimesis and desire’

--Word--
mimic 
--Type--
verb, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Imitate (someone or their actions or words), especially in order to entertain or ridicule.
(of an animal or plant) resemble or imitate (another animal or plant) to deter predators or for camouflage.
(of a drug) replicate the physiological effects of (another substance)
(of a disease) exhibit symptoms that bear a deceptive resemblance to those of (another disease)
A person skilled in imitating the voice or actions of others in an entertaining way.
An animal or plant that mimics another.
Imitative of something.
--Examples--
‘she mimicked Eileen's pedantic voice’
‘wild potatoes mimic an aphid alarm signal’
‘tiger beetles are mimicked by grasshoppers’
‘the drug ephedrine mimics noradrenaline’
‘bacterial meningitis can present with acute disturbance of behaviour which may closely mimic substance abuse’
‘he has great ability as a mimic’
‘how did these insects evolve to become such perfect mimics?’
‘they were waging mimic war’
--Word--
mimical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of an action, attribute, etc.: †befitting a mime or burlesque actor (obsolete); relating to, characterized by, or of the nature of mimicry or imitation, especially in the arts.
--Examples--

mimic 
--Type--
verb, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Imitate (someone or their actions or words), especially in order to entertain or ridicule.
(of an animal or plant) resemble or imitate (another animal or plant) to deter predators or for camouflage.
(of a drug) replicate the physiological effects of (another substance)
(of a disease) exhibit symptoms that bear a deceptive resemblance to those of (another disease)
A person skilled in imitating the voice or actions of others in an entertaining way.
An animal or plant that mimics another.
Imitative of something.
--Examples--
‘she mimicked Eileen's pedantic voice’
‘wild potatoes mimic an aphid alarm signal’
‘tiger beetles are mimicked by grasshoppers’
‘the drug ephedrine mimics noradrenaline’
‘bacterial meningitis can present with acute disturbance of behaviour which may closely mimic substance abuse’
‘he has great ability as a mimic’
‘how did these insects evolve to become such perfect mimics?’
‘they were waging mimic war’
--Word--
mimicker 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who imitates someone or their actions or words, especially in order to entertain or ridicule.
An animal or plant that imitates the behaviour or actions of another.
A disease that exhibits symptoms that bear a deceptive resemblance to those of another disease.
A drug or other substance that replicates the physiological effects of another substance.
--Examples--
‘as a mimicker of voices I am unrivalled’
‘lyrebirds are magnificent mimickers of other birds and noises’
‘a mimicker of dementia is severe depression’
‘syphilis is considered the great mimicker’
‘hormone mimickers’

--Word--
mimicry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or skill of imitating someone or something, especially in order to entertain or ridicule.
The close external resemblance of an animal or plant (or part of one) to another animal, plant, or inanimate object.
--Examples--
‘the word was spoken with gently teasing mimicry’
‘a playful mimicry of the techniques of realist writers’

--Word--
mina 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A monetary unit formerly used in Greece and the Middle East, equivalent to the weight of one mina in silver. (Rendered ‘pound’ in some English translations of the N.T.).
(A) A unit of weight formerly used in the Middle East, especially in Mesopotamia and Palestine, and in Egypt. (b) A unit of weight formerly used in ancient Greece, equal to 1/60th of a talent and 100 drachmas.

--Word--
mina 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A monetary unit formerly used in Greece and the Middle East, equivalent to the weight of one mina in silver. (Rendered ‘pound’ in some English translations of the N.T.).
(A) A unit of weight formerly used in the Middle East, especially in Mesopotamia and Palestine, and in Egypt. (b) A unit of weight formerly used in ancient Greece, equal to 1/60th of a talent and 100 drachmas.
--Examples--
--Word--
mynah 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An Asian and Australasian starling that typically has dark plumage, gregarious behaviour, and a loud call.
--Examples--

minasragrite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An acidic hydrated vanadyl sulphate, VO(SO₄).5H₂O, occurring as a blue efflorescence of minute monoclinic crystals on patronite.

--Word--
Minch 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A channel of the Atlantic, between the mainland of Scotland and the Outer Hebrides. The northern stretch is called the North Minch, the southern stretch, north-west of Skye, is called the Little Minch. Also called the Minches.

--Word--
mind 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The element of a person that enables them to be aware of the world and their experiences, to think, and to feel; the faculty of consciousness and thought.
A person's mental processes contrasted with physical action.
A person's ability to think and reason; the intellect.
A person's memory.
A particular way of thinking, influenced by a person's profession or environment.
A person identified with their intellectual faculties.
A person's attention.
A person's will or determination to achieve something.
Be distressed, annoyed, or worried by.
Object to.
Be reluctant to do something.
Used to express one's strong enthusiasm for something.
Regard as important; feel concern about.
Used to urge someone to remember or take care to do something.
Used to warn someone to avoid injury or an accident.
Used to emphasize a command.
Be careful about the quality or nature of.
Used to introduce a qualification to a previous statement.
Pay attention to; obey.
Remember.
Take care of temporarily.
Be inclined to do something.
--Examples--
‘a lot of thoughts ran through my mind’
‘I wrote a letter in my mind’
‘his keen mind’
‘the company's name slips my mind’
‘he had a deep contempt for the bureaucratic mind’
‘he was one of the greatest minds of his time’
‘employees should keep their minds on the job’
‘anyone can slim if they set their mind to it’
‘I don't mind the rain’
‘what does that mean, if you don't mind my asking?’
‘do you mind if I have a cigarette?’
‘I don't mind admitting I was worried’
‘I wouldn't mind some coaching from him!’
‘never mind the opinion polls’
‘why should she mind about a few snubs from people she disliked?’
‘mind you look after the children’
‘mind your head on that cupboard!’
‘mind out—there's a step missing’
‘be early to bed tonight, mind’
‘mind your manners!’
‘we've got some decorations up—not a lot, mind you’
‘you think about how much Cal does for you, and you mind her, you hear?’
‘I mind the time when he lost his false teeth’
‘we left our husbands to mind the children while we went out’
‘he was minded to reject the application’
--Word--
Mindanao 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The second largest island in the Philippines, in the south-east of the group; population 19,874,000 (est. 2007). Its chief town is Davao.
--Examples--
--Word--
mind-blind 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Suffering from or exhibiting mind-blindness.
--Examples--
--Word--
mind-blindness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Generally. An inability or refusal to acknowledge or accept evidence; lack of understanding. rare.
Medicine. The inability to recognize objects by sight, caused by lesions of certain parts of the cerebral cortex; visual agnosia. Also called psychic blindness. Now historical.
Psychology. An inability to recognize, understand, or interpret mental states (thoughts, beliefs, intentions, etc.) in oneself or others, attributed to persons with autism and related disorders.
--Examples--
--Word--
mind-blower

Mindel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Pleistocene glaciation in the Alps preceding the Riss, possibly corresponding to the Elsterian of northern Europe.

Riss 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The penultimate Pleistocene glaciation in the Alps, possibly corresponding to the Saale of northern Europe.
The system of deposits laid down during the Riss glaciation.

--Word--
sick 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Affected by physical or mental illness.
Relating to those who are ill.
(of an organization, system, or society) suffering from serious problems.
Feeling nauseous and wanting to vomit.
(of an emotion) so intense as to cause one to feel unwell or nauseous.
Disappointed, mortified, or miserable.
Pining or longing for someone or something.
Intensely annoyed with or bored by (someone or something) as a result of having had too much of them.
(especially of humour) having something unpleasant such as death or misfortune as its subject and dealing with it in an offensive way.
(of a person) having abnormal or unnatural tendencies; perverted.
Excellent.
Vomit.
Bring something up by vomiting.
--Examples--
‘nursing very sick children’
‘half my staff were off sick’
‘visiting the sick and the elderly’
‘the company organized a sick fund for its workers’
‘the British economy remains sick’
‘he was starting to feel sick’
‘Mark felt sick with fear’
‘he had a sick fear of returning’
‘he looked pretty sick at that, but he eventually agreed’
‘he was sick for a sight of her’
‘I'm absolutely sick of your moods’
‘this was someone's idea of a sick joke’
‘he is a deeply sick man from whom society needs to be protected’
‘she was busy wiping sick from the carpet’
‘he was passing blood and sicking it up’
‘she sicked up all over the carpet’

--Word--
mine 
--Type--
possessive pronoun, possessive determiner, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Used to refer to a thing or things belonging to or associated with the speaker.
(used before a vowel) my.
An excavation in the earth for extracting coal or other minerals.
An abundant source of something, especially information.
A type of bomb placed on or just below the surface of the ground or in the water, which detonates on contact with a person, vehicle, or ship.
A subterranean passage under the wall of a besieged fortress, especially one in which explosives were placed to blow up fortifications.
Obtain (coal or other minerals) from a mine.
Dig in (the earth) for coal or other minerals.
Dig or burrow in (the earth)
Exploit (a source of information or skill)
Analyse (a database) to generate new information.
Obtain units of (a cryptocurrency) by running a computer process to solve specific mathematical problems.
Lay explosive mines on or just below the surface of (the ground or water)
Destroy by means of an explosive mine.
--Examples--
‘you go your way and I'll go mine’
‘some friends of mine’
‘tears did fill mine eyes’
‘a copper mine’
‘the text is a mine of information for biographers and historians’
‘his jeep ran over a mine and he was killed’
‘the company came to the area to mine phosphate’
‘35 million tonnes of mined coal’
‘the hills were mined for copper oxide’
‘many financiers obtained concessions to mine for silver’
‘the earth beneath had been tortuously mined by pestilential rabbits’
‘how do they manage to mine such a rich vein of talent?’
‘if you're mining bitcoin you need to do it faster than anyone else’
‘the area was heavily mined’
‘HMS Ocean was mined in the Dardanelles in 1915’

Exploit (a source of information or skill)

‘it identifies the mineral or compound present’
‘the economy has long been dependent on exports of minerals, especially gold’
‘a wide range of necessary vitamins and minerals’
‘mineral ingredients such as zinc oxide’
--Word--
mineralize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Convert (organic matter) wholly or partly into a mineral or inorganic material or structure.
Impregnate (water or another liquid) with a mineral substance.
--Examples--
‘the aim is to mineralize the chlorinated and aromatic hydrocarbons’
‘the mineralized remains of organisms’
‘it is delicately mineralized and like any other mineral water has no calories at all’

--Word--
mineralist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Iatrochemist. Compare "mineral". Now historical.
More generally: a person expert in or familiar with the uses and properties of (especially economically important) minerals and ores; a mineralogist.
--Examples--
--Word--
mineralizable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Capable of being mineralized; (Ecology) capable of being converted from complex organic compounds into simple inorganic substances as part of a nutrient cycle.

--Word--
mineralizer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Geology. A volatile substance dissolved in magma which controls or promotes the formation of minerals by altering the properties of the magma, but which is not necessarily present in the final mineral. Also more widely: a substance which promotes the artificial synthesis of an inorganic substance in an industrial process.
Ecology. An agent which promotes the decomposition of complex organic compounds into inorganic substances.
--Examples--

--Word--
miner 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A person who works in a mine.
A person who obtains units of a cryptocurrency by running computer processes to solve specific mathematical problems.
A person who dug tunnels in order to destroy an enemy position with explosives.
A small South American bird of the ovenbird family, which excavates a long burrow for breeding.
An Australian bird of the honeyeater family, having a loud call.
--Examples--
‘he worked as a miner at Wearmouth Colliery for 27 years’
‘the miners were freed after spending four days trapped underground’
‘anyone can become a bitcoin miner’
--Word--
mine 
--Type--
possessive pronoun, possessive determiner, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Used to refer to a thing or things belonging to or associated with the speaker.
(used before a vowel) my.
An excavation in the earth for extracting coal or other minerals.
An abundant source of something, especially information.
A type of bomb placed on or just below the surface of the ground or in the water, which detonates on contact with a person, vehicle, or ship.
A subterranean passage under the wall of a besieged fortress, especially one in which explosives were placed to blow up fortifications.
Obtain (coal or other minerals) from a mine.
Dig in (the earth) for coal or other minerals.
Dig or burrow in (the earth)
Exploit (a source of information or skill)
Analyse (a database) to generate new information.
Obtain units of (a cryptocurrency) by running a computer process to solve specific mathematical problems.
Lay explosive mines on or just below the surface of (the ground or water)
Destroy by means of an explosive mine.
--Examples--
‘you go your way and I'll go mine’
‘some friends of mine’
‘tears did fill mine eyes’
‘a copper mine’
‘the text is a mine of information for biographers and historians’
‘his jeep ran over a mine and he was killed’
‘the company came to the area to mine phosphate’
‘35 million tonnes of mined coal’
‘the hills were mined for copper oxide’
‘many financiers obtained concessions to mine for silver’
‘the earth beneath had been tortuously mined by pestilential rabbits’
‘how do they manage to mine such a rich vein of talent?’
‘if you're mining bitcoin you need to do it faster than anyone else’
‘the area was heavily mined’
‘HMS Ocean was mined in the Dardanelles in 1915’

Minerva 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--

minette 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Geology. A dark-coloured lamprophyre consisting chiefly of biotite and alkaline feldspars.
Geology. More fully "minette ironstone", "minette ore". A low-grade oolitic iron ore found mainly in Luxembourg and Lorraine, France.

--Word--
Mingo 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Originally: a member of the Susquehannock people or of any of several related Northern Iroquoian groups of interior Pennsylvania. In later use: a member of an Iroquois Indian group, mostly Senecas, who were not affiliated with the League of the Iroquois and whose modern descendants are the Oklahoma Seneca-Cayuga.
Of, relating to, or inhabited by any of these peoples.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mingrelian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Mingrelia; specifically a speaker of the Mingrelian language.
The South Caucasian language of the Mingrelian people.
Of or relating to Mingrelia, its people, or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mingus, Charles 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1922–79), American jazz bassist and composer. A leading figure of the 1940s jazz scene, he experimented with atonality and was influenced by gospel and blues. His compositions include ‘Goodbye Porkpie Hat’.

--Word--
mynheer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
As a polite or respectful form of address to a Dutchman or an Afrikaner: sir, mister (Mr). Also used as a title or sometimes substituted for the name of the man or the pronoun that would stand for this. In British use often humorous or ironic.
A Dutchman, an Afrikaner; especially one who is a gentleman. Occasionally collectively: the Dutch, the Afrikaners.

--Word--
miniature 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Very small of its kind.
A thing that is much smaller than normal, especially a small replica or model.
A very small bottle of spirits.
A plant or animal that is a smaller version of an existing variety or breed.
A very small and highly detailed portrait or other painting.
A picture or decorated letter in an illuminated manuscript.
Represent on a smaller scale.
--Examples--
‘children dressed as miniature adults’
‘seven full-size car bodies and three miniatures were used’
‘he drank miniatures of brandy on the flight’
‘miniatures for your rock garden’
‘an exhibition of one hundred pastels and miniatures’
‘a catalogue devoted to cut-out miniatures from despoiled manuscripts’
‘she saw her own reflection miniatured’

minidisk 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(A virtual disk consisting of) a logical partition of a larger disk, especially on a mainframe computer.
A floppy disk of a relatively small size; specifically a 5¼-inch (17cm) disk.
Usually in form Minidisc. A trademark for: a magneto-optical disc resembling a small compact disc, which may be used to record sound or other data, or to play pre-recorded music, etc.
--Examples--
--Word--
minidisk 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(A virtual disk consisting of) a logical partition of a larger disk, especially on a mainframe computer.
A floppy disk of a relatively small size; specifically a 5¼-inch (17cm) disk.
Usually in form Minidisc. A trademark for: a magneto-optical disc resembling a small compact disc, which may be used to record sound or other data, or to play pre-recorded music, etc.

--Word--
Minié 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Attributive Designating or relating to an elongated bullet invented by Minié, which when fired is expanded by powder contained in an iron cup inserted in a cavity at its base. Especially in "Minié ball", "Minié rifle".
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Word--
minify 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To diminish in significance or importance; to regard or represent (something) as less significant than it really is; to depreciate, belittle.
To reduce in actual size or amount; (now) especially to reduce the size of (an image).
--Examples--
--Word--
minification 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Diminution or reduction in size, appearance, importance, etc.; especially (chiefly in scientific contexts) reduction in the size of an image.
--Examples--

minified 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

minifloppy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A floppy disk of a relatively small size, originally 5¼ inches (17cm), later 3½ inches (21.5cm). Frequently attributive Compare minidisk.
--Examples--

noun

noun

--Word--
minimal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a minimum amount, quantity, or degree; negligible.
Characterized by the use of simple forms or structures, especially geometric or massive ones.
Characterized by simplicity and lack of adornment or decoration.
Characterized by the repetition and gradual alteration of short phrases.
(of a pair of forms) distinguished by only one feature.
--Examples--
‘the aircraft suffered minimal damage’
‘production costs are minimal’
‘minimal, simple evening dresses in luxurious fabrics’
‘‘p’ and ‘b’ are a minimal pair, distinguished by the feature of voicing’
--Word--
minimalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A movement in sculpture and painting which arose in the 1950s, characterized by the use of simple, massive forms.
An avant-garde movement in music characterized by the repetition of very short phrases which change gradually, producing a hypnotic effect.
Deliberate lack of decoration or adornment in style or design.
--Examples--
‘his living room was a testament to minimalism’
--Word--
minimalist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who advocates or practises minimalism.
A person advocating moderate reform in politics.
Relating to minimalism.
Lacking decoration or adornment; deliberately simple or basic in design or style.
Advocating moderate political reform.
--Examples--
‘his recently renovated minimalist Conran kitchen’
--Word--

--Word--
minimax 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The lowest of a set of maximum values.
(in game theory) denoting a strategy that minimizes the greatest risk to a participant.
Denoting the theory that in a game with two players, a player's smallest possible maximum loss is equal to the same player's greatest possible minimum gain.
--Examples--

minimum 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The least or smallest amount or quantity possible, attainable, or required.
The lowest or smallest amount of a varying quantity (e.g. temperature) allowed, attained, or recorded.
Smallest or lowest.
--Examples--
‘keep costs to a minimum’
‘they checked visas with the minimum of fuss’
‘clients with a minimum of £500,000 to invest’
‘this can be done with the minimum amount of effort’

--Word--
minimus 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Numismatics. = "minim".
Anatomy and Zoology. The smallest finger or toe.
In certain British boys' public schools (used as postpositive): designating the youngest or (occasionally) the newest of several pupils with the same surname. Also in extended use. Abbreviated min. or mini.

--Word--
minuscule 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Extremely small; tiny.
So small as to be insignificant.
Of or in lower-case letters, as distinct from capitals or uncials.
Of or in a small cursive script of the Roman alphabet, with ascenders and descenders, developed in the 7th century AD.
Minuscule script.
A small or lower-case letter.
--Examples--
‘a minuscule fragment of DNA’
‘he believed the risk of infection was minuscule’
‘the humanistic hands of the 15th century were based on the Carolingian minuscule’

noun
--Meanings--
A small set of hi-fi equipment or other home entertainment system, not usually including a record turntable.

--Word--
minister 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
(in certain countries) a head of a government department.
A member of the clergy, especially in the Presbyterian and Nonconformist Churches.
The superior of some religious orders.
A diplomatic agent, usually ranking below an ambassador, representing a state or sovereign in a foreign country.
A person or thing used to achieve or convey something.
Attend to the needs of (someone)
Provide (something necessary or helpful)
Act as a minister of religion.
Administer (a sacrament)
--Examples--
‘the Defence Minister’
‘a minister of the Lutheran church’
‘a Unitarian minister’
‘the Angels are ministers of the Divine Will’
‘her doctor was busy ministering to the injured’
‘the story was able to minister true consolation’
‘will these women be permitted to minister as priests?’
‘bishops in England were faced with a loss of priests to minister the sacraments’

ministry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in certain countries) a government department headed by a minister.
The work or vocation of a minister of religion.
The period of tenure of a minister of religion.
The spiritual work or service of a Christian or a group of Christians, especially evangelism.
(in certain countries) a period of government under one prime minister.
The action of ministering to someone.
--Examples--
‘the Ministry of Defence’
‘he is training for the ministry’
‘a tablet in the church commemorates his ministry there’
‘a ministry of Christian healing’
‘Gladstone's first ministry was outstanding’
‘the soldiers were no less in need of his ministry’

Minnetaree 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
minitrack 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A system for tracking satellites by means of a lightweight oscillator placed in the satellite, whose position is calculated from the phase difference between radio signals received by each of a spaced pair of aerials on the ground. Usually attributive.
--Examples--

--Word--
minivet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A boldly patterned Asian cuckoo-shrike (songbird), the male of which is typically red and black, and the female yellow and grey.
--Examples--
--Word--
mink 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small semiaquatic carnivore resembling the stoat, native to North America and Eurasia. The American mink is widely farmed for its fur, resulting in it becoming naturalized in many parts of Europe.
The thick brown fur of the mink.
A coat made of mink.

--Word--
Mingo 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Originally: a member of the Susquehannock people or of any of several related Northern Iroquoian groups of interior Pennsylvania. In later use: a member of an Iroquois Indian group, mostly Senecas, who were not affiliated with the League of the Iroquois and whose modern descendants are the Oklahoma Seneca-Cayuga.
Of, relating to, or inhabited by any of these peoples.

Mingus, Charles 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1922–79), American jazz bassist and composer. A leading figure of the 1940s jazz scene, he experimented with atonality and was influenced by gospel and blues. His compositions include ‘Goodbye Porkpie Hat’.

mynheer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
As a polite or respectful form of address to a Dutchman or an Afrikaner: sir, mister (Mr). Also used as a title or sometimes substituted for the name of the man or the pronoun that would stand for this. In British use often humorous or ironic.
A Dutchman, an Afrikaner; especially one who is a gentleman. Occasionally collectively: the Dutch, the Afrikaners.

miniature 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Very small of its kind.
A thing that is much smaller than normal, especially a small replica or model.
A very small bottle of spirits.
A plant or animal that is a smaller version of an existing variety or breed.
A very small and highly detailed portrait or other painting.
A picture or decorated letter in an illuminated manuscript.
Represent on a smaller scale.
--Examples--
‘children dressed as miniature adults’
‘seven full-size car bodies and three miniatures were used’
‘he drank miniatures of brandy on the flight’
‘miniatures for your rock garden’
‘an exhibition of one hundred pastels and miniatures’
‘a catalogue devoted to cut-out miniatures from despoiled manuscripts’
‘she saw her own reflection miniatured’

minidisk 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(A virtual disk consisting of) a logical partition of a larger disk, especially on a mainframe computer.
A floppy disk of a relatively small size; specifically a 5¼-inch (17cm) disk.
Usually in form Minidisc. A trademark for: a magneto-optical disc resembling a small compact disc, which may be used to record sound or other data, or to play pre-recorded music, etc.

--Word--
minimal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a minimum amount, quantity, or degree; negligible.
Characterized by the use of simple forms or structures, especially geometric or massive ones.
Characterized by simplicity and lack of adornment or decoration.
Characterized by the repetition and gradual alteration of short phrases.
(of a pair of forms) distinguished by only one feature.
--Examples--
‘the aircraft suffered minimal damage’
‘production costs are minimal’
‘minimal, simple evening dresses in luxurious fabrics’
‘‘p’ and ‘b’ are a minimal pair, distinguished by the feature of voicing’
--Word--
minimalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A movement in sculpture and painting which arose in the 1950s, characterized by the use of simple, massive forms.
An avant-garde movement in music characterized by the repetition of very short phrases which change gradually, producing a hypnotic effect.
Deliberate lack of decoration or adornment in style or design.
--Examples--
‘his living room was a testament to minimalism’
--Word--
minimalist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who advocates or practises minimalism.
A person advocating moderate reform in politics.
Relating to minimalism.
Lacking decoration or adornment; deliberately simple or basic in design or style.
Advocating moderate political reform.
--Examples--
‘his recently renovated minimalist Conran kitchen’
--Word--
minimalist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who advocates or practises minimalism.
A person advocating moderate reform in politics.
Relating to minimalism.
Lacking decoration or adornment; deliberately simple or basic in design or style.
Advocating moderate political reform.
--Examples--
‘his recently renovated minimalist Conran kitchen’
--Word--
minimally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
To an extremely small extent; negligibly.
--Examples--
‘shipments were only minimally affected by the strike’
‘minimally invasive surgery’
--Word--
minimalness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or fact of being minimal.
--Examples--
--Word--
mini-market 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small supermarket or convenience store.
--Examples--
‘there is also a mini-market located at the hotel’
--Word--

--Word--
minimax 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The lowest of a set of maximum values.
(in game theory) denoting a strategy that minimizes the greatest risk to a participant.
Denoting the theory that in a game with two players, a player's smallest possible maximum loss is equal to the same player's greatest possible minimum gain.
--Examples--
--Word--

minimize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘the aim is to minimize costs’
‘they may minimize, or even overlook, the importance of such beliefs’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A note having the time value of two crotchets or half a semibreve, represented by a ring with a stem.
A small bronze or silver ancient Roman coin.
One sixtieth of a fluid drachm, about one drop of liquid.
(in calligraphy) a short vertical stroke, as in the letters i, m, n, u.

--Word--
minimum 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The least or smallest amount or quantity possible, attainable, or required.
The lowest or smallest amount of a varying quantity (e.g. temperature) allowed, attained, or recorded.
Smallest or lowest.
--Examples--
‘keep costs to a minimum’
‘they checked visas with the minimum of fuss’
‘clients with a minimum of £500,000 to invest’
‘this can be done with the minimum amount of effort’

--Word--
minimus 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Numismatics. = "minim".
Anatomy and Zoology. The smallest finger or toe.
In certain British boys' public schools (used as postpositive): designating the youngest or (occasionally) the newest of several pupils with the same surname. Also in extended use. Abbreviated min. or mini.
--Examples--

--Word--
minuscule 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Extremely small; tiny.
So small as to be insignificant.
Of or in lower-case letters, as distinct from capitals or uncials.
Of or in a small cursive script of the Roman alphabet, with ascenders and descenders, developed in the 7th century AD.
Minuscule script.
A small or lower-case letter.
--Examples--
‘a minuscule fragment of DNA’
‘he believed the risk of infection was minuscule’
‘the humanistic hands of the 15th century were based on the Carolingian minuscule’

miniseries

mini-system 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small set of hi-fi equipment or other home entertainment system, not usually including a record turntable.
A system constructed on a small scale; a system which is limited in application or scope compared to others of its type.

--Word--
minister 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
(in certain countries) a head of a government department.
A member of the clergy, especially in the Presbyterian and Nonconformist Churches.
The superior of some religious orders.
A diplomatic agent, usually ranking below an ambassador, representing a state or sovereign in a foreign country.
A person or thing used to achieve or convey something.
Attend to the needs of (someone)
Provide (something necessary or helpful)
Act as a minister of religion.
Administer (a sacrament)
--Examples--
‘the Defence Minister’
‘a minister of the Lutheran church’
‘a Unitarian minister’
‘the Angels are ministers of the Divine Will’
‘her doctor was busy ministering to the injured’
‘the story was able to minister true consolation’
‘will these women be permitted to minister as priests?’
‘bishops in England were faced with a loss of priests to minister the sacraments’

ministration 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The provision of assistance or care.
The services of a minister of religion or of a religious institution.
The action of administering the sacrament.
--Examples--
‘a kitchen made spotless by the ministrations of a cleaning lady’
‘the ministrations of Father Martin’
‘the celebration and ministration of the sacraments’

--Word--
ministry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in certain countries) a government department headed by a minister.
The work or vocation of a minister of religion.
The period of tenure of a minister of religion.
The spiritual work or service of a Christian or a group of Christians, especially evangelism.
(in certain countries) a period of government under one prime minister.
The action of ministering to someone.
--Examples--
‘the Ministry of Defence’
‘he is training for the ministry’
‘a tablet in the church commemorates his ministry there’
‘a ministry of Christian healing’
‘Gladstone's first ministry was outstanding’
‘the soldiers were no less in need of his ministry’

--Word--
minitrack 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A system for tracking satellites by means of a lightweight oscillator placed in the satellite, whose position is calculated from the phase difference between radio signals received by each of a spaced pair of aerials on the ground. Usually attributive.
--Examples--

--Word--
mink 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small semiaquatic carnivore resembling the stoat, native to North America and Eurasia. The American mink is widely farmed for its fur, resulting in it becoming naturalized in many parts of Europe.
The thick brown fur of the mink.
A coat made of mink.
--Examples--
--Word--

noun
--Meanings--
A small rorqual whale with a dark grey back, white underparts, and pale markings on the fins and behind the head.

--Meanings--

Minneapolis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial city and port on the Mississippi River in south-eastern Minnesota; population 382,605 (est. 2008) It is a major agricultural centre for the upper Midwest.

Minnesota 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state in the northern central US, on the Canadian border; population 5,220,393 (est. 2008); capital, St Paul. It became the 32nd state of the US in 1858.

minniebush

noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
min. 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Minim (fluid measure).
Minimum.
Minute(s).
--Examples--
--Word--
minnow 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small freshwater Eurasian fish of the carp family, which typically forms large shoals.
Used in names of small freshwater fishes similar to the minnow, e.g. mudminnow, topminnow.
An artificial lure imitating a minnow.
A small or insignificant person or organization.
--Examples--
‘the paper is a minnow in the national newspaper mass market’
--Word--
minnow 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small freshwater Eurasian fish of the carp family, which typically forms large shoals.
Used in names of small freshwater fishes similar to the minnow, e.g. mudminnow, topminnow.
An artificial lure imitating a minnow.
A small or insignificant person or organization.
--Examples--
‘the paper is a minnow in the national newspaper mass market’
--Word--
minnowed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a river, stream, etc.: containing minnows, full of minnows.
--Examples--
--Word--
Miño 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river that rises in north-western Spain and flows south to the Portuguese border, which it follows before entering the Atlantic Ocean north of Viana do Castelo.
--Examples--
--Word--
Minoan 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a Bronze Age civilization centred on Crete (c.3000–1050 BC), its people, or its language.
An inhabitant of Minoan Crete or member of the Minoan people.
The language or scripts associated with the Minoans.
--Examples--
--Word--
mangle 
--Type--
verb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Destroy or severely damage by tearing or crushing.
Ruin or spoil (a text, piece of music, etc.)
A machine having two or more rollers turned by a handle, between which wet laundry is squeezed to remove excess moisture.
A large machine for ironing sheets or other fabrics, usually when they are damp, using heated rollers.
Press or squeeze with a mangle.
--Examples--
‘the car was mangled almost beyond recognition’
‘he was mangling Bach on the piano’
‘the hard household labour often involved pounding clothes in a dolly tub and mangling them with a hand wringer’
--Word--
minor 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Lesser in importance, seriousness, or significance.
(of a scale) having intervals of a semitone between the second and third degrees, and (usually) the fifth and sixth, and the seventh and eighth.
(of an interval) characteristic of a minor scale and less by a semitone than the equivalent major interval.
(of a key or mode) based on a minor scale and tending to produce a sad or pensive effect.
(following a surname in public schools) indicating the younger of two brothers.
(of a term) occurring as the subject of the conclusion of a categorical syllogism.
(of a premise) containing the minor term in a categorical syllogism.
A person under the age of full legal responsibility.
A minor key, interval, or scale.
A system of change-ringing using six bells.
The minor leagues in baseball or American football.
A student's subsidiary subject or course.
A minor term or premise.
A small drab moth which has purplish caterpillars that feed on grass.
Study as or qualify in a subsidiary subject at college or university.
--Examples--
‘she requested a number of minor alterations’
‘the E flat clarinet sounds a minor third higher than the written notes’
‘Concerto in A minor’
‘Smith minor’
‘the court would take account of the minor's wishes’
‘Salinas was one of six teams in the minors’
‘a minor in American Indian studies’
‘a bid of two no trumps shows strength in the minors’
‘Clark had minored in Animal Science’
--Word--
labia minora 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
The smaller inner folds of the vulva.
--Examples--
--Word--
minoration 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mathematics= minorization.
--Examples--
--Word--
Minorca 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The most easterly and second largest of the Balearic Islands; population 92,434 (2008); capital, Mahón.
--Examples--
--Word--
Minorcan 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the island of Minorca, the most easterly and second largest of the Balearic Islands, or its inhabitants.
A native or inhabitant of the island of Minorca, the most easterly and second largest of the Balearic Islands.
--Examples--
‘a society of Spanish and Minorcan descendants’
‘the Minorcans continued to prosper’
--Word--
Minorca 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The most easterly and second largest of the Balearic Islands; population 92,434 (2008); capital, Mahón.
--Examples--
--Word--
minor 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Lesser in importance, seriousness, or significance.
(of a scale) having intervals of a semitone between the second and third degrees, and (usually) the fifth and sixth, and the seventh and eighth.
(of an interval) characteristic of a minor scale and less by a semitone than the equivalent major interval.
(of a key or mode) based on a minor scale and tending to produce a sad or pensive effect.
(following a surname in public schools) indicating the younger of two brothers.
(of a term) occurring as the subject of the conclusion of a categorical syllogism.
(of a premise) containing the minor term in a categorical syllogism.
A person under the age of full legal responsibility.
A minor key, interval, or scale.
A system of change-ringing using six bells.
The minor leagues in baseball or American football.
A student's subsidiary subject or course.
A minor term or premise.
A small drab moth which has purplish caterpillars that feed on grass.
Study as or qualify in a subsidiary subject at college or university.
--Examples--
‘she requested a number of minor alterations’
‘the E flat clarinet sounds a minor third higher than the written notes’
‘Concerto in A minor’
‘Smith minor’
‘the court would take account of the minor's wishes’
‘Salinas was one of six teams in the minors’
‘a minor in American Indian studies’
‘a bid of two no trumps shows strength in the minors’
‘Clark had minored in Animal Science’
--Word--
Minoress 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Franciscan nun of the second order; a Poor Clare. Also "Sister Minoress" (chiefly in plural, in the names of Franciscan institutions).
--Examples--

--Type--

--Word--
Minorite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Franciscan friar or Friar Minor.
--Examples--
--Word--
minority 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The smaller number or part, especially a number or part representing less than half of the whole.
The number of votes cast for or by the smaller party in a legislative assembly.
A small group of people within a community or country, differing from the main population in race, religion, language, or political persuasion.
The state or period of being under the age of full legal responsibility.
--Examples--
‘only a minority of properties are rented’
‘those who acknowledge his influence are in the minority’
‘a minority party’
‘a blocking minority of 23 votes’
‘ethnic minorities’
‘minority rights’
‘intrigues between factions striving to make the king their puppet continued throughout his minority’
--Word--

--Word--
minor league 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A league below the level of the major league in a professional sport, especially baseball.
Insignificant; small-time.
--Examples--
‘a minor-league villain’

minor-leaguer 
--Type--
noun

--Word--
minor 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Lesser in importance, seriousness, or significance.
(of a scale) having intervals of a semitone between the second and third degrees, and (usually) the fifth and sixth, and the seventh and eighth.
(of an interval) characteristic of a minor scale and less by a semitone than the equivalent major interval.
(of a key or mode) based on a minor scale and tending to produce a sad or pensive effect.
(following a surname in public schools) indicating the younger of two brothers.
(of a term) occurring as the subject of the conclusion of a categorical syllogism.
(of a premise) containing the minor term in a categorical syllogism.
A person under the age of full legal responsibility.
A minor key, interval, or scale.
A system of change-ringing using six bells.
The minor leagues in baseball or American football.
A student's subsidiary subject or course.
A minor term or premise.
A small drab moth which has purplish caterpillars that feed on grass.
Study as or qualify in a subsidiary subject at college or university.

‘she requested a number of minor alterations’
‘the E flat clarinet sounds a minor third higher than the written notes’

‘Smith minor’

‘Clark had minored in Animal Science’
--Word--
minorize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Mathematics. Of a function, set element, etc.: to be inferior to, or constitute the lower bound for (a mathematical entity of the same type), according to a particular criterion.
--Examples--
--Word--
Yamasaki, Minoru 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1912–86), American architect. He designed the influential barrel-vaulted St Louis Municipal Airport Terminal (1956) and the World Trade Center in New York (1972).
--Examples--
--Word--
Minos 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A legendary king of Crete, son of Zeus and Europa. His wife Pasiphaë gave birth to the Minotaur; Minos later exacted tribute from Athens in the form of young people to be devoured by the monster.
--Examples--
--Word--
Minot 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A commercial and industrial city in north central North Dakota; population 35,419 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
Minotaur 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A creature who was half-man and half-bull, the offspring of Pasiphaë and a bull with which she fell in love. Confined in Crete in a labyrinth made by Daedalus and fed on human flesh, it was eventually slain by Theseus.
--Examples--
--Word--
mijnpacht 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mining lease granted (in terms of mining laws) to the owner or lessee of the mining rights on land proclaimed a public gold field, entitling this person to claim a certain percentage of the land prior to any other claims being registered; the area held under such a lease.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

Minseito 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In Japan: the Constitutional Democratic Party, formed in 1927 and disbanded in 1940.
--Examples--

Minsk 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Belarus, an industrial city in the central region of the country; population 1,829,100 (est. 2009).
--Examples--
--Word--
minster 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large or important church, typically one of cathedral status in the north of England that was built as part of a monastery.
--Examples--
‘York Minster’

--Word--
minstrel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A medieval singer or musician, especially one who sang or recited lyric or heroic poetry to a musical accompaniment for the nobility.
A member of a band of entertainers with blackened faces who performed songs and music ostensibly of black American origin.
--Examples--
‘they listened to the minstrels singing songs of knightly prowess’
--Word--
minstreless 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A female minstrel.
--Examples--

--Type--

--Word--
mint 
--Type--
noun, noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
An aromatic plant native to temperate regions of the Old World, several kinds of which are used as culinary herbs.
The flavour of mint, especially peppermint.
A peppermint sweet.
A place where money is coined, especially under state authority.
A large sum of money.
(of an object) in pristine condition; as new.
Very good.
Make (a coin) by stamping metal.
Produce for the first time.
--Examples--
‘plant mint in a large pot with drainage holes’
‘there are many other mints with distinct aromas’
‘a tasty mint and chocolate flavoured cone’
‘Dickie pulled out a packet of mints from his pocket’
‘die links between coins indicate that they were made at the same mint’
‘the curtains had cost a mint’
‘the bank made a mint from the upheaval in the money markets’
‘a pair of speakers, mint, £160’
‘there was Dean, looking really mint in his new jacket’
‘only coins of a relatively high denomination were minted’
‘an example of newly minted technology’
--Word--
mintage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The minting of coins.
The number of copies issued of a particular coin.
--Examples--
‘the inscriptions refer to the place of mintage’
‘an estimated mintage of about 800’
--Word--
mintage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The minting of coins.
The number of copies issued of a particular coin.
--Examples--
‘the inscriptions refer to the place of mintage’
‘an estimated mintage of about 800’
--Word--
minted 
--Type--
adjective, adjective
--Meanings--
Having a lot of money; rich.
Flavoured or seasoned with mint.
--Examples--
‘I imagine those kids think I'm minted’
‘her minted parents are now splashing out on a diamond ring for her’
‘grilled lamb chops with minted potatoes’

mint mark 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

Minto 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of boiled sweet flavoured with peppermint. (Formerly a trademark.).

--Word--
Minton 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Pottery made at Stoke-on-Trent by Thomas Minton (1766–1836) or his factory. Minton's company popularized the willow pattern.
--Examples--
‘Minton china’

--Word--
minuet 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A slow, stately ballroom dance for two in triple time, popular especially in the 18th century.
A piece of music in triple time in the style of a minuet, typically as a movement in a suite, sonata, or symphony and frequently coupled with a trio.
Dance a minuet.
--Examples--
--Word--
minuet 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A slow, stately ballroom dance for two in triple time, popular especially in the 18th century.
A piece of music in triple time in the style of a minuet, typically as a movement in a suite, sonata, or symphony and frequently coupled with a trio.
Dance a minuet.
--Examples--
--Word--
minuet 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A slow, stately ballroom dance for two in triple time, popular especially in the 18th century.
A piece of music in triple time in the style of a minuet, typically as a movement in a suite, sonata, or symphony and frequently coupled with a trio.
Dance a minuet.
--Examples--
--Word--
Minuit, Peter 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1580–1638), Dutch colonial administrator, the first director general of the North American Dutch colony of New Netherland 1626–31. He is said to have purchased Manhattan Island from North American Indians in 1626 for 60 guilders.
--Examples--
--Word--
minus 
--Type--
preposition, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
With the subtraction of.
Lacking; deprived of.
(of temperature) below zero by.
(before a number) below zero; negative.
(after a grade) rather worse than.
Having a negative electric charge.
A mathematical operation of subtraction.
A disadvantage.
--Examples--
‘what's ninety three minus seven?’
‘he was minus a finger on each hand’
‘minus 40 degrees centigrade’
‘minus five’
‘C minus’
‘for every plus with this equipment there can be a minus’
--Word--
minuscular 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
minuscule 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Extremely small; tiny.
So small as to be insignificant.
Of or in lower-case letters, as distinct from capitals or uncials.
Of or in a small cursive script of the Roman alphabet, with ascenders and descenders, developed in the 7th century AD.
Minuscule script.
A small or lower-case letter.
--Examples--
‘a minuscule fragment of DNA’
‘he believed the risk of infection was minuscule’
‘the humanistic hands of the 15th century were based on the Carolingian minuscule’
--Word--
minuscule 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Extremely small; tiny.
So small as to be insignificant.
Of or in lower-case letters, as distinct from capitals or uncials.
Of or in a small cursive script of the Roman alphabet, with ascenders and descenders, developed in the 7th century AD.
Minuscule script.
A small or lower-case letter.
--Examples--
‘a minuscule fragment of DNA’
‘he believed the risk of infection was minuscule’
‘the humanistic hands of the 15th century were based on the Carolingian minuscule’

--Word--
minuter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Scottish Law. A person or party presenting a minute to a court.
--Examples--
--Word--
minute 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A period of time equal to sixty seconds or a sixtieth of an hour.
The distance covered in a minute by someone driving or walking.
A very short time.
A point in time.
A sixtieth of a degree of angular measurement (symbol: ʹ)
--Examples--
‘we waited for twenty minutes’
‘I'll be there in ten minutes' time’
‘the hotel is situated just ten minutes from the centre of the resort’
‘come and sit down for a minute’
‘she was laughing one minute and crying the next’
‘Delta Lyrae is a double star with a separation of over 10 minutes of arc’
--Word--

--Word--
minutely 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
With great attention to detail; meticulously.
--Examples--
‘systems of politics are examined minutely by academics’
‘minutely detailed descriptions covering every angle’
--Word--
minuteman 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a class of militiamen of the American revolutionary period who volunteered to be ready for service at a minute's notice.
A type of three-stage intercontinental ballistic missile.
--Examples--

‘she was laughing one minute and crying the next’
‘Delta Lyrae is a double star with a separation of over 10 minutes of arc’
--Word--
minutiae 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
The small, precise, or trivial details of something.
--Examples--
‘the minutiae of everyday life’
--Word--
minutiae 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
The small, precise, or trivial details of something.
--Examples--
‘the minutiae of everyday life’
--Word--
minutial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the nature of minutiae; relating to small points or details.
--Examples--
--Word--
minute 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A period of time equal to sixty seconds or a sixtieth of an hour.
The distance covered in a minute by someone driving or walking.
A very short time.
A point in time.
A sixtieth of a degree of angular measurement (symbol: ʹ)
--Examples--
‘we waited for twenty minutes’
‘I'll be there in ten minutes' time’
‘the hotel is situated just ten minutes from the centre of the resort’
‘come and sit down for a minute’
‘she was laughing one minute and crying the next’
‘Delta Lyrae is a double star with a separation of over 10 minutes of arc’

minverite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of basic intrusive rock found chiefly in Cornwall, which is an altered dolerite rich in albite and brown hornblende, also containing angite and other minerals.

--Word--
myoblast 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: an embryonic muscle-forming or myoepithelial cell in an invertebrate; (also) †embryonic muscle-forming tissue, mesoderm (obsolete). Later: any incompletely or poorly differentiated muscle cell; especially any of the mononuclear cells that fuse to form skeletal muscle fibres.
--Examples--

Originally: an embryonic muscle-forming or myoepithelial cell in an invertebrate; (also) †embryonic muscle-forming tissue, mesoderm (obsolete). Later: any incompletely or poorly differentiated muscle cell; especially any of the mononuclear cells that fuse to form skeletal muscle fibres.

--Word--
myofilament 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of the ultramicroscopic, rod-like aggregates of protein molecules that are arranged in an overlapping array in the sarcomere of a myofibril, occurring in two forms, the thick filament (composed of myosin molecules) and thin filament (composed of actin molecules).
--Examples--
--Word--
myogen 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a protein found in muscle-plasma, believed to be the soluble precursor of myosin (now historical). Later (more fully "myogen A", "myogen B", "myogen I", "myogen II", etc.): any of a group of soluble proteins obtained by extraction of muscle with cold water, most of which have been identified as glycolytic enzymes.

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(Usually with myo- italicized.) The most common of the isomers of inositol, which is a member of the vitamin B complex and is present in plant and animal tissue, especially muscle, often in phosphorylated form.

myoplasm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In an ascidian egg: a portion of the cytoplasm, deep yellow in colour, that is selectively distributed to muscle-forming cells during embryonic development.
Originally: the cytoplasm of a muscle cell; = "sarcoplasm". Later also: specifically the interfibrillary portion of the cytoplasm of a muscle fibre.

myotome 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The dorsal part of each somite in a vertebrate embryo, giving rise to the skeletal musculature.

St. Pierre and Miquelon 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A group of eight small islands in the North Atlantic Ocean, off the southern coast of Newfoundland; population 5,600 (estimated 2015). An overseas territory of France, the islands are the last remaining French possession in North America.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mir 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Soviet space station, launched in 1986 and designed to be permanently manned. It was deliberately brought down into the Pacific Ocean in 2001.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mira 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A star in the constellation Cetus, regarded as the prototype of long-period variable stars.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mirabeau, Comte de 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1749–91), French revolutionary politician; born Honoré Gabriel Riqueti. Pressing for a form of constitutional monarchy, Mirabeau was prominent in the early days of the French Revolution.
--Examples--
--Word--
mirabelle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sweet yellow fruit that is a variety of the greengage.
The tree that bears mirabelles.
A liqueur distilled from mirabelles.
--Examples--
--Word--
rete mirabile 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a network of small arterioles derived from the external carotid artery and located within the cavernous sinus at the base of the brain, found in ungulates and certain other mammals (and formerly supposed to exist in humans), now believed to assist in regulating the temperature of the blood entering the brain. In later use also: any of various similar networks of blood vessels, most of which are thought to operate as countercurrent systems that maintain a gradient of temperature or of gases or solutes in the blood.
--Examples--
--Word--
mirabilia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Treated as plural. Things which inspire wonder; (usually specifically) miraculous events.
--Examples--
--Word--
annus mirabilis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A remarkable or auspicious year.
--Examples--
--Word--
mirabilite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Native hydrated sodium sulphate, Na₂SO₄·10H₂O, a monoclinic mineral usually occurring as colourless prisms or massive deposits, especially near salt springs or lakes, and in caves. Also called Glauber's salt.
--Examples--
--Word--
mire 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A stretch of swampy or boggy ground.
Soft mud or dirt.
A wetland area or ecosystem based on peat.
A complicated or unpleasant situation from which it is difficult to extricate oneself.
Cause to become stuck in mud.
Cover or spatter with mud.
Involve someone or something in (a difficult situation)
--Examples--
‘acres of land had been reduced to a mire’
‘the roads retained their winter mire’
‘the service is sinking in the mire of its own regulations’
‘sometimes a heavy truck gets mired down’
‘the horse waded through the red mud that mired it to its hocks’
‘the economy is mired in its longest recession since the war’
--Word--
miracidium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A free-swimming ciliated larval stage in which a parasitic fluke passes from the egg to its first host, typically a snail.
--Examples--

miracidial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

miracidium 
--Type--

--Meanings--
A free-swimming ciliated larval stage in which a parasitic fluke passes from the egg to its first host, typically a snail.
--Examples--
--Word--
miracle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An extraordinary and welcome event that is not explicable by natural or scientific laws and is therefore attributed to a divine agency.
A remarkable event or development that brings very welcome consequences.
An exceptional product or achievement, or an outstanding example of something.
--Examples--
‘the miracle of rising from the grave’
‘it was a miracle that more people hadn't been killed’
‘industries at the heart of the economic miracle’
‘a machine which was a miracle of design’
‘a miracle drug’

noun
--Meanings--
An extraordinary and welcome event that is not explicable by natural or scientific laws and is therefore attributed to a divine agency.
A remarkable event or development that brings very welcome consequences.
An exceptional product or achievement, or an outstanding example of something.
--Examples--
‘the miracle of rising from the grave’
‘it was a miracle that more people hadn't been killed’
‘industries at the heart of the economic miracle’
‘a machine which was a miracle of design’
‘a miracle drug’
--Word--
miracle worker 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who seems to be able to perform miracles.
--Examples--
‘he is very good at his job, but he is not a miracle worker’
‘you're a miracle worker—how on earth did you cram everything in?’
--Word--
miracle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An extraordinary and welcome event that is not explicable by natural or scientific laws and is therefore attributed to a divine agency.
A remarkable event or development that brings very welcome consequences.
An exceptional product or achievement, or an outstanding example of something.
--Examples--
‘the miracle of rising from the grave’
‘it was a miracle that more people hadn't been killed’
‘industries at the heart of the economic miracle’

‘a miracle drug’
--Word--
miracle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An extraordinary and welcome event that is not explicable by natural or scientific laws and is therefore attributed to a divine agency.

‘a miracle drug’
--Word--
miraculist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A believer in miracles.
Of, relating to, or characterized by belief in miracles.
--Examples--
--Word--
miraculous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the nature of a miracle or having the power to work miracles.
Remarkable and bringing very welcome consequences.
--Examples--
‘a miraculous cure’
‘I felt amazed and grateful for our miraculous escape’
--Word--
miraculously 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that suggests or resembles a miracle.
In a remarkable and extremely lucky manner.
--Examples--
‘a shrine where people bring the sick to be miraculously healed’
‘the two drivers miraculously escaped with only minor injuries’
--Word--
miraculousness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--
A turret or tower attached to a building and providing an extensive view.
--Examples--

mirador 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A turret or tower attached to a building and providing an extensive view.
--Examples--
--Word--
mirage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An optical illusion caused by atmospheric conditions, especially the appearance of a sheet of water in a desert or on a hot road caused by the refraction of light from the sky by heated air.
An unrealistic hope or wish that cannot be achieved.
--Examples--
‘the surface of the road ahead rippled in the heat mirages’
‘the hope of sanctuary initially proved a mirage’
--Word--
mirage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An optical illusion caused by atmospheric conditions, especially the appearance of a sheet of water in a desert or on a hot road caused by the refraction of light from the sky by heated air.
An unrealistic hope or wish that cannot be achieved.
--Examples--
‘the surface of the road ahead rippled in the heat mirages’
‘the hope of sanctuary initially proved a mirage’
--Word--
miragy 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the nature of or resembling a mirage; producing mirages.
--Examples--
--Word--
Miramar 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in south Florida; population 108,484 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
Miranda 
--Type--
proper noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A satellite of Uranus, the eleventh closest to the planet, having a complex terrain of cratered areas and tracts of grooves and ridges, discovered in 1948 (diameter 480 km).
Denoting or relating to the duty of the police to inform a person taken into custody of their right to legal counsel and the right to remain silent under questioning.
--Examples--
‘the patrolman read Lee his Miranda rights’
--Word--
mirate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To express admiration or wonder; to marvel.
--Examples--
--Word--
mirbane 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Nitrobenzene as formerly used in perfumery. Chiefly in "essence of mirbane", "oil of mirbane".
--Examples--
--Word--
myrcene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A liquid terpene found in essential oils of bayberry, hop, and other plants, used in the manufacture of perfumes; 7-methyl-3-methylene-1,6-octadiene, CH₂:CHC(CH₂)CH₂CH₂CH:C(CH₃)₂.
--Examples--
--Word--
mire 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A stretch of swampy or boggy ground.
Soft mud or dirt.
A wetland area or ecosystem based on peat.
A complicated or unpleasant situation from which it is difficult to extricate oneself.
Cause to become stuck in mud.
Cover or spatter with mud.
Involve someone or something in (a difficult situation)
--Examples--
‘acres of land had been reduced to a mire’
‘the roads retained their winter mire’
‘the service is sinking in the mire of its own regulations’
‘sometimes a heavy truck gets mired down’
‘the horse waded through the red mud that mired it to its hocks’
‘the economy is mired in its longest recession since the war’

--Word--
Miri 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of an originally hill-dwelling people of the eastern Himalayas who subsequently settled in the Assam valley.
Any of a number of Tibeto-Burman languages of the Miris.
Of or relating to the Miris or their languages.
--Examples--
--Word--
miry 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Very muddy or boggy.
--Examples--
‘the roads were miry in winter’
--Word--
miryachit 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A syndrome characterized by echolalia and echopraxia in response to a sudden stimulus, observed in Siberia and variously regarded as a psychiatric disorder or as an exaggerated or abnormal startle response.
--Examples--
--Word--
myriad 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A countless or extremely great number of people or things.
(chiefly in classical history) a unit of ten thousand.
Countless or extremely great in number.
Having countless or very many elements or aspects.
--Examples--
‘myriads of insects danced around the light above my head’
‘the army was organized on a decimal system, up to divisions of 10,000 or myriads’
‘he gazed at the myriad lights of the city’
‘the myriad political scene’

misbirth 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An abortive delivery, a miscarriage. Also concrete: a miscarried fetus; a stillborn child, animal, etc. Now archaic (usually figurative).

adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Prematurely born; abortive.
Treated as plural. With the. Misborn people regarded as a class.

misbrand 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(A) To brand (cattle or other stock) incorrectly, especially so as to disguise ownership. (b) Chiefly US Law. To label or describe (a product or commodity) incorrectly, misleadingly, or dishonestly.
--Examples--

misbranded 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

misbranding 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
mithqal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A unit of weight, used chiefly for precious metals in the Islamic world, varying with place and period but now generally taken to be approximately 4.25 grams (65.6 grains); a coin of this weight. Also in Iran: a unit of weight equivalent to approximately 4.6 grams (71 grains).
--Examples--
--Word--
miscalculate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Calculate (an amount or measurement) wrongly.
Assess (a situation) wrongly.
--Examples--
‘they miscalculated the number of new houses that would need to be built’
‘the government has seriously miscalculated the effect of privatization’
‘you miscalculated if you imagined I'd fallen for your little scheme’

verb

--Word--
miscarry 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of a pregnant woman) experience a miscarriage.
(of a plan) fail to attain an intended outcome.
(of a letter) fail to reach its intended destination.
--Examples--
‘Wendy miscarried after five weeks’
‘she miscarried her first baby’
‘such a rash crime, and one so very likely to miscarry!’
‘many of my letters home miscarried because the post went through enemy-occupied Europe’
--Word--
miscarriage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The spontaneous or unplanned expulsion of a fetus from the womb before it is able to survive independently.
An unsuccessful outcome of something planned.
--Examples--
‘his wife had a miscarriage’
‘some pregnancies result in miscarriage’
‘the miscarriage of the project’

miscegenate 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A person born as a result of miscegenation; the issue of a union between people of different races or ethnic groups.
To give rise to miscegenation; (of a race) to intermarry with another race. Now frequently in extended and figurative use.
--Examples--
--Word--
miscegenation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The interbreeding of people considered to be of different racial types.
--Examples--
‘they believe in miscegenation as the answer to world peace’

--Word--
censure 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Express severe disapproval of (someone or something), especially in a formal statement.
The formal expression of severe disapproval.
--Examples--
‘the company was heavily censured by inspectors from the Department of Trade’
‘shareholders censured the bank for its extravagance’
‘two MPs were singled out for censure’
‘despite episcopal censures, the practice continued’
--Word--
mis- 
--Type--
prefix, prefix
--Meanings--
(added to verbs and their derivatives) wrongly.
Badly.
Unsuitably.
Occurring in a few words adopted from French expressing a sense with negative force.
--Examples--
‘misapply’
‘mismanage’
‘misname’
‘misadventure’
‘mischief’
--Word--
mischance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Bad luck.
An unlucky occurrence.
--Examples--
‘by pure mischance the secret was revealed’
‘innumerable mischances might ruin the enterprise’
--Word--
mischance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Bad luck.
An unlucky occurrence.
--Examples--
‘by pure mischance the secret was revealed’
‘innumerable mischances might ruin the enterprise’
--Word--
mischancy 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Originally: unlucky; unfortunate (chiefly Scottish and Irish English). Now usually: subject to (mis)chance; risky, dubious.
--Examples--
--Word--
mishanter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mishap or misadventure.
--Examples--
‘I drove into the loch by mishanter’
--Word--
mischarge 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A charge wrongly levied or entered in an account.
To charge an incorrect amount to (a person or organization).
To make a false or incorrect accusation against (a person or thing). Now rare.
Molecular Biology. To link (a molecule of transfer RNA) with the wrong amino acid.
--Examples--
--Word--
mischarged 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a transfer RNA molecule: linked to an amino acid other than the one specific to it.
--Examples--
--Word--
mischarge 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A charge wrongly levied or entered in an account.
To charge an incorrect amount to (a person or organization).
To make a false or incorrect accusation against (a person or thing). Now rare.
Molecular Biology. To link (a molecule of transfer RNA) with the wrong amino acid.
--Examples--
--Word--
mischarging 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The linking of a transfer RNA molecule and an amino acid that is not specific to it.
Of transfer RNA: that binds with an amino acid whose codon is not complementary to the transfer RNA anticodon.
--Examples--
--Word--
mischief 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Playful misbehaviour, especially on the part of children.
Playfulness that is intended to tease or create trouble.
Harm or trouble caused by someone or something.
A person responsible for harm or annoyance.
A wrong or hardship that a statute is designed to remove or for which the common law affords a remedy.
--Examples--
‘she'll make sure Danny doesn't get into mischief’
‘her eyes twinkled with irrepressible mischief’
‘she was bent on making mischief’
‘the statute was passed to prevent a mischief in respect of which the defendant was already under a duty at common law’
--Word--
mischiefful

adjective
--Meanings--
Of a person, etc.: full of or prone to do mischief; mischievous.

misconduct 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Unacceptable or improper behaviour, especially by an employee or professional person.
A penalty assessed against a player for unsportsmanlike conduct.
Mismanagement, especially culpable neglect of duties.
Behave in an improper manner.
Mismanage (an activity)
--Examples--
‘she was found guilty of professional misconduct by a disciplinary tribunal and dismissed’
‘Smith got a game misconduct for spearing Nick Kypreos’
‘the general was pardoned for misconduct of the war’
‘the committee reprimanded two members who were found to have misconducted themselves’
‘there is no evidence that the premises were being misconducted’

--Word--
miscue 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
(in billiards and snooker) a shot in which the player fails to strike the ball properly with the cue.
(in other sports) a faulty strike, kick, or catch.
A mistake.
(in snooker and other sports) fail to strike (the ball or a shot) properly.
An error in reading, especially one caused by failure to respond correctly to a phonetic or contextual cue in the text.
--Examples--
‘Guillen at shortstop made just three miscues in 160 games’
‘political miscues that led to resignations’
‘he miscued a simple penalty in the sixth minute’
‘he won the fourth frame on the pink when O'Sullivan miscued’
‘miscue analysis is a way of listening to children read aloud for diagnostic purposes’
--Word--
miscue 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
(in billiards and snooker) a shot in which the player fails to strike the ball properly with the cue.
(in other sports) a faulty strike, kick, or catch.
A mistake.

An error in reading, especially one caused by failure to respond correctly to a phonetic or contextual cue in the text.

‘political miscues that led to resignations’
‘he miscued a simple penalty in the sixth minute’
‘he won the fourth frame on the pink when O'Sullivan miscued’
‘miscue analysis is a way of listening to children read aloud for diagnostic purposes’

A mistake.
(in snooker and other sports) fail to strike (the ball or a shot) properly.
An error in reading, especially one caused by failure to respond correctly to a phonetic or contextual cue in the text.
--Examples--
‘Guillen at shortstop made just three miscues in 160 games’
‘political miscues that led to resignations’
‘he miscued a simple penalty in the sixth minute’
‘he won the fourth frame on the pink when O'Sullivan miscued’
‘miscue analysis is a way of listening to children read aloud for diagnostic purposes’
--Word--
miscue 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
(in billiards and snooker) a shot in which the player fails to strike the ball properly with the cue.
(in other sports) a faulty strike, kick, or catch.
A mistake.

--Word--
misdirection 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of directing someone to the wrong place or in the wrong direction.
The wrong or inappropriate use or application of something.
A wrong instruction given by a judge to a jury.
--Examples--
‘the deliberate misdirection that had put me off the track’
‘misdirections given by the coastguard to rescue services’
‘the misdirection of government funding’
‘wasteful misdirections of production’
‘he won his appeal on the basis of a misdirection by the trial judge’

myself 
--Type--
pronoun
--Meanings--
Used by a speaker to refer to himself or herself as the object of a verb or preposition when he or she is the subject of the clause.
I or me personally (used to emphasize the speaker)
Used by a speaker to refer to himself or herself; I.
--Examples--
‘I hurt myself by accident’
‘I strolled around, muttering to myself’
‘I myself am unsure how this problem should be handled’
‘I wrote it myself’
‘myself presented to him a bronze sword’

--Word--
miserable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a person) wretchedly unhappy or uncomfortable.
Causing unhappiness or discomfort.
(of a person) habitually morose.
Contemptible (used as a term of abuse or for emphasis)
Pitiably small or inadequate.
Miserly.
--Examples--
‘their happiness made Anne feel even more miserable’
‘horribly wet and miserable conditions’
‘a miserable man in his late sixties’
‘you miserable old creep!’
‘all they pay me is a miserable £8,000 a year’
‘a lousy dollar a day—could any government be more miserable?’
--Word--
miserableness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
miserably 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a wretchedly unhappy manner.
In a way that causes unhappiness or pain.
In a pitiable or contemptible manner; terribly.
--Examples--
‘he stared miserably into his hands’
‘he slumped miserably back into his chair’
‘a considerable number of animals perished miserably’
‘the miserably oppressed population’
‘all attempts have failed miserably in the past’
‘our team fared miserably’
‘a miserably paid job’

misery 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A state or feeling of great physical or mental distress or discomfort.
A cause or source of great distress or discomfort.
A person who is constantly miserable or discontented.
--Examples--
‘a man who had brought her nothing but misery’
‘the misery of the miner's existence’
‘the miseries of war’
‘have we really been such a bunch of miseries to work with?’
--Word--
misericord 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A ledge projecting from the underside of a hinged seat in a choir stall which, when the seat is turned up, gives support to someone standing.
An apartment in a monastery in which some relaxations of the monastic rule were permitted.
A small dagger used to deliver a death stroke to a wounded enemy.

‘the prize for the winner will be a miserly £3,500’
--Word--
miserliness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Excessive desire to save money; extreme meanness.
The quality of being small or inadequate; meagreness.
--Examples--
‘the party earned a damaging reputation for miserliness by cutting pensions’
‘the relative miserliness of the prizes involved’
--Word--
miser 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who hoards wealth and spends as little money as possible.
--Examples--
‘a typical miser, he hid his money in the house in various places’
--Word--
mise en scène 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

The setting or surroundings of an event.
