--Word--
misfire 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a gun or missile) fail to discharge or fire properly.
(of an internal combustion engine) undergo failure of the fuel to ignite correctly or at all.
(of a nerve cell) fail to transmit an electrical impulse at an appropriate moment.
(especially of a plan) fail to produce the intended result.
A failure of a gun or missile to fire correctly.
A failure of fuel to ignite correctly in an internal combustion engine.
--Examples--
‘as she raised her pistol again, it misfired’
‘the car would misfire occasionally from the cold’
‘as these nerves misfire and die, the muscles begin to shrink’
‘he didn't know that his plan had misfired’
‘the weapons are to be replaced because of problems with misfires’
‘he drove into the pits to have a misfire cured’
--Word--

--Word--
Mishima, Yukio 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1925–70), Japanese writer; pseudonym of Hiraoka Kimitake. His books include the four-volume The Sea of Fertility (1965–70), which deals with themes of reincarnation and the sterility of modern life. An avowed imperialist, he committed hara-kiri after failing to incite soldiers against the post-war regime.
--Examples--
--Word--
mishit 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(in various sports) hit or kick (a ball) badly or in the wrong direction.
An instance of hitting or kicking a ball badly or in the wrong direction.
--Examples--
‘an incompetent tennis player, he mishit the shot’
‘Perdita mishit wildly’
‘after a further mishit, his third attempt proved successful’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of having a modest or low view of one's importance.
--Examples--
‘he needs the humility to accept that their way may be better’
--Word--
Mysia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient region of north-western Asia Minor, on the Mediterranean coast south of the Sea of Marmara.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mysian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the ancient region of Mysia in north-western Asia Minor or its inhabitants.
A native or inhabitant of the ancient region of Mysia in north-western Asia Minor.
--Examples--
‘the Mysian king’
‘the Mysians fared best of those on the mainland’

mysid

noun
--Meanings--
A crustacean of an order that comprises the opossum shrimps.

--Word--
Mysis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of malacostracan crustaceans, originally comprising all the opossum shrimps, but now restricted to a smaller number of related marine and freshwater species. Also (usually in form mysis): a crustacean of this genus (also "mysis shrimp").
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--

noun

--Word--
mithqal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A unit of weight, used chiefly for precious metals in the Islamic world, varying with place and period but now generally taken to be approximately 4.25 grams (65.6 grains); a coin of this weight. Also in Iran: a unit of weight equivalent to approximately 4.6 grams (71 grains).
--Examples--

miskick 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Kick (a ball) badly or wrongly.
An instance of miskicking a ball.
--Examples--
‘the keeper miskicked a clearance and put the ball in his own net’
‘Tait miskicked in front of a gaping goal’
‘there were too many miskicks and misses’

--Type--
noun, adjective

--Word--
mis- 
--Type--
prefix, prefix
--Meanings--
(added to verbs and their derivatives) wrongly.
Badly.
Unsuitably.
Occurring in a few words adopted from French expressing a sense with negative force.
--Examples--
‘misapply’
‘mismanage’
‘misname’
‘misadventure’
‘mischief’

mismatch 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A failure to correspond or match; a discrepancy.
An unequal or unfair sporting contest.
Match (people or things) unsuitably or incorrectly.
--Examples--
‘a huge mismatch between supply and demand’
‘there are fewer mismatches so spectators get better value for money’
‘a pair of mismatched cops’

misnomer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A wrong or inaccurate name or designation.
A wrong or inaccurate use of a name or term.
--Examples--
‘morning sickness is a misnomer for many women, since the nausea can occur any time during the day’
‘to call this ‘neighbourhood policing’ would be a misnomer’

--Word--
misorder 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Disorder; specifically lack or breach of order; confusion; disorderly conduct, misbehaviour. Now rare.
An order placed in error.
To put into disorder; to confuse, disturb.
To order (an item of merchandise, etc.) in error; to place an incorrect order for.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mysore 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in the Indian state of Karnataka; population 1,042,400 (est. 2009). It was the capital of the princely state of Mysore and is noted for the production of silk, incense, and sandalwood oil.
--Examples--

--Word--
mis- 
--Type--
prefix, prefix
--Meanings--
(added to verbs and their derivatives) wrongly.
Badly.
Unsuitably.
Occurring in a few words adopted from French expressing a sense with negative force.
--Examples--
‘misapply’
‘mismanage’

misplace 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Put (an object) in the wrong place and so lose it temporarily.
Position incorrectly.
--Examples--
‘I'm sure the jewellery has just been misplaced, and not stolen’
‘Crewe came back into the game when Strachan misplaced a pass in the midfield’
--Word--
misplaced 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Incorrectly positioned.
Not appropriate or correct in the circumstances.
(of a feeling or emotion) directed unwisely or to an inappropriate object.
Temporarily lost.
--Examples--
‘a million dollars had been lost because of a misplaced comma’
‘a telling sign of misplaced priorities’
‘he began to wonder if his sympathy was misplaced’
‘her misplaced keys’

--Word--
misplay 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Play (a ball or card) wrongly, badly, or in contravention of the rules.
An instance of misplaying a ball or card.
--Examples--
‘both balls were misplayed’
‘Labour's leaders misplayed their hand last week’
‘they scored twice, helped by misplays from the left fielder’

--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Read (a piece of text) wrongly.
Judge or interpret (a situation or a person's manner or behaviour) incorrectly.
--Examples--
‘perhaps she'd misread the note and got the time wrong’
‘he withdrew an allegation based on his misreading of a newspaper article’
‘had she been completely misreading his intentions?’

noun
--Meanings--
Faulty or inaccurate recollection, forgetting; an instance of this.
--Examples--

--Word--
misrule 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The unfair or inefficient conduct of the affairs of a country or state.
The disruption of peace; disorder.
Govern (a country or state) badly.
--Examples--
‘a country that is recovering from decades of misrule’
‘there was a tradition of misrule before, during, and after games’
‘he misruled his country for fourteen years’

--Word--
miss 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Fail to hit, reach, or come into contact with (something aimed at)
Pass by without touching; chance not to hit.
Fail to catch (something thrown or dropped)
Fail to notice, hear, or understand.
Fail to attend, participate in, or watch (something one is expected to do or habitually does)
Be too late to catch (a passenger vehicle or the post)
Fail to see or have a meeting with (someone)
Not be able to experience or fail to take advantage of (an opportunity or chance)
Avoid; escape.
(of a woman) fail to have (a monthly period)
Notice the loss or absence of.
Feel regret or sadness at no longer being able to enjoy the presence of.
Feel regret or sadness at no longer being able to go to, do, or have.
(of an engine or motor vehicle) undergo failure of ignition in one or more cylinders.
A failure to hit, catch, or reach something.
An unsuccessful record or film.
--Examples--
‘a laser-guided bomb had missed its target’
‘he shot twice at the cashier, but missed both times’
‘the plane narrowly missed the control tower’
‘Mandy missed the catch, and flung the ball back crossly’
‘Callison tried for a catch and missed’
‘the villa is impossible to miss—it's right by the road’
‘these questions miss the point’
‘Teague looks certain to miss England's match against Fiji’
‘we'll miss the train if he doesn't hurry’
‘‘Potter's been here this morning?’ ‘You've just missed him.’’
‘don't miss the chance to visit the breathtaking Dolomites’
‘he failed to recover from a leg injury and missed out on a trip to Barcelona’
‘Christmas shoppers go out early to miss the crowds’
‘how many periods have you missed?’
‘I think I'm pregnant—this is the second time I've missed’
‘he's rich—he won't miss the money’
‘she slipped away when she thought she wouldn't be missed’
‘she misses all her old friends’
‘I still miss France and I wish I could go back’
‘the motor began missing and investigation found a cracked cylinder head’
‘the penalty miss cost us the game’
‘it is the public who decide whether a film is a hit or a miss’

--Type--

--Meanings--
Mississippi.
--Examples--
--Word--
missable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
mis- 
--Type--
prefix, prefix
--Meanings--
(added to verbs and their derivatives) wrongly.
Badly.
Unsuitably.
Occurring in a few words adopted from French expressing a sense with negative force.
--Examples--
‘misapply’
‘mismanage’
‘misname’
‘misadventure’
‘mischief’
--Word--
missaying 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A false statement; a mistake. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
missal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A book containing the texts used in the Catholic Mass throughout the year.
--Examples--
‘the bookcase contained an assortment of old prayer books, missals, and devotional pamphlets’
‘Christian influence on Viking art is demonstrated by the illuminated missals and gold reliquaries’

miss 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Fail to hit, reach, or come into contact with (something aimed at)
Pass by without touching; chance not to hit.
Fail to catch (something thrown or dropped)
Fail to notice, hear, or understand.
Fail to attend, participate in, or watch (something one is expected to do or habitually does)

Avoid; escape.
(of a woman) fail to have (a monthly period)
Notice the loss or absence of.
Feel regret or sadness at no longer being able to enjoy the presence of.
Feel regret or sadness at no longer being able to go to, do, or have.
(of an engine or motor vehicle) undergo failure of ignition in one or more cylinders.
A failure to hit, catch, or reach something.
An unsuccessful record or film.
--Examples--
‘a laser-guided bomb had missed its target’
‘he shot twice at the cashier, but missed both times’
‘the plane narrowly missed the control tower’
‘Mandy missed the catch, and flung the ball back crossly’
‘Callison tried for a catch and missed’

‘I still miss France and I wish I could go back’

‘the penalty miss cost us the game’
‘it is the public who decide whether a film is a hit or a miss’

--Examples--
--Word--
seek 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Attempt to find (something)
Attempt or desire to obtain or achieve (something)
Ask for (something) from someone.
Search for and find someone or something.
Go to (a place)
--Examples--
‘they came here to seek shelter from biting winter winds’
‘the new regime sought his extradition’
‘her parents had never sought to interfere with her freedom’
‘he sought help from the police’
‘it's his job to seek out new customers’
‘I sought my bedroom each night to brood over it’
--Word--
seem 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Give the impression of being something or having a particular quality.
Used to make a statement less forceful.
Used to suggest in a cautious or polite way that something is the case.
Be unable to do something, despite having tried.
--Examples--
‘Dawn seemed annoyed’
‘it seemed a dismal town’
‘there seems to be plenty to eat’
‘it seemed that he was determined to oppose her’
‘I seem to remember giving you very precise instructions’
‘it would seem that he has been fooling us all’
‘he couldn't seem to remember his lines’
--Word--
bird 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A warm-blooded egg-laying vertebrate animal distinguished by the possession of feathers, wings, a beak, and typically by being able to fly.
A bird that is hunted for sport or used for food.
An aircraft, spacecraft, or satellite.
A person of a specified kind or character.
A young woman or a girlfriend.
--Examples--
‘carve the bird and arrange on a warmed serving plate’
‘she's a sharp old bird’
--Word--
thrush 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A small or medium-sized songbird, typically having a brown back, spotted breast, and loud song.
Infection of the mouth and throat by a yeastlike fungus, causing whitish patches.
Infection of the genitals with the candida fungus, causing a whitish discharge.
A chronic condition affecting the frog of a horse's foot, causing the accumulation of a dark, foul-smelling substance.
--Examples--

miesies

noun

--Word--
missile 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An object which is forcibly propelled at a target, either by hand or from a mechanical weapon.
A weapon that is self-propelled or directed by remote control, carrying conventional or nuclear explosive.
--Examples--
‘one of the players was hit on the head by a missile thrown by a spectator’
‘the plane disintegrated after being hit by a missile launched from the ground’
‘the USAF approach uses small missiles fired from conventional fighter aircraft’

--Word--
missing 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a thing) not able to be found because it is not in its expected place.
Not present or included when expected or supposed to be.
(of a person) absent from a place, especially their home, and of unknown whereabouts.
(of a person) not yet traced or confirmed as alive, but not known to be dead, after an accident or during wartime.
--Examples--
‘a quantity of cash has gone missing’
‘you can fill in the missing details later’
‘he has been reported as a missing person’
‘four soldiers had been wounded and one man was missing’
‘servicemen listed as missing in action’
--Word--
missing 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a thing) not able to be found because it is not in its expected place.
Not present or included when expected or supposed to be.
(of a person) absent from a place, especially their home, and of unknown whereabouts.
(of a person) not yet traced or confirmed as alive, but not known to be dead, after an accident or during wartime.
--Examples--
‘a quantity of cash has gone missing’
‘you can fill in the missing details later’
‘he has been reported as a missing person’
‘four soldiers had been wounded and one man was missing’
‘servicemen listed as missing in action’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or condition of being missing; absence.
--Examples--
--Word--
missiology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The study of religious (typically Christian) missions and their methods and purposes.
--Examples--
--Word--
mission 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An important assignment given to a person or group of people, typically involving travel abroad.
A group of people sent on a mission.
An organization or institution involved in a long-term assignment abroad.
An operation carried out by military aircraft.
An expedition into space.
The vocation or calling of a religious organization, especially a Christian one, to go out into the world and spread its faith.
A building or group of buildings used by a Christian mission.
A strongly felt aim, ambition, or calling.
--Examples--
‘a fact-finding mission to the Czech Republic’
‘by then, the mission had journeyed over 3,500 miles’
‘the head of the West German mission’
‘a reconnaissance mission’
‘NASA has approved a mission to investigate the atmosphere of Mars’
‘the Christian mission’
‘Gandhi's attitude to mission and conversion’
‘a tour of the missions on the California coast’
‘his main mission in life has been to cut unemployment’

missional

adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or connected with a religious mission; missionary.
--Examples--
--Word--
missionary 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person sent on a religious mission, especially one sent to promote Christianity in a foreign country.
Relating to or characteristic of a missionary or a religious mission.
--Examples--
‘missionary work’
‘our taxi driver shared a sense of missionary zeal with us’
--Word--

noun, adjective

--Word--
missionization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The practice of missionary work; especially the introduction (or imposition) of Christian culture by missionaries.
--Examples--
--Word--
missionize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To conduct or promote a mission; to serve as a missionary, do missionary work.
To do missionary work among (a people) or in (a place). Also: (with pejorative connotation) to impose missionary influence upon (a people).
--Examples--
--Word--
missionizing 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Missionary activity or work, especially the conducting or promoting of religious missions.
Engaged on a religious mission, missionary.
--Examples--
--Word--
mission 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An important assignment given to a person or group of people, typically involving travel abroad.
A group of people sent on a mission.
An organization or institution involved in a long-term assignment abroad.
An operation carried out by military aircraft.
An expedition into space.
The vocation or calling of a religious organization, especially a Christian one, to go out into the world and spread its faith.
A building or group of buildings used by a Christian mission.
A strongly felt aim, ambition, or calling.
--Examples--
‘a fact-finding mission to the Czech Republic’
‘by then, the mission had journeyed over 3,500 miles’
‘the head of the West German mission’
‘a reconnaissance mission’
‘NASA has approved a mission to investigate the atmosphere of Mars’
‘the Christian mission’
‘Gandhi's attitude to mission and conversion’
‘a tour of the missions on the California coast’
‘his main mission in life has been to cut unemployment’

missus

noun
--Meanings--

Used as a form of address to a woman whose name is not known.

‘sit down, missus’

Mississauga 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A town in southern Ontario, Canada, on the western shores of Lake Ontario; population 668,549 (2006). It forms a southern suburb of Toronto.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mississippi 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A major river of North America, which rises in Minnesota near the Canadian border and flows south to a delta on the Gulf of Mexico. With its chief tributary, the Missouri River, it is 5,970 km (3,710 miles) long.
A state of the southern US, on the Gulf of Mexico, bounded to the west by the lower Mississippi River; population 2,938,618 (est. 2008); capital, Jackson. A French colony in the first half of the 18th century, it was ceded to Britain in 1763 and to the US in 1783, becoming the 20th state in 1817.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mississippian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the state of Mississippi.
Relating to or denoting the early part of the Carboniferous period in North America, following the Devonian and preceding the Pennsylvanian. This period corresponds to the Lower Carboniferous of Europe and lasted from about 363 to 323 million years ago.
Relating to or denoting a settled culture of the south-eastern US, dated to about AD 800–1300.
A native or inhabitant of Mississippi.
The Mississippian period or the system of rocks deposited during it.
The Mississippian culture or period.

Missolonghi 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in western Greece, on the north shore of the Gulf of Patras; population 12,800 (est. 2009). It is noted as the place where the poet Byron, who had joined the fight for Greek independence from the Turks, died of malaria in 1824.

--Word--
Missouri 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A major river of North America, one of the main tributaries of the Mississippi River. It rises in the Rocky Mountains in Montana and flows 3,736 km (2,315 miles) to meet the Mississippi just north of St Louis.
A state in the central US, bounded on the east by the Mississippi River; population 5,911,605 (est. 2008); capital, Jefferson City. It was acquired as part of the Louisiana Purchase in 1803 and became the 24th state of the US in 1821.

--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Guide or control the movement of (a vehicle, vessel, or aircraft), for example by turning a wheel or operating a rudder.
(of a vehicle, vessel, or aircraft) be guided in a specified direction.
Follow (a course) in a specified direction.
Guide the movement or course of.
The type of steering of a vehicle.
A piece of advice or information concerning the development of a situation.
--Examples--
‘he steered the boat slowly towards the busy quay’

‘he made an attempt to steer the conversation back to Heather’
‘some cars boast four-wheel steer’
‘the need for the NHS to be given a clear steer as to its future direction’

sway

verb, noun
--Meanings--

Control or influence (a person or course of action)
Rule; govern.

‘the country was under the sway of rival warlords’
--Word--
swear 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make a solemn statement or promise undertaking to do something or affirming that something is the case.
Take (an oath)
Take a solemn oath as to the truth of (a statement)
Make (someone) promise to observe a certain course of action.
Use offensive language, especially as an expression of anger.
--Examples--
‘Maria made me swear I would never tell anyone’
‘I swear by all I hold dear that I had nothing to do with it’
‘‘Never again,’ she swore, ‘will I be short of money’’
‘they were reluctant to swear allegiance’
‘he forced them to swear an oath of loyalty to him’
‘I asked him if he would swear a statement to this effect’
‘I've been sworn to secrecy’
‘Peter swore under his breath’

--Word--
mist 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A cloud of tiny water droplets suspended in the atmosphere at or near the earth's surface that limits visibility (to a lesser extent than fog; strictly, with visibility remaining above 1 km)
A condensed vapour settling in fine droplets on a surface.
A haze or film over the eyes, especially caused by tears, and resulting in blurred vision.
Used in reference to something that blurs one's perceptions or memory.
Cover or become covered with mist.
(of a person's eyes) become covered with a film of tears causing blurred vision.
Spray (something, especially a plant) with a fine cloud of water droplets.
--Examples--
‘the peaks were shrouded in mist’
‘a mist rose out of the river’
‘a breeze cooled the mist of perspiration that had dampened her temples’
‘Ruth saw most of the scene through a mist of tears’
‘Sardinia's origins are lost in the mists of time’
‘the windows of the car were misted up with condensation’
‘the glass was beginning to mist up’
‘her eyes misted over with relief and joy’
‘don't mist furry-leaved plants such as African violets’

--Word--
mistake 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An act or judgement that is misguided or wrong.
Something, especially a word, figure, or fact, which is not correct; an inaccuracy.
Be wrong about.
Wrongly identify someone or something as.
--Examples--
‘coming here was a mistake’
‘she made the mistake of thinking they were important’
‘a couple of spelling mistakes’
‘because I was inexperienced I mistook the nature of our relationship’
‘she thought he'd mistaken her for Diana’

mistal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A stable or shed for cattle.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mistassini 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a Cree people inhabiting the shores of Lac Mistassini in south central Quebec. Frequently attributive, especially in "Mistassini Cree", "Mistassini Indian".
The language of the Mistassini, a dialect of East Cree.
--Examples--
--Word--
misteach 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘they have been misled and mistaught about this matter for so long that they really do not know what to believe’

--Word--
clad 
--Type--
verb, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Clothed.
Covered with cladding.
Encase (a structure) with a covering or coating.
--Examples--
‘they were clad in T-shirts and shorts’
‘leather-clad boys’
‘copper-clad boards’
‘he cladded the concrete-frame structure in stainless steel’
--Word--
mist 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A cloud of tiny water droplets suspended in the atmosphere at or near the earth's surface that limits visibility (to a lesser extent than fog; strictly, with visibility remaining above 1 km)
A condensed vapour settling in fine droplets on a surface.
A haze or film over the eyes, especially caused by tears, and resulting in blurred vision.
Used in reference to something that blurs one's perceptions or memory.
Cover or become covered with mist.
(of a person's eyes) become covered with a film of tears causing blurred vision.
Spray (something, especially a plant) with a fine cloud of water droplets.
--Examples--
‘the peaks were shrouded in mist’
‘a mist rose out of the river’
‘a breeze cooled the mist of perspiration that had dampened her temples’
‘Ruth saw most of the scene through a mist of tears’
‘Sardinia's origins are lost in the mists of time’
‘the windows of the car were misted up with condensation’
‘the glass was beginning to mist up’
‘her eyes misted over with relief and joy’
‘don't mist furry-leaved plants such as African violets’
--Word--
misteach 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Teach (someone) wrongly or incorrectly.
--Examples--
‘they have been misled and mistaught about this matter for so long that they really do not know what to believe’

mister 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Used as a form of address to a man whose name is not known.

--Word--
mystery 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Something that is difficult or impossible to understand or explain.
Secrecy or obscurity.
A person or thing whose identity or nature is puzzling or unknown.
A novel, play, or film dealing with a puzzling crime, especially a murder.
The secret rites of Greek and Roman pagan religion, or of any ancient or tribal religion, to which only initiates are admitted.
The practices, skills, or lore peculiar to a particular trade or activity and regarded as baffling to those without specialized knowledge.
The Christian Eucharist.
A religious belief based on divine revelation, especially one regarded as beyond human understanding.
An incident in the life of Jesus or of a saint as a focus of devotion in the Roman Catholic Church, especially each of those commemorated during recitation of successive decades of the rosary.
A handicraft or trade, especially when referred to in indentures.
--Examples--
‘the mysteries of outer space’
‘what happened after he left home that day remains a mystery’
‘much of her past is shrouded in mystery’
‘‘He's a bit of a mystery,’ said Nina’
‘a mystery guest’
‘the 1920s murder mystery, The Ghost Train’
‘the mysteries of analytical psychology’
‘the mystery of Christ’
‘the first Sorrowful Mystery, the Agony in the Garden’
--Word--
mysteriarch 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--

mysterious 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Difficult or impossible to understand, explain, or identify.
(of a location) having an atmosphere of strangeness or secrecy.
(of a person) deliberately enigmatic.
--Examples--
‘his colleague had vanished in mysterious circumstances’
‘a mysterious benefactor provided the money’
‘a dark, mysterious, windowless building’
‘she was mysterious about herself but said plenty about her husband’
--Word--
mysteriously 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--

In a deliberately enigmatic manner.
--Examples--
‘her boyfriend mysteriously disappeared’
‘the radio went mysteriously quiet’
‘my wife just smiled mysteriously and refused to tell me what she had in mind’

misty 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Full of, covered with, or accompanied by mist.
(of a person's eyes) full of tears so as to blur the vision.
Indistinct or dim in outline.
(of a colour) not bright; soft.
--Examples--

‘the misty air above the frozen river’
‘it was their last night and Ruth turned her misty eyes to Fernando’
‘a misty out-of-focus silhouette’
‘a few misty memories’
‘a misty pink’

--Word--
mystic 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who seeks by contemplation and self-surrender to obtain unity with or absorption into the Deity or the absolute, or who believes in the spiritual apprehension of truths that are beyond the intellect.
--Examples--
‘the poetry of the 16th-century Spanish mystic, St John of the Cross’
--Word--
mystical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to mystics or religious mysticism.
Having a spiritual symbolic or allegorical significance that transcends human understanding.
Relating to ancient religious mysteries or other occult or esoteric rites.
Of hidden or esoteric meaning.
Inspiring a sense of spiritual mystery, awe, and fascination.
Concerned with the soul or the spirit, rather than with material things.
--Examples--
‘the mystical theology of Richard Rolle’
‘the mystical body of Christ’
‘the mystical practices of the Pythagoreans’
‘a geometric figure of mystical significance’
‘the mystical city of Kathmandu’
‘the beliefs of a more mystical age’

--Meanings--

--Word--
mysticism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Belief that union with or absorption into the Deity or the absolute, or the spiritual apprehension of knowledge inaccessible to the intellect, may be attained through contemplation and self-surrender.
Vague or ill-defined religious or spiritual belief, especially as associated with a belief in the occult.
--Examples--
‘St Theresa's writings were part of the tradition of Christian mysticism’
‘there is a hint of New Age mysticism in the show's title’

prefix, prefix

Unsuitably.

‘mischief’

--Meanings--
Make a mistake in typing (a word or letter)
Assign (someone or something) to an incorrect category.
--Examples--
‘I might have mistyped my password’
‘I mistyped you—I didn't think you looked the hunting type’
--Word--
mistype 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make a mistake in typing (a word or letter)
Assign (someone or something) to an incorrect category.
--Examples--
‘I might have mistyped my password’
‘I mistyped you—I didn't think you looked the hunting type’
--Word--
mystique 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A quality of mystery, glamour, or power associated with someone or something.
An air of secrecy surrounding a particular activity or subject that makes it impressive or baffling to those without specialized knowledge.
--Examples--
‘the mystique surrounding the monarchy’
‘eliminating the mystique normally associated with computers’

--Word--
mistress 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A woman in a position of authority or control.
A female schoolteacher who teaches a particular subject.
A woman who is skilled in a particular subject or activity.
The female owner of a dog, cat, or other domesticated animal.
A female head of a household.
(especially formerly) a female employer of domestic staff.
A woman (other than the man's wife) having a sexual relationship with a married man.
A woman loved and courted by a man.
Used as a title prefixed to the name of a married woman; Mrs.
--Examples--
‘she is always mistress of the situation, coolly self-possessed’
‘a Geography mistress’
‘a mistress of the sound bite, she is famed for the acidity of her tongue’
‘the cat rubbed itself against its mistress's legs’
‘he asked for the mistress of the house’
‘Mary, go and fetch your mistress some cold chicken’
‘Elsie knew her husband had a mistress tucked away somewhere’
--Word--
mistressdom 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or condition of being a mistress.
--Examples--
--Word--
mistress 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A woman in a position of authority or control.
A female schoolteacher who teaches a particular subject.
A woman who is skilled in a particular subject or activity.
The female owner of a dog, cat, or other domesticated animal.
A female head of a household.
(especially formerly) a female employer of domestic staff.
A woman (other than the man's wife) having a sexual relationship with a married man.
A woman loved and courted by a man.
Used as a title prefixed to the name of a married woman; Mrs.

--Word--
mistress-ship 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
As a title or polite form of address applied to a woman with the status of mistress. Only with possessive adjective, as "your (also occasionally thy) mistress-ship". Now archaic.
The position or status of a mistress or female head of a household, etc.; (a period of) female authority as mistress.
The position or status of a woman who has a long-lasting sexual relationship with a man (especially a married man) who is not her husband.
Also with capital initial. The post of a mistress in a school. Now rare.
--Examples--

noun

--Word--
mist 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A cloud of tiny water droplets suspended in the atmosphere at or near the earth's surface that limits visibility (to a lesser extent than fog; strictly, with visibility remaining above 1 km)
A condensed vapour settling in fine droplets on a surface.
A haze or film over the eyes, especially caused by tears, and resulting in blurred vision.
Used in reference to something that blurs one's perceptions or memory.
Cover or become covered with mist.
(of a person's eyes) become covered with a film of tears causing blurred vision.
Spray (something, especially a plant) with a fine cloud of water droplets.
--Examples--
‘the peaks were shrouded in mist’
‘a mist rose out of the river’
‘a breeze cooled the mist of perspiration that had dampened her temples’
‘Ruth saw most of the scene through a mist of tears’
‘Sardinia's origins are lost in the mists of time’
‘the windows of the car were misted up with condensation’
‘the glass was beginning to mist up’
‘her eyes misted over with relief and joy’
‘don't mist furry-leaved plants such as African violets’
--Word--
mist 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A cloud of tiny water droplets suspended in the atmosphere at or near the earth's surface that limits visibility (to a lesser extent than fog; strictly, with visibility remaining above 1 km)

Used in reference to something that blurs one's perceptions or memory.

--Word--
mis- 
--Type--
prefix, prefix
--Meanings--
(added to verbs and their derivatives) wrongly.
Badly.
Unsuitably.
Occurring in a few words adopted from French expressing a sense with negative force.
--Examples--
‘misapply’
‘mismanage’
‘misname’
‘misadventure’
‘mischief’

--Word--
misuse 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Use (something) in the wrong way or for the wrong purpose.
Treat (someone or something) badly or unfairly.
The wrong or improper use of something.
--Examples--
‘he was found guilty of misusing public funds’
‘we felt that we had been deceived and misused’
‘drugs of such potency that their misuse can have dire consequences’
‘a misuse of power’

mita 
--Type--
noun

--Word--
Mitchell principles 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Six recommendations arising from the investigations of the group chaired by Mitchell from 1995–6, urging all sides involved in the conflict in Northern Ireland to renounce violence and to agree to a process of disarmament before entering into all-party negotiations.
--Examples--
--Word--
mitchella 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Either of two trailing plants with fleshy berries constituting the genus Mitchella (family Rubiaceae), M. undulata, of north-east Asia, and the partridgeberry, M. repens, of North America. Also (in form Mitchella): the genus itself.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mitchell principles 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Six recommendations arising from the investigations of the group chaired by Mitchell from 1995–6, urging all sides involved in the conflict in Northern Ireland to renounce violence and to agree to a process of disarmament before entering into all-party negotiations.
--Examples--
--Word--
mite 
--Type--
noun, noun, adverb
--Meanings--
A minute arachnid which has four pairs of legs when adult, related to the ticks. Many kinds live in the soil and a number are parasitic on plants or animals.
A small child or animal, especially when regarded as an object of sympathy.
A very small amount.
A small coin, in particular a small Flemish copper coin of very low face value.
A little; slightly.
--Examples--
‘the poor little mite looks half-starved’
‘his teacher thought he needed a mite of discipline’
‘I haven't eaten yet and I'm feeling a mite peckish’
--Word--
mitella 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In form Mitella: a genus of perennial plants of the family Saxifragaceae, native to North America and north-east Asia and cultivated elsewhere, which have a basal rosette of leaves, racemes of small flowers, and fruits thought to resemble mitres; (also mitella) a plant of this genus. Compare mitrewort).
--Examples--
--Word--
mitre 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A tall headdress worn by bishops and senior abbots as a symbol of office, tapering to a point at front and back with a deep cleft between.
A joint made between two pieces of wood or other material at an angle of 90°, such that the line of junction bisects this angle.
A diagonal seam between two pieces of fabric that are sewn together at a corner.
A mollusc of warm seas which has a sharply pointed shell with a narrow aperture, supposedly resembling a bishop's mitre.
Join by means of a mitre joint or seam.
--Examples--
‘a mitre saw’
‘turn up a double hem, mitring the corners’
--Word--
clamper 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
mitred 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Joined with a mitre joint or seam.
Bearing, wearing, or entitled to wear a mitre.
--Examples--
‘complete the sides with mitred corners’
‘the mitred abbot of Battle’
--Word--
mitre 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A tall headdress worn by bishops and senior abbots as a symbol of office, tapering to a point at front and back with a deep cleft between.
A joint made between two pieces of wood or other material at an angle of 90°, such that the line of junction bisects this angle.
A diagonal seam between two pieces of fabric that are sewn together at a corner.
A mollusc of warm seas which has a sharply pointed shell with a narrow aperture, supposedly resembling a bishop's mitre.
Join by means of a mitre joint or seam.
--Examples--
‘a mitre saw’
‘turn up a double hem, mitring the corners’
--Word--
mitre-jointed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Joined by a mitre joint.
--Examples--
--Word--
mitre 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A tall headdress worn by bishops and senior abbots as a symbol of office, tapering to a point at front and back with a deep cleft between.
A joint made between two pieces of wood or other material at an angle of 90°, such that the line of junction bisects this angle.
A diagonal seam between two pieces of fabric that are sewn together at a corner.
A mollusc of warm seas which has a sharply pointed shell with a narrow aperture, supposedly resembling a bishop's mitre.
Join by means of a mitre joint or seam.
--Examples--
‘a mitre saw’
‘turn up a double hem, mitring the corners’
--Word--
mitrewort 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Now in full "false mitrewort". A tiarella (foamflower), especially T. cordifolia.
A mitella, especially M. diphylla.
Any of several small tropical American herbaceous plants of the genera Mitreola and Cynoctonum (family Loganiaceae); especially Cynoctonum mitreola. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
mite 
--Type--
noun, noun, adverb
--Meanings--
A minute arachnid which has four pairs of legs when adult, related to the ticks. Many kinds live in the soil and a number are parasitic on plants or animals.
A small child or animal, especially when regarded as an object of sympathy.
A very small amount.
A small coin, in particular a small Flemish copper coin of very low face value.
A little; slightly.
--Examples--
‘the poor little mite looks half-starved’
‘his teacher thought he needed a mite of discipline’
‘I haven't eaten yet and I'm feeling a mite peckish’
--Word--
Mitford 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Nancy (Freeman) (1904–73) and her sister Jessica (Lucy) (1917–96), English writers. Nancy achieved fame with comic novels including Love in a Cold Climate (1949). Jessica became an American citizen in 1944, and is best known for her works on American culture, notably The American Way of Death (1963). Among their four sisters were Unity (1914–48), who was an admirer of Hitler, and Diana (1910–2003), who married Sir Oswald Mosley in 1936.
--Examples--
--Word--
myth 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A traditional story, especially one concerning the early history of a people or explaining a natural or social phenomenon, and typically involving supernatural beings or events.
A widely held but false belief or idea.
A misrepresentation of the truth.
A fictitious or imaginary person or thing.
An exaggerated or idealized conception of a person or thing.
--Examples--
‘ancient Celtic myths’
‘the heroes of Greek myth’
‘the belief that evening primrose oil helps to cure eczema is a myth, according to dermatologists’
‘attacking the party's irresponsible myths about privatization’
‘nobody had ever heard of Simon's mysterious friend—Anna said he was a myth’
‘the book is a scholarly study of the Churchill myth’

--Word--
romantic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Conducive to or characterized by the expression of love.
(of a person) readily demonstrating feelings of love.
Relating to love or to sexual relationships.
Of, characterized by, or suggestive of an idealized view of reality.
Relating to or denoting the artistic and literary movement of romanticism.
A person with romantic beliefs or attitudes.
A writer or artist of the romantic movement.
--Examples--
‘a romantic candlelit dinner’
‘he's very handsome, and so romantic’
‘after their romantic relationship ended they became great friends’

‘romantic fiction’
‘a romantic attitude to the past’
‘some romantic dream of country peace’
‘the romantic tradition’
‘I am an incurable romantic’
‘Wordsworth, Coleridge, and the later romantics’

mythology

noun

‘Jewish and Christian mythologies’

‘this field includes archaeology, comparative mythology, and folklore’

--Word--
Mithras 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A god of light, truth, and honour, the central figure of the cult of Mithraism but probably of Persian origin. He was also associated with merchants and the protection of warriors.

Mithraism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The cult of the god Mithras, which became popular among Roman soldiers of the later empire, and was the main rival to Christianity in the first three centuries AD.

--Word--
mytilacean 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A bivalve of the group Mytilacea (now a superfamily), which comprises marine mussels.
Of, belonging to, or characteristic of the group Mytilacea of marine mussels.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mytilene 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The chief town of the Greek island of Lesbos; population 28,000 (est. 2009).
--Examples--
--Word--
mytiliform 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having the shape of a mussel shell.
--Examples--
--Word--
mytiloid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Originally: resembling a mussel, especially in shape. Later: specifically of or belonging to the order Mytiloida of marine bivalves, which includes marine mussels.
A mussel; (now) especially one of the marine order Mytiloida.
--Examples--
--Word--
mytilotoxin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A poisonous alkaloid produced by certain planktonic organisms and sometimes present in mussels.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mytilus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of bivalve molluscs originally of wide extent but now comprising a group of related species in the marine family Mytilidae, including the common edible mussel (Mytilus edulis).
--Examples--
--Word--
mite 
--Type--
noun, noun, adverb
--Meanings--
A minute arachnid which has four pairs of legs when adult, related to the ticks. Many kinds live in the soil and a number are parasitic on plants or animals.
A small child or animal, especially when regarded as an object of sympathy.
A very small amount.
A small coin, in particular a small Flemish copper coin of very low face value.
A little; slightly.
--Examples--
‘the poor little mite looks half-starved’
‘his teacher thought he needed a mite of discipline’
‘I haven't eaten yet and I'm feeling a mite peckish’
--Word--
Mitis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Attributive, especially in "Mitis casting". Designating pure iron made fluid enough for casting by the addition of a very small quantity of aluminium; (also) designating this method of production or a casting made by this method.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--

--Meanings--

Misnagid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Originally: a religious opponent of the Hasidim. Later also: a non-Hasidic Jew.
Of or belonging to the Misnagdim.
--Examples--
--Word--
mitochondrion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An organelle found in large numbers in most cells, in which the biochemical processes of respiration and energy production occur. It has a double membrane, the inner part being folded inwards to form layers (cristae).
--Examples--
--Word--
mitochondrial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of a mitochondrion or mitochondria.
--Examples--
‘the outer mitochondrial membrane’
‘mitochondrial DNA’
--Word--
mitochondrion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An organelle found in large numbers in most cells, in which the biochemical processes of respiration and energy production occur. It has a double membrane, the inner part being folded inwards to form layers (cristae).
--Examples--
--Word--
mitogen 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A substance that induces or stimulates mitosis.
--Examples--
--Word--
mitogenetic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Stimulating mitosis; (originally) specifically designating a type of ultraviolet radiation thought to be emitted by dividing cells and to stimulate division in other cells (now historical).
--Examples--

mitogenic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

mitogen 
--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
mitomycin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a group of closely related antibiotics produced by the soil bacterium Streptomyces caespitosus; specifically (in full "mitomycin C") the principal member of this group, which inhibits DNA synthesis by cross-linking the two chains of duplex DNA molecules and is used medically as an antineoplastic agent.
--Examples--
--Word--
mitosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of cell division that results in two daughter cells each having the same number and kind of chromosomes as the parent nucleus, typical of ordinary tissue growth.
--Examples--
‘the single large egg cell subdivides by repeated mitosis’
‘each mitosis seems to be associated with an increase in calcium’
--Word--
mitosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of cell division that results in two daughter cells each having the same number and kind of chromosomes as the parent nucleus, typical of ordinary tissue growth.
--Examples--
‘the single large egg cell subdivides by repeated mitosis’
‘each mitosis seems to be associated with an increase in calcium’
--Word--
mitosome 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An area of a cell in which mitochondria are aggregated (now rare, perhaps obsolete); (later) an organelle in the cytoplasm of certain protozoans that corresponds to a mitochondrion. Also: †a cytoplasmic structure formed by the remains of the mitotic spindle (obsolete).
--Examples--
--Word--
mitotic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
mitotically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
By mitosis; as regards mitosis.
--Examples--
--Word--
mitraille 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: shot fired from a cannon, consisting of fragments of scrap iron, etc. Later: bullets or projectiles fired from a mitrailleuse.

mitrailleur 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
mitrailleuse 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a machine-gun with a number of barrels, able to discharge projectiles rapidly and simultaneously in large quantities, or singly in quick succession. Later generally: any machine-gun.

--Word--
mitrate 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Botany and Zoology. Having the shape of a mitre or bonnet; (specifically of the calyptra of a moss) conical, symmetrical, and having two or more slits.
Palaeontology. Of, relating to, or designating a fossil echinoderm of the order Mitrata.
Palaeontology. Any member of the order Mitrata of fossil invertebrates of the Palaeozoic era, having a mitre- or leaf-shaped theca formed of calcite plates, generally regarded as atypical primitive echinoderms but sometimes interpreted as primitive chordates (calcichordates).
--Examples--
--Word--
mitre 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A tall headdress worn by bishops and senior abbots as a symbol of office, tapering to a point at front and back with a deep cleft between.
A joint made between two pieces of wood or other material at an angle of 90°, such that the line of junction bisects this angle.
A diagonal seam between two pieces of fabric that are sewn together at a corner.
A mollusc of warm seas which has a sharply pointed shell with a narrow aperture, supposedly resembling a bishop's mitre.
Join by means of a mitre joint or seam.
--Examples--
‘a mitre saw’
‘turn up a double hem, mitring the corners’
--Word--

‘the mitred abbot of Battle’

mitrewort 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Now in full "false mitrewort". A tiarella (foamflower), especially T. cordifolia.
A mitella, especially M. diphylla.
Any of several small tropical American herbaceous plants of the genera Mitreola and Cynoctonum (family Loganiaceae); especially Cynoctonum mitreola. rare.

--Word--
Mitterrand, François 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1916–96), French statesman, president 1981–95; full name François Maurice Marie Mitterrand. As president he initially moved to raise basic wages, increase social benefits, nationalize key industries, and decentralize government. The Socialist Party lost its majority vote in the 1986 general election and Mitterrand made the right-wing Jacques Chirac prime minister, resulting in a reversal of some policies.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
mix 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Combine or put together to form one substance or mass.
(of different substances) be able to be combined to form one substance or mass.
Make or prepare by combining various ingredients.
Juxtapose or put together to form a whole whose constituent parts are still distinct.
(of a person) associate with others socially.
(especially in sound recording) combine (two or more signals or soundtracks) into one.
Produce (a sound signal or recording) by combining a number of separate signals or recorded soundtracks.
Produce (a piece of continuous music, typically dance music) by combining a number of separate recordings.
Be belligerent physically or verbally.
Two or more different qualities, things, or people placed, combined, or considered together.
A group of people of different types within a particular society or community.
The proportion of different people or other constituents that make up a mixture.
A commercially prepared mixture of ingredients for making a particular type of food or a product such as concrete.
A version of a recording in which the component tracks are mixed in a different way from the original.
A continuous piece of music, typically dance music, produced by combining a number of separate recordings.
An image or sound produced by the combination of two separate images or sounds.
--Examples--
‘peppercorns are sometimes mixed with other spices’
‘these two chemicals, when mixed together, literally explode’
‘oil and water don't mix’
‘mixing concrete is hard physical work’
‘he continues to mix an off-hand sense of humour with a sharp insight’
‘the people he mixed with were nothing to do with show business’
‘up to eight tracks can be mixed simultaneously’
‘it was everyone's dream to mix their album in their front room’
‘Keith mixes great house music, featuring tunes with an African, Latin, and soulful flavour’
‘music was blaring and there was a DJ in the corner mixing and scratching’
‘he can't afford to mix it any more with a six-month suspended ban hanging over him’
‘the decor is a fascinating mix of antique and modern’
‘the school has a good social mix’
‘arriving at the correct mix of full-time to part-time staff’
‘trousers made from a cotton and polyester mix’
‘cake mixes have made cooking easier’
‘a dance mix version of ‘This Charming Man’’
‘a group of young women groove in a circle to a DJ mix of Missy Elliot, the Young Gunz, and Kelis’
‘titling mixes are added when vision and sound are still on separate film’

mixed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Consisting of different qualities or elements.
(of an assessment of, reaction to, or feeling about something) containing a mixture of both favourable and negative elements.
Composed of different varieties of the same thing.
(especially of an educational establishment or a sports team or competition) of or for members of both sexes.
Involving or showing a mixture of races or social classes.

‘a mixed diet’
‘beaches with mixed sand and shingle’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

mixer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A machine for mixing things, especially an electrical appliance for mixing foods.
A person considered in terms of their ability to mix socially with others.
A social gathering at which people can make new acquaintances.
A soft drink that can be mixed with alcohol.
A type of dry pet food which can be mixed with moist tinned food.
(in sound recording and cinematography) a device for merging input signals to produce a combined output in the form of sound or pictures.
A person who operates a signals mixer.
--Examples--
‘a food mixer’
‘media people need to be good mixers’
‘use low-calorie mixers in your cocktails’
‘dogs must be fed with an equal volume of canned food and mixer’
‘a sound mixer’

--Type--
verb, noun

Combine or put together to form one substance or mass.
(of different substances) be able to be combined to form one substance or mass.

--Meanings--
Containing cells which are of differing ploidy or (more generally) have differing numbers of chromosomes.
A mixoploid individual.
--Examples--
--Word--
mixoploidy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The property or state of being mixoploid.
--Examples--
--Word--
myxosarcoma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sarcoma with a mucoid stroma, or areas of this.
--Examples--

myxospore 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Microbiology. A resting spore formed in the fruiting bodies of certain myxobacteria in response to adverse conditions; a microcyst.
--Examples--
--Word--
Myxosporidia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A taxonomic group comprising the myxosporidians. Treated as plural (also myxosporidia): myxosporidian parasites collectively.
--Examples--
--Word--
myxosporidian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A protozoan parasite of the sporozoan phylum Myxospora or class Myxosporea, chiefly affecting fishes and producing spores with extrusible coiled filaments contained in polar capsules.
Of, relating to, caused by, or designating a myxosporidian.

mixotrophic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating, relating to, or characterized by a mixture of autotrophic and heterotrophic nutrition.

--Meanings--
Any of a group of RNA viruses including the influenza virus.

--Word--
Mixtec 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of an indigenous people of southern Mexico, noted for their skill in pottery and metallurgy.
The Otomanguean language of the Mixtec, spoken by about 250,000 people in several dialects.
Relating to the Mixtec or their language.

--Word--
mixtion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of mixing; the condition or fact of being or becoming mixed; an instance of this. In later use chiefly: the formation of chemical compounds.
--Examples--
--Word--
mixture 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A substance made by mixing other substances together.
The process of mixing or being mixed.
A combination of different things in which the component elements are individually distinct.
A person regarded as a combination of qualities and attributes.
The product of the random distribution of one substance through another without any chemical reaction, as distinct from a compound.
The charge of gas or vapour mixed with air which is admitted to the cylinder of an internal combustion engine, especially as regards the ratio of fuel to air.
An organ stop in which each key sounds a group of small pipes of different pitches, giving a very bright tone.
--Examples--
‘form the mixture into a manageable dough’
‘shandy is a mixture of beer and lemonade’
‘the old town is a mixture of narrow medieval streets and 18th-century architecture’
‘he was a curious mixture, an unpredictable man’
‘newer pilots often leave their mixture rich during an entire flight’

mix-up 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

‘a ghastly mix-up of furniture styles’

Mizoram 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state in north-eastern India that lies between Bangladesh and Burma (Myanmar); capital, Aizawl. Separated from Assam in 1972, it was administered as a Union Territory in India until 1986, when it became a state.

--Meanings--

myzostome 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= myzostomid.
--Examples--
--Word--
myzostomid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Any of various small annelid worms belonging to the class Myzostomida, which have disc-like bodies with suckers and are commensals and ectoparasites of echinoderms, especially crinoids.
Of, relating to, or designating a myzostomid.
--Examples--

mm

abbreviation, exclamation, abbreviation

Used to express contentment or pleasure.

Messieurs.
(in the UK) Military Medal.

Mnium

noun

--Word--
moan 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A long, low sound made by a person expressing physical or mental suffering or sexual pleasure.
A sound resembling a human moan.
A complaint which is perceived as trivial and not taken seriously by others.
Make a long, low sound expressing physical or mental suffering or sexual pleasure.
Make a sound resembling a human moan.
Lament.
Complain or grumble, typically about something trivial.
--Examples--
‘she gave a low moan of despair’
‘the moan of the wind in the chimneys’
‘there were moans about the car's feeble ventilation’
‘just then their patient moaned and opened his eyes’
‘‘Help me,’ I moaned’
‘the foghorn moaned at intervals’
‘we listen to the fierce Achilles moaning for his mistress’
‘passengers moaned about overcrowded coaches’
‘my friend always moans that I never make her a cake’

--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A deep, wide ditch surrounding a castle, fort, or town, typically filled with water and intended as a defence against attack.
Surround (a place) with a moat.
--Examples--
‘a moated castle’
--Word--
moat 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--

moat 
--Type--
noun, verb

--Word--
mob 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large crowd of people, especially one that is disorderly and intent on causing trouble or violence.
A group of people in the same place or with something in common.
An Aboriginal extended family or community.
The ordinary people.
The Mafia or a similar criminal organization.
A flock or herd of animals.
Crowd round (someone) or into (a place) in an unruly way.
(of a group of birds or mammals) surround and attack (a predator or other source of threat) in order to drive it off.
--Examples--
‘a mob of protesters’
‘he stood out from the rest of the mob with his silver hair and stacked shoes’
‘my mob travelled and traded with other people’
‘the local mob called this spot Gimba, which means good pastures’
‘the age-old fear that the mob may organize to destroy the last vestiges of civilized life’
‘he gambled at a time when the Mob ran gaming’
‘a mob of cattle’
‘he was mobbed by autograph hunters’
‘a cuckoo flew over, to be mobbed at once by two reed warblers’
‘small mammals may indulge in mobbing to rid themselves of a feared killer’
--Word--
mobed 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Zoroastrian priest; especially one who is a Parsee.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Word--
mobbish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling or having the characteristics of a mob; disorderly, tumultuous; crowded. Also (usually depreciative): characteristic of or appealing to the common people.
--Examples--
--Word--
mobbishness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mobbish quality or nature. Also (without negative connotation): the tendency to go about in mobs or groups.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

mob cap 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large soft hat covering all of the hair and typically having a decorative frill, worn indoors by women in the 18th and early 19th centuries.

--Word--
mobilism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A belief in or tendency towards change. In Philosophy: the view that nothing is fixed.
Geology. The hypothesis that the physical character of the earth's crust is such as to sustain great lateral movements, whereby the configurations of continents and ocean basins are changed with time. Compare "stabilism". Now chiefly historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
mobile 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Able to move or be moved freely or easily.
(of the face or its features) indicating feelings with fluid and expressive movements.
(of a shop, library, or other service) accommodated in a vehicle so as to travel around and serve various places.
(of a military or police unit) equipped and prepared to move quickly to any place it is needed.
Relating to mobile phones, handheld computers, and similar technology.
Able or willing to move easily or freely between occupations, places of residence, or social classes.
A decorative structure that is suspended so as to turn freely in the air.
A mobile phone.
The Internet as accessed via smartphones or other mobile devices, especially when regarded as a market sector.
--Examples--
‘he has a weight problem and is not very mobile’
‘highly mobile international capital’
‘her mobile features worked overtime to register shock and disapproval’
‘a mobile library visits once a fortnight’
‘a cup of tea from the mobile canteen’
‘at first the regiment's role was to act as a mobile reserve’
‘the next generation of mobile networks’
‘a mobile device’
‘an increasingly mobile society’
‘brightly coloured mobiles rotated from the ceiling’
‘we telephoned from our mobile to theirs’
‘the biggest growth area in games right now is in mobile’
--Word--
mobile 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Able to move or be moved freely or easily.
(of the face or its features) indicating feelings with fluid and expressive movements.
(of a shop, library, or other service) accommodated in a vehicle so as to travel around and serve various places.
(of a military or police unit) equipped and prepared to move quickly to any place it is needed.
Relating to mobile phones, handheld computers, and similar technology.
Able or willing to move easily or freely between occupations, places of residence, or social classes.
A decorative structure that is suspended so as to turn freely in the air.
A mobile phone.
The Internet as accessed via smartphones or other mobile devices, especially when regarded as a market sector.
--Examples--
‘he has a weight problem and is not very mobile’
‘highly mobile international capital’
‘her mobile features worked overtime to register shock and disapproval’
‘a mobile library visits once a fortnight’
‘a cup of tea from the mobile canteen’
‘at first the regiment's role was to act as a mobile reserve’
‘the next generation of mobile networks’
‘a mobile device’
‘an increasingly mobile society’
‘brightly coloured mobiles rotated from the ceiling’
‘we telephoned from our mobile to theirs’
‘the biggest growth area in games right now is in mobile’
--Word--
Mobilian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of the Mobile of North America; = "Mobile".
A native or inhabitant of the city of Mobile.
A pidgin form of Choctaw used as a lingua franca in parts of the south-eastern United States.
Designating or belonging to Mobilian. Especially in "Mobilian Jargon", "Mobilian trade language".
--Examples--
--Word--
mobiliary art 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= art mobilier.
--Examples--
--Word--
mobilizable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
mobilization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of a country or its government preparing and organizing troops for active service.
The action of organizing and encouraging a group of people to take collective action in pursuit of a particular objective.
The action of bringing resources into use for a particular purpose.
The action of making something movable or capable of movement.
--Examples--
‘mobilization of the army in 1941 brought 2,500,000 men under arms’
‘mobilization of the working class against big business’
‘the mobilization of resources to handle emergencies’
‘large-scale mobilization of capital through stable institutions’
‘mobilization of the shoulder can be resumed within 10 days following injury’
--Word--
mobilize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of a country or its government) prepare and organize (troops) for active service.
Organize and encourage (a group of people) to take collective action in pursuit of a particular objective.
Bring (resources) into use for a particular purpose.
Make (something) movable or capable of movement.
Make (a substance) able to be transported by or as a liquid.
--Examples--
‘the government mobilized regular forces, reservists, and militia’
‘it would be hard for worker representatives to mobilize the workforce against the employers’
‘at sea we will mobilize any amount of resources to undertake a rescue’
‘the physiotherapist might mobilize the patient's shoulder girdle’
‘acid rain mobilizes the aluminium in forest soils’

--Word--
Möbius transformation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A conformal transformation which maps a complex number z into az + b/cz + d, where ad ≠ bc.
--Examples--

mobled

adjective
--Meanings--
Of a person: muffled, wrapped. Also with up.

--Word--
mob 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large crowd of people, especially one that is disorderly and intent on causing trouble or violence.
A group of people in the same place or with something in common.
An Aboriginal extended family or community.
The ordinary people.
The Mafia or a similar criminal organization.
A flock or herd of animals.
Crowd round (someone) or into (a place) in an unruly way.
(of a group of birds or mammals) surround and attack (a predator or other source of threat) in order to drive it off.
--Examples--
‘a mob of protesters’
‘he stood out from the rest of the mob with his silver hair and stacked shoes’
‘my mob travelled and traded with other people’
‘the local mob called this spot Gimba, which means good pastures’
‘the age-old fear that the mob may organize to destroy the last vestiges of civilized life’
‘he gambled at a time when the Mob ran gaming’
‘a mob of cattle’
‘he was mobbed by autograph hunters’
‘a cuckoo flew over, to be mobbed at once by two reed warblers’
‘small mammals may indulge in mobbing to rid themselves of a feared killer’

mobocracy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Rule or domination by the masses.
--Examples--
‘the court will never permit mobocracy to overwhelm the law of the land’
‘will mobocracies emerge to replace the old despots?’

--Word--
Mobutuism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The national philosophy and ideology introduced by President Mobutu Sese Seko in Zaire (now the Democratic Republic of Congo), originally based on ‘authenticité’ (uniquely Zairean identity), but increasingly focusing on his personal role.
--Examples--
--Word--
moc 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A moccasin.
--Examples--
--Word--
moccasin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A soft leather slipper or shoe, strictly one without a separate heel, having the sole turned up on all sides and sewn to the upper in a simple gathered seam, in a style originating among North American Indians.
A venomous American pit viper.
--Examples--
--Word--
moccasin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A soft leather slipper or shoe, strictly one without a separate heel, having the sole turned up on all sides and sewn to the upper in a simple gathered seam, in a style originating among North American Indians.
A venomous American pit viper.
--Examples--
--Word--
moccasined 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Wearing or provided with moccasins.
--Examples--
--Word--
mocha 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of fine-quality coffee.
A drink or flavouring made with mocha, typically with chocolate added.
A dark brown colour.
A soft kind of leather made from sheepskin.
--Examples--
‘Kenyan, Colombian or mocha coffee’
‘espresso kiosks serving mochas and cappuccinos’
‘the eyeliner is available in soft mocha and soft charcoal’
--Word--

--Word--
Moche 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pre-Inca culture that flourished on the northern coast of Peru in the 1st to 7th centuries AD.
--Examples--

mochy 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of the weather) unpleasantly warm and humid.
--Examples--
‘I set off in a mochy drizzle’
--Word--
Mochica 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of the ancient Moche people of northern Peru.
The language of the Mochica.
Relating to the Mochica or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
mochila 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pouch or bag, typically of leather; especially one hung from a horse's saddle. Later also: a saddle cover made from leather or skins, usually with pockets on the sides.
--Examples--
--Word--
mochila 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pouch or bag, typically of leather; especially one hung from a horse's saddle. Later also: a saddle cover made from leather or skins, usually with pockets on the sides.
--Examples--
--Word--
mock 
--Type--
verb, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Tease or laugh at in a scornful or contemptuous manner.
Make (something) seem laughably unreal or impossible.
Mimic (someone or something) scornfully or contemptuously.
Make a replica or imitation of something.
Not authentic or real, but without the intention to deceive.
(of an examination, battle, etc.) arranged for training or practice.
Mock examinations.
An object of derision.
--Examples--
‘opposition MPs mocked the government's decision’
‘at Christmas, arguments and friction mock our pretence at peace’
‘he ought to find out who used his name, mocked his voice, and aped a few of his guitar lines’
‘a mock-Georgian red brick house’
‘Jim threw up his hands in mock horror’
‘mock GCSEs’
‘obtaining Grade A in mocks’
‘he has become the mock of all his contemporaries’
--Word--
mockable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
mockado 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A kind of fabric resembling velvet, much used for garments and trimmings in the 16th and 17th centuries. Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
mock-beggar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
British informal. Something which serves to disappoint the hopes of beggars. Chiefly attributive and in the genitive: designating a house that has an appearance of wealth but is either deserted or has poor or miserly inhabitants; especially in "Mock-Beggar Hall".
--Examples--
--Word--
mock-bird 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bird which mimics the calls of other birds; especially (chiefly US) = "mockingbird" 1b. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
mock-bird 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bird which mimics the calls of other birds; especially (chiefly US) = "mockingbird" 1b. Now rare.

Make (something) seem laughably unreal or impossible.
Mimic (someone or something) scornfully or contemptuously.
Make a replica or imitation of something.
Not authentic or real, but without the intention to deceive.
(of an examination, battle, etc.) arranged for training or practice.
Mock examinations.
An object of derision.
--Examples--
‘opposition MPs mocked the government's decision’
‘at Christmas, arguments and friction mock our pretence at peace’
‘he ought to find out who used his name, mocked his voice, and aped a few of his guitar lines’
‘a mock-Georgian red brick house’
‘Jim threw up his hands in mock horror’
‘mock GCSEs’
‘obtaining Grade A in mocks’
‘he has become the mock of all his contemporaries’
--Word--
mocker 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who mocks someone or something.
--Examples--
‘a mocker of authority’
--Word--
mockery 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Teasing and contemptuous language or behaviour directed at a particular person or thing.
An absurd misrepresentation or imitation of something.
Ludicrously futile action.
--Examples--
‘stung by her mockery, Frankie hung his head’
‘after a mockery of a trial in London, he was executed’
‘in her bitterness she felt that all rejoicing was mockery’

noun

mod 
--Type--
abbreviation, adjective, noun, preposition, noun, verb, noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
(in the UK) Ministry of Defence.
Modern.
(especially in the early 1960s) a young person of a subculture characterized by a smart stylish appearance, the riding of motor scooters, and a liking for soul music.
A modification.
Make modifications to; modify.
A person who moderates an online forum or discussion; a moderator.
(of the moderator of an online forum or discussion) delete (inappropriate or offensive content)
A Highland meeting for Gaelic literary and musical competitions.
--Examples--

‘both the single-player and multiplayer games can be modded’
‘the post was quickly removed by mods’
‘my post was modded and prevented from being posted’

--Word--
modal 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to mode or form as opposed to substance.
Of or denoting the mood of a verb.
Relating to a modal verb.
Relating to a value that occurs most frequently in a given set of data.
Of or denoting music using melodies or harmonies based on modes other than the ordinary major and minor scales.
(of a proposition) in which the predicate is affirmed of the subject with some qualification, or which involves the affirmation of possibility, impossibility, necessity, or contingency.
A modal word or construction.
--Examples--
--Word--
modalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The doctrine that the persons of the Trinity represent only three modes or aspects of the divine revelation, not distinct and coexisting parts of the divine nature.
The use of modal melodies and harmonies.

--Word--
mode 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A way or manner in which something occurs or is experienced, expressed, or done.
An option allowing a change in the method of operation of a device, especially a camera.
A way of operating or using a system.
Any of the distinct kinds or patterns of vibration of an oscillating system.
The character of a modal proposition (whether necessary, contingent, possible, or impossible).
A fashion or style in clothes, art, literature, etc.
The value that occurs most frequently in a given set of data.
A set of musical notes forming a scale and from which melodies and harmonies are constructed.
--Examples--
‘his preferred mode of travel was a kayak’
‘a camcorder in automatic mode’
‘some computers provide several so-called processor modes’
‘in the Seventies the mode for active wear took hold’
--Word--
model 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A three-dimensional representation of a person or thing or of a proposed structure, typically on a smaller scale than the original.
(in sculpture) a figure or object made in clay or wax, to be reproduced in another more durable material.
A thing used as an example to follow or imitate.
A person or thing regarded as an excellent example of a specified quality.
An actual person or place on which a specified fictional character or location is based.
The plan for the reorganization of the Parliamentary army, passed by the House of Commons in 1644–5.
A simplified description, especially a mathematical one, of a system or process, to assist calculations and predictions.
A person employed to display clothes by wearing them.
A person employed to pose for an artist, photographer, or sculptor.
A particular design or version of a product.
A garment or a copy of a garment by a well-known designer.
Fashion or shape (a three-dimensional figure or object) in a malleable material such as clay or wax.
(in drawing or painting) represent so as to appear three-dimensional.
Use (a system, procedure, etc.) as an example to follow or imitate.
Take (someone admired or respected) as an example to follow or imitate.
Devise a representation, especially a mathematical one, of (a phenomenon or system)
Display (clothes) by wearing them.
Work as a model by displaying clothes or posing for an artist or sculptor.
--Examples--
‘a model of St Paul's Cathedral’
‘a model aeroplane’
‘wax models were used by sculptors in the lost wax method of bronze casting’
‘the project became a model for other schemes’
‘as she grew older, she became a model of self-control’
‘he was a model husband and father’
‘Preston was the model for Coketown in ‘Hard Times’’
‘a statistical model used for predicting the survival rates of endangered species’
‘Jane was too small to be a model’
‘a well-known fashion model’
‘an artist's model’
‘the company revealed their latest model at the Motor Show’
‘strikes have dogged the production of the models’
‘use the icing to model a house’
‘the body of the woman to the right is modelled in softer, riper forms’
‘the research method will be modelled on previous work’
‘he models himself on rock legend Elvis Presley’
‘a computer program that can model the behaviour of smoke’
‘the clothes were modelled by celebrities’
‘he's been modelling for just two weeks’

modeless 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
In mystical use: not manifested in a particular form; formless. Now rare.
Computing. Designating a program, system, or user interface that allows the user to perform various different types of action without having to switch between different modes of operation; specifically designating a dialog box that does not need to be responded to before the system will permit any other interaction.

--Word--
moderate 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Average in amount, intensity, quality, or degree.
(of a person, party, or policy) not radical or excessively right- or left-wing.
A person who holds moderate views, especially in politics.
Make or become less extreme, intense, rigorous, or violent.
Review (examination papers, results, or candidates) in relation to an agreed standard so as to ensure consistency of marking.
(in academic and ecclesiastical contexts) preside over (a deliberative body) or at (a debate)
(especially in the Presbyterian Church in Scotland) act as a moderator; preside.
Monitor (an Internet forum or online discussion) for inappropriate or offensive content.
Retard (neutrons) with a moderator.
--Examples--
‘we walked at a moderate pace’
‘a moderate reform programme’
‘an unlikely alliance of radicals and moderates’
‘I shall not moderate my criticism’
‘the weather has moderated considerably’
‘the dependability of an examining system rests on those who set, moderate, and mark the papers’
‘a panel moderated by a Harvard University law professor’
‘it is the Presbytery that moderates’
‘the neutrons causing fission are not moderated but react at high energies’
