‘an unlikely alliance of radicals and moderates’
‘I shall not moderate my criticism’
‘the weather has moderated considerably’
‘the dependability of an examining system rests on those who set, moderate, and mark the papers’
‘a panel moderated by a Harvard University law professor’
‘it is the Presbytery that moderates’
‘the neutrons causing fission are not moderated but react at high energies’
--Word--
moderation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The avoidance of excess or extremes, especially in one's behaviour or political opinions.
The action of making something less extreme, intense, or violent.
The action or process of moderating examination papers, results, or candidates.
The first public examination in some faculties for the BA degree at Oxford University.
The retardation of neutrons by a moderator.
--Examples--
‘he urged the police to show moderation’
‘the union's approach was based on increased dialogue and the moderation of demands’
‘coursework may need to be filed separately for the purposes of moderation’
‘he took firsts in classical honour Moderations’
--Word--
moderationism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A policy or doctrine of being moderate or acting with moderation.
--Examples--
--Word--
moderationist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An advocate of moderation; specifically a person who is in favour of moderate drinking, as opposed to total abstinence.
--Examples--

--Word--
moderator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An arbitrator or mediator.
A presiding officer, especially a chairman of a debate.
A Presbyterian minister presiding over an ecclesiastical body.
A person who reviews examination papers to ensure consistency, or otherwise oversees an examination.
A person who moderates an Internet forum or online discussion.
A substance used in a nuclear reactor to retard neutrons.
--Examples--
‘Egypt managed to assert its role as a regional moderator’
‘the debates will each feature one moderator and a panel of three questioners’
‘the newly elected Moderator of the Dutch Reformed Church’
‘after marking by the tutor, the papers are returned to a moderator’
‘in a fast reactor there is no moderator to slow the reaction down’
--Word--
moderatorial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or characteristic of a moderator or chairman.
--Examples--

--Word--
modern 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the present or recent times as opposed to the remote past.
Characterized by or using the most up-to-date techniques, ideas, or equipment.
Denoting the form of a language that is currently used, as opposed to any earlier form.
Denoting a current or recent style or trend in art, architecture, or other cultural activity marked by a significant departure from traditional styles and values.
A person who advocates or practises a departure from traditional styles or values.
--Examples--
‘the pace of modern life’
‘modern European history’
‘they do not have modern weapons’
‘modern German’
‘Matisse's contribution to modern art’
‘they were moderns, they must not look back towards the old generation’

--Word--
modernism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Modern character or quality of thought, expression, or technique.
A style or movement in the arts that aims to depart significantly from classical and traditional forms.
A movement towards modifying traditional beliefs in accordance with modern ideas, especially in the Roman Catholic Church in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
--Examples--
‘a strange mix of nostalgia and modernism’
‘by the post-war period, modernism had become part of art history’

noun, adjective

A believer in or supporter of modernism, especially in the arts.
Of or associated with modernism, especially in the arts.
--Examples--
‘James Joyce and other 20th-century modernists’
‘his early work explored all manner of modernist styles’

--Word--
sounding 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The action of measuring the depth of a body of water.
A measurement taken by sounding.
The determination of any physical property at a depth in the sea or at a height in the atmosphere.
The area of sea close to the shore which is shallow enough for the bottom to be reached by means of a sounding line.
Information or evidence ascertained as a preliminary step before taking action.
Giving forth sound, especially loud or resonant sound.
Having an imposing sound but little substance.
--Examples--
‘he took soundings about the possibility of moving offices’
‘he went in with a sounding plunge’
‘the orator has been apt to deal in sounding commonplaces’
--Word--
mode 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A way or manner in which something occurs or is experienced, expressed, or done.
An option allowing a change in the method of operation of a device, especially a camera.
A way of operating or using a system.
Any of the distinct kinds or patterns of vibration of an oscillating system.
The character of a modal proposition (whether necessary, contingent, possible, or impossible).
A fashion or style in clothes, art, literature, etc.
The value that occurs most frequently in a given set of data.
A set of musical notes forming a scale and from which melodies and harmonies are constructed.
--Examples--
‘his preferred mode of travel was a kayak’
‘a camcorder in automatic mode’
‘some computers provide several so-called processor modes’
‘in the Seventies the mode for active wear took hold’
--Word--
modest 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Unassuming in the estimation of one's abilities or achievements.
(of an amount, rate, or level) relatively moderate, limited, or small.
Not large, elaborate, or expensive.
(of a woman) dressing or behaving so as to avoid impropriety or indecency, especially to avoid attracting sexual attention.
(of clothing) not revealing or emphasizing a person's figure.
--Examples--
‘he was a very modest man, refusing to take any credit for the enterprise’
‘drink modest amounts of alcohol’
‘employment growth was relatively modest’
‘a modest flat in Fulham’
‘it was a nice wedding, necessarily modest’
‘the modest women wear long-sleeved dresses and all but cover their faces’
‘modest dress means that hemlines must be below the knee’

modestness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Modesty.
--Examples--
--Word--
modesty 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or state of being unassuming in the estimation of one's abilities.
The quality of being relatively moderate, limited, or small in amount, rate, or level.
Behaviour, manner, or appearance intended to avoid impropriety or indecency.
--Examples--
‘with typical modesty he insisted on sharing the credit with others’
‘the modesty of his political aspirations’
‘modesty forbade her to undress in front of so many people’

--Word--
modestly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an unassuming manner; without vanity or arrogance.
To a relatively moderate or small degree.
In a manner that is not elaborate or luxurious.
So as to avoid impropriety or indecency.
--Examples--
‘he modestly shrugged off the tributes from his manager’
‘sales and profits have grown modestly in recent years’
‘a modestly furnished flat’
‘he lived modestly in a small house’
‘women are expected to dress modestly’
‘he modestly covered his eyes’

--Word--
modify 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make partial or minor changes to (something)
Transform (a structure) from its original anatomical form during development or evolution.
(especially of an adjective) restrict or add to the sense of (a noun)
Pronounce (a speech sound) differently from the norm for that sound.
--Examples--
‘she may be prepared to modify her views’
‘the traps of insectivorous plants are modified leaves’
‘the target noun is modified by a ‘direction’ word’

--Word--
modifier 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or thing that makes partial or minor changes to something.
A word, especially an adjective or noun used attributively, that restricts or adds to the sense of a head noun (e.g. good and family in a good family house).
A gene which modifies the phenotypic expression of a gene at another locus.
--Examples--
‘mood modifiers like Valium and Lithium’

--Word--
Modigliani, Amedeo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1884–1920), Italian painter and sculptor, resident in France from 1906. His portraits and nudes are noted for their elongated forms, linear qualities, and earthy colours.
--Examples--

--Word--
modoc 
--Type--
noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
A member of a North American Indian people living on the border of Oregon and California.
The extinct language of the Modoc, a dialect of Klamath (or Klamath–Modoc), which is hypothesized to be part of the Penutian superfamily.
Of, relating to, or designating the Modoc.
A person who takes up aviation for reasons of self-publicity or social prestige.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mods 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
The Moderations examination at Oxford University.
--Examples--
--Word--
Modulor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A modular system of proportion devised by the architect Le Corbusier, based on dimensions of 7 feet 5 inches (approx. 226.1 cm) and 3 feet 9 inches (114.3 cm), derived from the proportions of an idealized human figure six feet tall, and intended to be used for the coordinated design of buildings, their contents, and their surroundings.
--Examples--
--Word--
modulant 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A thing which effects modulation; a modulating agent.
--Examples--
--Word--
modular 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Employing or involving a module or modules as the basis of design or construction.
Relating to an educational course designed as a series of independent units of study that can be combined in a number of ways.
Relating to a modulus.
--Examples--
‘modular housing units’
‘moves to make all Britain's vocational qualifications modular’
‘modular courses coupled with practical experience’

--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
According to modular principles.
--Examples--
--Word--
modulate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Exert a modifying or controlling influence on.
Vary the strength, tone, or pitch of (one's voice)
Alter the amplitude or frequency of (an electromagnetic wave or other oscillation) in accordance with the variations of a second signal, typically one of a lower frequency.
Change from one key to another.
Change from one form or condition into (another)
--Examples--
‘the state attempts to modulate private business's cash flow’
‘we all modulate our voice by hearing it’
‘radio waves are modulated to carry the analogue information of the voice’
‘the first half of the melody, modulating from E minor to G’
‘the fraught silence would modulate into conciliatory monosyllables’

--Word--
modulate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Exert a modifying or controlling influence on.
Vary the strength, tone, or pitch of (one's voice)

--Word--
modulation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The exertion of a modifying or controlling influence on something.
Variation in the strength, tone, or pitch of one's voice.
Alteration of the amplitude or frequency of an electromagnetic wave or other oscillation in accordance with the variations of a second signal.
A change from one key to another in a piece of music.
The process of changing from one form or condition into another.
--Examples--
‘endorphins in the body are responsible for the modulation of pain sensation’
‘excellent voice modulation’
‘modulation of the ray amplitude will result in sound being heard’
‘researchers observed the modulation of electrical conductance’
‘their bold approach to harmony and modulation’
‘there is a beautiful modulation from B flat to G major’
‘the modulation from an oral to a written technology in ancient Greek civilization’
‘great modulations of tempo’
--Word--
modulation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The exertion of a modifying or controlling influence on something.
Variation in the strength, tone, or pitch of one's voice.
Alteration of the amplitude or frequency of an electromagnetic wave or other oscillation in accordance with the variations of a second signal.
A change from one key to another in a piece of music.
The process of changing from one form or condition into another.

‘endorphins in the body are responsible for the modulation of pain sensation’
‘excellent voice modulation’
‘modulation of the ray amplitude will result in sound being heard’
‘researchers observed the modulation of electrical conductance’
‘their bold approach to harmony and modulation’
‘there is a beautiful modulation from B flat to G major’
‘the modulation from an oral to a written technology in ancient Greek civilization’
‘great modulations of tempo’

--Word--
module 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of a set of standardized parts or independent units that can be used to construct a more complex structure, such as an item of furniture or a building.
Each of a set of independent units of study or training that can be combined in a number of ways to form a course at a college or university.
Any of a number of distinct but interrelated units from which a program may be built up or into which a complex activity may be analysed.
A detachable self-contained unit of a spacecraft.
--Examples--
‘ships are now built in modules rather than built in a whole from the base up’
‘nine optional modules must be taken’
‘a Law module’
‘a networking module’
‘Spacelab, an extra module for the shuttle, will quadruple the experimental facilities on board’
--Word--
module 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of a set of standardized parts or independent units that can be used to construct a more complex structure, such as an item of furniture or a building.
Each of a set of independent units of study or training that can be combined in a number of ways to form a course at a college or university.
Any of a number of distinct but interrelated units from which a program may be built up or into which a complex activity may be analysed.

--Examples--
‘ships are now built in modules rather than built in a whole from the base up’
‘nine optional modules must be taken’
‘a Law module’
‘a networking module’
‘Spacelab, an extra module for the shuttle, will quadruple the experimental facilities on board’
--Word--
Modulor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A modular system of proportion devised by the architect Le Corbusier, based on dimensions of 7 feet 5 inches (approx. 226.1 cm) and 3 feet 9 inches (114.3 cm), derived from the proportions of an idealized human figure six feet tall, and intended to be used for the coordinated design of buildings, their contents, and their surroundings.
--Examples--
--Word--
modulus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The positive square root of the sum of the squares of the real and imaginary parts of a complex number.
A constant factor or ratio.
A constant indicating the relation between a physical effect and the force producing it.
A number used as a divisor for considering numbers in sets, numbers being considered congruent when giving the same remainder when divided by a particular modulus.
--Examples--
‘the modulus of elasticity’
--Word--
modulize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To render modular; to modularize.
--Examples--
--Word--
modulo 
--Type--
preposition
--Meanings--
(in number theory) with respect to or using a modulus of a specified number. Two numbers are congruent modulo a given number if they give the same remainder when divided by that number.
Using moduli.
--Examples--
‘19 and 64 are congruent modulo 5’
‘8 is equivalent to 1 in arithmetic modulo 7’
‘modulo operations’
--Word--
modulus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The positive square root of the sum of the squares of the real and imaginary parts of a complex number.
A constant factor or ratio.
A constant indicating the relation between a physical effect and the force producing it.
A number used as a divisor for considering numbers in sets, numbers being considered congruent when giving the same remainder when divided by a particular modulus.
--Examples--
‘the modulus of elasticity’
--Word--
modus vivendi 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An arrangement or agreement allowing conflicting parties to coexist peacefully, either indefinitely or until a final settlement is reached.
A way of living.
--Examples--
‘the two states have with difficulty reached a modus vivendi, though hardly friendship’
‘the Christian faith and its implications for a modus vivendi’
--Word--
Moebius process 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An electrolytic process for refining silver and separating any gold that may be in it, in which anodes are made of the silver to be refined and placed in a solution of silver nitrate together with cathodes of pure silver or stainless steel.
--Examples--
--Word--
moellon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dark wax or grease used in curing leather; = "degras".
--Examples--

moeritherium

noun
--Meanings--
A medium-sized mammal of the late Eocene and Oligocene epochs with a long snout and short legs, related to modern elephants.

--Word--
Goth. 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Gothic.
--Examples--
--Word--
Gothic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the Goths or their extinct language, which belongs to the East Germanic branch of the Indo-European language family. It provides the earliest manuscript evidence of any Germanic language (4th–6th centuries AD).
Of or in the style of architecture prevalent in western Europe in the 12th–16th centuries (and revived in the mid 18th to early 20th centuries), characterized by pointed arches, rib vaults, and flying buttresses, together with large windows and elaborate tracery. English Gothic architecture is divided into Early English, Decorated, and Perpendicular.
Belonging to or redolent of the Dark Ages; portentously gloomy or horrifying.
(of lettering) of or derived from the angular style of handwriting with broad vertical downstrokes used in western Europe from the 13th century, including Fraktur and black-letter typefaces.
Relating to goths or goth music.
The extinct language of the Goths.
The Gothic style of architecture.
Gothic type.
--Examples--
‘19th-century Gothic horror’

Moët 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A trademark for: a brand of champagne produced by Moët et Chandon.

--Word--
Mogador 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Designating any of various substances or items distributed from Mogador (now Essaouira) in Morocco, as "Mogador colocynth", "Mogador gum", "Mogador furniture", etc. "Mogador tare"noun (perhaps) a unit of tare weight formerly used at Mogador.
Any of various substances or items distributed from or associated with Mogador, specifically a ribbed silk fabric used especially for ties.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mogador 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Designating any of various substances or items distributed from Mogador (now Essaouira) in Morocco, as "Mogador colocynth", "Mogador gum", "Mogador furniture", etc. "Mogador tare"noun (perhaps) a unit of tare weight formerly used at Mogador.
Any of various substances or items distributed from or associated with Mogador, specifically a ribbed silk fabric used especially for ties.

--Word--
mogul 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
An important or powerful person, especially in the film or media industry.
A steam locomotive of 2-6-0 wheel arrangement.
A bump on a ski slope formed by skiers turning.
A member of the Muslim dynasty of Mongol origin founded by the successors of Tamerlane, which ruled much of India from the 16th to the 19th century.
The Mogul emperor of Delhi.
--Examples--
‘the Hollywood movie mogul, Sam Goldwyn’
‘a mogul field’
‘Mogul architecture’

Mogollon 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a North and Central American Indian people, formerly living in western New Mexico.
Archaeology. A culture of south-western New Mexico and south-eastern Arizona which flourished 100 b.c.–a.d. 1400. Usually with the.
Of or relating to the Apache Mogollons.
Archaeology. Of or relating to the Mogollon.

mohar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Among the people of ancient Israel and Oriental Jews: the marriage payment made by a bridegroom either to his bride or to the bride's father, originally intended to be used in purchasing goods for the newly-weds and in securing the future financial independence of the bride.
--Examples--

Mojave Desert

--Meanings--
A desert in southern California, to the south-east of the Sierra Nevada and north and east of Los Angeles.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mohawk 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of an Iroquoian people originally inhabiting parts of what is now upper New York State, one of the five peoples comprising the original Iroquois confederacy.
The Iroquoian language of the Mohawk.
A hairstyle in which the head is shaved except for a strip of hair running centrally from the middle of the forehead to the back of the neck.
A step from either edge of the skate to the same edge on the other foot in the opposite direction.
Relating to the Mohawk or their language.
--Examples--

Mohican 
--Type--
noun
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
A hairstyle with the head shaved except for a strip of hair from the middle of the forehead to the back of the neck, typically stiffened to stand erect or in spikes.
--Examples--
‘I was a nihilistic punk with a Mohican and a ring in my nose’
‘a Mohican haircut’

Mohock 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a band of aristocratic hooligans who allegedly roamed the streets of London by night in the early 18th cent. and were suspected of ruffianism. Hence (more generally): any hooligan or delinquent. Now historical and archaic.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mohock 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a band of aristocratic hooligans who allegedly roamed the streets of London by night in the early 18th cent. and were suspected of ruffianism. Hence (more generally): any hooligan or delinquent. Now historical and archaic.
--Examples--
--Word--
Moholy-Nagy, László 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1895–1946), Hungarian-born American painter, sculptor, and photographer. He pioneered the experimental use of plastic materials, light, photography, and film.
--Examples--

--Word--
Mohr 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Attributive and in the genitive. Designating instruments, techniques, etc., used or introduced by K. F. Mohr in his work on volumetric analysis.
"Mohr cubic centimetre"noun a unit of volume (approx. 1.00238 cm3) equal to the volume of one gram of water at a particular temperature, usually 17.5°C. Similarly "Mohr (also Mohr's) litre".
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--

--Word--
moiety 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of two parts into which a thing is or can be divided.
Each of two social or ritual groups into which a people is divided, especially among Australian Aborigines and some North American Indians.
A part or portion, especially a lesser share.
A distinct part of a large molecule.
--Examples--
‘the tax was to be delivered in two moieties’
‘the enzyme removes the sulphate moiety’
--Word--
moiety 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of two parts into which a thing is or can be divided.
Each of two social or ritual groups into which a people is divided, especially among Australian Aborigines and some North American Indians.
A part or portion, especially a lesser share.
A distinct part of a large molecule.
--Examples--
‘the tax was to be delivered in two moieties’
‘the enzyme removes the sulphate moiety’
--Word--
moil 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Work hard.
Move around in confusion or agitation.
Hard work; drudgery.
Turmoil; confusion.
--Examples--
‘men who moiled for gold’
‘a crowd of men and women moiled in the smoky haze’
‘this night his weekly moil is at an end’
‘the moil of his intimate thoughts’

--Word--
Moine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
With the. In full "the Moine Series". An intensely folded series of metamorphic rocks in north-west Scotland and western Ireland, chiefly granulites and schists, which are thought to have been deposited in Precambrian (possibly Torridonian) times and metamorphosed later. In plural: the rocks themselves.
--Examples--
--Word--
Shearer, Moira 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1926–2006), Scottish ballet dancer and actress; full name Moira Shearer King. A ballerina with Sadler's Wells from 1942, she is perhaps best known for her portrayal of a dedicated ballerina in the film The Red Shoes (1948).
--Examples--
--Word--

moire 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Silk fabric that has been subjected to heat and pressure rollers after weaving to give it a rippled appearance.
(of silk) having a rippled, lustrous finish.
Having a pattern of irregular wavy lines like that of moire.
--Examples--
‘a backless dress fashioned out of moire in the new fashionable colour’
‘many brocades and moires have a high acetate content’
‘another video picture defect is the flickering moiré effect seen on finely patterned surfaces’
--Word--
moire 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Silk fabric that has been subjected to heat and pressure rollers after weaving to give it a rippled appearance.
(of silk) having a rippled, lustrous finish.
Having a pattern of irregular wavy lines like that of moire.
--Examples--
‘a backless dress fashioned out of moire in the new fashionable colour’
‘many brocades and moires have a high acetate content’
‘another video picture defect is the flickering moiré effect seen on finely patterned surfaces’
--Word--
Mohism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The doctrines of the Chinese philosopher Mozi and his followers.
--Examples--
--Word--
Moissan, Henri 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1852–1907), French chemist; full name Ferdinand Frédéric Henri Moissan. In 1886 he succeeded in isolating the very reactive element fluorine. In 1892 he invented the electric-arc furnace that bears his name. Nobel Prize for Chemistry (1906).
--Examples--
--Word--
moissanite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Trigonal silicon carbide, SiC, which occurs as colourless to blue or green hexagonal plates with a metallic lustre and is the naturally occurring form of carborundum.
--Examples--
--Word--
moist 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Slightly wet.
(of the eyes) wet with tears.
(of a climate) rainy.
Marked by a fluid discharge.
--Examples--
‘the moist, fertile soil’
‘her brother's eyes became moist’
‘exposure to the Atlantic on the west gives rise to a cool, moist climate’
--Word--
moisten 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Wet slightly.
(of the eyes) fill with tears.
--Examples--
‘she moistened her lips with the tip of her tongue’
‘her eyes moistened’

moki 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Any of various edible marine fishes of the percoid families Latrididae and Cheilodactylidae, found off New Zealand coasts; especially (a) the bottom-dwelling Latridopsis ciliaris, which is blue-grey and silver (also "blue moki"); (b) (in full "red moki") Cheilodactylus spectabilis, which is reddish brown with whitish vertical bars on its sides.
A Maori raft, usually made of bulrushes or other similar material.
--Examples--
--Word--
moky 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Cloudy, foggy, hazy.
--Examples--

--Word--
mole 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun, noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A small burrowing mammal with dark velvety fur, a long muzzle, and very small eyes, feeding mainly on worms, grubs, and other invertebrates.
A spy who gradually achieves an important position within the security defences of a country.
Someone within an organization who anonymously betrays confidential information.
A small, often slightly raised blemish on the skin made dark by a high concentration of melanin.
A large solid structure on a shore serving as a pier, breakwater, or causeway.
A harbour formed or protected by a mole.
The SI unit of amount of substance, equal to the quantity containing as many elementary units as there are atoms in 0.012 kg of carbon-12.
An abnormal mass of tissue in the uterus.
A highly spiced Mexican sauce made chiefly from chilli peppers and chocolate, served with meat.
--Examples--
‘a well-placed mole was feeding them the names of operatives’
‘the company is hunting for the mole who revealed details of planned job cuts’
‘a mole on her arm had not been there at the beginning of the summer’

--Word--
molasse 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally (formerly also with capital initial): a deposit of soft greenish sandstone mixed with marls and fossiliferous conglomerates, of Miocene to Oligocene age, found along the northern edge of the Alps. Later also (more generally): any thick paralic sedimentary deposit formed after a period of orogeny and consisting of soft, ungraded sandstones, shales, marls, etc.
--Examples--
--Word--
molasses 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Thick, dark brown juice obtained from raw sugar during the refining process.
Syrup used in baking and to pour over food.

--Word--
Moldavia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A former principality of south-eastern Europe. Formerly a part of the Roman province of Dacia, the principality came under Turkish rule in the 16th century. In 1861 Moldavia united with Wallachia to form Romania.
--Examples--

--Word--
mould 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A hollow container used to give shape to molten or hot liquid material when it cools and hardens.
A pudding or savoury mousse made in a mould.
A distinctive and typical style, form, or character.
Form or shape, especially the features or physique of a person or the build of an animal.
A frame or template for producing mouldings.
Form (an object) out of malleable material.
Give a shape to (malleable material)
Influence the formation or development of.
(of a column, ceiling, or other part of a building) having a decorative moulding.
--Examples--
‘the smith would pour the molten metal into the shaped mould’
‘a jelly mould’
‘a lobster mould with a sauce of carrots and port’
‘he's a superb striker in the same mould as Gary Lineker’
‘he planned to conquer the world as a roving reporter in the mould of his hero’
‘he was manly in size, mould, and bearing’
‘all the moulds, masters or originals, had been kept for reference’
‘mould the figure from white fondant’
‘take the marzipan and mould it into a cone shape’
‘the professionals who were helping to mould US policy’
‘a corridor with a moulded cornice’
--Word--
moulder 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Slowly decay or disintegrate, especially because of neglect.
A person or thing that moulds something.
--Examples--
‘the smell of mouldering books’
‘I couldn't permit someone of your abilities to moulder away in a backwater’
‘a moulder of public opinion’

--Word--
mole 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun, noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A small burrowing mammal with dark velvety fur, a long muzzle, and very small eyes, feeding mainly on worms, grubs, and other invertebrates.
A spy who gradually achieves an important position within the security defences of a country.
Someone within an organization who anonymously betrays confidential information.
A small, often slightly raised blemish on the skin made dark by a high concentration of melanin.
A large solid structure on a shore serving as a pier, breakwater, or causeway.
A harbour formed or protected by a mole.
The SI unit of amount of substance, equal to the quantity containing as many elementary units as there are atoms in 0.012 kg of carbon-12.
An abnormal mass of tissue in the uterus.
A highly spiced Mexican sauce made chiefly from chilli peppers and chocolate, served with meat.
--Examples--
‘a well-placed mole was feeding them the names of operatives’
‘the company is hunting for the mole who revealed details of planned job cuts’
‘a mole on her arm had not been there at the beginning of the summer’

mole

A small burrowing mammal with dark velvety fur, a long muzzle, and very small eyes, feeding mainly on worms, grubs, and other invertebrates.
A spy who gradually achieves an important position within the security defences of a country.
Someone within an organization who anonymously betrays confidential information.
A small, often slightly raised blemish on the skin made dark by a high concentration of melanin.
A large solid structure on a shore serving as a pier, breakwater, or causeway.
A harbour formed or protected by a mole.
The SI unit of amount of substance, equal to the quantity containing as many elementary units as there are atoms in 0.012 kg of carbon-12.
An abnormal mass of tissue in the uterus.
A highly spiced Mexican sauce made chiefly from chilli peppers and chocolate, served with meat.
--Examples--
‘a well-placed mole was feeding them the names of operatives’
‘the company is hunting for the mole who revealed details of planned job cuts’
‘a mole on her arm had not been there at the beginning of the summer’

--Word--
mole 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun, noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A small burrowing mammal with dark velvety fur, a long muzzle, and very small eyes, feeding mainly on worms, grubs, and other invertebrates.
A spy who gradually achieves an important position within the security defences of a country.
Someone within an organization who anonymously betrays confidential information.
A small, often slightly raised blemish on the skin made dark by a high concentration of melanin.
A large solid structure on a shore serving as a pier, breakwater, or causeway.
A harbour formed or protected by a mole.
The SI unit of amount of substance, equal to the quantity containing as many elementary units as there are atoms in 0.012 kg of carbon-12.
An abnormal mass of tissue in the uterus.
A highly spiced Mexican sauce made chiefly from chilli peppers and chocolate, served with meat.
--Examples--
‘a well-placed mole was feeding them the names of operatives’
‘the company is hunting for the mole who revealed details of planned job cuts’
‘a mole on her arm had not been there at the beginning of the summer’

--Word--
moleskins 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
Trousers made of a thick, strong cotton fabric with a shaved pile surface, as worn by agricultural workers, gold prospectors, and others from the early 19th century onwards.
--Examples--
‘they wear the standard uniform of bush hat, check shirt, and scrubby moleskins’

molybdenite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A blue-grey mineral, typically occurring as hexagonal crystals. It consists of molybdenum disulphide and is the most common ore of molybdenum.
--Examples--
--Word--
molybdenum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 42, a brittle silver-grey metal of the transition series, used in some alloy steels.

molybdic 
--Type--
adjective

molybdite

noun
--Meanings--
Molybdenum trioxide, crystallizing in the orthorhombic system and usually occurring as flat yellow needles and plates forming encrustations.

Molière 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1622–73), French playwright; pseudonym of Jean-Baptiste Poquelin. He wrote more than twenty comic plays about contemporary France, developing stock characters from Italian commedia dell'arte. Notable works: Tartuffe (1664), Le Misanthrope (1666), and Le Bourgeois gentilhomme (1670).

Molinia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of perennial densely tufted grasses typically having long, narrow panicles; (also molinia) a grass of this genus, specifically Molinia caerulea subsp. caerulea, purple moor grass, plentiful over large areas of damp peaty moorland in Eurasia.

--Word--
Molinism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The doctrine, propounded in 1588 by Luis de Molina, which linked the efficacy of divine grace with the free cooperation of mankind, free will in turn being safeguarded by divine grace.
--Examples--

molimo 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Among the Sotho speakers of eastern and southern Africa: the supreme being, the Christian God.
A type of wooden trumpet-like musical instrument used by the Mbuti people of the Ituri forest (Democratic Republic of Congo).
Among the Mbuti people: a religious festival or ritual marking an important occasion such as marriage, death, etc., and characterized by the singing of particular songs.

mollities 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Medicine. Abnormal softening or softness of a part or organ. Chiefly in scientific Latin compounds. "mollities cerebri"noun Obsolete. softening of cerebral tissue; encephalomalacia. "mollities ossium"noun now historical. any of various conditions causing softening (demineralization) or destruction of bone, as rickets, osteomalacia, myelomatosis, etc.; an instance or case of such softening.

--Word--
mollusc 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An invertebrate of a large phylum which includes snails, slugs, mussels, and octopuses. They have a soft unsegmented body and live in aquatic or damp habitats, and most kinds have an external calcareous shell.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mollusca 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In form Mollusca, with singular or plural concord. Originally: a heterogeneous group of mostly shell-less invertebrates, forming the second order of the class Vermes in Linnaeus's classification (Systema Naturae (ed. 10, 1758) I. vi. ii. 652) and including cephalopods, echinoderms, hydroids, slugs, and annelids. Now, mainly following the classification proposed by Cuvier in 1788–1800: a phylum of invertebrates that live in aquatic or damp habitats and have a soft, unsegmented body and usually an external calcareous shell. Also, treated as plural (also mollusca): animals of this phylum (collectively or individually).
--Examples--
--Word--
molluscan 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
molluscan 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
Molluscoidea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A former division of invertebrates comprising the groups Bryozoa (formerly Polyzoa) and Brachiopoda, now phyla in their own right, and originally also the group Tunicata (now the subphylum Urochordata of the phylum Chordata).

An invertebrate of a large phylum which includes snails, slugs, mussels, and octopuses. They have a soft unsegmented body and live in aquatic or damp habitats, and most kinds have an external calcareous shell.

molluscum virus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(Originally) a virus that causes molluscum or molluscum-like lesions; (later) specifically = molluscum contagiosum virus.

Molniya orbit 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A highly elliptical orbit inclined at an angle of about 65° to the plane of the equator, such as is occupied by the Russian Molniya satellites.

--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island in Hawaii, east of Oahu Island, site of numerous resorts.
--Examples--
--Word--
Molokan 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a religious sect founded in south-eastern Russia in the early 18th cent., characterized by its acknowledgement of the truth of the Bible alone, its denial of the authority of the Orthodox Church, and its rejection of all forms of ritual and iconolatry.
--Examples--
--Word--
Molossian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Molossia in ancient Epirus.
A Molossian dog.
Of or relating to Molossia in ancient Epirus.
Designating or relating to a breed of large dog resembling a mastiff, said to have originated in Molossia in ancient Epirus.
--Examples--

molossic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Using or composed of molossi; having a rhythm resembling that of a molossus.

--Word--
molly 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A small live-bearing killifish which is popular in aquaria and has been bred in many colours, especially black.
The drug MDMA, especially in powdered or crystalline form.
--Examples--
‘the men were high on Molly’
--Word--
moult 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of an animal) shed old feathers, hair, or skin to make way for a new growth.
(of hair or feathers) fall out to make way for new growth.
A loss of feathers, hair, or skin, especially as a regular feature of an animal's life cycle.
--Examples--
‘the adult birds were already moulting’
‘the snake moults its skin’
‘the last of his juvenile plumage had moulted’
‘the mountain goat is brilliant white after the autumn moult’
‘in the complete life cycle there are four moults’

--Word--
Molucca Islands 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island group in Indonesia, between Sulawesi and New Guinea; capital, Ambon. Settled by the Portuguese in the early 16th century, the islands were taken a century later by the Dutch. They were formerly known as the Spice Islands.
--Examples--
--Word--
Moluccan 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the Molucca Islands, an island group in Indonesia.
A native or inhabitant of the Molucca Islands, an island group in Indonesia.
--Examples--
‘a new genus of rat was discovered in the Moluccan province’
‘many Moluccans served as soldiers in the Dutch colonial army’
--Word--
Molucca Islands 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island group in Indonesia, between Sulawesi and New Guinea; capital, Ambon. Settled by the Portuguese in the early 16th century, the islands were taken a century later by the Dutch. They were formerly known as the Spice Islands.

Mombasa 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A seaport and industrial city in south-eastern Kenya, on the Indian Ocean; population 862,100 (est. 2006). It is the leading port and second largest city of Kenya.

--Word--
moment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A very brief period of time.
An exact point in time.
An appropriate time for doing something; an opportunity.
A particular stage in the development of something or in a course of events.
Importance.
A turning effect produced by a force acting at a distance on an object.
The magnitude of a turning effect produced by a force acting at a distance, expressed as the product of the force and the distance from its line of action to a given point.
A quantity that expresses the average or expected value of the first, second, third, or fourth power of the deviation of each component of a frequency distribution from a given value, typically mean or zero. The first moment is the mean, the second moment the variance, the third moment the skew, and the fourth moment the kurtosis.
--Examples--
‘she was silent for a moment before replying’
‘a few moments later he returned to the office’
‘she would always remember the moment they met’
‘I was waiting for the right moment to tell him’
‘one of the great moments in aviation history’
‘the issues were of little moment to the electorate’

momenta

--Meanings--
--Examples--

adjective
--Meanings--
Mathematics. Of or relating to a moment of inertia.
Statistics. Of or relating to the moments of a random variable.

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Word--
momentaneous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Lasting only a moment; momentary (Linguistics, with reference to the time taken to perform the action expressed by a verb).
Mathematics. Designating the increment in the value of a time-varying quantity that occurs in an infinitesimal period of time. Compare "moment", "momentary". Now historical.
--Examples--

momentaneously 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--

--Meanings--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A very brief period of time.
An exact point in time.
An appropriate time for doing something; an opportunity.
A particular stage in the development of something or in a course of events.
Importance.
A turning effect produced by a force acting at a distance on an object.
The magnitude of a turning effect produced by a force acting at a distance, expressed as the product of the force and the distance from its line of action to a given point.
A quantity that expresses the average or expected value of the first, second, third, or fourth power of the deviation of each component of a frequency distribution from a given value, typically mean or zero. The first moment is the mean, the second moment the variance, the third moment the skew, and the fourth moment the kurtosis.

--Word--
momentum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quantity of motion of a moving body, measured as a product of its mass and velocity.
The impetus gained by a moving object.
The impetus and driving force gained by the development of a process or course of events.
--Examples--
‘the vehicle gained momentum as the road dipped’
‘the investigation gathered momentum in the spring’

Mommsen, Theodor 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1817–1903), German historian. He is noted for his three-volume History of Rome (1854–6; 1885) and his treatises on Roman constitutional law (1871–88). Nobel Prize for Literature (1902).

--Word--
Momus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(A) The Greek god of censure and ridicule, who was banished from Olympus for his criticisms of the gods; (also) a representation of the god. (b) A person who habitually grumbles or finds fault, a carping critic. Now rare.
--Examples--

noun, adjective

Monacan 
--Type--
noun, adjective, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
A member of a North American Indian people, or confederacy, inhabiting the upper waters of the James River of Virginia in the Colonial Period. Also: a present-day group in Amherst County, Virginia, claiming descent from these.
Of or relating to the Monacans.
Of or relating to Monaco or its inhabitants.
A native or inhabitant of Monaco.

--Word--
Monache 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of any of at least six Numic-speaking Northern Uto-Aztecan peoples living west of the Sierra Nevada crest in central California; also called Mono or Western Mono.
The nearly extinct Western Numic language spoken by the Monache and the Owens Valley Paiute, especially the dialects spoken west of the Sierras by the Monache; = "Mono".

monadism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

monarch 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sovereign head of state, especially a king, queen, or emperor.
A large migratory orange and black butterfly that occurs mainly in North America. The caterpillar feeds on milkweed, using the toxins in the plant to render both itself and the adult unpalatable to predators.
A flycatcher found in Africa, Asia, and Australasia, typically having boldly marked or colourful plumage.
--Examples--
‘the reigning monarch’
‘this followed an attempt by the deposed monarch to regain his throne’

--Word--
monarcho-fascist 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Especially in communist phraseology: of or designating an extreme right-wing form of government with a king as titular head of state, such as that established in Greece after the Second World War.
An adherent of monarcho-fascist government.
--Examples--
--Word--
monarchomachist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who fights against monarchy; an anti-monarchist. In earlier use: a person who argues against the Divine Right of monarchs.
--Examples--
--Word--
monarch 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sovereign head of state, especially a king, queen, or emperor.
A large migratory orange and black butterfly that occurs mainly in North America. The caterpillar feeds on milkweed, using the toxins in the plant to render both itself and the adult unpalatable to predators.
A flycatcher found in Africa, Asia, and Australasia, typically having boldly marked or colourful plumage.
--Examples--
‘the reigning monarch’
‘this followed an attempt by the deposed monarch to regain his throne’
--Word--
monarda 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various aromatic North American plants constituting the genus Monarda (family Lamiaceae (Labiatae)), allied to Salvia, especially one of those grown for ornament; specifically (more fully "scarlet monarda") the plant M. didyma, also called Oswego tea, bee-balm, or bergamot, which has showy red flowers. Also (in form Monarda): the genus itself.
--Examples--
--Word--
monarda 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various aromatic North American plants constituting the genus Monarda (family Lamiaceae (Labiatae)), allied to Salvia, especially one of those grown for ornament; specifically (more fully "scarlet monarda") the plant M. didyma, also called Oswego tea, bee-balm, or bergamot, which has showy red flowers. Also (in form Monarda): the genus itself.

monchiquite 
--Type--

--Meanings--
A lamprophyre containing small phenocrysts of olivine and augite, and usually also biotite or an amphibole, in a glassy groundmass consisting of or containing analcite.

--Word--
Monck, George 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
1st Duke of Albemarle (1608–70), English general. Initially a Royalist, he became a supporter of Oliver Cromwell and later suppressed the Royalists in Scotland (1651). Concerned at the growing unrest following Cromwell's death (1658), Monck negotiated the return of Charles II in 1660.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mond 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Attributive Designating industrial processes devised by Ludwig Mond and the plant and products of these processes, especially: (a) a method of manufacturing producer gas by passing air and an excess of steam into a gas producer so that most of the nitrogen of the coal is converted into ammonia and can be recovered; (b) a process for obtaining high-purity nickel by thermal decomposition of volatile nickel carbonyl obtained from crude nickel oxide by reduction with hydrogen followed by reaction with carbon monoxide.
--Examples--
--Word--
Monday 
--Type--
noun, adverb
--Meanings--
The day of the week before Tuesday and following Sunday.
On Monday.
On Mondays; each Monday.
--Examples--
‘I saw him on Monday’
‘the Monday before last’
‘she's only in the office on Mondays’
‘I'll ring you Monday’
‘the restaurant is closed Mondays’
--Word--
Mondayish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Originally of a clergyman: suffering from lethargy or indisposition on Monday, as a result of the work of Sunday (now rare). Subsequently also more widely: affected by lethargy or disinclination resulting from a busy or eventful weekend, or from having to resume work after the weekend.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mondayishness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of feeling produced by Mondays. Originally of a clergyman: an indisposition or lethargy, caused by the work of Sunday (now rare). Subsequently also more widely: the lethargy or disinclination resulting from a busy or eventful weekend or from having to resume work after the weekend.
--Examples--

--Word--
Mondayize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Transfer the celebration of (a public holiday) from the actual date to the nearest Monday, in order to make a long weekend.
--Examples--
‘a bill to Mondayize all public holidays is set to pass its second reading tomorrow’
--Word--
Mondale, Walter 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1928), US vice president 1977–81; full name Walter Frederick Mondale ; known as "Fritz." A Minnesota Democrat, he served in the US Senate 1964–76. He ran for the US vice presidency in 1980 and the US presidency in 1984, losing both times to the Republican Reagan-Bush ticket. He was US ambassador to Japan 1993–96.

Mondrian, Piet 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1872–1944), Dutch painter; born Pieter Cornelis Mondriaan. He was a co-founder of the De Stijl movement and the originator of neoplasticism, one of the earliest and strictest forms of geometrical abstract painting.

money 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A current medium of exchange in the form of coins and banknotes; coins and banknotes collectively.
Sums of money.
The assets, property, and resources owned by someone or something; wealth.
Financial gain.
Payment for work; wages.
--Examples--
‘I counted the money before putting it in my wallet’
‘he borrowed money to modernize the shop’
‘a statement of all moneys paid into and out of the account’
‘the college is very short of money’
‘the main aim of a commercial organization is to make money’
‘she accepted the job at the bank since the money was better’
--Word--
money bag 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bag for holding money. Also in plural (humorous): wealth.
Informal (occasionally derogatory). A person characterized as having or desiring money; a wealthy person. Also of a group of people, a country, etc. Frequently in plural (usually as money-bags or moneybags) with singular concord and sense.
Cookery (chiefly British). A filled pastry parcel in which the edges of a thin piece of pastry are gathered together around a filling so as to resemble a bag of money.
--Examples--

moneybags 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘he is befriended by the daughter of the local moneybags’

money's worth 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Something that is worth money or is recognized as equivalent to money. Frequently in "money or money's-worth".
An equivalent for the sum of money paid or to be paid; (full) value for one's money. Now chiefly with possessive adjective, especially in "to get one's money's worth".

monepiscopacy

--Examples--
--Word--
Monera 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally, in Haeckel's taxonomic system: a subdivision of the single-celled organisms (Protozoa or Protista) comprising those lacking a visible nucleus and organelles. In later use: a kingdom comprising all prokaryotic organisms (i.e. bacteria, cyanobacteria, and archaebacteria) in classifications where these are distinguished from the kingdom Protista. Also (in form monera): organisms of this group, prokaryotes.
In singular (in form moneron). A member of the Monera; a prokaryote. Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
moneran 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of the Monera; a prokaryote.
Of or relating to the Monera. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--

monoestrous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating a mammalian sexual cycle in which the periods of oestrus occur singly and at relatively long intervals, especially annually.
--Examples--
--Word--
Monet, Claude 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1840–1926), French painter. A founder member of the impressionists, his fascination with the play of light on objects led him to produce series of paintings of single subjects painted at different times of the day and under different weather conditions, such as the Water-lilies sequence (1899–1906; 1916 onwards).

monetize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Convert into or express in the form of currency.
Convert or adapt (a society, economy, etc.) to trade based on the exchange of money.
Earn revenue from (an asset, business, etc.)
--Examples--
‘Hamilton had monetized the entire federal and state war debts’
‘a fully monetized society’
‘the company has not said how it expects to monetize the game’
‘some of this content can be monetized’

--Word--
monetite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A triclinic hydrogen phosphate of calcium, CaH(PO₄), occurring as translucent, pale yellowish white crystals.
--Examples--
--Word--
monetization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
monetize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Convert into or express in the form of currency.
Convert or adapt (a society, economy, etc.) to trade based on the exchange of money.
Earn revenue from (an asset, business, etc.)
--Examples--
‘Hamilton had monetized the entire federal and state war debts’
‘a fully monetized society’
‘the company has not said how it expects to monetize the game’
‘some of this content can be monetized’

mongcorn 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mixture of different kinds of grain (usually wheat and rye), especially when sown together. Compare maslin. Now historical.

-monger 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
Denoting a dealer or trader in a specified commodity.
Denoting a person who promotes a specified activity, situation, or feeling, especially one that is undesirable or discreditable.

‘cheesemonger’
‘warmonger’

--Type--
noun, adjective

A person with Down's syndrome.

--Examples--
--Word--
Mongolia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A large and sparsely populated country of East Asia, bordered by Siberian Russia and China; population 3,000,000 (estimated 2015); official language, Mongolian; capital, Ulaanbaatar (Ulan Bator).
--Examples--
--Word--
Mongolian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Mongolia.
The language of Mongolia, a member of the Altaic family with an unusual vertical cursive script. It has some 2 million speakers, and related forms are spoken by over 3 million people in northern China.
Relating to Mongolia, its people, or their language.

--Word--
Tatar 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a Turkic people living in Tatarstan and various other parts of Russia and Ukraine. They are the descendants of the Tartars who ruled central Asia in the 14th century.
The Turkic language of the Tatars, with about 6 million speakers.
Relating to the Tatars or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Turkic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a large group of closely related Altaic languages of western and central Asia, including Turkish, Azerbaijani, Kazakh, Kyrgyz, Uighur, Uzbek, and Tatar.
The Turkic languages collectively.

monimostylic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating or relating to a vertebrate skull in which the quadrate bone is immovably fixed to the squamosal, so that the lower jaw cannot be protruded. Contrasted with "streptostylic".

--Examples--
--Word--
monitor 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A device used for observing, checking, or keeping a continuous record of something.
A person operating a monitor.
A person who observes a process or activity to check that it is carried out fairly or correctly, especially in an official capacity.
A person who listens to and reports on foreign radio broadcasts and signals.
A television receiver used in a studio to select or verify the picture being broadcast from a particular camera.
A screen which displays an image generated by a computer.
A loudspeaker used by performers on stage to hear themselves or in the studio to hear what has been recorded.
A school pupil with disciplinary or other special duties.
A large tropical Old World lizard with a long neck, narrow head, forked tongue, strong claws, and a short body. Monitors were formerly believed to give warning of crocodiles.
A shallow-draught warship mounting one or two heavy guns for bombardment.
Observe and check the progress or quality of (something) over a period of time; keep under systematic review.
Maintain regular surveillance over.
Listen to and report on (a foreign radio broadcast or a telephone conversation)
Check or regulate the technical quality of (a radio transmission or television signal)
--Examples--
‘a heart monitor’
‘a monitor aboard the vessel said he had measured radiation levels ten times the normal level’
‘the deployment of troops went ahead despite the shooting down of an EC monitor's helicopter’
‘the independent judicial monitor’
‘radio monitors reported they heard the pilot say he was heading for Paris’
‘the playback can be displayed on an external television screen or monitor’
‘I was amazed at the quality of the sound coming from the monitors’
‘he was a school monitor and a choir boy’
‘equipment was installed to monitor air quality’
‘he was a man of routine and it was easy for an enemy to monitor his movements’
‘listening devices were used to monitor conversations’
‘it was not easy to discover exactly how many calls were monitored’
‘a sound assistant monitors the signal on headphones’

--Word--
monkey 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small to medium-sized primate that typically has a long tail, most kinds of which live in trees in tropical countries.
(in general use) any primate.
A mischievous person, especially a child.
A person who is dominated or controlled by another (with reference to the monkey traditionally kept by an organ-grinder).
A sum of £500.
A piledriving machine consisting of a heavy hammer or ram working vertically in a groove.
Behave in a silly or playful way.
Tamper with.
Ape; mimic.
--Examples--
‘where have you been, you little monkey!’
‘I saw them monkeying about by the shop’
‘don't monkey with that lock!’
‘then marched the Three who monkeyed our Great and Dead’
--Word--
monkey 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small to medium-sized primate that typically has a long tail, most kinds of which live in trees in tropical countries.
(in general use) any primate.
A mischievous person, especially a child.
A person who is dominated or controlled by another (with reference to the monkey traditionally kept by an organ-grinder).
A sum of £500.
A piledriving machine consisting of a heavy hammer or ram working vertically in a groove.
Behave in a silly or playful way.
Tamper with.
Ape; mimic.
--Examples--
‘where have you been, you little monkey!’
‘I saw them monkeying about by the shop’
‘don't monkey with that lock!’
‘then marched the Three who monkeyed our Great and Dead’
--Word--
monkey 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small to medium-sized primate that typically has a long tail, most kinds of which live in trees in tropical countries.
(in general use) any primate.
A mischievous person, especially a child.
A person who is dominated or controlled by another (with reference to the monkey traditionally kept by an organ-grinder).
A sum of £500.
A piledriving machine consisting of a heavy hammer or ram working vertically in a groove.
Behave in a silly or playful way.
Tamper with.
Ape; mimic.
--Examples--
‘where have you been, you little monkey!’
‘I saw them monkeying about by the shop’
‘don't monkey with that lock!’
‘then marched the Three who monkeyed our Great and Dead’
--Word--
monkey-face 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A face like that of a monkey; an amusing or funny face.
Caribbean informal. A grimace, especially one intended to frighten, or made by a child as a sign of disrespect or annoyance.
US. A freshwater mussel, Quadrula metanevra (family Unionidae), with a yellow to light brown shell, found in medium to large rivers in parts of the United States. Also (with distinguishing word): any other mussel of this genus.
United States regional. The barn owl, Tyto alba.
--Examples--
--Word--
monkey-face 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A face like that of a monkey; an amusing or funny face.
Caribbean informal. A grimace, especially one intended to frighten, or made by a child as a sign of disrespect or annoyance.
US. A freshwater mussel, Quadrula metanevra (family Unionidae), with a yellow to light brown shell, found in medium to large rivers in parts of the United States. Also (with distinguishing word): any other mussel of this genus.
United States regional. The barn owl, Tyto alba.

--Type--

--Meanings--
Having a face like that of a monkey.

noun
--Meanings--
A plant of boggy ground, having yellow or red flowers which resemble snapdragons.

--Meanings--

monkey-pod 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The rain tree or saman, Albizia saman (also "monkey-pod tree"); the wood of this tree.
--Examples--
--Word--
monkey-pot 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The lidded woody capsule of any of several trees of the genus Lecythis (family Lecythidaceae), of tropical South America, which is used to trap monkeys; (more fully "monkey-pot tree") a tree of the genus Lecythis or the family Lecythidaceae.
A vessel used in tropical countries for cooling drinking water.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--

A vessel used in tropical countries for cooling drinking water.

--Word--
Mon-Khmer 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a family of languages spoken throughout SE Asia, of which the most important are Mon and Khmer. They are distantly related to Munda, with which they form the Austro-Asiatic phylum or superfamily.
The Mon-Khmer group of languages.

monocarp 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
monocentric 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Science. Having a single centre.
Optics. Of a compound lens: having a common centre of curvature for all its components.
Botany. Of the thallus of fungi of the order Chytridiales: having a single centre of growth and development.
Cell Biology. Having a single centromere.
Optics. A monocentric lens.
Cell Biology. A monocentric chromosome.
--Examples--
--Word--
monocephalous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a stem, stalk, etc.: bearing a single capitulum or umbel. Of a plant: having its flowers in a single capitulum or umbel.

--Word--
Monoceros 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An inconspicuous constellation (the Unicorn), lying on the celestial equator in the Milky Way between Canis Major and Canis Minor.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Monoceros.

‘the star Alpha Monocerotis’

monochlamydeous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having only one series of perianth segments, i.e. not having the perianth differentiated into corolla and calyx; specifically (now rare) belonging to the Monochlamydeae, a division or subclass of dictyledonous plants having flowers with only one series of perianth segments or sometimes no perianth, including the Chenopodiaceae, Euphorbiaceae, etc.

--Word--
monocotyl 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Chiefly North American= "monocotyledonous".
--Examples--
--Word--
monocotyledon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A flowering plant with an embryo that bears a single cotyledon (seed leaf). Monocotyledons constitute the smaller of the two great divisions of flowering plants, and typically have elongated stalkless leaves with parallel veins (e.g. grasses, lilies, palms).
--Examples--
--Word--
monocotyledonous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
monocotyledon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A flowering plant with an embryo that bears a single cotyledon (seed leaf). Monocotyledons constitute the smaller of the two great divisions of flowering plants, and typically have elongated stalkless leaves with parallel veins (e.g. grasses, lilies, palms).
--Examples--
--Word--
monocot 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A monocotyledon.

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
monocultural 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
monoculture 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The cultivation of a single crop in a given area.
--Examples--
‘the replacement of natural forest with pine monoculture’
--Word--
monoculus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Medicine. A bandage for one eye. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
monodactyl 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
monodactyly 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A condition in which there is only one finger or toe on each hand or foot.
--Examples--
--Word--
monodactyl 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
monodactylous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Zoology and Medicine. Having only one digit, finger, or toe (as a normal condition in some mammals or a congenital abnormality in humans and other vertebrates).
Zoology and Entomology. Having a single claw, especially one that is able to fold back on a leg in order to grasp.
--Examples--
--Word--
monodelphic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, characteristic of, or designating nematodes whose females have a single reproductive tract (ovary, oviduct, and uterus).
--Examples--
--Word--
monodelphous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, belonging to, or characteristic of mammals whose females have a single uterus and vagina (i.e. all mammals other than marsupials and monotremes).
--Examples--
--Word--
monodermic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having, consisting of, or derived from a single germinal layer.
--Examples--
--Word--
monody 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An ode sung by a single actor in a Greek tragedy.
A poem lamenting a person's death.
Music with only one melodic line.
--Examples--
‘the Italian masters of monody’

--Type--

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
monodomous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a colony of social hymenoptera, especially ants: occupying a single nest. Of a population or species: consisting of such colonies. Also, of any other animal: permanently based at a single location (rare). Opposed to polydomous.
--Examples--
--Word--
monodon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: the narwhal, Monodon monoceros. Now (in form Monodon): the monotypic genus (family Monodontidae) that comprises the narwhal.
--Examples--
--Word--
monodont 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of an animal: †having one persistent tusk or tooth (obsolete). Of a tooth: = "homodont".
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dramatic piece for one performer.

mono-dramatist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A writer or performer of monodramas.
--Examples--
--Word--
monodromy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A property of certain functions f(z) of a complex variable. Usually attributive.
--Examples--
--Word--
monodromic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or exhibiting monodromy. Also (of a function): having a single value for each value of the variable.
--Examples--
--Word--
monoecy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Monoecia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the Linnaean artificial system: the twenty-first class of plants, comprising those which have the stamens and pistils (male and female organs) in separate flowers on the same plant.
--Examples--
--Word--
monoecy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
monoecious 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a plant or invertebrate animal) having both the male and female reproductive organs in the same individual; hermaphrodite.

monoenergetic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(Of particles or radiation) having energies confined to a very narrow range; consisting of such particles; emitting such radiation.

monoester 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any compound having a single ester group in its molecule.
--Examples--
--Word--
monoestrous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating a mammalian sexual cycle in which the periods of oestrus occur singly and at relatively long intervals, especially annually.
--Examples--
--Word--
monoethanolamine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A viscous high-boiling liquid, H₂NCH₂CH₂OH, used in making detergents; 2-aminoethanol.

monofilament

--Meanings--

monoflagellate 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
monogamy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The practice of marrying or state of being married to one person at a time.
The practice or state of having a sexual relationship with only one partner.
The habit of having only one mate at a time.
--Examples--
‘Judaism has journeyed from polygamy to strict monogamy’
‘younger men were more likely to stray, saying monogamy was outdated’
‘monogamy is rare in most animal groups, but is common among birds’
--Word--
monogamian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to monogamy; practising monogamy, monogamous. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
monogamic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to monogamy; practising monogamy, monogamous.
--Examples--
--Word--
monogamy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The practice of marrying or state of being married to one person at a time.
The practice or state of having a sexual relationship with only one partner.
The habit of having only one mate at a time.

--Examples--
--Word--
monogamist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
monogamous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Involving marriage to one person at a time.
Having a sexual relationship with only one partner at a time.
Having only one mate at a time.
--Examples--
‘under Canadian law all marriages must be monogamous’
‘she admits that she has never been strictly monogamous’
‘with me it was a monogamous relationship’
‘penguins form monogamous couples for breeding purposes’
--Word--
monogamously 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that involves marriage to one person at a time.
In a way that involves a sexual relationship with only one partner.
In a way that involves having only one mate at a time.
--Examples--
‘in the historical period, Greeks were expected to marry monogamously’
‘Crispin and I have been dating monogamously for two years’
‘zebra finches mate monogamously’
--Word--
monogamousness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Monogamy.
--Examples--
--Word--
monogastric 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Anatomy. Of a muscle: having a single ‘belly’ or fleshy part; (originally) specifically †designating the tensor tympani (obsolete). Compare "digastric"rare.
Zoology. Of an animal: having a single stomach or digestive cavity.
--Examples--
--Word--
monogeneity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or property of being monogenic.
--Examples--
--Word--
monogenean 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to a group of flukes that are chiefly external or gill parasites of fish and only require a single host.
A monogenean fluke.
--Examples--
--Word--
monogeneity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or property of being monogenic.
--Examples--
--Word--
monogeneous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Mathematics= "monogenic".
--Examples--
--Word--
monogenesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The theory that humans are all descended from a single pair of ancestors.
The hypothetical origination of language or of a surname from a single source at a particular place and time.

--Word--
monogenous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Biology and Ethnology. Having a single common origin, monophyletic; of or relating to monogenism. Now only in extended use (rare).
Mathematics= "monogenic". rare.
Zoology= "monogenic".
--Examples--
--Word--
monogerm 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating or relating to varieties of sugar beet, etc., in which each seed ball has its contents reduced to a single embryo and so gives rise to only one seedling.

--Word--
monogram 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A motif of two or more interwoven letters, typically a person's initials, used to identify a personal possession or as a logo.
Decorate with a monogram.
--Examples--
‘a handkerchief with his monogram embroidered on one corner’
‘Irish linen napkins monogrammed with the initials C.S’
‘monogrammed sheets’

--Word--
monograph 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A detailed written study of a single specialized subject or an aspect of it.
Write a monograph on; treat in a monograph.
--Examples--
‘they are publishing a series of monographs on music in late medieval and Renaissance cities’
‘Meissner first monographed the plant in 1826’

--Word--
monoid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A surface which possesses a conical point of the highest possible order (i.e. n − 1, where n is the order of the equation defining the surface). Now rare.
A semigroup possessing an identity element.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
One; alone; single.
(forming names of compounds) containing one atom or group of a specified kind.
--Examples--
‘monocoque’
‘monoamine’

--Type--

--Examples--
--Word--
monolith 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large single upright block of stone, especially one shaped into or serving as a pillar or monument.
A very large and characterless building.
A large block of concrete sunk in water, e.g. in the building of a dock.
A large, impersonal political, corporate, or social structure regarded as indivisible and slow to change.
--Examples--
‘we passed Stonehenge, the strange stone monoliths silhouetted against the horizon’
‘the 72-storey monolith overlooking the waterfront’
‘independent voices have been crowded out by the media monoliths’
--Word--
monolithal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Monolithic.
--Examples--
--Word--
monolithic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Formed of a single large block of stone.
(of a building) very large and characterless.
(of an organization or system) large, powerful, indivisible, and slow to change.
(of a solid-state circuit) composed of active and passive components formed in a single chip.
--Examples--
‘later Byzantine columns were monolithic and usually made of marble’
‘IPC moved the paper from Covent Garden to the monolithic King's Reach Tower’
‘rejecting any move towards a monolithic European superstate’
‘a video converter on a single monolithic chip’
--Word--
monolithically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a monolithic form or manner.
--Examples--
--Word--
monolithism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or fact of being monolithic.
--Examples--
--Word--
monolith 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large single upright block of stone, especially one shaped into or serving as a pillar or monument.
A very large and characterless building.
A large block of concrete sunk in water, e.g. in the building of a dock.
A large, impersonal political, corporate, or social structure regarded as indivisible and slow to change.
--Examples--
‘we passed Stonehenge, the strange stone monoliths silhouetted against the horizon’
‘the 72-storey monolith overlooking the waterfront’
‘independent voices have been crowded out by the media monoliths’

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
monologue 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A long speech by one actor in a play or film, or as part of a theatrical or broadcast programme.
A long, tedious speech by one person during a conversation.
--Examples--
‘he was reciting some of the great monologues of Shakespeare’
‘he had a long and exacting monologue at the end of the film’
‘Fred carried on with his monologue as if I hadn't spoken’

--Word--
monologist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The speaker or writer of a monologue.
--Examples--
‘a long-form improvisation in which a monologist tells personal stories’
‘his legendary reputation as a garrulous monologist’
--Word--
monologize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Deliver a monologue or long speech.
--Examples--
‘they monologize about the unexpected results of decisions’

--Word--
monologue 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A long speech by one actor in a play or film, or as part of a theatrical or broadcast programme.
A long, tedious speech by one person during a conversation.
--Examples--
‘he was reciting some of the great monologues of Shakespeare’
‘he had a long and exacting monologue at the end of the film’
‘Fred carried on with his monologue as if I hadn't spoken’
--Word--
monologue 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A long speech by one actor in a play or film, or as part of a theatrical or broadcast programme.
A long, tedious speech by one person during a conversation.

‘he had a long and exacting monologue at the end of the film’

--Word--
monomark 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A combination of letters or figures or a mixture of the two used to identify an individual person (especially for the purposes of postal delivery), and as a mark to identify personal property.

monomyarian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of a bivalve mollusc: having only one (posterior) adductor muscle; relating to or characteristic of such a mollusc. Formerly also: †belonging to the former group Monomyaria of bivalves (obsolete).
A bivalve mollusc of a type having only one (posterior) adductor muscle (e.g. an oyster).

mononucleotide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several compounds which are formed from a single molecule each of phosphoric acid, a sugar, and a heterocyclic base, and are the units of which nucleic acids are composed; a monomeric nucleotide.

monophase 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Electricity (Of an electric current or signal) exhibiting a single phase; (of an electrical device) operating on a single phase.
Physical Chemistry. Of a substance or mixture: consisting of a single phase.
Science. Of a process, or a curve representing it: occurring or performed in a single stage.
Physical Chemistry. A substance or mixture consisting of a single phase.
--Examples--
--Word--
monophasic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Electricity (Of an electric current or signal) exhibiting a single phase; (of an electrical device) operating on a single phase.
Physiology. Designating or relating to (a record of) a nerve impulse that is of the same sign throughout, and experimental arrangements devised to give such records.
Physical Chemistry. Of a substance or mixture: consisting of a single phase.
Science. Of a process, or a curve representing it: occurring in a single phase; not marked by two or more stages of different character.

monophone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Phonetics. Originally, H. E. Palmer's name for: a phone or phoneme consisting of a single unit of sound. In later use more generally: a phone, as distinguished from speech units comprising more than one phone.
