--Word--
monopoly 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The exclusive possession or control of the supply of or trade in a commodity or service.
A company or group having exclusive control over a commodity or service.
A commodity or service in the exclusive control of a company or group.
The exclusive possession, control, or exercise of something.
A board game in which players engage in simulated property and financial dealings using imitation money. It was invented in the US and the name was coined by Charles Darrowc.1935.
--Examples--
‘the state's monopoly of radio and television broadcasting’
‘passenger services were largely in the hands of state-owned monopolies’
‘France's electricity monopoly, EDF’
‘electricity, gas, and water were considered to be natural monopolies’
‘men don't have a monopoly on unrequited love’
--Word--

noun
--Meanings--
The exclusive possession or control of the supply of or trade in a commodity or service.
A company or group having exclusive control over a commodity or service.
A commodity or service in the exclusive control of a company or group.

noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
monopolize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of an organization or group) obtain exclusive possession or control of (a trade, commodity, or service)
Have or take the greatest share of.
Get or keep exclusively to oneself.
--Examples--
‘they instituted press censorship and monopolized the means of communication’
‘the bigger clubs monopolize the most profitable sponsorships and TV deals’
‘Sophie monopolized the guest of honour for most of the evening’

monopsychism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The theory, found in Neoplatonic thought and in the Averroistic school of medieval Aristotelianism, that there is but one immortal soul or intellect in which all humans somehow share.

adjective
--Meanings--
Physiology. Relating to or involving vision with one eye; monocular.
--Examples--
--Word--
monoptical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That has only one eye; one-eyed.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

monosexuality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Biology. The condition of having reproductive organs of one sex only.
The condition of having members of one sex predominant. rare.
The condition of having sexual relations in which one seeks to gratify only oneself. rare.
The state or condition of being sexually attracted to members of one sex only. Opposed to bisexuality.

monosymmetric 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Chiefly Botany. Divisible into exactly similar halves in one plane only; (of a flower) zygomorphic. Also (Engineering): having, or designating a cross-section with, a single plane of symmetry.
--Examples--

--Word--
monosodium glutamate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A compound which occurs naturally as a breakdown product of proteins and is used as a flavour enhancer in food (although itself tasteless). A traditional ingredient in oriental cooking, it was originally obtained from seaweed but is now mainly made from bean and cereal protein.
--Examples--
--Word--
monosomatic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Geology. Consisting of a single crystal or a single mineral.
Genetics. Of a somatic tissue or cell of a plant: having the number of chromosomes typical of the species (usually the diploid number).

monothetic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That assumes or is based on a single essential element or idea.
Specifically. Of a system or method of classification, or its categories: based on a single characteristic, or a series of single characteristics.
Mathematics. Of a group: containing a cyclic subgroup whose closure is the group itself.

monotocardian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Designating or relating to prosobranch molluscs having only one gill and whose heart consists of one auricle and one ventricle (formerly placed in a suborder Monotocardia).
A monotocardian gastropod.

--Word--
monotonal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of music, speech, etc.: having little or no variety in tone or pitch. Of a person: speaking in a monotone.
Of or in a single colour.
--Examples--
--Word--
monotone 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A continuing sound, especially of a person's voice, that is unchanging in pitch and without intonation.
(of a voice or other sound) unchanging in pitch; without intonation or expressiveness.
Without colour or variety; dull.
--Examples--
‘he sat and answered the questions in a monotone’
‘his monotone reading of the two-hour report’
‘the monotone housing estates of the big cities’
--Word--
monotone 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A continuing sound, especially of a person's voice, that is unchanging in pitch and without intonation.
(of a voice or other sound) unchanging in pitch; without intonation or expressiveness.
Without colour or variety; dull.
--Examples--
‘he sat and answered the questions in a monotone’
‘his monotone reading of the two-hour report’
‘the monotone housing estates of the big cities’
--Word--
monotony 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Lack of variety and interest; tedious repetition and routine.
Sameness of pitch or tone in a sound or utterance.
--Examples--
‘you can become resigned to the monotony of captivity’
‘depression flattens the voice almost to monotony’

adjective
--Meanings--

Speaking or uttered with an unchanging pitch or tone.
--Examples--
‘her dour, monotonic husband’

--Word--
Monotremata 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Treated as plural. The single order of mammals included in the subclass Prototheria, comprising egg-laying mammals which which have a common opening for the urogenital and digestive systems; animals of this order (collectively or individually), monotremes.
--Examples--
--Word--
monotrematous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Monotreme; resembling the monotremes; (more generally) having a single aperture.
--Examples--
--Word--
monotreme 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A primitive mammal that lays large yolky eggs and has a common opening for the urogenital and digestive systems. Monotremes are now restricted to Australia and New Guinea, and comprise the platypus and the echidnas.
--Examples--
--Word--
monotrichous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a bacterial cell: having a single polar flagellum.
--Examples--
--Word--
monotrochal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a trochophore larva: having a single band or ring of cilia round the body.
--Examples--
--Word--
Monotropa 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of saprophytic (mycotrophic) dicotyledonous plants (family Ericaceae) which have brownish-yellow stems, scale leaves lacking chlorophyll, and drooping flowers; (also monotropa) either of the two plants of this genus, M. uniflora (the Indian pipe) and (more fully "yellow monotropa") M. hypopitys (the yellow bird's nest).
--Examples--
--Word--
monotropaceous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the family Monotropaceae of saprophytic (mycotrophic) plants, of which Monotropa is the type genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
monotrophic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Feeding on one kind of food; specifically (of a parasitic organism) infesting only one host species; feeding on one kind of food; = monoxenous. Of a bee: = monotropic.
--Examples--
--Word--
monotropy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The existence of allotropes of an element, one of which is stable and the others metastable under all known conditions.
--Examples--
--Word--
monotropic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Physical Chemistry. Exhibiting monotropy.
Ecology. Of a bee or other pollinator: that visits the flowers of only one species.
Medicine. Involving a single tropic hormone.
Virology. Infecting monocytes or macrophages (especially as opposed to lymphocytes).

--Meanings--
A mineral now regarded as identical with sillimanite.

mons 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A town in southern Belgium, capital of the province of Hainaut; population 91,152 (2008). It was the scene in August 1914 of the first major battle of the First World War between British and German forces.

Munsee 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a North American Indian people formerly inhabiting the headwaters of the Delaware River in eastern North America.
The Algonquian language spoken by the Munsee and related peoples of the lower Hudson River Valley.
Of, relating to, or designating the Munsee or their language.

monsoon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A seasonal prevailing wind in the region of South and SE Asia, blowing from the south-west between May and September and bringing rain (the wet monsoon), or from the north-east between October and April (the dry monsoon).
The rainy season accompanying the wet monsoon.

--Word--
monsoon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A seasonal prevailing wind in the region of South and SE Asia, blowing from the south-west between May and September and bringing rain (the wet monsoon), or from the north-east between October and April (the dry monsoon).
The rainy season accompanying the wet monsoon.
--Examples--
--Word--
monster 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large, ugly, and frightening imaginary creature.
An inhumanly cruel or wicked person.
A rude or badly behaved person, typically a child.
A thing of extraordinary or daunting size.
A congenitally malformed or mutant animal or plant.
Criticize or reprimand severely.
--Examples--
‘a monster with the head of a hyena and hindquarters of a wolf’
‘a world of fable, inhabited by other-worldly monsters’
‘he was an unfeeling, treacherous monster’
‘he's only a year old, but already he is a little monster’
‘this is a monster of a book, almost 500 pages’
‘a monster 36lb carp’
‘my mum used to monster me for coming home so late’
--Word--
monstera 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large tropical American climbing plant of the arum family, which typically has divided or perforated leaves and corky aerial roots. Several kinds are cultivated as indoor plants when young.
--Examples--

monsterer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who ‘monsters’. Originally: †one who exaggerates to a remarkable degree (obsolete). Now: one who criticizes harshly or savagely (Australian informal).

monstrosity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A thing, especially a building, which is very large and unsightly.
A grossly malformed animal or plant.
A thing which is outrageously evil or wrong.
The state or fact of being monstrous.
--Examples--
‘the shopping centre, a multi-storey monstrosity of raw concrete’
‘how could anyone be capable of such monstrosities?’
‘had my tone of reason in the face of monstrosity finally registered?’
--Word--
monstrosity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A thing, especially a building, which is very large and unsightly.
A grossly malformed animal or plant.
A thing which is outrageously evil or wrong.
The state or fact of being monstrous.
--Examples--
‘the shopping centre, a multi-storey monstrosity of raw concrete’
‘how could anyone be capable of such monstrosities?’
‘had my tone of reason in the face of monstrosity finally registered?’
--Word--
monstrous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having the ugly or frightening appearance of a monster.
Inhumanly or outrageously evil or wrong.
Extraordinarily and dauntingly large.
--Examples--
‘monstrous, bug-eyed fish’
‘he wasn't lovable, he was monstrous and violent’
‘it is a monstrous waste of money’
‘the monstrous tidal wave swamped the surrounding countryside’

montage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The technique of selecting, editing, and piecing together separate sections of film to form a continuous whole.
A sequence of film made using the technique of montage.
The technique of producing a new composite whole from fragments of pictures, text, or music.
--Examples--
‘montage was a useful device for overcoming the drawbacks of silent film’
‘montage sequences’
‘a montage of excerpts from the film’
‘the art of montage in theatre and film’
‘a montage of photographs’

Montagna, Bartolommeo Cincani 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1450–1523), Italian painter. He is noted for his altarpiece Sacra Conversazione (1499).

--Word--
Montagnais 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a North American people living in a vast area of Canada from north of the Gulf of St Lawrence to the southern shores of Hudson Bay.
The Algonquian language of the Montagnais, closely related to Cree. It has about 7,000 speakers.
Relating to the Montagnais or their language.

Montaigne, Michel de 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1533–92), French essayist; full name Michel Eyquem de Montaigne. Widely regarded as the originator of the modern essay, he wrote about prominent personalities and ideas of his age in his scepticalEssays (1580; 1588).

Montana 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state in the western US, on the Canadian border to the east of the Rocky Mountains; population 967,440 (est. 2008); capital, Helena. Acquired from France as part of the Louisiana Purchase in 1803, it became the 41st state of the US in 1889.

Montanism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The tenets of a heretical millenarian and ascetic Christian sect that set great store by prophecy, founded in Phrygia by the priest Montanus in the middle of the 2nd century.

Montauk 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating a North American Indian people inhabiting the eastern end of Long Island, New York or their Algonquian language. Also: of or relating to any of various other peoples inhabiting this area and subjugated by the Montauk.
A member of the Montauk people or of one of the tribes subjugated by them.
The Eastern Algonquian language of the Montauk, closely related to Mohegan (of which it is sometimes classified as a dialect). Now historical.

Montcalm, Marquis de 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1712–59), French general; born Louis Joseph de Montcalm-Gozon. He defended Quebec against British troops under General Wolfe, but was defeated and fatally wounded in the battle on the Plains of Abraham.

--Word--
Montem 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A festival celebrated (at first annually, later triennially) by the scholars of Eton College, who processed in fancy dress to ‘Salt Hill’, a mound near Slough, to raise money towards the expenses of the senior colleger (called the ‘Captain of the Montem’) when he went up to King's College, Cambridge.

mons

Montespan, Marquise de 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1641–1707), French noblewoman; born Françoise-Athénaïs de Rochechouart. She was mistress of Louis XIV from 1667 to 1679, and had seven illegitimate children by him. She subsequently fell from favour when the king became attracted to the children's governess, Madame de Maintenon.
--Examples--
--Word--
Montesquieu, Charles 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Baron de La Brède et de (1689–1755), French political philosopher; born Charles Louis de Secondat. His reputation rests chiefly on L'Esprit des lois (1748), a comparative study of political systems in which he championed the separation of judicial, legislative, and executive powers as being most conducive to individual liberty.
--Examples--
--Word--

Monteverdi, Claudio 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1567–1643), Italian composer. His madrigals are noted for their use of harmonic dissonance; other important works include his opera Orfeo (1607) and his sacred Vespers (1610).

Montezuma quail 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plump, short-tailed quail, Cyrtonyx montezumae (family Odontophoridae), native to the southern United States and Mexico, the male of which has a bold black and white facial pattern.
--Examples--
--Word--
Montfort, Simon de 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1165–1218), French soldier. From 1209 he led the Albigensian Crusade against the Cathars in southern France.
Earl of Leicester (c.1208–65), English soldier, born in Normandy. He was the son of Simon de Montfort. He led the baronial opposition to Henry III, defeating the king at Lewes in 1264 and summoning a Parliament (1265). He was defeated and killed by reorganized royal forces under Henry's son (later Edward I).
--Examples--
--Word--
Montgolfier 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Joseph Michel (1740–1810) and Jacques Étienne (1745–99), French inventors and pioneers in hot-air ballooning. In 1782 they built a large balloon from linen and paper and successfully lifted a number of animals; the first human ascents followed in 1783.
--Examples--
--Word--
Montgolfier 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Joseph Michel (1740–1810) and Jacques Étienne (1745–99), French inventors and pioneers in hot-air ballooning. In 1782 they built a large balloon from linen and paper and successfully lifted a number of animals; the first human ascents followed in 1783.

--Meanings--
The state capital of Alabama; population 202,696 (est. 2008).

Montgomeryshire 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A former county of central Wales. It became a part of Powys in 1974.

--Word--
month 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of the twelve named periods into which a year is divided.
A period of time between the same dates in successive calendar months.
A period of 28 days or four weeks.
--Examples--
‘the first six months of 1992’
‘it was the end of the month’
‘the president's rule was extended for six more months from March 3’
--Word--
monthly 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Done, produced, or occurring once a month.
Once a month; every month.
A magazine that is published once a month.
A menstrual period.
--Examples--
‘the Council held monthly meetings’
‘most of us get paid monthly’
‘an Anglo-American monthly whose appeal was always international’
‘cramps from your monthlies so bad you could weep’

--Word--
month's mind 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly Roman Catholic Church. The commemoration of a deceased person by the celebration of a requiem mass, prayers, etc., on a day one month from the date of the death or funeral.
Used allusively or humorously as a synonym for "mind": an inclination, fancy, liking. Especially in "to have (also bear) a month's mind". "to be in a month's mind": to have a strong expectation (rare). Now regional.
--Examples--
--Word--
Monty Pythonesque 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or reminiscent of Monty Python's Flying Circus; = "Pythonesque".
--Examples--
--Word--
monticellite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An orthorhombic mineral of the olivine group which is a calcium magnesium silicate and usually occurs as yellowish crystals.

--Meanings--

monticuliporoid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the genus Monticulipora or related genera of massive stony colonial bryozoans found as fossils from early Palaeozoic times.
A bryozoan of the group typified by the genus Monticulipora.

Montmartre 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A district in northern Paris, on a hill above the River Seine, much frequented by artists in the late 19th and early 20th centuries when it was a separate village.

Montparnasse 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A district of Paris, on the left bank of the River Seine. Frequented in the late 19th century by writers and artists, it is traditionally associated with Parisian cultural life.

Montpelier 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Vermont, in the north central part of the state, on the Winooski River; population 7,760 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
Montpellier 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in southern France, near the Mediterranean coast, capital of Languedoc-Roussillon; population 254,974 (2006). A distinguished medical school and university, world-famous in medieval times, was founded there in 1221.

montre 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An organ stop having pipes that form part of the visible case of the instrument; especially the open diapason of the great organ.
--Examples--
--Word--
Montreal 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A port on the St Lawrence River in Quebec, south-eastern Canada; population 1,162,693 (2006). Founded in 1642, Montreal was under French rule until 1763; almost two thirds of its present-day population are French-speaking. French name Montréal /mɔ̃ʀeal/.
--Examples--
--Word--
Montreux 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A resort town in south-western Switzerland, at the east end of Lake Geneva; population 23,800 (2007). Since the 1960s it has hosted annual festivals of both jazz and television.
--Examples--
--Word--
montroydite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Native mercuric oxide, HgO, an orthorhombic mineral occurring as deep red translucent to transparent crystals.
--Examples--
--Word--
Montrose, James Graham 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
1st Marquis of Montrose (1612–50), Scottish general. Montrose supported Charles I in the English Civil War and inflicted a dramatic series of defeats on the stronger Covenanter forces in the north before being defeated. In 1650 he attempted to restore Charles II, but was betrayed to the Covenanters and hanged.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mont. 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Montana.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mont St. Michel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A rocky islet off the coast of Normandy, northwestern France. An island only at high tide, it is surrounded by sandbanks and linked to the mainland by a causeway. It is home to a medieval Benedictine abbey-fortress.
--Examples--
--Word--
Montserrat 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island in the Caribbean, one of the Leeward Islands; population 5,000 (estimated 2015); capital, Plymouth. It was colonized by Irish settlers in 1632 and is now a British overseas territory. Since 1995 it has been severely affected by the ongoing eruption of the Soufrière Hills volcano, causing the evacuation of the southern part of the island, including the now destroyed city of Plymouth.

monument 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A statue, building, or other structure erected to commemorate a notable person or event.
A statue or other structure placed over a grave in memory of the dead.
A building, structure, or site that is of historical importance or interest.
An enduring and memorable example of something.
--Examples--
‘a simple stone monument marked the nearby crash site’
‘a monument to Magellan is in the main square of the city’
‘a handsome monument of granite is placed over the grave’
‘the amphitheatre is one of the many Greek monuments in Sicily’
‘recordings that are a monument to the art of playing the piano’

monzonite

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
moon 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The natural satellite of the earth, visible (chiefly at night) by reflected light from the sun.
A natural satellite of any planet.
A month.
Anything that one could desire.
Behave or move in a listless and aimless manner.
Act in a dreamily infatuated manner.
Expose one's buttocks to someone in order to insult or amuse them.
--Examples--
‘there was no moon, but a sky sparkling with brilliant stars’
‘the first man on the moon’
‘Titan, Saturn's largest moon’
‘that wonderful night four moons ago’
‘I got my first laser printer many moons ago’
‘you must know he'd give you the moon’
‘I don't want her mooning about in the morning’
‘Timothy's mooning over her like a schoolboy’
‘the crew dropped their trousers and mooned at them’
‘Dan had whipped round, bent over, and mooned the crowd’

blanch 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make white or pale by extracting colour.
Whiten (a plant) by depriving it of light.
Flinch or grow pale from shock, fear, or a similar emotion.
Prepare (vegetables) for freezing or further cooking by immersing briefly in boiling water.
Peel (almonds) by scalding them.
--Examples--
‘the cold light blanched her face’
‘blanch endive by covering plants with large flowerpots’
‘he visibly blanched at this reminder of mortality’
‘blanch corn in boiling water for one minute’
‘blanched almonds’

bright 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Giving out or reflecting much light; shining.
Full of light.
(of a period of time) having sunny, cloudless weather.
(of colour) vivid and bold.
Having a vivid colour.
Intelligent and quick-witted.
Cheerful and lively.
(of someone's future) likely to be successful and happy.
(of sound) clear, vibrant, and typically high-pitched.
Brightly.
Bold and vivid colours.
Headlights switched to full beam.
--Examples--
‘the sun was dazzlingly bright’
‘her bright, dark eyes’
‘the rooms are bright and spacious’
‘the long, bright days of June’
‘the bright green leaves’
‘a bright tie’
‘a bright idea’
‘a bright young journalist’
‘at breakfast she would be persistently bright and chirpy’
‘she gave a bright smile’
‘these young people have a bright future ahead of them’
‘her voice is fresh and bright’
‘a full moon shining bright’
‘a choice of colours from pastels through to brights’
‘he turned the brights on and we drove along the dirt road’

--Word--
Mooney 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Attributive Used with reference to various concepts relating to the measurement of physical properties of rubber and other elastic solids, and instruments employed in such measurement; "Mooney material"noun a material (such as rubber) whose behaviour under large elastic deformation approximates to that of an ideal, perfectly elastic material which is isotropic and incompressible. "Mooney viscometer"noun a type of viscometer for measuring the viscosity of unvulcanized rubber.
--Examples--
--Word--
moon-eye 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A herring-like freshwater fish with large eyes, that lives in the south of the Great Lakes region of North America.
--Examples--
--Word--
moon-eye 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A herring-like freshwater fish with large eyes, that lives in the south of the Great Lakes region of North America.
--Examples--
--Word--
moon-eyed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a horse: affected with recurrent uveitis; moon-blind.
Having large, wide open eyes.

mooner 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Informal. A person who moons or idles about.
Slang. A person who exposes his or her buttocks.
--Examples--
--Word--
moon-face 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A moon-shaped face; a round full face. Also poetic: a face likened to the moon in beauty.
Medicine. The rounded face characteristic of persons with chronically elevated glucocorticoid levels, whether endogenously produced (as in Cushing's disease) or as the result of high-dose therapy.
--Examples--
--Word--
moon-faced 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a round face.
--Examples--
‘he was a moon-faced, roly-poly little man’

--Word--
fern 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A flowerless plant which has feathery or leafy fronds and reproduces by spores released from the undersides of the fronds. Ferns have a vascular system for the transport of water and nutrients.
--Examples--

--Word--
moon 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The natural satellite of the earth, visible (chiefly at night) by reflected light from the sun.
A natural satellite of any planet.
A month.
Anything that one could desire.
Behave or move in a listless and aimless manner.
Act in a dreamily infatuated manner.
Expose one's buttocks to someone in order to insult or amuse them.
--Examples--
‘there was no moon, but a sky sparkling with brilliant stars’
‘the first man on the moon’
‘Titan, Saturn's largest moon’
‘that wonderful night four moons ago’
‘I got my first laser printer many moons ago’
‘you must know he'd give you the moon’
‘I don't want her mooning about in the morning’
‘Timothy's mooning over her like a schoolboy’
‘the crew dropped their trousers and mooned at them’
‘Dan had whipped round, bent over, and mooned the crowd’
--Word--
moonish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling or belonging to the moon; round like the full moon. Also: †influenced by the moon; acting as if so influenced, changeable, fickle (obsolete).
--Examples--

--Word--
mad 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, verb
--Meanings--
Mentally ill; insane.
(of behaviour or an idea) extremely foolish; not sensible.
In a frenzied mental or physical state.
(of a dog) rabid.
Very enthusiastic about someone or something.
Very exciting.
Very angry.
Great; remarkable.
Very; extremely.
Make (someone) mad.
--Examples--
‘he felt as if he were going mad’
‘Antony's mother told him he was mad to be leaving Dublin’
‘she pictured loved ones mad with anxiety about her’
‘it was a mad dash to get ready’
‘he's mad about football’
‘another myth is that Scorpios are sex-mad’
‘don't be mad at me’
‘I got mad respect for him’
‘this author has mad skills with the written word’
‘he was mad cool—we immediately hit it off’
‘had I but seen thy picture in this plight, it would have madded me’

moonraking 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of ‘raking’ the moon, or engaging in foolish or unprofitable activity. Chiefly figurative in "one's wits are (also have) gone moon-raking": used to indicate that a person has lost his or her reason (British regional).

moonwort 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A widely distributed fern with a single small frond of fan-shaped lobes and a separate spike bearing the spore-producing organs, growing typically in grassy uplands and old meadows.
--Examples--
--Word--
moonwort 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
moor 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A tract of open uncultivated upland, typically covered with heather.
A moor preserved for shooting.
A fen.
Make fast (a boat) by attaching it by cable or rope to the shore or to an anchor.
A member of a north-western African Muslim people of mixed Berber and Arab descent. In the 8th century they conquered the Iberian peninsula, but were finally driven out of their last stronghold in Granada at the end of the 15th century.
--Examples--
‘a little town in the moors’
‘a grouse moor’
‘twenty or so fishing boats were moored to the pierside’
‘we moored alongside a jetty’
--Word--
moorage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of mooring a boat or ship to the shore or to an anchor.
A place where a boat or ship is moored.
A fee charged for mooring a boat or ship.
--Examples--
‘regulations prohibiting the long-term moorage of vessels’
‘I left the boat on a knee-deep moorage for two summers’
‘the marinas provide moorage for 1,200 boats’
‘the boat owner hadn't paid the moorage’
--Word--

moor-berry

noun
--Meanings--

Moorhead 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A commercial city in western Minnesota, a transportation hub across the Red River of the North from Fargo in North Dakota; population 36,012 (est. 2008).

moory 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Marshy; specifically designating or consisting of a kind of soft, dark, peaty soil found in fenland and marshland; especially in "moory earth", "moory land".

--Word--
mooring 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A place where a boat or ship is moored.
The ropes, chains, or anchors by or to which a boat, ship, or buoy is moored.
--Examples--
‘they tied up at Water Gypsy's permanent moorings’
‘the great ship slipped her moorings and slid out into the Atlantic’

--Type--

Moor 2.

pout 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Push one's lips or one's bottom lip forward as an expression of petulant annoyance or in order to make oneself look sexually attractive.

moor 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A tract of open uncultivated upland, typically covered with heather.
A moor preserved for shooting.
A fen.
Make fast (a boat) by attaching it by cable or rope to the shore or to an anchor.
A member of a north-western African Muslim people of mixed Berber and Arab descent. In the 8th century they conquered the Iberian peninsula, but were finally driven out of their last stronghold in Granada at the end of the 15th century.
--Examples--
‘a little town in the moors’
‘a grouse moor’
‘twenty or so fishing boats were moored to the pierside’
‘we moored alongside a jetty’

noun

moosewood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A compact North American maple with large leaves and vertically striped bark. Moose often feed on the bark during severe winters.

--Word--
moot 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Subject to debate, dispute, or uncertainty.
Having little or no practical relevance, typically because the subject is too uncertain to allow a decision.
Raise (a question or topic) for discussion; suggest (an idea or possibility)
An assembly held for debate, especially in Anglo-Saxon and medieval times.
A regular gathering of people having a common interest.
A mock judicial proceeding set up to examine a hypothetical case as an academic exercise.
--Examples--
‘whether the temperature rise was mainly due to the greenhouse effect was a moot point’
‘it is a moot point whether such a controversial scheme would have succeeded’
‘the whole matter is becoming increasingly moot’
‘the scheme was first mooted last October’
‘the object of a moot is to provide practice in developing an argument’
--Word--
mootness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The condition of being moot; (US Law) the fact of having no practical significance or relevance.
--Examples--

--Word--
mooter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A speaker; a person who argues or engages in discussion; a lawyer who argues cases in a court of justice, a pleader. Now also: a person, especially a law student, who discusses a moot case.

--Word--
mop 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, abbreviation
--Meanings--
An implement consisting of a bundle of thick loose strings or a sponge attached to a handle, used for wiping floors or other surfaces.
An act of wiping something clean.
A thick mass of disordered hair.
Clean or soak up liquid from (something) by wiping.
Wipe (something) away from a surface.
Wipe sweat or tears from (one's face or eyes)
mop something up (also mop up)
Complete the military conquest of an area by capturing or killing remaining enemy troops.
An autumn fair or gathering at which farmhands and servants were hired.
Macanese pataca(s).
--Examples--
‘the kitchen needed a quick mop’
‘her tousled mop of blonde hair’
‘she mopped the floor and cleaned out two cupboards’
‘a barmaid rushed forward to mop up the spilt beer’
‘he pulled a handkerchief from his pocket to mop his brow’
‘troops mopped up the last pockets of resistance’
--Word--

noun
--Meanings--
A tree found in arid regions of southern Africa, with bitter-tasting leaves that are shaped like butterfly wings and fold together in intense heat.

mope 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Feel dejected and apathetic.
Wander about listlessly and aimlessly because of unhappiness or boredom.
A person given to prolonged spells of low spirits.
Low spirits; depression.
--Examples--
‘no use moping—things could be worse’
‘you spend too much time moping about the house’
‘a bunch of totally depressed mopes’
‘they switched to treating him like a child just bravely out of its mopes’

--Word--
mora 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Scottish Law. Undue delay in the assertion of a claim, etc.
Prosody. A unit of metrical time equal to the duration of a short syllable.
Linguistics. The smallest or basic unit of duration of a speech sound.
Any one of the (originally six) divisions of which the Spartan army was made up.
In South Asia: a stool; a footstool; a wicker chair.
A tall tree, Mora excelsa (family Caesalpiniaceae (Leguminosae)), native to the Caribbean and tropical South America (also "mora tree"); the wood of this tree.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Word--
moray 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A mainly nocturnal eel-like predatory fish of warm seas, that typically hides in crevices with just the head protruding.
A council area and former county of northern Scotland, bordered on the north by the Moray Firth; administrative centre, Elgin.

noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A mainly nocturnal eel-like predatory fish of warm seas, that typically hides in crevices with just the head protruding.
A council area and former county of northern Scotland, bordered on the north by the Moray Firth; administrative centre, Elgin.
--Examples--
--Word--
moral 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Concerned with the principles of right and wrong behaviour.
Concerned with or derived from the code of behaviour that is considered right or acceptable in a particular society.
Examining the nature of ethics and the foundations of good and bad character and conduct.
Holding or manifesting high principles for proper conduct.
A lesson that can be derived from a story or experience.
Standards of behaviour; principles of right and wrong.
--Examples--
‘the moral dimensions of medical intervention’
‘a moral judgement’
‘they have a moral obligation to pay the money back’
‘moral philosophers’
‘he prides himself on being a highly moral and ethical person’
‘he is a caring, moral man’
‘the moral of this story was that one must see the beauty in what one has’
‘the corruption of public morals’
‘they believe addicts have no morals and cannot be trusted’
--Word--
morale 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The confidence, enthusiasm, and discipline of a person or group at a particular time.
--Examples--
‘the team's morale was high’
--Word--
morale 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
morale 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The confidence, enthusiasm, and discipline of a person or group at a particular time.
--Examples--
‘the team's morale was high’
--Word--
moralize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Comment on issues of right and wrong, typically with an unfounded air of superiority.
Reform the character and conduct of.
Interpret or explain as giving lessons on good and bad character and conduct.
--Examples--
‘the self-righteous moralizing of his aunt was ringing in his ears’
‘he endeavoured to moralize an immoral society’
‘mythographers normally moralize Narcissus as the man who wastes himself in pursuing worldly goods’

--Word--
moralism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The practice of moralizing, especially the tendency to make judgements about others' morality.
--Examples--
‘the patriotic moralism of many political leaders’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
moralist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who teaches or promotes morality.
A person given to moralizing.
A person who behaves in a morally commendable way.
--Examples--
--Word--
moralistic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Overfond of making moral judgements about others' behaviour; too ready to moralize.
--Examples--
‘a moralistic stance on advertising’
‘modernized fairy tales are often moralistic and cleaned up’

adverb

--Word--
morality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Principles concerning the distinction between right and wrong or good and bad behaviour.
A particular system of values and principles of conduct.
The extent to which an action is right or wrong.
--Examples--
‘the matter boiled down to simple morality: innocent prisoners ought to be freed’
‘a bourgeois morality’
‘the issue of the morality of the possession of nuclear weapons’

--Word--
moran 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of the warrior group of the Masai people of East Africa, which comprises the younger unmarried males.
--Examples--
--Word--
Morar, Loch 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A loch in western Scotland. At 310 m (1,017 ft), it is Scotland's deepest loch.
--Examples--
--Word--
mora 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Scottish Law. Undue delay in the assertion of a claim, etc.
Prosody. A unit of metrical time equal to the duration of a short syllable.
Linguistics. The smallest or basic unit of duration of a speech sound.
Any one of the (originally six) divisions of which the Spartan army was made up.
In South Asia: a stool; a footstool; a wicker chair.
A tall tree, Mora excelsa (family Caesalpiniaceae (Leguminosae)), native to the Caribbean and tropical South America (also "mora tree"); the wood of this tree.
--Examples--

--Word--
Moravia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A region of the Czech Republic, situated between Bohemia in the west and the Carpathians in the east; chief town, Brno. A province of Bohemia from the 11th century, it was made an Austrian province in 1848, becoming a part of Czechoslovakia in 1918.
--Examples--
--Word--
Moravian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Moravia or its people.
Relating to or denoting a Protestant Church founded in Saxony by emigrants from Moravia holding views derived from the Hussites and accepting the Bible as the only source of faith.
A native or inhabitant of Moravia.
A member of the Moravian Church.
--Examples--
--Word--
Moravianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The religious beliefs and practices of the Moravian Church.
--Examples--
--Word--
Moraxella 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of Gram-negative bacteria (family Neisseriaceae) inhabiting the mucous membranes of mammals and causing infections of the middle ear, respiratory tract, and conjunctiva; specifically a subgenus of this genus comprising rod-shaped bacteria occurring in pairs or chains; (also moraxella) a bacterium of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
morbid 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Characterized by an abnormal and unhealthy interest in disturbing and unpleasant subjects, especially death and disease.
Of the nature of or indicative of disease.
--Examples--
‘his morbid fascination with the horrors of contemporary warfare’
‘the treatment of morbid obesity’
--Word--
morbidezza 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Art. Lifelike delicacy in flesh tints.
Generally. Delicacy, softness, especially in musical performance; sensibility, smoothness. Also occasionally with negative connotation: unwholesomeness, effeminacy, sickliness.
--Examples--

morcellation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Division into many pieces; specifically (a) Surgery the action or process of breaking up a tumour, organ, etc., into small pieces, especially in the course of excision; (b) historical the division of property or land.

morcellement 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Especially in France: division of land or property into small portions. Now rare.
Surgery= morcellation.

--Word--
mordant 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
(especially of humour) having or showing a sharp or critical quality; biting.
A substance, typically an inorganic oxide, that combines with a dye or stain and thereby fixes it in a material.
An adhesive compound for fixing gold leaf.
A corrosive liquid used to etch the lines on a printing plate.
Impregnate or treat (a fabric) with a mordant.
--Examples--
‘a mordant sense of humour’
‘mordanting a fibre is simple’
‘mordanted wool’

Richler, Mordecai 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1931–2001), Canadian writer. His best-known novel is probably The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz (1959).
--Examples--
--Word--
mordenite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An orthorhombic hydrated silicate of aluminium, calcium, sodium, and potassium, which belongs to the zeolite group and usually occurs as white glassy needles, especially in igneous rocks.
--Examples--
--Word--
mordent 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A rapid alternation of a note with the note immediately below or above it in the scale (sometimes further distinguished as lower mordent and upper mordent). The term inverted mordent usually refers to the upper mordent.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A rapid alternation of a note with the note immediately below or above it in the scale (sometimes further distinguished as lower mordent and upper mordent). The term inverted mordent usually refers to the upper mordent.

Mordvin 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a non-Russian people inhabiting Mordvinia.
The Finno-Ugric language of the Mordvin, which has two distinct dialects and over 1 million speakers altogether.
Relating to the Mordvin or their language.

--Word--
more 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, adverb
--Meanings--
A greater or additional amount or degree.
Forming the comparative of adjectives and adverbs, especially those of more than one syllable.
To a greater extent.
Extremely (used before an adjective conveying a positive feeling or attitude)
Again.
Moreover.
--Examples--
‘I poured myself more coffee’
‘tell me more’
‘they proved more of a hindrance than a help’
‘for them enthusiasm is more important than talent’
‘I like chicken more than turkey’
‘she is more than happy to oblige’
‘repeat once more’
‘he was rich, and more, he was handsome’

Moreau, Jeanne

proper noun
--Meanings--
(1928–2017), French actress. Notable films: Les Liaisons dangereuses (1959), Jules et Jim (1961), and Nikita (1990).

Morecambe, Eric 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1926–84), English comedian; born John Eric Bartholomew. In 1941 he formed a double act with comedian Ernie Wise (1925–99) that led to the enduringly popular TV series The Morecambe and Wise Show (1961–76).

Morelia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in central Mexico, capital of the state of Michoacán; population 608,049 (2005). Founded in 1541, it was known as Valladolid until 1828.

--Word--
morena 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A woman with a dark complexion, especially (in South and Central America) a woman of mixed descent or of African origin.
Especially among speakers of the Sotho languages: a title of or respectful form of address used to a chief or (more generally) any person in authority. Hence: a chief, a master.
--Examples--
--Word--
morendo 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
As a musical direction: with the sound gradually dying away. Also as noun: a style of performance using such an effect.
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--

morenosite

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
mores 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
The essential or characteristic customs and conventions of a society or community.
--Examples--
‘an offence against social mores’
--Word--
Port Moresby 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Papua New Guinea, situated on the south coast of the island of New Guinea, on the Coral Sea; population 307,600 (est. 2009).

--Word--
Morgagni 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Anatomy"ventricle of Morgagni"noun the ventricle of the larynx, a recess in each of its lateral walls located between the vocal and vestibular folds (the true and false vocal cords). Now rare.
Anatomy"hydatid of Morgagni"noun any of various small, nodular, often cystic structures attached to the testis, epididymis, or Fallopian tube, usually representing vestigial remnants of the Müllerian duct; especially the appendix testis (a small body attached to the upper pole of the testis) and any of the vesicular appendices of the Fallopian tube (pedunculated bodies attached to its fimbrial end).
Anatomy"columns of Morgagni"noun longitudinal folds in the mucous membrane of the distal rectum.
Anatomy"foramen of Morgagni"noun a defect in the diaphragm located between its sternal and costal attachments (on either side).
--Examples--
--Word--
Morgan 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A horse of a light thickset breed developed in New England.
--Examples--
--Word--
Fata Morgana 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mirage.
--Examples--
‘the war sometimes seemed unreal, more Fata Morgana than memory’
--Word--
morganatic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a marriage in which neither the spouse of lower rank, nor any children, have any claim to the possessions or title of the spouse of higher rank.
--Examples--
‘he contracted a morganatic marriage with a German-born actress’

Morganization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The restructuring of an industry or business sector, especially one that is unstable, by buying up competing companies and combining their resources in a single corporation.

Morgantown

--Meanings--
A commercial city in northern West Virginia, home to West Virginia University; population 29,642 (est. 2008).

--Word--
morgen 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in the Netherlands, South Africa, and parts of the US) a measure of land equal to about 0.8 hectare or two acres.
(in Norway, Denmark, and Germany) a measure of land now equal to about 0.3 hectare or two thirds of an acre.

morgue 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mortuary.
Used in reference to a place that is quiet, gloomy, or cold.
A newspaper's collection of miscellaneous information for use in future obituaries.
--Examples--
‘the cadavers were bagged and removed to the city morgue’
‘she put us in that draughty morgue of a sitting room’
‘a full-time obituaries editor in charge of the morgue’

moria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: impairment of the intellectual faculties; mental dullness or retardation. Later: inappropriate jocularity, as a sign of mental illness or neurological disease.

moriche 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several palms of the genus Mauritia, native to Trinidad and northern South America; especially the ita palm, M. flexuosa, valued as a source of fibre, timber, and wine. More fully "moriche palm".

--Word--
morin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A flavonoid found in the wood of old fustic and related trees, used as a yellow dye and as an antioxidant; 3,5,7,2′,4′-pentahydroxyflavone, C₁₅H₁₀O₇.
--Examples--
--Word--
Morinda 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of small trees and shrubs of the family Rubiaceae, native especially to tropical Asia and Australia, several of which have roots and root bark yielding red and yellow dyes; (also morinda) any of the plants of this genus, especially M. citrifolia and M. tinctoria, used as dye plants in South Asia. Frequently attributive, especially in "Morinda bark", "Morinda root".
--Examples--
--Word--
morindin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An orange-red glycoside of morindone which is present in the roots of morindas and in certain other trees, and has been used as a dye.
--Examples--
--Word--
morindone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An orange-red anthraquinone derivative which occurs in the roots and heartwood of morindas and is the aglycone of morindin; 1,5,6-trihydroxy-2-methylanthraquinone, C₁₅H₁₀O₅.
--Examples--
--Word--
Moringa 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small genus of deciduous trees constituting the dicotyledonous family Moringaceae, native to the Old World tropics and subtropics; (also moringa) a tree of this genus, especially the ben nut tree or horseradish tree, Moringa oleifera.

Morison, Samuel Eliot 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1887–1976), US historian and naval officer. He wrote Oxford History of the United States (1927), Admiral of the Ocean Sea: A Life of Christopher Columbus (1942), and John Paul Jones (1959).
--Examples--
--Word--
Morisonian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A follower or supporter of James Morison or his theological views, chiefly the rejection of the Calvinist doctrine of election; a member of the Evangelical Union, an association of presbyterian and congregational churches founded by Morison (amalgamated with the Congregational Union of Scotland in 1896).
Characteristic of or supporting Morison, his views, or the principles of the Evangelical Union.
--Examples--
--Word--
Morisonian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A follower or supporter of James Morison or his theological views, chiefly the rejection of the Calvinist doctrine of election; a member of the Evangelical Union, an association of presbyterian and congregational churches founded by Morison (amalgamated with the Congregational Union of Scotland in 1896).
Characteristic of or supporting Morison, his views, or the principles of the Evangelical Union.

morita 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A dried, smoked jalapeño pepper, used especially in Mexican cookery; a variety of chipotle.
A form of psychotherapy in which total rest is followed by behavioural and occupational therapy. Frequently attributive, especially in "Morita therapy".

Schlick, Moritz 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1882–1936), German philosopher and physicist, founder of the Vienna Circle. Notable works: General Theory of Knowledge (1918).
--Examples--
--Word--
Morley, Edward Williams 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1838–1923), American chemist. In 1887 he collaborated with Albert Michelson in an experiment to determine the speed of light, the result of which disproved the existence of the ether.

--Word--
mormyrid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Any of various thick-bodied freshwater fishes of the African family Mormyridae, many of which possess electric organs and some of which have an elongated snout resembling an elephant's trunk.
Of or relating to the family Mormyridae; characteristic of a mormyrid.
--Examples--
--Word--
mormyrus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
†(a) A marine fish with distinctive markings, (probably) the striped sea bream, Lithognathus mormyrus. Obsolete. (b) (In later use) any fish of the genus Mormyrus (family Mormyridae), comprising African freshwater fishes with curved elongate snouts and weak electric organs; an elephant-snout fish; (in form Mormyrus) the genus itself.
--Examples--

morning 
--Type--
noun, adverb, exclamation
--Meanings--
The period of time between midnight and noon, especially from sunrise to noon.
Sunrise.
Every morning.
--Examples--
‘I've got a meeting this morning’
‘it was a beautiful sunny morning’
‘the morning papers’
‘a hint of steely light showed that morning was on its way’
‘mornings, she'd sleep late’
--Word--
breathing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process of taking air into and expelling it from the lungs.
A sign in Greek (῾ or ᾿) indicating the presence of an aspirate (rough breathing) or the absence of an aspirate (smooth breathing) at the beginning of a word.
--Examples--
‘his breathing was shallow’
--Word--
bright 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Giving out or reflecting much light; shining.
Full of light.
(of a period of time) having sunny, cloudless weather.
(of colour) vivid and bold.
Having a vivid colour.
Intelligent and quick-witted.
Cheerful and lively.
(of someone's future) likely to be successful and happy.
(of sound) clear, vibrant, and typically high-pitched.
Brightly.
Bold and vivid colours.
Headlights switched to full beam.
--Examples--
‘the sun was dazzlingly bright’
‘her bright, dark eyes’
‘the rooms are bright and spacious’
‘the long, bright days of June’
‘the bright green leaves’
‘a bright tie’
‘a bright idea’
‘a bright young journalist’
‘at breakfast she would be persistently bright and chirpy’
‘she gave a bright smile’
‘these young people have a bright future ahead of them’
‘her voice is fresh and bright’
‘a full moon shining bright’
‘a choice of colours from pastels through to brights’
‘he turned the brights on and we drove along the dirt road’

--Word--
morocco 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
Fine flexible leather made (originally in Morocco) from goatskins tanned with sumac, used especially for book covers and shoes.
A country in north-western Africa, with coastlines on the Mediterranean Sea and Atlantic Ocean; population 34,400,000 (estimated 2015); languages, Arabic (official), Berber; capital, Rabat.
--Examples--
‘a small fat volume bound in red morocco’
‘morocco leather’

morph 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Change smoothly from one image to another by small gradual steps using computer animation techniques.
Undergo or cause to undergo a gradual process of transformation.
An image that has been morphed.
An instance of morphing an image.
An actual linguistic form.
Each of several variant forms of an animal or plant.
--Examples--
‘the characters can be morphed on screen’
‘the cute moppet has morphed into the moody moll of the indie world’
‘the present participle in English is always the morph ‘-ing’’
--Word--
-morph 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
Denoting something having a specified form or character.
--Examples--
‘endomorph’
‘polymorph’

--Word--
morphoea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: = morphew. Now: specifically a form of scleroderma characterized by localized or circumscribed skin lesions; frequently with distinguishing word indicating the distribution or shape of lesions.
--Examples--
--Word--
Morphean 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, belonging to, or relating to Morpheus; sleepy, drowsy.
--Examples--
--Word--
morpheme 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A meaningful morphological unit of a language that cannot be further divided (e.g. in, come, -ing, forming incoming).
A morphological element considered in respect of its functional relations in a linguistic system.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A meaningful morphological unit of a language that cannot be further divided (e.g. in, come, -ing, forming incoming).
A morphological element considered in respect of its functional relations in a linguistic system.

morphic resonance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(according to the theory developed by Rupert Sheldrake, British biologist b.1942) a paranormal influence by which a pattern of events or behaviour can facilitate subsequent occurrences of similar patterns.

--Word--
morphism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or condition of being a morph; variance of form in an animal or plant species; polymorphism.
Mathematics. Any of a class of elements in a category which are associated with pairs of that category's objects, and which may be combined associatively under the operation of composition specified for that category.
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
morphology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The study of the forms of things.
The branch of biology that deals with the form of living organisms, and with relationships between their structures.
The study of the forms of words, in particular inflected forms.
A particular form, shape, or structure.
--Examples--
‘grammar is organized along two main dimensions: morphology and syntax’
‘a generative approach to Italian morphology’
--Word--
morphological 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the form or structure of things.
Relating to the branch of biology that deals with the form of living organisms, and with relationships between their structures.
Relating to the forms of words, in particular inflected forms.
--Examples--
‘the purely morphological fact that with a little dam one could hold back a lot of water’
‘studies of genetic variation of morphological traits in mammals’
‘the geraniums have a number of unusual morphological adaptations’
‘the language's phonological, morphological and syntactic structure’
‘morphological and syntactic similarities between languages’

--Word--
morrel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several trees of the genus Eucalyptus (family Myrtaceae) of south-western Australia, especially the rough-barked trees E. longicornis, which has a durable reddish wood, and E. melanoxylon, which has a very hard blackish wood.
--Examples--
--Word--
sodium morrhuate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The sodium salt of a mixture of fatty acids from cod liver oil, used chiefly as a sclerosing agent in the treatment of vascular malformations and tumours.
--Examples--
--Word--
Morris, William 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
(1834–96), English designer, craftsman, poet, and writer. A leading figure in the Arts and Crafts Movement, in 1861 he established Morris & Company, an association of craftsmen whose members included Edward Burne-Jones and Dante Gabriel Rossetti, to produce handcrafted goods for the home. His many writings include News from Nowhere (1891), which portrays a socialist utopia.
--Examples--
--Word--
morris dance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A lively traditional English dance performed out of doors by groups known as ‘sides’. Dancers wear a distinctive costume that is mainly black and white and has small bells attached, and often carry handkerchiefs or sticks.
--Examples--
--Word--
Morris, William 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
(1834–96), English designer, craftsman, poet, and writer. A leading figure in the Arts and Crafts Movement, in 1861 he established Morris & Company, an association of craftsmen whose members included Edward Burne-Jones and Dante Gabriel Rossetti, to produce handcrafted goods for the home. His many writings include News from Nowhere (1891), which portrays a socialist utopia.
--Examples--
--Word--
Morrison, Toni 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1931), US novelist; full name Chloe Anthony Morrison. Her novels depict the black American experience and heritage. Beloved (1987) won the Pulitzer Prize, and Morrison became the first black woman writer to receive the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1993.

--Word--
mortal 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a living human being, often in contrast to a divine being) subject to death.
Relating to humans as subject to death.
Causing or liable to cause death; fatal.
(of a battle) fought to the death.
(of an enemy or a state of hostility) admitting or allowing no reconciliation until death.
(of a feeling, especially fear) very intense.
Denoting a grave sin that is regarded as depriving the soul of divine grace.
Conceivable or imaginable.
Very great.
Long and tedious.
A human being subject to death, as opposed to a divine being.
A person contrasted with others regarded as being of higher status or ability.
--Examples--
‘all men are mortal’
‘the coffin held the mortal remains of her uncle’
‘a mortal disease’
‘the scandal appeared to have struck a mortal blow to the government’
‘the drawing shows Holmes and Moriarty locked in mortal combat’
‘the screams of men in mortal combat’
‘a mortal foe’
‘parents live in mortal fear of children's diseases’
‘she had committed a mortal sin’
‘he knew every mortal thing you did’
‘he was in a mortal hurry’
‘for three mortal days it rained’
‘capacities only possible of God rather than mortals’
‘an ambassador had to live in a style which was not expected of lesser mortals’
--Word--
mortalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The belief that the soul is mortal and dies with the body, or lies unconscious until the final resurrection.
--Examples--
--Word--
mortalist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who believes that the soul is mortal and dies with the body; an adherent of mortalism.
That believes the doctrine of mortalism.
--Examples--
--Word--
mortality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state of being subject to death.
Death, especially on a large scale.
The number of deaths in a given area or period, or from a particular cause.
--Examples--
‘the work is increasingly haunted by thoughts of mortality’
‘the causes of mortality among infants and young children’
‘post-operative mortality was 90 per cent for some operations’

--Word--
mortar 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
A short smooth-bore gun for firing shells (technically called bombs) at high angles.
A device used for firing a lifeline or firework.
A cup-shaped receptacle in which ingredients are crushed or ground, used in cooking or pharmacy.
Attack or bombard with a mortar.
A mixture of lime with cement, sand, and water, used in building to bond bricks or stones.
Fix or join using mortar.
--Examples--
‘mortars and machine guns’
‘nine civilians died in a horrific mortar attack’
‘a pestle and mortar’
‘the Commando positions were being heavily mortared’
‘at first light the mortaring and sniping started’
‘the pipe can be mortared in place’
--Word--
mortarboard 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An academic cap with a stiff, flat, square top and a tassel.
A small square board with a handle on the underside, used by bricklayers for holding mortar.

‘the Commando positions were being heavily mortared’
‘at first light the mortaring and sniping started’
‘the pipe can be mortared in place’

--Word--
pre-mortem 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Taking place or performed before death. Opposed to post-mortem.
A discussion or analysis of a presumed or future demise or death. Chiefly figurative.
--Examples--
--Word--
mortgage 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A legal agreement by which a bank, building society, etc. lends money at interest in exchange for taking title of the debtor's property, with the condition that the conveyance of title becomes void upon the payment of the debt.
The amount of money borrowed in a mortgage.
A deed effecting a mortgage.
Convey (a property) to a creditor as security on a loan.
Expose to future risk or constraint for the sake of immediate advantage.
--Examples--
‘I put down a hundred thousand in cash and took out a mortgage for the rest’
‘a £60,000 mortgage’
‘the estate was mortgaged up to the hilt’
‘a heavily mortgaged farm’
‘some people worry that selling off state assets mortgages the country's future’

mortgageable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--

mortise 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A hole or recess cut into a part which is designed to receive a corresponding projection (a tenon) on another part so as to join or lock the parts together.
Join securely by using a mortise and tenon.
Cut a mortise in or through.
--Examples--
‘a mortise and tenon joint’
‘the top plate of the rudder assembly can be mortised to the top of the rudder post’
‘the mortised ports’

--Word--
Pullman, George Mortimer 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1831–97) US industrialist. The founder of the Pullman Palace Car Company in 1867, he converted railroad coaches into sleeping cars with lower and upper berths. He also designed the first railroad dining car in 1868. The town of Pullman, Illinois, was built to house his workers.
--Examples--
--Word--
rigor mortis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Stiffening of the joints and muscles of a body a few hours after death, usually lasting from one to four days.
--Examples--

--Word--
mortlake 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Attributive Designating a kind of tapestry woven at Mortlake under royal patronage in the reigns of James I and Charles I, originally to Flemish designs, later depicting the paintings of prominent European artists of the day (notably Raphael). Now historical.
An oxbow lake.

Morton, John 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1420–1500), English prelate and statesman. He was appointed Archbishop of Canterbury in 1486 and Chancellor under Henry VII a year later. The Crown's stringent taxation policies made the regime in general and Morton in particular widely unpopular.
--Examples--

--Word--
mosaic 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective, adjective
--Meanings--
A picture or pattern produced by arranging together small pieces of stone, tile, glass, etc.
A colourful and variegated pattern.
A combination of diverse elements forming a more or less coherent whole.
An arrangement of photosensitive elements in a television camera.
An individual (especially an animal) composed of cells of two genetically different types.
A virus disease that results in leaf variegation in tobacco, maize, sugar cane, and other plants.
Decorate with a mosaic.
Combine (distinct or disparate elements) to form a picture or pattern.
Denoting an individual composed of cells of two genetically different types.
Of or associated with Moses.
--Examples--
‘mosaics on the interior depict scenes from the Old Testament’
‘the walls and vaults are decorated by marble and mosaic’
‘the bird's plumage was a mosaic of slate-grey, blue, and brown’
‘a cultural mosaic’
‘he mosaicked the walls, ceilings, and floors’
‘the digital data were combined, or mosaicked, to delineate counties’

mosasaur

noun

Mosel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river of western Europe, which rises in the Vosges mountains of north-eastern France and flows 550 km (346 miles) north-east through Luxembourg and Germany to meet the River Rhine at Koblenz.
--Examples--
--Word--
Moseley, Henry 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1887–1915), English physicist; full name Henry Gwyn Jeffreys Moseley. He determined the atomic numbers of elements from their X-ray spectra, demonstrated that an element's chemical properties are determined by this number, and showed that there are only ninety-two naturally occurring elements.
--Examples--
--Word--
Moselle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A light medium-dry white wine produced in the valley of the River Mosel.
--Examples--
--Word--
Moses 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(fl.c.14th–13th centuries BC), Hebrew prophet and lawgiver, brother of Aaron. According to the biblical account, he was born in Egypt and led the Israelites away from servitude there, across the desert towards the Promised Land. During the journey he was inspired by God on Mount Sinai to write down the Ten Commandments on tablets of stone (Exod. 20).
--Examples--
--Word--
mosesite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A cubic hydrated nitrogen compound of mercury (chemically, a salt of Millon's base) which occurs as yellow crystals and has the formula Hg₂NX.H₂O, where X represents chiefly chloride and sulphate (and sometimes also molybdate).
--Examples--
--Word--
MOSFET 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A field-effect transistor in which there is a thin layer of silicon oxide between the gate and the channel.

Dayan, Moshe 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1915–81), Israeli statesman and general. As Minister of Defence he oversaw Israel's victory in the Six Day War and as Foreign Minister he played a prominent role in negotiations towards the Camp David Accords of 1978.

--Examples--
--Word--
Mosley, Sir Oswald 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
6th Baronet (1896–1980), English Fascist leader; full name Oswald Ernald Mosley. Successively a Conservative, Independent, and Labour MP, he founded the British Union of Fascists, also known as the Blackshirts, in 1932. The party was effectively destroyed by the Public Order Act of 1936. In 1948 Mosley founded the right-wing Union Movement.
--Examples--

Muslimize

verb

mosquito 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A slender long-legged fly with aquatic larvae. The bite of the bloodsucking female can transmit a number of serious diseases including malaria and elephantiasis.

--Examples--
--Word--
moss 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small flowerless green plant which lacks true roots, growing in low carpets or rounded cushions in damp habitats and reproducing by means of spores released from stalked capsules.
Used in names of algae, lichens, and higher plants resembling moss, e.g. reindeer moss, Ceylon moss, Spanish moss.
A green colour like that of moss.
A bog, especially a peat bog.
Cover with moss.
--Examples--
‘the trees are overgrown with vines and moss’
‘the bog is home to rare mosses’
‘the mossed old trees’

--Word--
Mössbauer effect 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An effect in which certain atomic nuclei bound in a crystal emit gamma rays of sharply defined frequency which can be used as a probe of energy levels in other nuclei.
--Examples--
--Word--
moss 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--

‘the bog is home to rare mosses’
‘the mossed old trees’
--Word--
mossberry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various small berries growing on marshy ground or in mossy areas; specifically (a) a species of cranberry, Vaccinium oxycoccos, or its fruit; (b) North American regional (Alaska and Canadian) the crowberry, Empetrum nigrum, or its fruit.

--Word--
mosser 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Scottish History= "moss-trooper".
Scottish and Irish English. A person who cuts and prepares peat in a moss or bog. Now historical.
A collector or gatherer of moss (chiefly Irish English).
--Examples--

--Word--
most 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, adverb
--Meanings--
Greatest in amount or degree.
The majority of; nearly all of.
Forming the superlative of adjectives and adverbs, especially those of more than one syllable.
To the greatest extent.
Extremely; very.
Almost.
--Examples--
‘they've had the most success’
‘we had the most to lose’
‘most oranges are sweeter than these’
‘I spent most of the winter on the coast’
‘the most important event of my life’
‘sandy plains where fire tends to spread most quickly’
‘the things he most enjoyed’
‘what she wanted most of all’
‘it was most kind of you’
‘that is most probably correct’
‘most everyone understood’

Mosul 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
mot 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A girl or young woman, especially a man's girlfriend.
(in the UK) a compulsory annual test for safety and exhaust emissions of motor vehicles of more than a specified age.
A document certifying that a vehicle has passed the MOT test.
--Examples--
‘Chrissie, Frank's mot, started flinging things down at them from the bedroom window’

noun
--Meanings--
An Austronesian language spoken on Mota, formerly used as a lingua franca in some parts of the Solomon Islands and Vanuatu.

--Word--
moth 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An insect with two pairs of broad wings covered in microscopic scales, typically drably coloured and held flat when at rest. Moths are chiefly nocturnal, and lack the clubbed antennae of butterflies.
A clothes moth.
--Examples--
‘I store my sweaters in plastic bags to protect them from moths’
--Word--
mothball 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small pellet of a pungent substance, typically naphthalene, put in among stored garments to keep away clothes moths.
Store (clothes) with mothballs.
Stop using (a piece of equipment or a building) but keep it in good condition so that it can readily be used again.
Cancel or postpone work on (a plan or project)
--Examples--
‘it would cost the company a lot of money just to mothball the mine’
‘mothballed ships from World War II’
‘plans to invest in four superstores have been mothballed’

root-balled 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

eat

Put (food) into the mouth and chew and swallow it.
Have (a meal)

Have a meal at home rather than in a restaurant.
Perform fellatio or cunnilingus on (someone).

--Word--
mother 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A woman in relation to her child or children.
A female animal in relation to its offspring.
(especially as a form of address) an elderly woman.
Denoting an institution or organization from which others of the same type derive.
(especially as a title or form of address) the head of a female religious community.
An extreme example or very large specimen of something.
Bring up (a child) with care and affection.
Look after (someone) kindly and protectively, sometimes excessively so.
Give birth to.
--Examples--
‘she returned to Bristol to nurse her ageing mother’
‘a mother of three’
‘a mother penguin’
‘the initiatives were based on the experience of the mother company’
‘I got stuck in the mother of all traffic jams’
‘the art of mothering’
‘she mothered her husband, insisting he should take cod liver oil in the winter’
‘she's mothered two foals that have gone on to be impressive dressage competitors’
--Word--
motherboard 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A printed circuit board containing the principal components of a computer or other device, with connectors for other circuit boards to be slotted into.
--Examples--
--Word--
mother church 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The Roman Catholic Church, regarded as a mother in its functions of nourishing and protecting the believer.
The principal church of a country, region, or city.
The original church from which others have sprung.
--Examples--
‘they have been loyal servants to Mother Church’
‘the traditional teachings of Holy Mother Church’
‘the cathedral is the mother church of the diocese of Chelmsford’
‘the Church of England is considered the mother church of the Anglican Communion’
‘they founded the First Baptist Church of Charleston, which became the mother church of Baptists in the South’

motherer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
motherfucker 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A despicable or very unpleasant person or thing.
A person or thing of a specified kind, especially one that is formidable, remarkable, or impressive in some way.
--Examples--
‘that cover photo proves he is one talented motherfucker’
‘it's a scorching, swooping, diving, all-out motherfucker of a record’

--Word--
mothery 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling mother; (especially of wine or beer) full of sediment or dregs; mouldy.
English regional (Lincolnshire). Of the weather: damp, drizzly; close.
--Examples--
--Word--
mothery 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling mother; (especially of wine or beer) full of sediment or dregs; mouldy.
English regional (Lincolnshire). Of the weather: damp, drizzly; close.
--Examples--
--Word--
mother 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A woman in relation to her child or children.
A female animal in relation to its offspring.
(especially as a form of address) an elderly woman.
Denoting an institution or organization from which others of the same type derive.
(especially as a title or form of address) the head of a female religious community.
An extreme example or very large specimen of something.
Bring up (a child) with care and affection.
Look after (someone) kindly and protectively, sometimes excessively so.
Give birth to.
--Examples--
‘she returned to Bristol to nurse her ageing mother’
‘a mother of three’
‘a mother penguin’
‘the initiatives were based on the experience of the mother company’
‘I got stuck in the mother of all traffic jams’
‘the art of mothering’
‘she mothered her husband, insisting he should take cod liver oil in the winter’
‘she's mothered two foals that have gone on to be impressive dressage competitors’
--Word--
mother-in-law 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The mother of one's husband or wife.
--Examples--
--Word--
motherkins 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mother, ‘mummy’. Frequently as an affectionate form of address. Also: used as a form of address to a woman who acts as a maternal figure to another.

--Word--
mother-of-pearl 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A smooth shining iridescent substance forming the inner layer of the shell of some molluscs, especially oysters and abalones, used in ornamentation.
--Examples--
‘mother-of-pearl buttons’

--Word--
Motherwell, Robert 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1915–91), US artist. He was a founder and leading exponent of the New York school of abstract expressionism. Many of his works, such as the series Elegies to the Spanish Republic (1948–68) were done in black and white oil paints.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
motherwort 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tall strong-smelling European plant of the mint family. It is used in herbal medicine, especially in the treatment of gynaecological disorders.

--Word--
moth 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An insect with two pairs of broad wings covered in microscopic scales, typically drably coloured and held flat when at rest. Moths are chiefly nocturnal, and lack the clubbed antennae of butterflies.
A clothes moth.
--Examples--
‘I store my sweaters in plastic bags to protect them from moths’
--Word--
motif 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A decorative image or design, especially a repeated one forming a pattern.
A decorative device applied to a garment or textile.
A dominant or recurring idea in an artistic work.
A leitmotif or figure.
A distinctive sequence on a protein or DNA, having a three-dimensional structure that allows binding interactions to occur.
--Examples--
‘the colourful hand-painted motifs which adorn narrowboats’
‘floral or other motifs are then appliquéd to net veils’
‘superstition is a recurring motif in the book’
‘in this opera, Verdi used identifying motifs’
--Word--
motific 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to a motif or motifs.

--Word--
motion 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The action or process of moving or being moved.
A gesture.
A piece of moving mechanism.
A formal proposal put to a legislature or committee.
An application for a rule or order of court.
An evacuation of the bowels.
Direct or command (someone) with a movement of the hand or head.
Propose for discussion and resolution at a meeting or legislative assembly.
--Examples--
‘the laws of planetary motion’
‘a cushioned shoe that doesn't restrict motion’
‘she made a motion with her free hand’
‘the earliest engines had the Gresley conjugated motion for the middle cylinder’
‘opposition parties tabled a no-confidence motion’
‘often the defendant contributes to the length of proceedings by filing many procedural motions’
‘73% of the patients had fewer than three bowel motions a day’
‘her mother put on her nappy for her to pass a motion’
‘he motioned Dennis to a plush chair’
‘he motioned the young officer to sit down’
‘a resolution, motioned by Adam Tyler, proposed that members without a CCL could still belong to the association’
‘Councillor Byrne motioned that the committee call on the area manager to install street lighting’

motivate 
--Type--
verb
