--Word--
motivation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A reason or reasons for acting or behaving in a particular way.
Desire or willingness to do something; enthusiasm.
A set of facts and arguments used in support of a proposal.
--Examples--
‘escape can be a strong motivation for travel’
‘keep staff up to date and maintain interest and motivation’
‘the following proposal and motivation is submitted for consideration’

--Word--
motive 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A reason for doing something.
A motif in art, literature, or music.
Producing physical or mechanical motion.
Causing or being the reason for something.
--Examples--
‘police were unable to establish a motive for his murder’
‘the charge of gas is the motive force for every piston stroke’
‘the motive principle of a writer's work’

--Word--
motor 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A machine, especially one powered by electricity or internal combustion, that supplies motive power for a vehicle or for another device with moving parts.
A source of power, energy, or motive force.
A car.
Driven by a motor.
Relating to motor vehicles.
Giving or producing motion or action.
Relating to muscular movement or the nerves activating it.
Travel in a motor vehicle.
Run or move as fast as possible.
--Examples--
‘these electric motors are highly reliable’
‘the sander has a smooth and powerful 520 watt motor’
‘hormones are the motor of the sexual functions’
‘we drove out in my motor’
‘a motor van’
‘motor insurance’
‘demand is the principle motor force governing economic activity’
‘the motor functions of each hand’
‘they motored north up the M6’
‘he had motored along to second base on a passed ball’

--Word--
motor-boating 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of driving or travelling in a motor boat, especially as a sport or leisure pursuit.
Electronics. Oscillation in an amplifier that is of such low frequency that individual cycles may be heard, giving a characteristic sound, and caused by feedback from the output to the input of earlier stages, often through a common voltage supply.

--Word--
motor 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A machine, especially one powered by electricity or internal combustion, that supplies motive power for a vehicle or for another device with moving parts.
A source of power, energy, or motive force.
A car.
Driven by a motor.
Relating to motor vehicles.
Giving or producing motion or action.
Relating to muscular movement or the nerves activating it.
Travel in a motor vehicle.
Run or move as fast as possible.
--Examples--
‘these electric motors are highly reliable’
‘the sander has a smooth and powerful 520 watt motor’
‘hormones are the motor of the sexual functions’
‘we drove out in my motor’
‘a motor van’
‘motor insurance’
‘demand is the principle motor force governing economic activity’
‘the motor functions of each hand’
‘they motored north up the M6’
‘he had motored along to second base on a passed ball’
--Word--
motor generator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device consisting of a mechanically coupled electric motor and generator which may be used to control the voltage, frequency, or phase of an electrical supply.
--Examples--

motoric 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to muscular movement.

--Examples--
‘the infants' motoric and linguistic capabilities’
‘the motorik pulse of 70's Krautrock’

--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
motorium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Psychology and Medicine. Originally: the motor areas of the brain (now rare); a hypothetical centre coordinating these (disused). Later also: the motor apparatus of the body; motor functioning or performance.
Zoology. In some ciliate protozoans: an area of cytoplasm containing a system of fibrils connected with the cirri or myonemes, thought to be a centre of neuromotor control. Now chiefly historical.
--Examples--
--Word--

moto perpetuo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A piece of fast-moving instrumental music consisting mainly of notes of equal length.
--Examples--
--Word--
Motown 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Music released on or reminiscent of the US record label Tamla Motown. The first black-owned record company in the US, Tamla Motown was founded in Detroit in 1959 by Berry Gordy, and was important in popularizing soul music, producing artists such as the Supremes, Stevie Wonder, and Marvin Gaye.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Motor function; the faculty or power of movement by the body or a body part.
--Examples--
--Word--
mot 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A girl or young woman, especially a man's girlfriend.
(in the UK) a compulsory annual test for safety and exhaust emissions of motor vehicles of more than a specified age.
A document certifying that a vehicle has passed the MOT test.
--Examples--
‘Chrissie, Frank's mot, started flinging things down at them from the bedroom window’

motty 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A mark at which a player aims in quoits, marbles, etc.
Mining. A miner's tally; a stick of wood or disc of metal, notched or stamped in a particular way, placed on a full corf to identify it as the work of a certain miner.
A word, opinion; especially in "to put one's motty in": to stick one's oar in, to interfere.

motto 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A short sentence or phrase chosen as encapsulating the beliefs or ideals of an individual, family, or institution.
A phrase which recurs throughout a musical work and has some symbolical significance.
--Examples--
‘the family motto is ‘Faithful though Unfortunate’’
‘they were developing the use of leitmotifs or mottoes that appear throughout an opera’

--Word--
mottramite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An orthorhombic basic vanadate of lead, copper, and zinc occurring as green or brownish blades or black encrustations and forming a series with descloizite.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mott, Lucretia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1793–1880), US social reformer; full name Lucretia Coffin Mott. A progressive Quaker minister, she was a highly motivated activist in the cause of abolition, women's rights, and freedom of religion. She wrote Discourse on Women (1850), and with Elizabeth Cady Stanton she organized the 1848 Seneca Falls women's rights convention.
--Examples--
--Word--
Motu 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a Melanesian people of Papua New Guinea inhabiting the area around Port Moresby.
The language of the Motu, the base of a pidgin known as Hiri Motu or (formerly) Police Motu, widely used as a lingua franca for administrative purposes.
Relating to the Motu or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
mou 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Mouth.
A Chinese unit of area, varying according to locality but usually equivalent to about 670 square metres (approx. 800 square yards).

--Word--
warp 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make or become bent or twisted out of shape, typically as a result of the effects of heat or damp.
Make abnormal or strange; distort.
(with reference to a ship) move or be moved along by hauling on a rope attached to a stationary object ashore.
(in weaving) arrange (yarn) so as to form the warp of a piece of cloth.
Cover (land) with a deposit of alluvial soil by natural or artificial flooding.
A twist or distortion in the shape of something.
Relating to or denoting (fictional or hypothetical) space travel by means of distorting space–time.
An abnormality or perversion in a person's character.
(in weaving) the threads on a loom over and under which other threads (the weft) are passed to make cloth.
A rope attached at one end to a fixed point and used for moving or mooring a ship.
Alluvial sediment; silt.
--Examples--
‘moisture had warped the box’
‘wood has a tendency to warp’
‘your judgement has been warped by your obvious dislike of him’
‘crew and passengers helped warp the vessels through the shallow section’
‘cotton string will be warped on the loom in the rug-weaving process’
‘the main canal may be cut so as to warp the lands on each side of it’
‘the head of the racket had a curious warp’
‘warp speed’
‘no mind is more capable of warps than his’
‘the warp and weft are the basic constituents of all textiles’
‘rugby is woven into the warp and weft of South African society’
‘the warp or muddy deposit dug from an old riverbed’

--Word--
mould 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A hollow container used to give shape to molten or hot liquid material when it cools and hardens.
A pudding or savoury mousse made in a mould.
A distinctive and typical style, form, or character.
Form or shape, especially the features or physique of a person or the build of an animal.
A frame or template for producing mouldings.
Form (an object) out of malleable material.
Give a shape to (malleable material)
Influence the formation or development of.
(of a column, ceiling, or other part of a building) having a decorative moulding.
--Examples--
‘the smith would pour the molten metal into the shaped mould’
‘a jelly mould’
‘a lobster mould with a sauce of carrots and port’
‘he's a superb striker in the same mould as Gary Lineker’
‘he planned to conquer the world as a roving reporter in the mould of his hero’
‘he was manly in size, mould, and bearing’
‘all the moulds, masters or originals, had been kept for reference’
‘mould the figure from white fondant’
‘take the marzipan and mould it into a cone shape’
‘the professionals who were helping to mould US policy’
‘a corridor with a moulded cornice’

‘a jelly mould’
‘a lobster mould with a sauce of carrots and port’
‘he's a superb striker in the same mould as Gary Lineker’
‘he planned to conquer the world as a roving reporter in the mould of his hero’
‘he was manly in size, mould, and bearing’
‘all the moulds, masters or originals, had been kept for reference’
‘mould the figure from white fondant’
‘take the marzipan and mould it into a cone shape’
‘the professionals who were helping to mould US policy’
‘a corridor with a moulded cornice’
--Word--
moulder 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Slowly decay or disintegrate, especially because of neglect.
A person or thing that moulds something.
--Examples--
‘the smell of mouldering books’
‘I couldn't permit someone of your abilities to moulder away in a backwater’
‘a moulder of public opinion’

--Word--
mould 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A hollow container used to give shape to molten or hot liquid material when it cools and hardens.
A pudding or savoury mousse made in a mould.
A distinctive and typical style, form, or character.
Form or shape, especially the features or physique of a person or the build of an animal.
A frame or template for producing mouldings.
Form (an object) out of malleable material.
Give a shape to (malleable material)
Influence the formation or development of.
(of a column, ceiling, or other part of a building) having a decorative moulding.
--Examples--
‘the smith would pour the molten metal into the shaped mould’
‘a jelly mould’
‘a lobster mould with a sauce of carrots and port’
‘he's a superb striker in the same mould as Gary Lineker’
‘he planned to conquer the world as a roving reporter in the mould of his hero’
‘he was manly in size, mould, and bearing’
‘all the moulds, masters or originals, had been kept for reference’
‘mould the figure from white fondant’

--Word--
moult 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of an animal) shed old feathers, hair, or skin to make way for a new growth.
(of hair or feathers) fall out to make way for new growth.
A loss of feathers, hair, or skin, especially as a regular feature of an animal's life cycle.
--Examples--
‘the adult birds were already moulting’
‘the snake moults its skin’
‘the last of his juvenile plumage had moulted’
‘the mountain goat is brilliant white after the autumn moult’
‘in the complete life cycle there are four moults’

mound 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A rounded mass projecting above a surface.
A small hill.
A raised mass of earth and stones created for purposes of defence or burial.
A slight elevation from which the pitcher delivers the ball.
A large pile or quantity of something.
Heap up into a rounded pile.
Enclose or fortify with an embankment.
--Examples--
‘the bushes were little more than vague mounds beneath the snow’
‘he built his castle high upon the mound’
‘the dead were cremated, and then buried at the centre of a great mound’
‘a mound of dirty crockery’
‘basmati rice was mounded on our plates’
‘a sand-built ridge Of heaped hills that mound the sea’

--Word--
mount 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Climb up (stairs, a hill, or other rising surface)
Climb or move up on to (a raised surface)
Get up on (an animal or bicycle) in order to ride it.
Set (someone) on horseback; provide with a horse.
(of a male mammal or bird) assume a position on top of (a female) in order to copulate.
Organize and initiate (a campaign or other course of action)
Establish; set up.
Produce (a play, exhibition, or other artistic event) for public viewing.
Grow larger or more numerous.
(of a feeling) become stronger or more intense.
(of blood) rise visibly into the cheeks.
Place or fix (an object) on a support.
Set in or attach to a backing or setting.
Fix (an object for viewing) on a microscope slide.
Make (a disk or disk drive) available for use.
A backing or setting on which a photograph, gem, or work of art is set for display.
A glass microscope slide for securing a specimen to be viewed.
A stamp hinge.
A support for a gun, camera, or similar piece of equipment.
A horse that is ridden or is available for riding.
An opportunity to ride a horse, especially as a jockey.
--Examples--
‘he mounted the steps’
‘the master of ceremonies mounted the platform’
‘he mounted the horse’
‘he took the bicycle, mounted it, and rode to the station’
‘she was mounted on a white horse’
‘a female was immediately mounted by the cat’
‘the company had successfully mounted takeover bids’
‘security forces mounted check points at every key road’
‘the museum is mounting an exhibition of sixteenth-century drawings’
‘the theatre mounted a brilliant all-male ‘As You Like It’’
‘police mounted a reconstruction of what they believe happened before the explosion’
‘the costs mount up when you buy a home’
‘his anxiety mounted as messages were left unanswered’
‘feeling the blush mount in her cheeks, she looked down quickly’
‘fluorescent lights are mounted on the ceiling’
‘the engine is mounted behind the rear seats’
‘the photographs will be mounted and framed’
‘there is a limit to the number of hard disks you can have mounted’
‘a decorated photograph mount’
‘delicate mounts for necklaces, earrings, and rings’
‘heavy cannon were torn from their mounts’
‘a mount for a pair of binoculars’
‘he hung on to his mount's bridle’
‘the jockey's injuries forced him to give up the coveted mount on Cool Ground’

--Word--
Mountbatten, Louis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma (1900–79), British admiral and administrator, uncle of Britain's Prince Philip; full name Louis Francis Albert Victor Nicholas Mountbatten. He was supreme Allied commander in SE Asia (1943–5); after the war, he was the last viceroy (1947) and first Governor General of India (1947–8). He was killed by an IRA bomb while on his yacht.
--Examples--

mount 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Climb up (stairs, a hill, or other rising surface)
Climb or move up on to (a raised surface)
Get up on (an animal or bicycle) in order to ride it.
Set (someone) on horseback; provide with a horse.

Grow larger or more numerous.

(of blood) rise visibly into the cheeks.
Place or fix (an object) on a support.
Set in or attach to a backing or setting.
Fix (an object for viewing) on a microscope slide.
Make (a disk or disk drive) available for use.
A backing or setting on which a photograph, gem, or work of art is set for display.
A glass microscope slide for securing a specimen to be viewed.
A stamp hinge.
A support for a gun, camera, or similar piece of equipment.
A horse that is ridden or is available for riding.
An opportunity to ride a horse, especially as a jockey.
--Examples--
‘he mounted the steps’
‘the master of ceremonies mounted the platform’
‘he mounted the horse’

‘a female was immediately mounted by the cat’

‘the photographs will be mounted and framed’
‘there is a limit to the number of hard disks you can have mounted’
‘a decorated photograph mount’
‘delicate mounts for necklaces, earrings, and rings’
‘heavy cannon were torn from their mounts’
‘a mount for a pair of binoculars’
‘he hung on to his mount's bridle’
‘the jockey's injuries forced him to give up the coveted mount on Cool Ground’
--Word--
mourn 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Feel or show sorrow for the death of (someone), typically by following conventions such as the wearing of black clothes.
Feel regret or sadness about (the loss or disappearance of something)
--Examples--
‘Isobel mourned her husband’
‘she mourned for her friends who died in the accident’
‘publishers mourned declining sales of hardback fiction’

--Word--
mouse 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small rodent that typically has a pointed snout, relatively large ears and eyes, and a long tail.
(in general use) any small mammal similar to a mouse, such as a shrew or vole.
A shy, timid, and quiet person.
A dull light brown colour reminiscent of a mouse's fur.
A small handheld device which is moved across a mat or flat surface to move the cursor on a computer screen.
A lump or bruise on or near the eye.
(of a cat or owl) hunt for or catch mice.
Prowl about as if searching.
Use a mouse to move or position a cursor on a computer screen.
--Examples--
‘Jane may be a bit of a mouse, but she is very nosy’
‘her flaxen hair dulled to mouse’
‘copy the file with a click of the mouse’
‘the right mouse button’
‘she touched the mouse under her eye’
‘female cats are usually much better at mousing than males’
‘he was mousing among the books of the old library’
‘simply mouse over any item on the list’

--Word--
still 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adverb, verb
--Meanings--
Not moving or making a sound.
(of air, water, or the weather) undisturbed by wind, sound, or current; calm and tranquil.
(of a drink) not effervescent.
Deep silence and calm; stillness.
An ordinary static photograph as opposed to a motion picture, especially a single shot from a cinema film.
Up to and including the present or the time mentioned; even now (or then) as formerly.
Referring to something that will or may happen in the future.
Nevertheless; all the same.
Even (used with comparatives for emphasis)
Make or become still; quieten.
--Examples--
‘the still body of the young man’
‘the sheriff commanded him to stand still and drop the gun’
‘she sat very still, her eyes closed’
‘he lay still, unable to move’
‘her voice carried on the still air’
‘a still autumn day’
‘the still of the night’
‘film stills’
‘stills photography’
‘he still lives with his mother’
‘it was still raining’
‘we could still win’
‘I'm afraid he's crazy. Still, he's harmless’
‘write, or better still, type, captions for the pictures’
‘Hank, already sweltering, began to sweat still more profusely’
‘she raised her hand, stilling Erica's protests’
‘the din in the hall stilled’
--Word--
mousetail 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The tail of a mouse.
A dwarf plant of seasonally wet places, Myosurus minimus (family Ranunculaceae), with single tiny yellowish-green flowers and numerous achenes in an elongating spike, which is native to Old World temperate regions and naturalized elsewhere. Also (with distinguishing word): any of several related North American species of Myosurus.
In full "mousetail grass". A foxtail grass with a slender spike, especially black grass, Alopecurus myosuroides. Also (British regional) in plural with singular concord. Now rare.
A fescue grass of the genus Vulpia having a narrow panicle; specifically (more fully "mousetail fescue" (also "mousetail fescue-grass"), †"mousetail grass"), rat's-tail fescue, V. myuros.
In singular and plural US slang. A moustache; specifically a pencil-line moustache. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
mousetrap 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A trap for catching and usually killing mice, especially one with a spring bar which snaps down on to the mouse when it touches a piece of cheese or other bait attached to the mechanism.
Cheese of poor quality.
Induce (someone) to do something by means of a trick.
Block (a user's) efforts to exit from a website, usually one to which they have been redirected.
--Examples--
‘the editor mousetrapped her into giving him an article’

--Word--
mousse 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A sweet or savoury dish made as a smooth, light mass in which the main ingredient is whipped with cream and egg white.
A mass of tiny bubbles that forms on the top of a glass of champagne or sparkling wine.
A light, foamy preparation used for styling hair.
A cosmetic or skincare product with a foamy consistency.
A frothy brown emulsion of oil and seawater formed by weathering of an oil slick.
Style (hair) using mousse.
--Examples--
‘sponge topped with chocolate mousse’
‘a salmon mousse’
‘the Brut Réserve possesses a wonderful creamy mousse of small, compact bubbles’
‘apply a dollop of volumizing mousse to the roots and work it in towards the ends of your hair’
‘experiment with different styling products such as mousses and gels’
‘this rich shower mousse has an uplifting blend of grapefruit, lemon, orange peel, and cedarwood oils’
‘mousse each section before winding on rollers’
‘his blow-dried and moussed hair’
--Word--
mousseline 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A very fine, semi-opaque fabric similar to muslin.
A soft, light sweet or savoury mousse.
Hollandaise sauce that has been made frothy with whipped cream or egg white, served mainly with fish or asparagus.
--Examples--
‘a silk mousseline camisole’

--Word--
Mussorgsky, Modest 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1839–81), Russian composer; full name Modest Petrovich Mussorgsky. His best-known works include the opera Boris Godunov (1874), Songs and Dances of Death (1875–7), and the piano suite Pictures at an Exhibition (1874).

--Word--
Mousterian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting the main culture of the Middle Palaeolithic period in Europe, between the Acheulian and Aurignacian periods (chiefly 80,000–35,000 years ago). It is associated with Neanderthal peoples and is typified by flints worked on one side only.
The Mousterian culture or period.
--Examples--
--Word--
Moutan 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tall shrubby peony with pink or white blotched flowers, native to China and Tibet and the parent of many garden varieties.
--Examples--
--Word--
mouth 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The opening and cavity in the lower part of the human face, surrounded by the lips, through which food is taken in and vocal sounds are emitted.
The opening through which an animal takes in food, corresponding to the human mouth.
A horse's readiness to feel and obey the pressure of the bit in its mouth.
The character or quality of a wine as judged by its feel or flavour in the mouth (rather than its aroma).
Talkativeness or impudence.
An opening or entrance to a hollow, concave, or enclosed structure.
The opening for filling or emptying a container.
The muzzle of a gun.
The place where a river enters the sea.
The opening or entrance to a harbour or bay.
Move the lips as if saying (something)
Say (something dull or unoriginal), especially in a pompous or affected way.
Utter very clearly and distinctly.
Take in or touch with the mouth.
Train the mouth of (a horse) so that it responds to a bit.
--Examples--
‘Ben stood transfixed with disbelief, his mouth open’
‘he leaned over and kissed her on the mouth’
‘she could have bitten her tongue the moment the words left her mouth’
‘the carp picks up the bait by sucking it into its mouth’
‘the horse had a hard mouth’
‘you've got more mouth on you than anyone I've ever known’
‘the mouth of a cave’
‘the mouth of the bottle’
‘why would anyone want to be shot out of the mouth of a cannon?’
‘a pool at the mouth of the river’
‘sand from the beach is silting up the harbour mouth’
‘she mouthed a silent farewell’
‘‘Come on,’ he mouthed’
‘this clergyman mouths platitudes in breathy, soothing tones’
‘she would carefully mouth the right pronunciation’
‘puppies may mouth each other's collars during play’
‘the young horse was being mouthed, or bitted, for the first time’
--Word--
mouthable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That may be spoken with good effect; suitable for oratory or recitation.
--Examples--
--Word--
mouth-breeder 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mouth brooder.
--Examples--
--Word--
mouthbrooder 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A freshwater cichlid fish which protects its eggs (and in some cases its young) by carrying them in its mouth.
--Examples--
--Word--
mouthed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a person or animal) having a mouth of a specified kind.
Having an opening or entrance of a specified kind.
--Examples--
‘a clown's face, wide-mouthed and laughing’
‘a shallow, wide-mouthed cave’
‘a small-mouthed bottle’

mouthly 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Done with the mouth; oral.
--Examples--
--Word--
mouth-filling 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of an oath, compliment, etc.: bombastic, inflated. Now archaic.
Of wine or its flavour: full-bodied; stimulating to the mouth.
--Examples--
--Word--
mouthful 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A quantity of food or drink that fills or can be put in the mouth.
A long or complicated word or phrase that is difficult to say.
--Examples--
‘he took a mouthful of beer’
‘poliomyelitis is a bit of a mouthful’

mouthy 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Inclined to talk a lot, especially in a rude or insolent way.
--Examples--
‘an especially mouthy eleven-year-old’

mouthiness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The tendency or inclination to talk a lot, especially in a rude or insolent way.
--Examples--
‘Penn is well suited to capture Wilson's arrogance and mouthiness’
--Word--
mouth 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The opening and cavity in the lower part of the human face, surrounded by the lips, through which food is taken in and vocal sounds are emitted.
The opening through which an animal takes in food, corresponding to the human mouth.
A horse's readiness to feel and obey the pressure of the bit in its mouth.
The character or quality of a wine as judged by its feel or flavour in the mouth (rather than its aroma).
Talkativeness or impudence.
An opening or entrance to a hollow, concave, or enclosed structure.
The opening for filling or emptying a container.
The muzzle of a gun.
The place where a river enters the sea.
The opening or entrance to a harbour or bay.
Move the lips as if saying (something)
Say (something dull or unoriginal), especially in a pompous or affected way.
Utter very clearly and distinctly.
Take in or touch with the mouth.
Train the mouth of (a horse) so that it responds to a bit.
--Examples--
‘Ben stood transfixed with disbelief, his mouth open’
‘he leaned over and kissed her on the mouth’
‘she could have bitten her tongue the moment the words left her mouth’

‘‘Come on,’ he mouthed’

‘she would carefully mouth the right pronunciation’
‘puppies may mouth each other's collars during play’
‘the young horse was being mouthed, or bitted, for the first time’

mouthpart 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of the appendages, typically found in pairs, surrounding the mouth of an insect or other arthropod and adapted for feeding.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
mouthpiece 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The part of a musical instrument, telephone, etc. designed to be put in or against the mouth.
A gumshield.
A person or organization who speaks on behalf of another person or organization.
A lawyer.
--Examples--
‘he shouted into the mouthpiece, but there was no response’
‘the snorkel's mouthpiece’
‘he yanked out his brother's mouthpiece so he could breathe through all the blood’
‘the media acts as a mouthpiece for the Party’
‘his attorney isn't one of those cheap mouthpieces you see on a billboard’
--Word--
mouthpiece 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The part of a musical instrument, telephone, etc. designed to be put in or against the mouth.
A gumshield.

‘his attorney isn't one of those cheap mouthpieces you see on a billboard’
--Word--
mouth-root 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small North American plant of shady swamps, Coptis trifolia (family Ranunculaceae), which has an astringent root reputed to cure sore mouths; also called goldthread.
--Examples--

--Word--
mouth-to-mouth 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Denoting a method of artificial respiration in which a person breathes into an unconscious patient's lungs through their mouth.
Mouth-to-mouth respiration.
--Examples--
‘mouth-to-mouth resuscitation’
‘Stacey needed mouth-to-mouth’

mouthwatering 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Smelling, looking, or sounding delicious.
Highly attractive or tempting.
--Examples--
‘a small but mouthwatering collection of recipes’
‘investors expected the new boss to tie up some mouthwatering deals’

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

Highly attractive or tempting.
--Examples--
‘a mouth-watering mixture of French and English cuisine’
‘mouth-watering views of the mountains’

mouton 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Sheepskin cut and dyed to resemble beaver fur or sealskin.
--Examples--
--Word--
roche moutonnée 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small bare outcrop of rock shaped by glacial erosion, with one side smooth and gently sloping and the other steep, rough, and irregular.

--Word--
movability 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
movable 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Capable of being moved.
(of a feast or festival) variable in date from year to year.
(of property) of the nature of a chattel, as distinct from land or buildings.
Property or possessions not including land or buildings.
An article of furniture that may be removed from a house, as distinct from a fixture.
--Examples--
‘they stripped the town of all movable objects and fled’
‘a perpetual calendar for all religious feasts, both fixed and movable’
‘a man of sufficient movable property but with hardly any land’
‘in many cases the movables are the facilities and stock-in-trade of a business’
‘a tax of one shilling in the pound on movables’
‘all the movables have been removed and the roof has fallen in’
--Word--
movably 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Word--
move 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Go in a specified direction or manner; change position.
Change the place, position, or state of.
Change one's place of residence or work.
(of a player) change the position of a piece in a board game.
Depart; start off.
Hurry up.
Go quickly.
(with reference to merchandise) sell or be sold.
Make progress; develop in a particular manner or direction.
Change from one state, opinion, or activity to another.
Take action.
Spend one's time in (a particular sphere) or among (a particular group of people)
Influence or prompt (someone) to do something.
Arouse a strong feeling, especially of sorrow or sympathy, in (someone)
Stir up (an emotion) in someone.
Propose for discussion and resolution at a meeting or legislative assembly.
Apply formally to (a court or assembly) for something.
Empty (the bowels)
A change of place, position, or state.
A change of house or business premises.
An act that initiates or advances a process or plan.
A manoeuvre in a sport or game.
A player's turn to change the position of a piece in a board game.
--Examples--
‘she moved to the door’
‘I heard him moving about upstairs’
‘she moved the tray to a side table’
‘can you move your car so I can get mine out?’
‘his family moved to London when he was a child’
‘they moved house four days after the baby was born’
‘White has forced his opponent to move’
‘if Black moves his bishop he loses a pawn’
‘let's move—it's time we started shopping’
‘come on—move it!’
‘Kennings was really moving when he made contact with a tyre at the hairpin and flipped over’
‘booksellers should easily be able to move this biography of Lincoln’
‘aircraft design had moved forward a long way’
‘councillors are anxious to get things moving as soon as possible’
‘the school moved over to the new course in 1987’
‘she deftly moved the conversation to safer territory’
‘hardliners may yet move against him, but their success might be limited’
‘she moved in the pop and art worlds’
‘his deep love of music moved him to take lessons with Dr Hill’
‘she felt deeply moved by this picture of his plight’
‘he justly moves one's derision’
‘she intends to move an amendment to the Bill’
‘I beg to move that this House deplores the government's economic policies’
‘his family moved the Special Court for adequate ‘maintenance expenses’ to run the household’
‘if you haven't moved your bowels today you'd better do it now’
‘she made a sudden move towards me’
‘the country's move to independence’
‘a career move’
‘Annie mourned her move from the noisy, crowded town to the peace of the countryside’
‘the need for more space led to the move to the present offices’
‘my next move is to talk to Matthew’
‘Robson began a move which saw Webb run from the halfway line down the right’
‘in this position Karpov had to seal his 41st move’
‘I am a pawn and bishop down after 12 moves’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or condition of being motionless or immobile.
--Examples--
--Word--
movelessness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
movement 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An act of moving.
An arrival or departure of an aircraft.
The activities and whereabouts of someone during a particular period of time.
General activity or bustle.
The moving parts of a mechanism, especially a clock or watch.
A change or development.
A group of people working together to advance their shared political, social, or artistic ideas.
A campaign undertaken by a political, social, or artistic movement.
A principal division of a longer musical work, self-sufficient in terms of key, tempo, and structure.
An act of defecation.
--Examples--
‘a slight movement of the body’
‘the free movement of labour’
‘the Civil Aviation Authority directed 125,000 aircraft movements in 1991’
‘your movements and telephone conversations are recorded’
‘the scene was almost devoid of movement’
‘we restore antique clock movements’
‘the movement towards greater sexual equality’
‘movements in the underlying financial markets’
‘the labour movement’
‘a movement to declare war on poverty’
‘the slow movement of his violin concerto’

--Word--
mover 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or thing that moves.
A person whose job is to remove and transport furniture from one house to another.
A person who makes a formal proposal at a meeting or in an assembly.
A person who instigates or organizes something.
--Examples--
‘she's a lovely mover’
‘job movers’
‘he watched movers load the remaining boxes on an 18-wheel van’
‘movers and seconders rise and give speeches’
‘she was the key mover in making this successful conference happen’

‘my next move is to talk to Matthew’
‘Robson began a move which saw Webb run from the halfway line down the right’
‘in this position Karpov had to seal his 41st move’
‘I am a pawn and bishop down after 12 moves’

--Word--
Movietone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A trademark for: a system for recording sound on a film negative, formerly used chiefly in making newsreels; a film made using this system. Also used allusively of the very formal style of presentation characteristic of newsreels produced by the Movietone Company. Usually attributive Compare phonofilm, "Vitaphone".

mow 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Cut down (grass) with a machine.
Cut down (grass or a cereal crop) with a scythe.
mow someone down
Kill someone with a fusillade of bullets or other missiles.
Recklessly knock down someone with a car or other vehicle.
A stack of hay, corn, or other crop.
A place in a barn where a stack of hay, corn, etc. is put.
--Examples--
‘Roger mowed the lawn’
‘they mowed green corn, to give the blades to horses’
‘he was mown down in a hail of machine-gun bullets’
‘a father-of-four was mown down and killed as he cycled home from work’
‘a hay mow’

Swahili 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A Bantu language widely used as a lingua franca in East Africa and having official status in several countries. There are probably fewer than 2 million native speakers, but it is in everyday use by over 20 million.
A member of a people of Zanzibar and nearby coastal regions, descendants of the original speakers of Swahili.
Relating to Swahili or to its native speakers.

--Word--
much 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, adverb
--Meanings--
A large amount.
Used to refer disparagingly to someone or something as being a poor specimen.
To a great extent; a great deal.
For a large part of one's time; often.
--Examples--
‘I didn't get much sleep that night’
‘I did so much shopping’
‘he does not eat much’
‘they must bear much of the blame’
‘I'm not much of a gardener’
‘did it hurt much?’
‘thanks very much’
‘they did not mind, much to my surprise’
‘they look much better’
‘I'm not there much’

muchacho 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in Spanish-speaking countries) a young man (or woman).
A male (or female) servant.
--Examples--
--Word--
much 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, adverb
--Meanings--
A large amount.
Used to refer disparagingly to someone or something as being a poor specimen.
To a great extent; a great deal.
For a large part of one's time; often.
--Examples--
‘I didn't get much sleep that night’
‘I did so much shopping’
‘he does not eat much’
‘they must bear much of the blame’
‘I'm not much of a gardener’
‘did it hurt much?’
‘thanks very much’
‘they did not mind, much to my surprise’
‘they look much better’
‘I'm not there much’

--Word--
branched 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a tree or plant) having parts that grow out from the trunk or from a bough.
Having lateral extensions or subdivisions extending from the main part.
--Examples--
‘a tall, branched plant with flowers’
‘many trees are bare-branched already’
‘the elaborate branched antlers of the stag’
‘a branched network’

--Word--
hunger 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A feeling of discomfort or weakness caused by lack of food, coupled with the desire to eat.
A severe lack of food.
A strong desire or craving.
Have a strong desire or craving for.
Feel or suffer hunger.
--Examples--
‘she was faint with hunger’
‘they died from cold and hunger’
‘her hunger for knowledge’
‘he hungered for a sense of self-worth’
‘when he had fasted forty days and forty nights, he afterwards hungered’

--Word--
muciferous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Containing, secreting, or covered with mucus or mucoid material; conveying mucus; (in later use) specifically designating the mucocysts of protozoans, especially in "muciferous body".
--Examples--
--Word--
muciform 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling mucus; mucoid.
--Examples--
--Word--
mucigen 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A substance that is an intracellular precursor or storage form of mucin. Frequently attributive.
--Examples--
--Word--
mucigenous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Containing mucigen; producing mucus.
--Examples--
--Word--
mucilage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A viscous secretion or bodily fluid.
A polysaccharide substance extracted as a viscous or gelatinous solution from plant roots, seeds, etc., and used in medicines and adhesives.
An adhesive solution; gum or glue.
--Examples--
--Word--
mucilage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A viscous secretion or bodily fluid.
A polysaccharide substance extracted as a viscous or gelatinous solution from plant roots, seeds, etc., and used in medicines and adhesives.
An adhesive solution; gum or glue.
--Examples--
--Word--
mucilaginous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a viscous or gelatinous consistency.
(of a plant, seed, etc.) containing a polysaccharide substance that is extracted as a viscous or gelatinous solution and used in medicines and adhesives.
--Examples--
‘a mucilaginous paste’
‘greasy and mucilaginous foods’
‘the young leaves are tender and mucilaginous’

--Word--
muck 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Dirt, rubbish, or waste matter.
Farmyard manure, widely used as fertilizer.
Something regarded as distasteful, unpleasant, or of poor quality.
Remove manure and other dirt from a horse's stable or other animal's dwelling.
Spread manure on (land)
--Examples--
‘I'll just clean the muck off the windscreen’
‘he was covered in cow muck and mud’
‘why do you let her read this muck?’
‘I was mucking out some of the dirtiest piggeries I had ever seen’
‘half the farm is mucked every year’
--Word--
muckamuck 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person of great importance or self-importance.
--Examples--
‘a big Hollywood muckety-muck’

noun

--Word--
muckerism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: unsportsmanlike conduct. Later generally: rowdy, coarse, or unsophisticated behaviour or attitudes. In quot. 1952: prejudice against such behaviour or attitudes.
--Examples--

--Word--
mucket 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A North American freshwater mussel of the family Unionidae; specifically Actinonaias ligamentina of the eastern United States or a related species, usually of the genus Lampsilis or Leptodea.
--Examples--

--Meanings--
Now chiefly regional and archaic= muck-heap.

muckite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An opaque, yellow resinous variety of retinite found in coal-beds in Moravia, in the Czech Republic.

--Word--
muckweed 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A goosefoot, Chenopodium album, which grows on manure heaps.

--Examples--
--Word--
muckworm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who is despicable, especially one who is intellectually or morally deficient; a lowly person. Now rare.
A worm or grub that lives in manure; specifically the larva of a dung beetle. Now US.
--Examples--

combining form
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
mucocele 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mucus-filled cyst, cyst-like structure, or cavity, most commonly resulting from obstruction in a lacrimal or salivary gland, the vermiform appendix, or a paranasal sinus.
--Examples--
--Word--
mucocutaneous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Anatomy and Medicine. Designating the junction between a mucous membrane and the skin, as at the mouth, anus, etc.
Medicine. Of, relating to, or affecting mucous membranes and skin.
--Examples--
--Word--
mucodermal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Medicine= mucocutaneous.
--Examples--

mucolytic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Able to degrade or disperse mucus or mucoids, or decrease their viscosity.
A mucolytic agent.
--Examples--
--Word--
mucomembranous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
muconic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A crystalline unsaturated dicarboxylic acid, (HOOC·CH:CH—)₂; 2,4-hexadienedioic acid.
--Examples--
--Word--
mucopolysaccharide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a group of compounds occurring chiefly as components of connective tissue. They are complex polysaccharides containing amino groups.
--Examples--
--Word--
mucoprotein 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Glycoprotein that is rich in acidic polysaccharides; a particular glycoprotein of this type, especially a proteoglycan.
--Examples--
--Word--
mucopurulent 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Consisting of mucus and pus.
--Examples--
--Word--
mucopus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mucus mixed with pus.
--Examples--
--Word--
mucor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mouldiness, mustiness; mould. Now rare.
Mycology. In form Mucor. A genus of fungi, originally (especially in Linnaean use) comprising diverse (chiefly mould-forming) fungi and slime moulds, but later restricted to some fifty usually saprophytic zygomycetes which produce abundant mycelium; (also mucor) a fungus of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
mucoraceous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Belonging to or characteristic of the family Mucoraceae, which includes Mucor.
--Examples--
--Word--
mucorine 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
= mucoraceous.
--Examples--
--Word--
mucormycosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Infection of a human, other mammal, or bird with a zygomycete fungus, especially one of the family Mucoraceae; an instance of this.
--Examples--
--Word--
mucorrhoea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
mucorrhoea 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Discharge of mucus (whether pathological or physiological).
--Examples--
--Word--
mucor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Mouldiness, mustiness; mould. Now rare.
Mycology. In form Mucor. A genus of fungi, originally (especially in Linnaean use) comprising diverse (chiefly mould-forming) fungi and slime moulds, but later restricted to some fifty usually saprophytic zygomycetes which produce abundant mycelium; (also mucor) a fungus of this genus.
--Examples--

mucus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A slimy substance, typically not miscible with water, secreted by the mucous membranes and glands of animals for lubrication, protection, etc.
A gummy substance found in plants; mucilage.
--Examples--
--Word--
mucus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A slimy substance, typically not miscible with water, secreted by the mucous membranes and glands of animals for lubrication, protection, etc.
A gummy substance found in plants; mucilage.

mud 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

Information or allegations regarded as damaging or scandalous.

‘the two sides took over the local media to throw mud at each other’
--Word--
mudar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Either of two tropical shrubs of the genus Calotropis (family Asclepiadaceae), C. gigantea, of eastern Asia, and C. procera, of Asia and Africa, which have bark yielding a fibre and seed-floss which can be used like kapok. Also: a medicinal preparation of the root of either of these shrubs.
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--
A bank of mud on the bed of a river or the bottom of the sea.

mudcat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several North American freshwater catfishes of the family Ictaluridae, found in muddy rivers especially in the Mississippi valley.
An inhabitant of Mississippi.

--Word--
muddy 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Covered in or full of mud.
Not bright or clear; dirty-looking.
(of a sound, especially in music) not clearly defined.
Confused, vague, or illogical.
Cover or fill (something) with mud.
Make (something) hard or harder to understand.
--Examples--
‘they changed their muddy boots’
‘the original colours were blurred into muddy pink and yellow’
‘an awful muddy sound that renders his vocals incoherent’
‘some sentences are so muddy that their meaning can only be guessed’
‘the linoleum flooring was muddied’
‘the first year's results muddy rather than clarify the situation’
--Word--
complexioned 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
‘they were both fair-complexioned’

mudding 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly Canadian. The filling of cracks in the walls of a house or log cabin with mud. Also concrete: the mud itself.
The playing of MUD computer games; this activity as a pastime or interest.

--Word--
muddle 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Bring into a disordered or confusing state.
Confuse (a person or their thoughts)
Busy oneself in an aimless or ineffective way.
Mix (a drink) or stir (an ingredient) into a drink.
An untidy and disorganized state or collection.
A mistake arising from or resulting in confusion.
muddle through
Cope more or less satisfactorily despite lack of expertise, planning, or equipment.
muddle something up
Confuse two or more things with each other.
--Examples--
‘they were muddling up the cards’
‘Paul was hopelessly muddled by the rates of exchange’
‘he was muddling about in the kitchen’
‘the finances were in a muddle’
‘she was able to cut through confusion and muddle’
‘a bureaucratic muddle’
‘while the children were young, we managed to muddle through’
‘the words seemed to have got muddled up’
--Word--
muddled

adjective
--Meanings--
Not arranged in order; untidy.
Not clear or coherent; confused.
--Examples--
‘the muddled display of pictures has been taken down’
‘such a view reflects muddled thinking’

--Word--
Mudejar 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or denoting a partly Gothic, partly Islamic style of architecture and art prevalent in Spain in the 12th to 15th centuries.
Relating to Muslim subjects of Christian monarchs during the reconquest of the Iberian peninsula from the Moors (11th–15th centuries) who, until 1492, were allowed to retain Islamic laws and religion in return for loyalty to a Christian monarch.
A Mudejar Muslim during the Christian reconquest of the Iberian peninsula from the Moors.
--Examples--
--Word--
exhausted 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Very tired.
(of resources or reserves) completely used up.
(of a place) no longer productive as a result of being drained of resources.
--Examples--
‘she returned home, exhausted from work’
‘Kirov spat, his patience suddenly exhausted’
‘exhausted peat workings’

--Word--
mudhead 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
US informal (derogatory). A native of Tennessee. Now rare.
Among the Zuni and Hopi peoples of North America: a ceremonial clown who wears a mask daubed with mud.
Slang (derogatory). A stupid person; = "blockhead".
--Examples--
--Word--
mudhole 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hole containing mud or in which mud collects, especially one which forms a defect or obstacle in a road; specifically a hot mud spring.
A hole at the base of a boiler, condenser, etc., through which sediment can be removed.
A despised place; a place of filth and squalor.
A situation or factor that impedes progress or entraps a person.

--Word--
lost 
--Type--
verb, adjective
--Meanings--
Unable to find one's way; not knowing one's whereabouts.
Unable to be found.
Unable to understand or to cope with a situation.
That has been taken away or cannot be recovered.
(of time or an opportunity) not used advantageously; wasted.
Having died or been destroyed.
(of a game or contest) in which a defeat has been sustained.
--Examples--
‘Help! We're lost!’
‘he turned up with my lost golf clubs’
‘she stood there clutching a drink, feeling completely lost’
‘I'd be lost without her’
‘if only one could recapture one's lost youth’
‘the decision meant a lost opportunity to create 200 jobs’
‘a memorial to the lost crewmen’
‘the lost election of 1979’

--Word--
shot 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The firing of a gun or cannon.
An attempt to hit a target by shooting.
A person with a specified level of ability in shooting.
A critical or hostile remark.
A hit, stroke, or kick of the ball in sports such as football, tennis, or golf.
An attempt to score a goal.
An attempt to do something.
A ball of stone or metal used as a missile shot from a large gun or cannon.
Tiny lead pellets used in quantity in a single charge or cartridge in a shotgun.
A heavy ball thrown by a shot-putter.
A photograph.
A film sequence photographed continuously by one camera.
The range of a camera's view.
A small drink of spirits.
A single serving of espresso coffee.
An injection of a drug or vaccine.
The launch of a space rocket.
--Examples--
‘Mulder killed him with a single shot’
‘they have fired the opening shot in what's expected to be a savage price war’
‘he asked me if I would like to have a shot at a pheasant’
‘Roy was a very good shot’
‘Paul tried one last shot—‘You realize what you want will cost more money?’’
‘his partner pulled off a winning backhand shot’
‘he took a shot that the goalie stopped’
‘several of the competitors will have a shot at the all-round title’
‘metal fragments and lead shot were sent in all directions’
‘a group shot of all the family’
‘the movie's opening shot is of a character walking across a featureless landscape’
‘a prop man was standing just out of shot’
‘he took a shot of whisky’
‘steamed milk with a shot of espresso’
‘a shot of impure heroin’
‘a moon shot’

--Word--
mudskipper 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A goby (fish) with its eyes on raised bumps on top of the head, found in mangrove swamps from East Africa to Australia. It moves about on land with great agility, often basking on mud or mangrove roots.
--Examples--
--Word--
mudslide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mass of mud and other earthy material that is falling or has fallen down a hillside or other slope.
--Examples--
--Word--
mudsling 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make malicious or scandalous allegations about an opponent with the aim of damaging their reputation.
--Examples--
‘it's difficult to see how any parliamentary opposition would voluntarily give up the opportunity to smear and mudsling’

--Word--
mud-slinging 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The use of insults and accusations, especially unjust ones, with the aim of damaging the reputation of an opponent.
--Examples--
‘politicians seem to rely on mud-slinging instead of argument’

mudsucker 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various birds, especially waders, that obtain their food from mud.
US. Any of various North American freshwater fishes that feed on the bottom of streams and ponds; especially a goby, Gillichthys mirabilis, often used as bait.
--Examples--

mud-walled 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having mud walls. Also †figurative (obsolete).
--Examples--
--Word--
mudwort 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A very small creeping plant that grows in mud and damp soils in north temperate regions.

--Word--
Munster 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A province of the Republic of Ireland, in the south-western part of the country.
A city in north-western Germany; population 272,100 (est. 2006). It was formerly the capital of Westphalia; the Treaty of Westphalia, which ended the Thirty Years War, was signed simultaneously here and at Osnabrück in 1648.

muff 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A tube made of fur or other warm material into which the hands are placed for warmth.
A warm or protective covering for other parts of the body.
A woman's genitals.
Handle (a situation, task, or opportunity) clumsily or badly.
A mistake or failure, especially a failure to catch or receive a ball cleanly in sport.
A clumsy or incompetent person, especially in relation to a sport or manual skill.
--Examples--
‘the administration muffed several of its biggest projects’

--Word--
muffle 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Wrap or cover for warmth.
Cover or wrap up (a source of sound) to reduce its loudness.
Make (a sound) quieter or less distinct.
A receptacle in a furnace or kiln in which things can be heated without contact with combustion products.
--Examples--
‘everyone was muffled up in coats and scarves’
‘the soft beat of a muffled drum’
‘his voice was muffled’
‘the trade unions fear their voice within the party is being muffled’
‘a muffle furnace’
--Word--
muffled 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a sound) not loud because of being obstructed in some way; muted.
--Examples--
‘they heard the sounds of muffled voices’
--Word--
muffledly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a muffled manner; indistinctly.

muffler 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A wrap or scarf worn around the neck and face for warmth.
A device used to deaden the sound of a drum, bell, piano, or other instrument.
A device fixed to the exhaust of a motor vehicle to reduce engine noise; a silencer.

mufti 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--

--Type--
noun, noun

--Word--
mug 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large cup, typically cylindrical with a handle and used without a saucer.
The contents of a mug.
A person's face.
A stupid or gullible person.
A hoodlum or thug.
Attack and rob (someone) in a public place.
Make faces, especially silly or exaggerated ones, before an audience or a camera.
--Examples--
‘she picked up her coffee mug’
‘I drank a mug of tea’
‘I don't want to see Barry's ugly mug when I get home’
‘they were no mugs where finance was concerned’
‘he was mugged by three men who stole his bike’
‘he mugged for the camera’
--Word--
muga 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A wild silk obtained in Assam from the cocoons of the silkworm Antheraea assama (also "muga silk"); the silkworm itself (also "muga silkworm").
--Examples--
--Word--
Mugabe, Robert 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1924), Zimbabwean statesman, prime minister 1980–7 and president since 1987; full name Robert Gabriel Mugabe. He became prime minister in Zimbabwe's first post-independence elections. In 1987 his party ZANU merged with ZAPU and Mugabe became executive president of a one-party state.
--Examples--
--Word--
mugearite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dark, fine-grained trachyte which has oligoclase as the main feldspar and also contains olivine, orthoclase, and apatite.

mugget 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The intestines of a calf or sheep, especially when cooked as food. Also: the uterus of a deer; = "gather-bag". Now historical and English regional (south-western).
A dish made from the cooked intestines of a calf or sheep. Now historical.

--Word--
Muggletonian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a small Christian sect founded in England c.1651 by Lodowicke Muggleton (1609–98) and John Reeve (1608–58), who claimed to be the two witnesses mentioned in the book of Revelation (Rev. 11:3–6). Despite many eccentric doctrines, the sect survived into the late 19th century.
Relating to the Muggletonians.
--Examples--
--Word--
Muggletonianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The doctrines or practice of the Muggletonians.
--Examples--
--Word--
mugo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In full "mugo pine". The dwarf mountain pine, Pinus mugo, of central and south-eastern European mountains, which forms a counterpart to the tree-sized P. uncinata of south-western Europe.

muhajir 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who accompanied Muhammad in his emigration from Mecca to Medina in 622.
A person who emigrates from a country which is, or has become, ruled by non-Muslims. Now: specifically one of the Muslim emigrants who left India for Pakistan at or after the time of the Indian Partition in 1947; a descendant of these people.

muid 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A dry measure used for grain, meat, salt, etc.
A liquid measure of widely varying capacity; a cask holding this amount.
A dry measure of capacity approximately equal to three bushels (109 litres), used chiefly for grain.

Muir, John 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1838–1914), Scottish-born American naturalist, a pioneer of environmental conservation. Muir was largely responsible for the establishment of Yosemite and Sequoia National Parks in California (1890).

mujtahid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person accepted as an original authority in Islamic law. Such authorities continue to be recognized in the Shia tradition, but Sunni Muslims accord this status only to the great lawmakers of early Islam.

--Word--
mulattoism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The interbreeding or sexual union of whites and non-whites resulting in the birth of mulattos. In later use also: the racial, social, and cultural mix resulting from such interbreeding; multiculturalism.
--Examples--

mulberry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small deciduous tree with broad leaves, native to East Asia and long cultivated elsewhere.
The dark red or white fruit of the mulberry.
A dark red or purple colour.
--Examples--
‘a mulberry carpet’
--Word--
mulch 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Material (such as decaying leaves, bark, or compost) spread around or over a plant to enrich or insulate the soil.
An application of mulch.
Treat or cover with mulch.
--Examples--
‘regular mulches keep down annual weeds’
‘the perennials have been cut back and mulched’
‘mulch annually around the plants to retain the moisture’
--Word--
mulch 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Material (such as decaying leaves, bark, or compost) spread around or over a plant to enrich or insulate the soil.
An application of mulch.
Treat or cover with mulch.
--Examples--
‘regular mulches keep down annual weeds’
‘the perennials have been cut back and mulched’
‘mulch annually around the plants to retain the moisture’
--Word--
mulcher 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A machine which reduces plant material, etc., to the consistency of mulch; especially one that shreds plant clippings, etc., for use as mulch.
--Examples--

--Word--
mulct 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Extract money from (someone) by fine or taxation.
Take money or possessions from (someone) by fraudulent means.
A fine or compulsory payment.
--Examples--
‘no government dared propose to mulct the taxpayer for such a purpose’
‘a rapacious old woman who would never miss the few dollars mulcted of her’

Muldoonism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The political policies associated with the former New Zealand Prime Minister Robert Muldoon.
--Examples--
‘economic policy changes were needed in the mid-1980s after nine years of Muldoonism’
--Word--
mule 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
The offspring of a donkey and a horse (strictly, a male donkey and a female horse), typically sterile and used as a beast of burden.
An obstinate person.
A courier for illegal drugs.
A hybrid plant or animal, especially a sterile one.
Any of several standard cross-bred varieties of sheep.
A kind of spinning machine producing yarn on spindles, invented by Samuel Crompton in 1779.
A small tractor or locomotive, typically one that is electrically powered.
A coin with the obverse and reverse of designs not originally intended to be used together.
A woman's slipper or light shoe without a back.
--Examples--
--Word--
muleback 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In "on (also by,etc.) muleback": mounted or loaded on the back of a mule or mules.
--Examples--
--Word--
muled 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a coin: having the obverse and reverse produced by dies not originally intended for use on the same coin.
--Examples--

--Type--

--Word--
Mulhacén 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A mountain in southern Spain, south-east of Granada, in the Sierra Nevada range. Rising to 3,482 m (11,424 ft), it is the highest mountain in the country.

--Word--
Mulhouse 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial city in north-eastern France, in Alsace; population 112,260 (2006). It was a free imperial city until it joined the French Republic in 1798. In 1871, after the Franco-Prussian War, the city became part of the German Empire until it was reunited with France in 1918.

mulier 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A legitimate child; a child born in wedlock. "mulier puisne"noun a younger child born in wedlock to parents who produced before their marriage an illegitimate child subsequently legitimized by that marriage; also Anglicized as "mulier youngest".

mull 
--Type--
verb, verb, noun, noun, noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
Think about (a fact, proposal, or request) deeply and at length.
Warm (an alcoholic drink, especially wine or beer) and add sugar and spices to it.
Humus formed under non-acid conditions.
A promontory.
Thin, soft, plain muslin, used in bookbinding for joining the spine of a book to its cover.
A large island of the Inner Hebrides; chief town, Tobermory. It is separated from the coast of Scotland near Oban by the Sound of Mull.
--Examples--
‘she began to mull over the various possibilities’
‘the government is mulling an overhaul of outdated insurance laws’
‘a glass of mulled wine’
‘the Mull of Kintyre’

--Word--
Müllerian mimicry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A form of mimicry in which two or more harmful or unpalatable animals develop similar appearances as a shared protective device.

mullite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An orthorhombic silicate of aluminium, Al₆Si₂O₁₃, that is formed by the action of high temperatures on other aluminium silicates and is used for making refractory porcelains and bricks.

multicentric 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating, exhibiting, or relating to origin from, or involvement of, several sites in the body or an organ.
Biology. Of a chromosome: having more than one centromere; specifically having more than two centromeres.
Generally. Relating to or having many centres or foci.
Medicine. Of a study or trial: = "multicentre".

noun
--Meanings--
The existence of a perfect or nearly perfect linear correlation between a set of variables when the regression of some dependent variable on them is being investigated; an instance of this.

noun

--Word--
multiplane 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of a kite: having more than one flat surface (rare). Of an aircraft or its design: having two or more wings placed one above another. Now historical.
Film. Designating or relating to a technique in which several images in distinct planes or layers are used to give an enhanced impression of perspective, used especially for animated films.
Generally. Involving or occupying several distinct planes, layers, or levels (not necessarily horizontal).
An aircraft having two or more sets of wings placed one above another (as in a biplane or triplane). Now historical.

--Meanings--

adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having or involving several parts, elements, or members.
Numerous and often varied.
(of a disease, injury, etc.) complex in its nature or effects; affecting several parts of the body.
A number that may be divided by another a certain number of times without a remainder.
A shop with branches in many places, especially one selling a specific type of product.
--Examples--
‘multiple occupancy’
‘a multiple pile-up’
‘words with multiple meanings’
‘a multiple fracture of the femur’
‘15, 20, or any multiple of five’
‘the major food multiples’
--Word--
multiple-choice 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a question in an examination) accompanied by several possible answers from which the candidate must try to choose the correct one.
--Examples--
--Word--
clutch 
--Type--
verb, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Grasp (something) tightly.
A tight grasp.
A person's power or control, especially when regarded as inescapable.
A mechanism for connecting and disconnecting an engine and the transmission system in a vehicle, or the working parts of any machine.
The pedal operating the clutch in a vehicle.
A clutch bag.
(in sport) denoting or occurring at a critical situation in which the outcome of a game or competition is at stake.
(of a player or action) achieving or characterized by success at a critical moment in a game or competition.
--Examples--
‘he stood clutching a microphone’
‘Mrs Longhill clutched at the idea’
‘she made a clutch at his body’
‘Tom had fallen into Amanda's clutches’
‘she let the clutch in and the car surged forward’
‘they both are hard-nosed players who seem to thrive in clutch situations’
‘a clutch quarterback’
‘clutch performances’
--Word--
die 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of a person, animal, or plant) stop living.
Become extinct.
Be forgotten.
Become less loud or strong.
(of a plant) decay from the tip toward the root.
Die one after another until few or none are left.
(of a fire or light) stop burning or gleaming.
(of a machine) stop functioning or run out of electric charge.
Be very eager for something.
Used to emphasize how strongly one is affected by a particular feeling or emotion.
Have an orgasm.
--Examples--
‘he died of tuberculosis’
‘trees are dying from acid rain’
‘the king died a violent death’
‘many species died out’
‘her genius has assured her name will never die’
‘after a while, the noise died down’
‘at last the storm died away’
‘rhubarb dies back to a crown of buds each winter’
‘the original founders died off or retired’
‘the fire had died and the room was cold’
‘three toasters have died on me’
‘I was halfway through a text message when the phone died’
‘they must be dying for a drink’
‘he's dying to meet you’
‘only the thought of Matilda prevented him from dying of boredom’
‘we nearly died laughing when he told us’
--Word--
multiple-disc 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating a kind of friction clutch consisting of a row of coaxial discs, fixed alternately to the driving and the driven parts, which may be brought in contact to transmit the drive from the one to the other; compare multi-disc.
Designating a disc brake with several pairs of discs.
--Examples--
--Word--
dome 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A rounded vault forming the roof of a building or structure, typically with a circular base.
The revolving openable hemispherical roof of an observatory.
A sports stadium with a domed roof.
A thing shaped like a dome.
A natural vault or canopy, such as that of the sky or trees.
A rounded uplifted landform or underground structure.
The top of the head.
A stately building.
(of stratified rock or a surface) become rounded in formation; swell.
--Examples--
‘the dome of St Paul's Cathedral’
‘the dome of the sky’
‘a content face topped by a shaved dome’
--Word--
drill 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A tool or machine with a rotating cutting tip or reciprocating hammer or chisel, used for making holes.
A tool with a rotating tip used by a dentist for cutting away part of a tooth before filling it.
Instruction or training in military exercises.
Intensive instruction or training in something, typically by means of repeated exercises.
A rehearsal of the procedure to be followed in an emergency.
The correct or recognized procedure or way of doing something.
A predatory mollusc that bores into the shells of other molluscs in order to feed on the soft tissue.
Produce (a hole) in something by or as if by boring with a drill.
Make a hole in (something) by boring with a drill.
Make a hole in or through something by using a drill.
Sink a borehole in order to obtain oil or water.
(of a dentist) cut away part of (a tooth) before filling it.
(of a sports player) hit (a shot) hard and in a straight line.
Subject (someone) to military training exercises.
(of a person) take part in military training exercises.
Instruct (someone) in something by the means of repeated exercises or practice.
Cause (someone) to learn something by repeating it regularly.
--Examples--
‘parade-ground drill’
‘tables can be mastered by drill and practice’
‘language-learning drills’
‘air-raid drills’
‘he didn't know the drill’
‘drill holes through the tiles for the masonry pins’
‘a power tool for drilling wood’
‘do not attempt to drill through a joist’
‘his eyes drilled into her’
‘BP has been licensed to drill for oil in the area’
‘I didn't like having my teeth drilled, but extractions were worse’
‘he drilled a right-foot volley into the back of the net’
‘a sergeant was drilling new recruits’
‘the troops were drilling’
‘I reacted instinctively because I had been drilled to do just that’
‘his mother had drilled into him the need to pay for one's sins’

--Word--
series 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A number of events, objects, or people of a similar or related kind coming one after another.
A set of books, periodicals, or other documents published in a common format or under a common title.
A set of games played between two teams.
A range of products sharing features of design or assembly and marketed with a separate number from other lines.
A set of stamps, banknotes, or coins issued at a particular time.
A set or sequence of related television or radio programmes.
Denoting electrical circuits or components arranged so that the current passes through each successively.
(in chronostratigraphy) a range of strata corresponding to an epoch in time, being a subdivision of a system and itself subdivided into stages.
A set of elements with common properties or of compounds related in composition or structure.
A set of quantities constituting a progression or having the several values determined by a common relation.
A group of speech sounds having at least one phonetic feature in common but distinguished in other respects.
--Examples--
‘the explosion was the latest in a series of accidents’
‘he gave a series of lectures on modern art’
‘the first four books in the Toybox Science series’
‘a series of travel books’
‘the Test series against Australia’
‘early models of the 600D series incorporated a centrifugal oil filter’
‘a series III SWB Land Rover’
‘a series of five stamps issued today to mark the 14th World Orchid Conference’
‘a new drama series’
‘a series circuit’
‘the series connection of the two coils’
‘the Pliocene series’
‘the metals of the lanthanide series’
‘the voiced plosive series [b], [d], [g]’
--Word--
speed 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The rate at which someone or something moves or operates or is able to move or operate.
Rapidity of movement or action.
The rate at which something happens or is done.
Each of the possible gear ratios of a bicycle.
Each of the possible gear ratios of a motor vehicle.
The light-gathering power or f-number of a camera lens.
The duration of a photographic exposure.
The sensitivity of photographic film to light.
An amphetamine drug, especially methamphetamine.
Success; prosperity.
Move quickly.
(of a motorist or vehicle) travel at a speed that is greater than the legal limit.
Move or work more quickly.
Cause to move or happen more quickly.
Make prosperous or successful.
Take or be under the influence of an amphetamine drug.
--Examples--
‘we turned on to the runway and began to gather speed’
‘an engine running at full speed’
‘the car has a top speed of 147 mph’
‘the accident was due to excessive speed’
‘they were bemused by the speed of events’
‘the course is delivered on CDROM so students can progress at their own speed’
‘wish me good speed’
‘I got into the car and home we sped’
‘the car that crashed was speeding’
‘you force yourself to speed up because you don't want to keep others waiting’
‘they sought to speed up decision-making’
‘may God speed you’
‘more kids than ever are speeding, tripping, and getting stoned’
--Word--
multiplet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A group of closely associated things, especially closely spaced spectral lines or atomic energy levels, or subatomic particles differing only in a single property (e.g. charge or strangeness).
--Examples--

well-tuned 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of an instrument, the voice, etc.: finely or properly tuned; having a good tone; (of music or sound) tuneful, melodious. Also of a group of musicians, etc.: in good harmony.
Of the ear, etc.: highly attuned to or appreciative of music, melody, or harmony.
Characterized by or exhibiting euphony, balance, or apt arrangement.
Of an engine, motor vehicle, etc.: having its moving parts carefully adjusted so as to run smoothly and efficiently; in good working order or condition.

A cinema with several separate screens.
Incorporate into a multiplex signal or system.

‘thirty-two of these signals can be multiplexed together to form a 2Mb data stream’

--Word--
multiply 
--Type--
verb, adverb
--Meanings--
Obtain from (a number) another which contains the first number a specified number of times.
Increase or cause to increase greatly in number or quantity.
(of an animal or other organism) increase in number by reproducing.
Propagate (plants)
In several different ways or respects.
--Examples--
‘multiply fourteen by nineteen’
‘we all know how to multiply by ten’
‘ever since I became a landlord my troubles have multiplied tenfold’
‘cigarette smoking combines with other factors to multiply the risks of atherosclerosis’
‘listeria and other bacteria were able to multiply in very low temperatures’
‘researchers multiply these varieties to provide new plants for the farmers’
‘multiply injured patients’

--Word--
multiplicate 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Originally: †multiplied, increased (obsolete). In later use: of many parts, elements, or sections; manifold; multiple, repeated.
Botany= "multiple".
"in multiplicate": in several or many exactly corresponding copies.
Each of many exact copies of a document, sample, etc.
To make multiple copies of, to replicate.
Multiply.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--

‘these formulae involve a number of multiplications’

multiplier 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or thing that multiplies.

multistage 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Consisting of, occurring in, or involving several stages or processes.
(of a rocket) having at least two sections which contain their own motor and are jettisoned as their fuel runs out.
--Examples--
‘a multistage decision-making process’
--Word--
multistate 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Extending over, relating to, or involving a number of the states of a union, federation, etc. (especially of the United States or Australia), or a number of independent states.
Science. Having more than two possible states; capable of existing in any of a number of states.

multithread 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Having more than one thread, multithreaded (also figurative); (Engineering, of a screw) = "multithreaded".
Computing. = "multithreaded".
Engineering. A multithreaded screw.
Computing. Each of the multiple parts of a program executed concurrently in multithreading.
To employ multithreading in the performance of (a program or process).

multitrack 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--

--Word--
multituberculate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small primitive fossil mammal of a mainly Cretaceous and Palaeocene order, distinguished by having molar teeth with several cusps arranged in two or three rows.

--Type--

multitude 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large number of people or things.
The mass of ordinary people without power or influence.
The state of being numerous.
--Examples--
‘a multitude of medical conditions are due to being overweight’
‘Father Peter addressed the multitude’
‘placing ultimate political power in the hands of the multitude’
‘they would swarm over the river in their multitude’

multivalent 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having or susceptible of many applications, interpretations, meanings, or values.
(of an antigen or antibody) having several sites at which attachment to an antibody or antigen can occur.
--Examples--
‘visually complex and multivalent work’
‘a multivalent antiserum’
--Word--
multivalued 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Mathematics. Of a function: having the property that a single argument may map to more than one value.
Logic. Designating a logic in which a proposition can be assigned any of three or more values, rather than being restricted to the values of truth and falsity. Cf many-valued.
Generally. Having or involving more than one value.
--Examples--
--Word--
multivalve 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Denoting an internal combustion engine having more than two valves per cylinder, typically four (two inlet and two exhaust)

‘a switch to multivalve technology’

--Word--
mumble 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Say something indistinctly and quietly, making it difficult for others to hear.
Bite or chew (something) with toothless gums or without making much use of the teeth.
A quiet and indistinct utterance.
--Examples--
‘he mumbled something she didn't catch’
‘‘Sorry,’ she mumbled’
‘she mumbled a piece of black bread’
‘Rosie had replied in a mumble’
