--Word--
peg 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A short pin or bolt, typically tapered at one end, that is used for securing something in place, hanging things on, or marking a position.
A pin or bolt driven into the ground to hold one of the ropes or corners of a tent in position.
A bung for stoppering a cask.
A footrest on a motorbike.
A point or limit on a scale, especially of exchange rates.
A measure of spirits.
A place marked by a peg and allotted to a competitor to fish or shoot from.
A person's leg.
A strong throw.
Fix, secure, or mark with a peg or pegs.
Hang (washing) on a line with clothes pegs.
Allot a specified place to (a competitor) in a fishing or shooting competition by means of a marker.
Fix (a price, rate, or amount) at a particular level.
Form a fixed opinion of; categorize.
Throw (a ball) hard and low.
--Examples--
‘she put her mac on a peg in the hall’
‘the Mexican peso, linked to the dollar by a crawling peg, was distinctly too high’
‘have a peg of whisky’
‘I have a good right peg and the ball ended up in the back of the net’
‘drape plants with nets, pegging down the edges’
‘clothes were pegged out on a line’
‘we've been pegged next to the winning team’
‘the dividend was pegged at 23.59p’
‘the officer probably has us pegged as anarchists’
‘the catcher pegs the ball to the first baseman’

mu-meson 
--Type--

--Examples--
--Word--
Mumetal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a series of nickel-iron alloys containing approximately 75–78 per cent nickel, 4–6 per cent copper, and 1½–2 per cent chromium by weight, which are used to make transformer cores and magnetic shields because of their high permeability and low hysteresis loss in weak magnetic fields. [A trademark in the United Kingdom.]
--Examples--
--Word--
Mumford, Lewis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1895–1990), US social philosopher. He was an expert on regional and city planning and wrote The Renewal of Life in four volumes (1934–51), The Culture of Cities (1938), The City in History (1961), and The Myth of the Machine (1967).

--Meanings--

--Word--
mummy 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
(especially in ancient Egypt) a body of a human being or animal that has been ceremonially preserved by removal of the internal organs, treatment with natron and resin, and wrapping in bandages.
One's mother.
--Examples--
‘the mummy of Tutankhamen’
‘he loves his mummy’
‘here's Mummy’
--Word--

--Type--
noun, noun

--Word--
mummichog 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small marine killifish which lives along the sheltered shores and estuaries of eastern North America. It is widely kept in aquaria and is also used as bait and for biological research.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--
The cloth used to wrap a mummy; a piece of such cloth.
US= momie.

--Word--
mummify 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(especially in ancient Egypt) preserve (a body) by embalming and wrapping it in cloth.
Dry up (a body) and so preserve it.
--Examples--
‘the mummified bodies entombed in the pyramids’
‘the bodies of prehistoric men, mummified by the effect of the acid in the bog water’

A boy or man who is excessively influenced by or attached to his mother.

Mumm

noun
--Meanings--
A trademark for: champagne produced by the house of Mumm in Rheims, France.

--Word--
mum 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
One's mother.
Silent.
--Examples--
‘she often goes round to see her mum, who lives nearby’
‘Jane worried all the way home about telling Mum’
--Word--
mump 
--Type--
noun, verb, verb
--Meanings--
A block of peat; a spade's depth in digging turf.
To assume a demure, melancholy, or sanctimonious expression; to be silent and sullen; to sulk, mope. Also with object with it.
Scottish. To grumble, complain peevishly. Now often in "to mump and moan".
To utter indistinctly or inarticulately, as if with toothless gums; to mumble, mutter. Also with out.
To beg, go about begging; to sponge upon.
British slang. Of a police officer: to accept a small gift or bribe in return for services.
--Examples--
--Word--
mump 
--Type--
noun, verb, verb
--Meanings--
A block of peat; a spade's depth in digging turf.
To assume a demure, melancholy, or sanctimonious expression; to be silent and sullen; to sulk, mope. Also with object with it.
Scottish. To grumble, complain peevishly. Now often in "to mump and moan".
To utter indistinctly or inarticulately, as if with toothless gums; to mumble, mutter. Also with out.
To beg, go about begging; to sponge upon.
British slang. Of a police officer: to accept a small gift or bribe in return for services.

mumping 
--Type--
noun, noun, adjective, adjective
--Meanings--
The action of mump; grimacing; grumbling; hinting by means of facial expression; an instance of this.
The action of mump; begging. Later also: the acceptance of small bribes.
That grimaces or assumes a demure, sanctimonious, or melancholy expression; querulous, complaining.
That begs; given to begging.

mumps 
--Type--

--Meanings--

--Word--
Munchausen, Baron 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The hero of a book of fantastic travellers' tales (1785) written in English by a German, Rudolph Erich Raspe. The original Baron Munchausen is said to have lived 1720–97, to have served in the Russian army against the Turks, and to have related extravagant tales of his prowess.
--Examples--
--Word--
Munchausen's syndrome 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mental disorder in which a person repeatedly feigns severe illness so as to obtain hospital treatment.
A mental disorder in which a person seeks attention by inducing or feigning illness in another person, typically a child.

Munda 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a group of indigenous peoples living scattered in a region from east central India to Nepal and Bangladesh.
A family of languages spoken by the Munda, distantly related to the Mon-Khmer family, with which they are sometimes classified as Austro-Asiatic. The most widely spoken is Santali.
Any language of the Munda family.
Relating to the Munda or their languages.

Mundugumor 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a people living on the banks of the Yuat River in the East Sepik Province of Papua New Guinea. Now more commonly called Biwat.
Frequently in form Munduguma. The Sepik-Ramu language of the Mundugumor people. Now usually called Biwat.
Of or relating to the Mundugumor or their language.

munj

Munsee 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a North American Indian people formerly inhabiting the headwaters of the Delaware River in eastern North America.
The Algonquian language spoken by the Munsee and related peoples of the lower Hudson River Valley.

--Word--
Munster 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A province of the Republic of Ireland, in the south-western part of the country.
A city in north-western Germany; population 272,100 (est. 2006). It was formerly the capital of Westphalia; the Treaty of Westphalia, which ended the Thirty Years War, was signed simultaneously here and at Osnabrück in 1648.

--Word--
muon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An unstable subatomic particle of the same class as an electron (a lepton), but with a mass around 200 times greater. Muons make up much of the cosmic radiation reaching the earth's surface.

--Word--
Murat, Joachim 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1767–1815), French general, king of Naples 1808–15. Murat made his name as a cavalry commander in Napoleon's Italian campaign (1800) and was made king of Naples. He attempted to become king of all Italy in 1815, but was captured in Calabria and executed.
--Examples--
--Word--
Muratorian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to Muratori or his work; especially designating or relating to an 8th-cent. Latin manuscript fragment containing a translation (probably from the Greek) of the earliest surviving Western list of New Testament scriptures, generally dated to the later part of the 2nd cent. a.d. Chiefly in "Muratorian canon", "Muratorian fragment".
--Examples--
--Word--
Murchison Rapids 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Murcia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An autonomous region in south-eastern Spain. In the Middle Ages, along with Albacete, it formed an ancient Moorish kingdom.
The capital city of Murcia; population 430,571 (2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
murder 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The unlawful premeditated killing of one human being by another.
A very difficult or unpleasant task or experience.
A group of crows.
Kill (someone) unlawfully and with premeditation.
Punish severely or be very angry with.
Conclusively defeat (an opponent) in a game or sport.
Spoil by lack of skill or knowledge.
Consume (food or drink) greedily or with relish.
--Examples--
‘the brutal murder of a German holidaymaker’
‘he was put on trial for attempted murder’
‘the 40-mile-per-hour winds at the summit were murder’
‘a murder of crows flew past the window’
‘he was accused of murdering his wife's lover’
‘my father will murder me if I'm home late’
‘the only thing he had murdered was the English language’
‘I could murder some chips’
--Word--
murder 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The unlawful premeditated killing of one human being by another.
A very difficult or unpleasant task or experience.
A group of crows.
Kill (someone) unlawfully and with premeditation.
Punish severely or be very angry with.
Conclusively defeat (an opponent) in a game or sport.
Spoil by lack of skill or knowledge.
Consume (food or drink) greedily or with relish.
--Examples--
‘the brutal murder of a German holidaymaker’
‘he was put on trial for attempted murder’
‘the 40-mile-per-hour winds at the summit were murder’
‘a murder of crows flew past the window’
‘he was accused of murdering his wife's lover’
‘my father will murder me if I'm home late’
‘the only thing he had murdered was the English language’
‘I could murder some chips’

--Word--
murderous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Capable of or intending to murder; dangerously violent.
(of an action, event, or plan) involving murder or extreme violence.
Extremely arduous or unpleasant.
--Examples--
‘a brutal and murderous despot’
‘Mark gave him a murderous look’
‘the most vicious and murderous acts of human aggression’
‘the team had a murderous schedule of four games in ten days’

--Word--
Murdoch, Rupert 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1931), Australian-born US publisher and media entrepreneur; full name Keith Rupert Murdoch. As the founder and head of News Corporation he owns major newspapers in Australia, Britain, and the US, together with film and television companies and the publishing firm HarperCollins.
--Examples--
--Word--
murdrum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
From the 11th to the 15th cent.: a fine imposed by the Crown on a manor or hundred in which a murder (i.e. the unlawful killing of an unknown by an unknown person) had been committed.

murexide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The acid ammonium salt of purpuric acid, a purple-red crystalline solid used in complexometric titrations; 5,5'-nitrilodibarbituric acid ammonium, C₈H₈N₆O₆. Also (more fully "murexide colour"): the characteristic purple-red colour of this salt.
--Examples--
--Word--
Murfreesboro 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A commercial city in central Tennessee, southeast of Nashville; population 101,753 (est. 2008). A Civil War battle fought near here in January 1863 is also called the Battle of Stones River.

murid 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A rodent of a very large family (Muridae ) which includes most kinds of rats, mice, and voles.
A follower of a Muslim saint, especially a Sufi disciple.
A member of any of several Muslim movements, especially one which advocated rebellion against the Russians in the Caucasus in the late 19th century.
--Examples--
--Word--
Muridism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An Islamic revival movement active in the Caucasus throughout the 19th cent., which advocated the rising of Muslims against their religious and political Russian opponents.
--Examples--

muriform 
--Type--
adjective, adjective, adjective
--Meanings--
Composed of cells that are arranged in a regular fashion, like bricks in a wall.
Of a spore of a lichen or fungus: having both longitudinal and transverse septa.
Shaped like a mulberry.
Resembling a mouse in form; mouse-like.

Murmansk 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A port in north-western Russia, on the northern coast of the Kola Peninsula, in the Barents Sea; population 314,700 (est. 2008). It is the largest city located north of the Arctic Circle. Its port is ice-free throughout the year.
--Examples--
--Word--
murmur 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A low continuous background noise.
A softly spoken or almost inaudible utterance.
The quiet or subdued expression of a particular feeling by a group of people.
A rumour.
A recurring sound heard in the heart through a stethoscope that is usually a sign of disease or damage.
Say something in a low or indistinct voice.
Express one's discontent about (someone or something) in a subdued manner.
Make a low continuous sound.
--Examples--
‘the distant murmur of traffic’
‘a quiet murmur of thanks’
‘there were murmurs of dissent from his colleagues’
‘he had heard hints only, murmurs’
‘she had been born with a heart murmur’
‘Nina murmured an excuse and hurried away’
‘‘How interesting,’ he murmured quietly’
‘now they do not simply murmur against him, they quarrel noisily with him’
‘the wind was murmuring through the trees’
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A flock of starlings.
The action of murmuring.
--Examples--
‘the murmuration of a flock of warblers’

Murraya 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small genus of trees and shrubs (family Rutaceae) native to Asia and Australia and cultivated elsewhere, chiefly for their fragrant flowers or foliage; (also murraya) a tree or shrub of this genus, especially orange jessamine or mock orange, Murraya paniculata, and the curry leaf tree, M. koenigii.

--Word--
Murrow, Edward R. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1908–65), US journalist; born Egbert Roscoe Murrow. He broadcast from London during the Blitz of World War II, ending each program with “Good night, and good luck.” He later created the radio series Hear It Now (1950–51) and the television series See It Now (1951–58). He was also well known for his television interview series Person to Person (1953–59).
--Examples--

murr 
--Type--

--Meanings--
Of a cat: to purr.
--Examples--
--Word--
Murrumbidgee 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river of south-eastern Australia, in New South Wales. Rising in the Great Dividing Range, it flows 1,759 km (1,099 miles) westwards to join the River Murray, of which it is a major tributary.

Murut 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a Dayak people of Borneo, originally inhabiting hill country in the interior of Sabah (North Borneo) and Sarawak, although now more widely dispersed.
The Malayo-Polynesian language of the Muruts.
Of, relating to, or designating the Muruts or their language.

moorva 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Either of two sansevierias, Sansevieria roxburghiana and S. zeylanica, grown in South Asia for the strong white fibre present in their leaves. Also: the fibre produced by either of these plants (more fully "moorva fibre").

--Meanings--
A dry white wine from the part of the Loire region in France nearest the west coast.
--Examples--
--Word--
muscadin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Especially in Paris in the 18th and 19th centuries: a dandy, a fop. Hence depreciatively: a member of a Moderate party (composed chiefly of young men of the upper middle class) in the early years of the French Revolution (1794–6).
--Examples--
--Word--
muscadine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a group of species and varieties of wine grape native to Mexico and the south-eastern US, typically having thick skins and a musky flavour.
--Examples--
--Word--
muscae volitantes 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
Dark specks appearing to float before the eyes, generally caused by particles in the vitreous humour of the eye.
--Examples--
--Word--
muscardine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various fungal diseases affecting silkworms and other insects (more fully "muscardine disease"). Also: any of the fungi, especially of the genera Beauveria and Metarhizium, causing these diseases (more fully "muscardine fungus").
--Examples--
--Word--
muscari 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant of the genus Muscari, especially M. botryoides; a grape hyacinth; (in form Muscari) the genus itself.
--Examples--

muscariform 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling a brush in having an elongated structure with hairs or bristles at one end.

muscarine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A poisonous compound present in certain fungi, including the fly agaric.
--Examples--
--Word--
muscarinic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to a type of acetylcholine receptor in the nervous system which is capable of responding to muscarine.
--Examples--

muscari 
--Type--

--Word--
muscat 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A variety of white, red, or black grape with a musky scent, grown in warm climates for wine or raisins or as table grapes.
A wine made from muscat grapes, especially a sweet or fortified white wine.
The capital of Oman, a port in the north-eastern part of the country on the south-eastern coast of the Arabian peninsula; population 620,000 (est. 2007).
--Examples--
--Word--
muscatel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A muscat grape, especially as grown for drying to make raisins.
A raisin made from a muscatel grape.
A wine made from muscatel grapes.

--Word--
muscle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A band or bundle of fibrous tissue in a human or animal body that has the ability to contract, producing movement in or maintaining the position of parts of the body.
A muscle or muscles when well developed or prominently visible under the skin.
Physical power; strength.
A man or men exhibiting physical power or strength, typically employed to use or threaten violence.
Power or influence, especially in a commercial or political sphere.
Move (an object) in a particular direction by using one's physical strength.
Coerce by violence or by economic or political pressure.
--Examples--
‘the calf muscle’
‘the sheet of muscle between the abdomen and chest’
‘his muscles rippled beneath his tanned skin’
‘he had muscle but no brains’
‘an ex-marine of enormous proportions who'd been brought along as muscle’
‘many companies lack the financial muscle to adopt a more hard-nosed relationship with buyers’
‘they were muscling baggage into the hold of the plane’
‘he was eventually muscled out of the market’
--Word--
muscle-bound 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having well-developed or overdeveloped muscles.
--Examples--
‘a muscle-bound hunk’
--Word--
muscle-bound 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having well-developed or overdeveloped muscles.
--Examples--
‘a muscle-bound hunk’

-building

The process of promoting something.

‘boat-building’
‘bridge-building (between the nations)’
‘reef-building coral’

celled

muscoid 
--Type--
adjective, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Resembling moss; mosslike. Now rare.
Relating to or designating dipteran flies of the section Schizophora (suborder Cyclorrhapha), especially of the superfamily Muscoidea which includes Muscidae and related families.
A muscoid fly.

muscone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A solid ketone which is the component of musk principally responsible for its odour, used as a fixative in perfumery; 3-methylcyclopentadecanone, C₁₆H₃₀O.
--Examples--
--Word--
muscovado 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Unrefined sugar made from the juice of sugar cane by evaporating it and draining off the molasses.
--Examples--
--Word--
Muscovy 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A medieval principality in west central Russia, centred on Moscow, which formed the nucleus of modern Russia. As Muscovy expanded, princes of Muscovy became the rulers of Russia; in 1472 Ivan III, grand duke of Muscovy, completed the unification of the country, and 1547 Ivan the Terrible became the first tsar of Russia.
Russia.
--Examples--
--Word--
muscovite 
--Type--
noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--

A native or citizen of Moscow.
A Russian.
Relating to Moscow.
Relating to Russia.
--Examples--
‘Leon was a Muscovite by birth’
‘two Muscovite women’
‘Muscovite traditions’

--Word--
musculo-spiral 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating a branch of the brachial plexus that winds around the humerus to supply muscles and skin of the arm and forearm (now known as the radial nerve); of, relating to, or associated with this nerve.
--Examples--
--Word--
musculocutaneous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a nerve or blood vessel: supplying both muscles and skin; specifically designating a branch of the brachial plexus that supplies the biceps and brachialis muscles of the arm and continues as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm.
Consisting of, relating to, or affecting muscle and skin.
--Examples--
--Word--
musculoligamentous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Consisting of or relating to both muscle and ligament.
--Examples--

musculomembranous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Consisting of a thin layer of muscular tissue; consisting of muscle and mucous membrane.
--Examples--

musculophrenic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating a branch of the internal thoracic artery that supplies blood to the diaphragm and lower intercostal muscles.

--Word--
muse 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
(in Greek and Roman mythology) each of nine goddesses, the daughters of Zeus and Mnemosyne, who preside over the arts and sciences.
A person or personified force who is the source of inspiration for a creative artist.
Be absorbed in thought.
Say to oneself in a thoughtful manner.
Gaze thoughtfully at.
An instance or period of reflection.
--Examples--
‘Yeats' muse, Maud Gonne’
‘the landscape was Gorky's primary muse’
‘he was musing on the problems he faced’
‘‘I think I've seen him somewhere before,’ mused Rachel’
‘he sat on the edge of the bank, legs dangling, eyes musing on the water’

--Word--
musette 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A kind of small bagpipe played with bellows, common in the French court in the 17th–18th centuries and in later folk music.
A tune or piece of music imitating the sound of the musette, typically with a drone.
A dance to a musette, especially in the 18th-century French court.
A small, simple variety of oboe, used chiefly in 19th-century France.
A small knapsack.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--

--Meanings--

A small knapsack.

museum

noun
--Meanings--
A building in which objects of historical, scientific, artistic, or cultural interest are stored and exhibited.
--Examples--
‘the Museum of Modern Art’
‘the museum is noted for its fine fossil collection’
‘a museum curator’
‘it is difficult to avoid the feeling that the city is now a living museum’

--Word--
mush 
--Type--
noun, verb, verb, exclamation, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A soft, wet, pulpy mass.
Feeble or cloying sentimentality.
Thick maize porridge.
Reduce (a substance) to a soft, wet, pulpy mass.
Go on a journey across snow with a dog sled.
Urge on (the dogs) during a journey with a dog sled.
A command urging on dogs pulling a sled during a journey across snow.
A journey across snow with a dog sled.
A person's mouth or face.
Used as a form of address.
--Examples--
‘red lentils cook quickly and soon turn to mush’
‘the flowers had been flattened into a sodden pink mush’
‘the film's not just romantic mush’
‘a cake combining layers of mushed prune and pastry’
‘they got into the sleigh and mushed over the ice and snow’
‘McDowell mushed a dog team the eighty miles to Aklavik’
‘a twelve-day mush for men and dogs over the frozen subarctic prairie’
‘what you doing round here, mush?’

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Word--
mush 
--Type--
noun, verb, verb, exclamation, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A soft, wet, pulpy mass.
Feeble or cloying sentimentality.
Thick maize porridge.
Reduce (a substance) to a soft, wet, pulpy mass.
Go on a journey across snow with a dog sled.
Urge on (the dogs) during a journey with a dog sled.
A command urging on dogs pulling a sled during a journey across snow.
A journey across snow with a dog sled.
A person's mouth or face.
Used as a form of address.
--Examples--
‘red lentils cook quickly and soon turn to mush’
‘the flowers had been flattened into a sodden pink mush’
‘the film's not just romantic mush’
‘a cake combining layers of mushed prune and pastry’
‘they got into the sleigh and mushed over the ice and snow’
‘McDowell mushed a dog team the eighty miles to Aklavik’
‘a twelve-day mush for men and dogs over the frozen subarctic prairie’
‘what you doing round here, mush?’

--Word--
mushroom 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A fungal growth that typically takes the form of a domed cap on a stalk, with gills on the underside of the cap.
A thing resembling a mushroom in shape.
A pale pinkish-brown colour.
Increase, spread, or develop rapidly.
Form a shape resembling that of a mushroom.
(of a bullet) expand and flatten on reaching its target.
Gather mushrooms.
--Examples--
‘she sautéd the mushrooms in butter’
‘mushroom soup’
‘a mushroom of smoke and flames’
‘a mushroom leather bag’
‘environmental concern mushroomed in the 1960s’
‘the grenade mushroomed into red fire as it hit the hillside’
‘these are high-performance bullets which mushroom upon impact’
‘he went mushrooming with his father’

Musial, Stan 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1920–2013), US baseball player; full name Stanley Frank Musial ; known as Stan the Man. A first baseman and an outfielder, he played for the St. Louis Cardinals 1941–63 and led the National League in batting seven times. Baseball Hall of Fame (1969).

--Word--
musica reservata 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A style of 16th-cent. music characterized by heightened expressiveness, usually employing mannerist and chromatic techniques to intensify the imagery and emotion of the words in singing.
--Examples--

adjective, noun

musk 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A strong-smelling reddish-brown substance which is secreted by the male musk deer for scent-marking and is an important ingredient in perfumery.
A relative of the monkey flower, formerly cultivated for a musky fragrance which has been lost in the development of modern varieties.
--Examples--

cod 
--Type--
noun, adjective, noun, verb, noun, abbreviation
--Meanings--
A large marine fish with a small barbel on the chin.
Used in names of fishes that are similar or related to the cod, e.g. rock cod, tomcod.
Not authentic; fake.
A joke or hoax.
A foolish person.
Play a joke or trick on (someone)
Nonsense.
Cash on delivery.
Collect on delivery.
--Examples--
‘a cod Mittel-European accent’
‘I suppose it could all be a cod’
‘he's making a cod of himself’
‘he was definitely codding them’
--Word--
musk deer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small solitary deerlike East Asian mammal without antlers, the male having long protruding upper canine teeth. Musk is produced in a sac on the abdomen of the male.
--Examples--

musk duck

--Meanings--
An Australian stiff-tailed duck with dark grey plumage and a musky smell, the male having a large black lobe of skin hanging below the bill.

An infantryman's light gun with a long barrel, typically smooth-bored and fired from the shoulder.
--Examples--
‘a volley of musket fire’
--Word--
musket 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Muskie, Edmund 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1914–96), US lawyer and politician; full name Edmund Sixtus Muskie. He served as governor of Maine 1955–59, as a member of the US Senate 1959–80, and as US secretary of state 1980–81. He was a Democratic vice presidential candidate in 1968.

Muskogean 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A family of languages spoken in the south-eastern US, including Chikasaw, Choctaw, Creek, and Seminole.
Relating to the Muskogean language family.
Denoting or relating to speakers of any of the Muskogean languages.
--Examples--
‘he learned to speak a language composed of several of the region's Muskogean dialects’
‘the region was originally settled by Muskogean people’
--Word--
Muskogee 
--Type--
proper noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A commercial city in east central Oklahoma, on the Arkansas River; population 40,099 (est. 2008).
A member of a North American people of the south-eastern US, who formed part of the Creek Indian confederacy.
The Muskogean language of the Muskogee.
Relating to the Muskogee or their language.

musk ox 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large heavily built goat-antelope with a thick shaggy coat and a horny protuberance on the head, native to the tundra of North America and Greenland. The male emits a musky odour during the breeding season.

musk 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A strong-smelling reddish-brown substance which is secreted by the male musk deer for scent-marking and is an important ingredient in perfumery.
A relative of the monkey flower, formerly cultivated for a musky fragrance which has been lost in the development of modern varieties.

musnud

noun

--Word--
Mussolini, Benito 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1883–1945), Italian Fascist statesman, prime minister 1922–43; known as Il Duce (‘the leader’); full name Benito Amilcare Andrea Mussolini. He founded the Italian Fascist Party in 1921. He annexed Abyssinia in 1936 and entered the Second World War on Germany's side in 1940. Forced to resign after the Allied invasion of Sicily, he was rescued from imprisonment by German paratroopers, but was captured and executed by Italian communist partisans.
--Examples--
--Word--
Mussorgsky, Modest 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1839–81), Russian composer; full name Modest Petrovich Mussorgsky. His best-known works include the opera Boris Godunov (1874), Songs and Dances of Death (1875–7), and the piano suite Pictures at an Exhibition (1874).
--Examples--

--Word--
must 
--Type--
modal verb, noun, noun, noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Be obliged to; should (expressing necessity)
Expressing insistence.
Used in ironic questions expressing irritation.
Expressing an opinion about something that is logically very likely.
Something that should not be overlooked or missed.
Grape juice before or during fermentation.
Mustiness, dampness, or mould.
A condition of heightened aggression and unpredictable behaviour occurring annually in certain male animals, especially elephants and camels, in association with a surge in testosterone level, equivalent to the rutting season of deer and some other mammals.
(of a male elephant or camel) in a condition marked by heightened aggression and unpredictable behaviour that usually occurs annually in association with a surge in testosterone level.
--Examples--
‘you must show your ID card’
‘the essay mustn't be over 2,000 words’
‘she said she must be going’
‘you must try some of this fish’
‘if you must smoke you could at least go in the living room’
‘Charlotte, must you put spanners in the works?’
‘there must be something wrong’
‘you must be tired’
‘this video is a must for everyone’
‘a pervasive smell of must’
‘a big old bull elephant in must’
‘two musth males competing for a female’

mustard 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hot-tasting yellow or brown paste made from the crushed seeds of certain plants, typically eaten with meat or used as a cooking ingredient.
The yellow-flowered Eurasian plant of the cabbage family whose seeds are used to make mustard.
Used in names of related plants, only some of which are used to produce mustard for the table, e.g. hedge mustard.
A brownish yellow colour.
--Examples--
‘Dijon mustard’
‘mustard sauce’
‘a mustard sweater’

--Word--
musteline 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or like a weasel; (Zoology) of, belonging to, or characteristic of the weasel family Mustelidae or the subfamily Mustelinae.
Zoology. A mustelid; (now usually) specifically a member of the subfamily Mustelinae, which includes weasels, martens, and polecats.
--Examples--
--Word--
musteloid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or characteristic of the mammalian family Mustelidae of weasels, stoats, badgers, etc., or a larger group comprising this and other closely related families.
A mustelid or closely related animal.

--Word--
muster 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Assemble (troops), especially for inspection or in preparation for battle.
(of troops) gather for inspection or in preparation for battle.
(of a group of people) gather together.
Round up (livestock)
Collect or assemble (a number or amount)
Summon up (a feeling, attitude, or response)
A formal gathering of troops, especially for inspection, display, or exercise.
A rounding up of livestock.
The number of people attending a meeting.
A group of peacocks.
--Examples--
‘17,000 men had been mustered on Haldon Hill’
‘the cavalrymen mustered beside the other regiments’
‘reporters mustered outside her house’
‘my father needed help with mustering sheep’
‘he could fail to muster a majority’
‘he replied with as much dignity as he could muster’
‘I finally mustered up the courage to call them’
‘he attended the musters, which were called to train all able-bodied men’
‘a meeting was held to fix the times and places of muster’
‘a cattle muster’
‘the sound was like the cry of a muster of peacocks’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who rounds up livestock.

--Word--
muster-master 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An officer in charge of the muster roll of part of an army or (less commonly) of a dockyard, penal colony, etc.; a person responsible for the accuracy of a muster roll.
--Examples--

--Word--
musty 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a stale, mouldy, or damp smell.
Having a stale taste.
Lacking freshness or vitality; old-fashioned.
--Examples--
‘a dark musty library’
‘the beer tasted sour, thin, and musty’
‘the musty formalities of the occasion’

mustn't 
--Type--
contraction
--Meanings--
Must not.
--Examples--
--Word--
mustn't 
--Type--
contraction
--Meanings--
Must not.
--Examples--
--Word--
must 
--Type--
modal verb, noun, noun, noun, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Be obliged to; should (expressing necessity)
Expressing insistence.
Used in ironic questions expressing irritation.
Expressing an opinion about something that is logically very likely.
Something that should not be overlooked or missed.
Grape juice before or during fermentation.
Mustiness, dampness, or mould.
A condition of heightened aggression and unpredictable behaviour occurring annually in certain male animals, especially elephants and camels, in association with a surge in testosterone level, equivalent to the rutting season of deer and some other mammals.
(of a male elephant or camel) in a condition marked by heightened aggression and unpredictable behaviour that usually occurs annually in association with a surge in testosterone level.
--Examples--
‘you must show your ID card’
‘the essay mustn't be over 2,000 words’
‘she said she must be going’
‘you must try some of this fish’
‘if you must smoke you could at least go in the living room’
‘Charlotte, must you put spanners in the works?’
‘there must be something wrong’
‘you must be tired’
‘this video is a must for everyone’
‘a pervasive smell of must’
‘a big old bull elephant in must’
‘two musth males competing for a female’

mutatis mutandis 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--

--Word--
mutate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Change in form or nature.
(with reference to a cell, DNA molecule, etc.) undergo or cause to undergo change in a gene or genes.
--Examples--
‘rhythm and blues mutated into rock and roll’
‘the virus is able to mutate into new forms that are immune to the vaccine’
‘certain nucleotides were mutated’

--Word--
mutate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Change in form or nature.
(with reference to a cell, DNA molecule, etc.) undergo or cause to undergo change in a gene or genes.
--Examples--
‘rhythm and blues mutated into rock and roll’
‘the virus is able to mutate into new forms that are immune to the vaccine’

--Word--
mutation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of mutating.
The changing of the structure of a gene, resulting in a variant form that may be transmitted to subsequent generations, caused by the alteration of single base units in DNA, or the deletion, insertion, or rearrangement of larger sections of genes or chromosomes.
A distinct form resulting from genetic mutation.
Regular change of a sound when it occurs adjacent to another.
(in Celtic languages) change of an initial consonant in a word caused (historically) by the preceding word.
(in Germanic languages) the process by which the quality of a vowel was altered in certain phonetic contexts; umlaut.
--Examples--
‘the mutation of punk's angry energy into something more thuggish and mindless’
‘his first novel went through several mutations’
‘mutation is, ultimately, the only way in which new variation enters the species’
‘whether his goats were a new mutation or part of an older breed remains unclear’
--Word--
mutational 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to mutation, especially genetic change.
--Examples--
‘random mutational changes’
‘the mutational variance was greater in females than in males’
--Word--
mutationally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
mutationism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The view that mutation, rather than natural selection, is the main driving force in evolution; especially = mutation theory.
--Examples--
--Word--
mutationist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An advocate of mutation theory; a person who believes that evolution is caused primarily by mutation. Also attributive or as adjective Compare "selectionist".
--Examples--
--Word--
mutation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of mutating.
The changing of the structure of a gene, resulting in a variant form that may be transmitted to subsequent generations, caused by the alteration of single base units in DNA, or the deletion, insertion, or rearrangement of larger sections of genes or chromosomes.
A distinct form resulting from genetic mutation.
Regular change of a sound when it occurs adjacent to another.
(in Celtic languages) change of an initial consonant in a word caused (historically) by the preceding word.
(in Germanic languages) the process by which the quality of a vowel was altered in certain phonetic contexts; umlaut.
--Examples--
‘the mutation of punk's angry energy into something more thuggish and mindless’
‘his first novel went through several mutations’
‘mutation is, ultimately, the only way in which new variation enters the species’
‘whether his goats were a new mutation or part of an older breed remains unclear’

--Word--
Mu'tazilite 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a Muslim sect originating in the early 8th cent. which introduced speculative dogmatics into Islam and, in particular, denied predestination.
Of, relating to, or designating this sect.

mutchkin 
--Type--

--Word--
mutchkin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Scottish unit of capacity equal to a quarter of the old Scottish pint, or roughly three quarters of an imperial pint (0.43 litres)
--Examples--
‘they shared the half-mutchkin of raw whisky’
--Word--
mute 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Refraining from speech or temporarily speechless.
Not expressed in speech.
Characterized by an absence of sound; quiet.
(of hounds) not giving tongue while hunting.
(of a person) lacking the faculty of speech.
(of a letter) not pronounced.
A person lacking the faculty of speech.
(in some Asian countries) a servant who was deprived of the power of speech.
An actor in a dumbshow.
A professional attendant or mourner at a funeral.
A clamp placed over the bridge of a stringed instrument to deaden the resonance without affecting the vibration of the strings.
A pad or cone placed in the opening of a brass or other wind instrument to soften the sound.
A device on a television, telephone, or other appliance that temporarily turns off the sound.
Deaden, muffle, or soften the sound of.
Muffle the sound of (a musical instrument), especially by the use of a mute.
Reduce the strength or intensity of.
A pack of hounds.
--Examples--
‘Harry sat mute, his cheeks burning resentfully’
‘she gazed at him in mute appeal’
‘the great church was mute and dark’
‘he'd been bullied into silence—people often wondered if he was actually mute’
‘mute e is generally dropped before suffixes beginning with a vowel’
‘the child remained as silent as a mute’
‘an undertaker's mute’
‘her footsteps were muted by the thick carpet’
‘when muted and blown hard the trombone produces a very nasal and metallic sound’
‘his professional contentment was muted by personal sadness’
‘the abbot had a mute of hounds’
--Word--
muted 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a sound or voice) quiet and soft.
(of a musical instrument) having a muffled sound as a result of being fitted with a mute.
Not expressed strongly or openly.
(of colour or lighting) not bright; subdued.
--Examples--
‘the muted hum of the distant traffic’
‘muted anger’
‘a dress in muted tones of powder blue and dusty pink’

Mutilla 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of velvet ants (family Mutillidae); (also mutilla) a velvet ant of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
mutillid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Any of various solitary fossorial parasitic wasps constituting the family Mutillidae; a velvet ant.
Of or belonging to the family Mutillidae; of the nature of a mutillid.
--Examples--

--Word--
mutiny 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An open rebellion against the proper authorities, especially by soldiers or sailors against their officers.
Refuse to obey the orders of a person in authority.
--Examples--
‘a mutiny by those manning the weapons could trigger a global war’
‘the crew were on the verge of mutiny’
‘thousands of the soldiers mutinied over the non-payment of wages’

--Word--
mutoscope 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device for viewing a series of photographs of a moving object (usually taken with a mutograph) in quick succession, giving the impression of a moving picture. Also: a booklet of such photographs, producing the same effect when its pages are flicked through rapidly.

--Word--
mutter 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Say something in a low or barely audible voice, especially in dissatisfaction or irritation.
Talk or grumble in secret or in private.
A barely audible utterance, especially one expressing dissatisfaction or irritation.
--Examples--
‘he muttered something under his breath’
‘‘I knew she was a troublemaker,’ Rebecca muttered’
‘back-benchers were muttering about the next reshuffle’
‘a little mutter of disgust’

--Word--
mutton chops 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
mutton-fish 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly US. Any of various marine fishes of the Caribbean and western Atlantic whose flesh when cooked is supposed to taste of mutton; especially (a) the mutton snapper, Lutjanus analis; (b) the ocean pout, Macrozoarces americanus; (c) the Irish pompano, Diapterus auratus.
Australian. Any of various edible gastropod molluscs of the genus Haliotis; an abalone; especially the large H. ruber, common in southern and eastern Australia.
--Examples--
--Word--
mutton-fish 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly US. Any of various marine fishes of the Caribbean and western Atlantic whose flesh when cooked is supposed to taste of mutton; especially (a) the mutton snapper, Lutjanus analis; (b) the ocean pout, Macrozoarces americanus; (c) the Irish pompano, Diapterus auratus.
Australian. Any of various edible gastropod molluscs of the genus Haliotis; an abalone; especially the large H. ruber, common in southern and eastern Australia.
--Examples--
--Word--
muttonhead 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A stupid person.
--Examples--
‘straighten up there, you shambling muttonheads!’

--Word--
mutt 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dog, especially a mongrel.
A stupid or incompetent person.
--Examples--
‘a long-haired mutt of doubtful pedigree’
‘he pitied the poor mutt who ever fell for her charms’
--Word--
mutual 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a feeling or action) experienced or done by each of two or more parties towards the other or others.
(of two or more people) having the same specified relationship to each other.
Held in common by two or more parties.
Denoting a building society or insurance company owned by its members and dividing some or all of its profits between them.
A mutual building society or insurance company.
--Examples--
‘a partnership based on mutual respect and understanding’
‘my father hated him from the start and the feeling was mutual’
‘his contract with City has been terminated by mutual consent’
‘they cooperated as potentially mutual beneficiaries of the settlement’
‘we were introduced by a mutual friend’
‘Scottish Amicable may switch from mutual to plc status’
‘the world's oldest mutual insurance company’
‘life insurance firms are mutuals, owned by their policyholders’
--Word--
mutualization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of mutualizing.
--Examples--
--Word--
mutualize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Organize (a company or business) on mutual principles.
Share out (something) equally between involved parties.
--Examples--
‘was the BBC about to be mutualized, with viewers becoming stockholders?’
‘the ruling council of Lloyd's has refused to contemplate anything that would appear to mutualize names' losses’
--Word--

noun

mvule 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In East Africa: the iroko tree, Milicia (or Chlorophora) excelsa (also "mvule tree"); the hardwood timber of this tree, used especially in cabinetmaking, building, and shipbuilding.

--Word--
muzzy 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Unable to think clearly; confused.
Not thought out clearly; vague.
Blurred; indistinct.
--Examples--
‘she was shivering and her head felt muzzy from sleep’
‘society's muzzy notion of tolerance’
‘a slightly muzzy picture’

--Word--
muzzle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The projecting part of the face, including the nose and mouth, of an animal such as a dog or horse.
A guard, typically made of straps or wire, fitted over an animal's muzzle to stop it biting or feeding.
The part of a person's face including the nose, mouth, and chin.
The open end of the barrel of a firearm.
Put a muzzle on (an animal)
Prevent (a person or group) from expressing their opinions freely.
--Examples--
‘she patted the horse's velvety muzzle’
‘the law says that pit bull terriers have to wear a muzzle’
‘his close-shaven muzzle’
‘Devlin jammed the muzzle of the gun into the man's neck’
‘the dog should have been muzzled’
‘opposition leaders accused him of muzzling the news media’
--Word--
muzzle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The projecting part of the face, including the nose and mouth, of an animal such as a dog or horse.
A guard, typically made of straps or wire, fitted over an animal's muzzle to stop it biting or feeding.
The part of a person's face including the nose, mouth, and chin.
The open end of the barrel of a firearm.
Put a muzzle on (an animal)
Prevent (a person or group) from expressing their opinions freely.
--Examples--

‘the law says that pit bull terriers have to wear a muzzle’
‘his close-shaven muzzle’
‘Devlin jammed the muzzle of the gun into the man's neck’
‘the dog should have been muzzled’
‘opposition leaders accused him of muzzling the news media’

muzzler 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who puts a muzzle on an animal; (figurative) a person who constrains the speech or actions of another or others.
Nautical. A strong headwind.
US slang. An obnoxious or annoying person; someone held in contempt.

--Word--
Mx 
--Type--
noun, abbreviation
--Meanings--
A title used before a person's surname or full name by those who wish to avoid specifying their gender or by those who prefer not to identify themselves as male or female.
Maxwell(s).
Middlesex.
--Examples--
‘the bank is planning to introduce the honorific ‘Mx’ as an alternative for anyone who feels that they don’t, for reasons of undetermined gender, fit into being either a Mr, Mrs, Miss or a Ms’
